subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Clerk” means the clerk of the circuit court for the county with appropriate jurisdiction.
“Comptroller” means the Comptroller of the State.
“Consumer member” means a nonprofessional member of a regulatory unit who is appointed from the general public.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

section.text: A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by:

paragraph.text: a written statement signed by the individual making it in which the individual solemnly affirms under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the individual’s knowledge, information, and belief; or

a certification of an officer authorized to administer an oath that a named individual made oath that the contents of the document are true to the best of the individual’s knowledge, information, and belief.

section.text: A false statement made under oath under this article is subject to the penalties of perjury.

subsection.text: If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this article, then, on complaint filed by the issuing authority, a court of competent jurisdiction may order compliance with the subpoena.

If a person refuses to be sworn or to give evidence before an officer or unit authorized by this article to administer oaths, then, on complaint of the officer or unit, a court of competent jurisdiction may order the person to be sworn or to give evidence.
This section does not apply in Baltimore City or Prince George’s and Worcester counties.
Except as otherwise provided in this article or Article 24, Title 11 of the Code, a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State may not:

paragraph.text: require a local license in that county, municipal corporation, or political subdivision to engage in a business or occupation for which a State license is required under this article; or
impose a local fee or tax to engage in a business or occupation for which a State license is required under this article.

subsection.text: A county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State may require a local license if necessary for regulatory purposes in the interest of the public health, safety, or morals.
A public local law passed after October 1, 1941, does not repeal any provision of this section unless the public local law expressly refers to and repeals the provision.

section.text: Before a license or permit is issued under this article to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the issuing authority:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the Maryland workers’ compensation laws; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: A person who must have a license issued by the Department under this article but does not get the license on time shall pay, in addition to the required license fee, a late fee.
The late fee shall be the sum of:

paragraph.text: up to 20% of the required license fee for the calendar month following the calendar month when the required license fee is due; and
up to 4% of the required license fee for each calendar month or part of a month after that.

subsection.text: By August 31 of each year, the Department shall provide to the Department of Assessments and Taxation a list of the following persons issued licenses during the previous fiscal year, to assist the Department of Assessments and Taxation in identifying new businesses within the State:

paragraph.text: managers and promotors, licensed under Title 4 of this article;
collection agencies, licensed under Title 7 of this article;
home improvement contractors and subcontractors, licensed under Title 8 of this article;
employment agencies, licensed under Title 9 of this article;
heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractors with master licenses and master restricted licenses, licensed under Title 9A of this article;
owners and trainers, licensed under Title 11 of this article; and
secondhand precious metal object dealers and pawnbrokers, licensed under Title 12 of this article.

subsection.text: The list provided under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be provided free of charge; and
include, for each person on the list:

subparagraph.text: the name and mailing address of the person; and
the federal tax identification number of the person or, if the person does not have a federal tax identification number, the Social Security number of the person.

subsection.text: In this section, “license” means all or any part of permission that:

paragraph.text: is required by law to be obtained from a unit;
is not required only for revenue purposes; and
is in any form, including:

subparagraph.text: an approval;
a certificate;
a charter;
a permit; or
a registration.

subsection.text: This section:

paragraph.text: applies only to a fee for an initial license issued for a 2-year term under Title 8, Title 9A, or Title 12 of this article;
does not apply to a fee renewal of a license; and
may not affect any other law that requires a unit to prorate a fee on any basis for the issuance or renewal of a license.
For a license issued at any time during the first year of the term of the license, the issuing authority shall charge the full amount of the fee to the license applicant.
For a license issued in the second year of the term of the license, the issuing authority shall charge the license applicant:

subparagraph.text: one-half of the fee, if issued in the first 6 months of the second year; or
one-quarter of the fee, if issued in the last 6 months of the second year.

subsection.text: If payment of the fee for the issuance or renewal of a license, issued by the Department or by a unit within the Department, is made by a check or other negotiable instrument that is dishonored, the license for which the fee was paid shall be suspended by operation of law. Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the suspension is effective beginning on the tenth business day after the day on which the notice is sent in accordance with subsection (b) of this section until the date that payment of the fee, and any late charge provided for in this article, has been made.

paragraph.text: When the Department or a unit within the Department receives notice that a check or other negotiable instrument, given by an applicant in payment of a license issuance or renewal fee, has been dishonored, it shall inform the applicant by regular mail sent to the applicant’s last known business address, that the license will be suspended by operation of law if within 10 business days after the date of the notice the applicant fails to make payment of the fee, and any late charge, or fails to present evidence to the Department or unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.
An applicant shall be given a prompt opportunity to make payment of the fee, and any late charge, or to present evidence to the Department or unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.

subsection.text: If a license is suspended under subsection (a) of this section, the license shall be reinstated effective the date the license was suspended if within 5 business days from the date of the suspension the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the fee and late charge; or
presents evidence to the Department or the unit that the notice of dishonor was in error.

subsection.text: Suspension of a license under this section may not affect any otherwise valid claim under any guaranty fund made by a person who dealt in good faith with a licensee, without knowledge of the suspension.

A license or permit is considered renewed for purposes of this section if the license or permit is issued by a unit of State government to a person for the period immediately following a period for which the person previously possessed the same or a substantially similar license.

Before any license or permit may be renewed under this article, the issuing authority shall verify through the Office of the Comptroller that the applicant has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions payable to the Comptroller or the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or that the applicant has provided for payment in a manner satisfactory to the unit responsible for collection.

section.text: In this subtitle, “business record” includes:

paragraph.text: a book of account;
a canceled check;
a document;
a letter;
a payroll;
a production report or other record that relates to equipment, personnel, or sales; and
a voucher.

section.text: This subtitle applies to each private business, occupation, private institution, and profession, whether or not carried on for profit.
This subtitle does not diminish the authority of an officer of the State to allow the destruction of a business record.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a minute book of a corporation; or
a record of a sale or other transaction that involves a weapon or poison that can be used in committing a crime.

subsection.text: Unless a specific period is set by law for the preservation of a business record that is required by the laws of this State to be kept, the business record may be destroyed 3 years after it is made.

In this section, “reproduction” means a reproduction or durable medium for making a reproduction obtained by a photographic, photostatic, microfilm, microcard, miniature photographic, or other process that accurately reproduces or forms a durable medium for so reproducing the original.

If, in the regular course of business, a person makes a reproduction of an original business record, the preservation of the reproduction complies with a requirement of a law of the State that the business record be kept.

section.text: This subtitle shall be construed and interpreted to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law of the states that enact this subtitle.
This subtitle is the Maryland Uniform Preservation of Private Business Records Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” includes an assignee, legal representative, or successor of a person who submits an application for registration of a mark under this subtitle.
“Mark” means a name, symbol, word, or combination of 2 or more of these that a person:

paragraph.text: places on goods that the person sells or distributes, a container of the goods, a display associated with the goods, or a label or tag affixed to the goods to identify those goods that the person makes or sells and to distinguish them from goods that another person makes or sells; or

displays or otherwise uses to advertise or sell services that the person performs to identify those services that the person performs and to distinguish them from services that another person performs.

subsection.text: “Person” includes a governmental entity or unit or instrumentality of a governmental entity.
“Registrant” includes an assignee, legal representative, or successor of a person who registers a mark under this subtitle.

“Trade name” means a name, symbol, word, or combination of 2 or more of these that a person uses to identify the business or occupation of the person and to distinguish it from the business or occupation of another person.

section.text: This subtitle does not affect adversely a right or the enforcement of a right in a mark acquired in good faith at any time at common law.
The Secretary of State shall keep a public record of the marks registered under this subtitle.

subsection.text: If a person uses a mark in the State, the person may register the mark in accordance with this subtitle.
A person may not register a mark that:

paragraph.text: is deceptive, immoral, or scandalous;
may disparage, falsely suggest a connection with, or bring into contempt or disrepute:

subparagraph.text: a belief;
an individual, living or dead;
an institution; or
a national symbol;

paragraph.text: is, simulates, or includes a coat of arms, flag, or other insignia of a government;
is or includes the name, portrait, or signature of a living individual, except with the written consent of the individual; or
is likely, when applied to the goods or services of the person, to confuse or deceive because the mark resembles:

subparagraph.text: another mark registered in the State; or
a mark or trade name that another person has used in the State and has not abandoned.

paragraph.text: Unless the mark has become distinctive of the person’s goods or services, a person may not register a mark that:

subparagraph.text: only describes or deceptively misdescribes goods or services;
primarily describes or deceptively misdescribes the geographic origin of goods or services; or
is primarily merely a surname.

paragraph.text: As evidence that a mark has become distinctive of the goods or services of a person, the Secretary of State may accept proof that the person has used the mark as a mark in the State or elsewhere continuously for at least 5 years immediately before the day on which the person applies for registration.

subsection.text: A person may not register a trade name that is not a mark.
For convenience of administration of this subtitle, the general classes of goods under this subtitle are:

paragraph.text: raw or partly prepared materials.
receptacles.
baggage, animal equipments, portfolios, and pocketbooks.
abrasives and polishing materials.
adhesives.
chemicals and chemical compositions.
cordage.
smokers’ articles, not including tobacco products.
explosives, firearms, equipments, and projectiles.
fertilizers.
inks and inking materials.
construction materials.
hardware and plumbing and steam-fitting supplies.
metals and metal castings and forgings.
oils and greases.
paints and painters’ materials.
tobacco products.
medicines and pharmaceutical preparations.
vehicles.
linoleum and oiled cloth.
electrical apparatus, machines, and supplies.
games, toys, and sporting goods.
cutlery, machinery, and tools, and parts thereof.
laundry appliances and machines.
locks and safes.
measuring and scientific appliances.
horological instruments.
jewelry and precious metalware.
brooms, brushes, and dusters.
crockery, earthenware, and porcelain.
filters and refrigerators.
furniture and upholstery.
glassware.
heating, lighting, and ventilating apparatus.
belting, hose, machinery packing, and nonmetallic tires.
musical instruments and supplies.
paper and stationery.
prints and publications.
clothing.
fancy goods, furnishings and notions.
canes, parasols, and umbrellas.
knitted, netted and textile fabrics, and substitutes therefor.
thread and yarn.
dental, medical, and surgical appliances.
soft drinks and carbonated waters.
foods and ingredients of foods.
wines.
malt beverages and liquors.
distilled alcoholic liquors.
merchandise not otherwise classified.
cosmetics and toilet preparations.
detergents and soaps.

subsection.text: For convenience of administration of this subtitle, the general classes of services under this subtitle are:

paragraph.text: miscellaneous.
advertising and business.
insurance and financial.
construction and repair.
communications.
transportation and storage.
material treatment.
education and entertainment.

subsection.text: The classification of goods and services in this section does not limit or extend the rights of an applicant or registrant.
An applicant for registration of a mark shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Secretary of State:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form that the Secretary of State provides; and
3 specimens or reproductions of the mark; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Secretary of State a fee of $50.

subsection.text: An application shall be signed, under oath:

paragraph.text: for an individual, by the individual;
for a partnership, by a partner; or
for a corporation or association, by an officer of the corporation or association.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required on an application form, the form shall require:

paragraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the business address of the applicant;
for an applicant that is a corporation, the state of incorporation;
the goods or services with which the applicant uses the mark;
the way the applicant uses the mark with the goods or services;
the class under § 1-405 of this subtitle to which the goods or services belong;
the date when the applicant or the applicant’s predecessor in business:

subparagraph.text: first used the mark anywhere; and
first used the mark in the State; and

paragraph.text: a statement that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant owns the mark;
another person does not have the right to use the mark in the State; and
the mark is not deceptively similar to a mark that another person has a right to use in the State.

subsection.text: A single application for registration of a mark:

paragraph.text: may cover use of the mark with any number of goods or services in a single class; but
may not cover use of the mark with goods or services in different classes.

subsection.text: Before denying registration of a mark, the Secretary of State shall give the applicant an opportunity for an informal hearing before the Secretary of State or the Secretary’s designee.
The denial of registration of a mark is not a contested case under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary of State shall register the mark of and issue a certificate of registration to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Secretary of State shall include on each certificate of registration:

paragraph.text: the signature of the Secretary of State, under the seal of the Secretary of State;
the name of the registrant;
the business of the registrant;
the address of the registrant;
for a registrant that is a corporation, the state of incorporation;
the date that the registrant claims to have first used the mark anywhere;
the date that the registrant claims to have first used the mark in the State;
a description of the goods or services with which the registrant uses the mark;
the class under § 1-405 of this subtitle to which the goods or services belong;
a reproduction of the mark;
the date of registration; and
the term of registration.

subsection.text: Unless registration of a mark is renewed for a 10-year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the tenth anniversary of its effective date.
Within 1 year before registration of a mark expires, the Secretary of State shall mail to the registrant, at the last known address of the registrant:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current registration expires;
the date by which the Secretary of State must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the registration expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the registration of a mark expires, the registrant periodically may renew it for an additional 10-year term if, within 6 months before the expiration of the term of the registration:

paragraph.text: the registrant submits to the Secretary of State a renewal application on the form that the Secretary of State provides;
the registrant states in the renewal application that the mark is still in use in the State;
the mark otherwise is entitled to be registered; and
the registrant pays to the Secretary of State a renewal fee of $50.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall renew the registration of and issue a renewal certificate to each registrant who meets the requirements of this section.
A mark and its registration may be assigned with:

paragraph.text: the good will of the business that uses the mark; or
that part of the good will of the business connected with the mark.

subsection.text: The assignment shall be by a written, signed instrument.
A person may record the assignment of registration of a mark by:

paragraph.text: submitting the instrument of assignment to the Secretary of State; and
paying to the Secretary of State a fee of $10.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall record an assignment of the registration of a mark and issue a new certificate of registration in the name of the assignee to each person who meets the requirements of this section.
The term of assignment is the rest of the term of registration of the mark.

An assignment of the registration of a mark under this subtitle is void against a subsequent purchaser for valuable consideration without notice of the assignment unless the assignment is recorded with the Secretary of State:

paragraph.text: within 3 months after the date of the assignment; or
before the subsequent purchase.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall cancel a registration of a mark if:

paragraph.text: the registrant asks that it be canceled;
the registrant fails to renew it;
a court of competent jurisdiction orders that it be canceled on any ground; or
a court of competent jurisdiction finds that:

subparagraph.text: the mark is abandoned;
the registrant does not own the mark;
the registration was granted improperly; or
the registration was obtained fraudulently.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Secretary of State shall cancel the registration of a mark if a court of competent jurisdiction finds the mark to be likely to confuse or deceive because it resembles a mark that:

subparagraph.text: was registered by another person in the United States Patent Office before the date the registrant applied for registration under this subtitle; and
is not abandoned.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State may not cancel the registration of a mark if the registrant proves that:

subparagraph.text: the registrant holds a concurrent registration of the mark in the United States Patent Office; and
the registration in the United States Patent Office covers an area that includes the State.

section.text: A person who, for the person or for another, applies to register or registers a mark under this subtitle by knowingly making a false or fraudulent representation, orally or in writing, or by other fraudulent means is liable for any damages sustained as a result of the application or registration.

subsection.text: Subject to § 1-402 of this subtitle, a person may not:

paragraph.text: use, without the consent of the registrant, a reproduction or colorable imitation of a mark registered under this subtitle in connection with the sale, offering for sale, or advertising of goods or services if the use is likely to confuse or deceive about the origin of the goods or services; or

reproduce or colorably imitate a mark registered under this subtitle and apply the reproduction or colorable imitation to an advertisement, label, package, print, receptacle, sign, or wrapper that is intended to be used:

subparagraph.text: with goods or services; or
in conjunction with the sale or other distribution of goods or services in the State.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this section is liable in a civil action to a registrant for any remedy provided in this section.
A registrant may recover profits or damages from a person who violates subsection (a)(2) of this section only if the person intended that the mark be used to confuse or deceive.

subsection.text: A registrant may sue to enjoin the display, manufacture, sale, or use of a reproduction or colorable imitation of a mark of the registrant.
A court of competent jurisdiction may:

paragraph.text: grant an injunction to restrain the display, manufacture, sale, or use of a reproduction or colorable imitation of a registered mark;
require the defendant to pay to the registrant for the wrongful display, manufacture, sale, or use of a reproduction or colorable imitation of a mark:

subparagraph.text: any profit that the defendant derived;
any damages that the registrant suffered; or
both; and

paragraph.text: require the defendant to deliver to an officer of the court or to the registrant, for destruction, any reproduction or colorable imitation of the mark that is in the possession or under the control of the defendant.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not, with intent to defraud, do business in the State under or imitate a name, title, or trade name that is the same as, or similar to, that used by another person already doing business in the State.
This section does not apply to individuals with similar names.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each day that the offense is committed.

section.text: It is the purpose of this subtitle to require certain reports and records of transactions involving currency where such reports and records have a high degree of usefulness in criminal investigations or proceedings that pertain to the subject of the report.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Currency” means currency and coin of the United States or any other country.
“Department” means the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Person engaged in a trade or business” means an individual, partnership, limited liability company, firm, trust, estate, association, corporation, or other entity:

paragraph.text: engaged in vehicle sales, including motor vehicle, airplane, and boat sales;
that conducts real estate closings and settlements; or
engaged in the sale or pledging of jewelry.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

A person engaged in a trade or business who, in the course of that trade or business, receives more than $10,000 in currency in 1 transaction shall keep a record of the transaction and shall file with the Department within 15 days of the date of the transaction a report of the transaction.
The reporting requirements of this section are complied with if the person engaged in a trade or business files with the Department a duplicate copy of the report required by 26 U.S.C. § 6050-I.

The Secretary shall adopt regulations appropriate to carry out the purposes of this subtitle and to provide for exemption of transactions that are clearly of a legitimate nature for which mandatory reporting would serve no useful purpose.

The Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Department of State Police, and the Office of the Attorney General shall have access to and shall be authorized to inspect and copy any reports filed with the Department under this article.
The Department may make the contents of a report available to other criminal justice agencies only for purposes of investigation or prosecution of the subject of the report.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may assess a civil penalty against a person engaged in a trade or business for each knowing and willful violation of this subtitle.
The civil penalty may not exceed $50 for each day the violation continues.
For purposes of this section, a separate violation occurs at each office, branch, or place of business where a violation occurs or continues.
The total civil penalty may not exceed $1,000.

subsection.text: In the event of the failure of a person to pay a penalty assessed under this section, a civil action for recovery of the penalty may be brought by the State against the person.

section.text: There is a Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, established as a principal department of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, who shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor. The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.

The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department. The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Office of the Secretary as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.
The Secretary is responsible for establishing policy to be followed by the units in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a deputy secretary.
The deputy secretary:

subparagraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary;
is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget; and
has the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may employ a staff attached to the Office of the Secretary, in accordance with the State budget.

Each staff assistant in the Office of the Secretary in charge of a particular area of responsibility and each professional consultant is in the executive service, management service, or is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System and is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
Unless otherwise provided by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all other staff in the Office of the Secretary in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

The Secretary may review any personnel action taken by any unit in the Department. The Secretary may delegate to the head or governing body of any unit in the Department the power to approve any appointment or removal.
Whenever the Secretary is authorized by law to make an appointment with the approval of the Governor, the Secretary may not remove the appointee without first obtaining the approval of the Governor.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for the budget of the Office of the Secretary and for the budget of each unit in the Department.
The Secretary shall have a seal.

paragraph.text: The Secretary is responsible for the planning of activities, programs, and services of the Department.
The Secretary may review and approve, disapprove, or modify the plans and proposals of the units in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary may investigate or hold a hearing on any complaint about the operation of a unit in the Department and may report the findings of the Secretary to the Governor.
At any time, the Secretary may call a meeting of a board or commission in the Department to consider any subject.

The Secretary may not exercise or perform any power, duty, responsibility, or function granted to the Board of Appeals in §§ 8–5A–05, 8–5A–07, 8–5A–10, 8–5A–11, 8–5A–12, 8–611(j), 8–629(f), 8–638, 8–639, and 8–808(a) of the Labor and Employment Article.
The Secretary may adopt regulations for the Office of the Secretary.
Before a unit in the Department publishes a proposed regulation under § 10-112 of the State Government Article, the unit shall submit the proposed regulation to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the Secretary may approve any proposed regulation.

Within 30 days after submission of a proposed regulation on a regulatory, supervisory, quasi-judicial, disciplinary, or enforcement function of a unit, the Secretary may disapprove the proposed regulation but only if the Secretary finds that it:

subparagraph.text: would discourage competition within a regulated occupation or profession;
would unfairly restrict entry of applicants into a regulated occupation or profession; or
otherwise is contrary to the public interest.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may disapprove or revise any other proposed regulation.

subsection.text: There is a Licensing Testing Fund for the Department.

The Secretary shall ensure that each unit in the Department that collects fees for a licensing examination given by a national testing association pays all of the fees into the Licensing Testing Fund.

paragraph.text: The Licensing Testing Fund shall be used to pay the money that the Department owes to a national testing association.
At the end of each fiscal year, any money in the Licensing Testing Fund that is not needed under paragraph (1) of this subsection reverts to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: This section applies to the following occupational and professional licensing boards:

paragraph.text: the State Board of Architects established under Title 3 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article;
the State Board of Certified Interior Designers established under Title 8 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article;
the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects established under Title 9 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article;
the State Board for Professional Engineers established under Title 14 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article; and
the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors established under Title 15 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article.

subsection.text: There is a State Occupational and Professional Licensing Design Boards’ Fund in the Department, which shall be a continuing, nonlapsing special fund.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, each occupational and professional licensing board described in subsection (a) of this section shall pay all fees collected to the Comptroller of the State.
The Comptroller shall distribute the fees to the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of each occupational and professional licensing board described in subsection (a) of this section.
The Secretary or a designee of the Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In consultation with each board described in § 2–106.1 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall annually calculate the direct and indirect costs attributable to each board.
Each board shall establish fees based on the calculations provided by the Secretary under this section.
Each fee established by an individual board may not be increased annually by more than 12.5% of the existing and corresponding fee of the board.

subsection.text: In order to establish fees that more equitably distribute the costs associated with the operation of each board among similar boards, the Secretary may average the direct and indirect costs of one or more boards provided that the boards consent to having their direct and indirect costs averaged together.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the State Real Estate Commission.
“Fund” means the State Real Estate Commission Fund.
There is a State Real Estate Commission Fund in the Department.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of fees collected by the Commission and distributed to the Fund under § 17-213 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Commission.
The Secretary or a designee of the Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.
In this section, “Commission” means the State Real Estate Commission.
In consultation with the Commission, the Secretary shall annually calculate the direct and indirect costs attributable to the Commission.
Beginning on July 1, 2007, the Commission shall establish fees based on the calculations provided by the Secretary under this section.
Each fee established by the Commission may not be increased annually by more than 12.5% of the existing and corresponding fee of the Commission.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Public Accountancy.
“Fund” means the State Board of Public Accountancy Fund.
There is a State Board of Public Accountancy Fund in the Department.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of fees collected by the Board and distributed to the Fund under § 2–209 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article.
The Fund shall be used to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board.
The Secretary or a designee of the Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.
In this section, “Board” means the State Board of Public Accountancy.
In consultation with the Board, the Secretary shall annually calculate the direct and indirect costs attributable to the Board.
Beginning on July 1, 2008, the Board shall establish fees based on the calculations provided by the Secretary under this section.
Each fee established by the Board may not be increased annually by more than 12.5% of the existing and corresponding fee of the Board.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors.
“Fund” means the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors Fund.
There is a State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors Fund in the Department.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of fees collected by the Commission and distributed to the Fund under Title 16 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article.
The Fund shall be used to cover the Commission’s actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Commission.
The Secretary or a designee of the Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.
At the end of each fiscal year, any unspent and unencumbered portion of the Fund in excess of $100,000 shall revert to the General Fund of the State.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the General Fund.
In this section, “Commission” means the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors.
In consultation with the Commission, the Secretary shall calculate annually the direct and indirect costs attributable to the Commission.
Beginning on July 1, 2011, the Commission shall establish fees based on the calculations provided by the Secretary under this section.
Each fee established by the Commission may not be increased annually by more than 12.5% of the existing and corresponding fee of the Commission.

The fees established for each profession regulated under Title 16 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article shall be set so as to produce funds to approximate the cost of regulating each profession.
This section does not apply to a unit in the Department to the extent that the unit is authorized by law to employ its own legal adviser or counsel.
The Attorney General is legal adviser to the Department.
The Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of assistant attorneys general authorized by law for the Department and its units.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate 1 of the assistant attorneys general assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department. After the Attorney General designates the counsel to the Department, the Attorney General may not reassign the counsel without consulting the Secretary.

The counsel may have no duty other than to give the legal aid, advice, and counsel required by the Secretary or any other official of the Department, to supervise the other assistant attorneys general assigned to the Department, and to perform for the Department the duties that the Attorney General assigns. The counsel shall perform these duties subject to the control and supervision of the Attorney General.

subsection.text: The following units are in the Department:

paragraph.text: the Division of Labor and Industry.
the Division of Employment and Training.
the Commissioner of Financial Regulation.
the State Board of Architects.
the State Athletic Commission.
the State Board of Barbers.
the Board of Boiler Rules.
the State Collection Agency Licensing Board.
the State Board of Cosmetologists.
the State Board of Master Electricians.
the State Board of Stationary Engineers.
the State Board for Professional Engineers.
the State Board of Foresters.
the State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning and Refrigeration Contractors.
the Maryland Home Improvement Commission.
the State Board of Certified Interior Designers.
the State Board of Examiners of Landscape Architects.
the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors.
the State Board of Pilots.
the State Board of Plumbing.
the State Board of Public Accountancy.
the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers.
the State Racing Commission.
the State Real Estate Commission.
the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors.
the Real Estate Hearing Board.
the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation.
the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc.
the State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board.
the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board.
the Maryland–Bred Race Fund Advisory Committee.
the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund Advisory Committee.
the Advisory Council on Prevailing Wage Rates.

subsection.text: The Department also includes each other unit that is assigned to the Department.

paragraph.text: Each unit created within the Department shall include at least 1 consumer member.
Each consumer member of the unit:

subparagraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the unit;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the unit; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the unit.

paragraph.text: While a member of the unit, a consumer member may not:

subparagraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the unit; or
grade any examination given by or for the unit.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary may create advisory units.

paragraph.text: Each advisory unit created under this section shall include at least 1 consumer member.
Each consumer member of an advisory unit created under this section shall be a member of the general public.
A consumer member of an advisory unit created under this section may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the unit.

subsection.text: In this section, “license”:

paragraph.text: means any grant of authority to conduct a business or to practice an occupation; and
includes a certificate, permit, or registration.

subsection.text: A unit in the Department may not require as a condition for a license an ability to communicate in English, except to the extent that the unit expressly determines that the ability is needed to engage in the business or occupation for which the license is sought.

paragraph.text: If a unit in the Department determines that the use of an interpreter of a foreign language or sign language will not compromise the integrity of a testing procedure for a license, then, on request, the unit may allow an applicant to use an interpreter during that procedure.
An applicant who uses an interpreter shall pay the cost of the interpreter.
In this section, “license” means any grant of authority to an individual to practice an occupation or profession.
“License” includes a certificate, permit, or registration.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to licenses issued under Title 11, Subtitles 5 and 6 of the Financial Institutions Article.
A unit in the Department that is authorized to issue a license may allow an individual licensee who is a member of an armed force deployed outside the State to:

paragraph.text: renew the license after the expiration of the renewal period without payment of a penalty or reinstatement fee if the late renewal is a direct result of the deployment; and
complete any continuing education or continuing competency requirements for renewal within a reasonable time after renewing the license.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Amusement attraction” means:

subparagraph.text: an amusement ride; or
a structure that gives amusement, excitement, pleasure, or thrills to people who move around, over, or through the structure without the aid of a moving device integral to the structure.

paragraph.text: “Amusement attraction” does not include a structure that is devoted principally to exhibitions related to agriculture, the arts, education, industry, religion, or science.

subsection.text: “Amusement owner” means a person, the State, or a political subdivision of the State that owns an amusement attraction or, if the amusement attraction is leased, the lessee.
“Amusement park” means an area that is used principally for 1 or more permanently erected amusement attractions.
“Amusement ride” means a device that is intended to give amusement, excitement, pleasure, or thrills to passengers whom the device carries:

paragraph.text: along or around a fixed or restricted course; or
within a defined area.

subsection.text: “Carnival” means an itinerant enterprise that consists principally of 1 or more temporarily located amusement attractions.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
“Fair” means an enterprise that:

paragraph.text: is devoted principally to periodic exhibitions related to agriculture, the arts, education, industry, religion, or science; and
has 1 or more amusement attractions operated along with the exhibitions.

subsection.text: “Inflatable amusement attraction” means an air–supported amusement attraction that:

paragraph.text: incorporates a structural and mechanical system; and
uses a high strength fabric or film that achieves its strength, shape, and stability by tensioning from internal air pressure.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: an unsafe amusement attraction is likely to cause serious and preventable injuries to members of the public; and
for the welfare of the people of the State, these injuries must be prevented and the public must be protected from unsafe amusement attractions.

subsection.text: The purpose of this title is to ensure, as far as possible, the safety of the public in the use of amusement attractions at carnivals, fairs, and amusement parks in the State by providing for:

paragraph.text: adoption of safety regulations;
an effective enforcement and compliance program; and
reporting procedures on the safety of amusement attractions that:

subparagraph.text: help to achieve the purpose of this title; and
describe accurately the hazards of amusement attractions.

subsection.text: This title does not apply to a single-passenger, coin-activated amusement ride that is electrically, manually, or mechanically operated unless admission is charged for access to the place where the amusement ride is located.
This title does not repeal or modify § 21-1112 (“Medicine or patent medicine shows”) or § 21-1212 (“Violation of § 21-1112”) of the Health - General Article.
This title does not prevent the licensing of carnivals, fairs, or amusement attractions by the State or a political subdivision of the State.
This title does not repeal or modify the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act.

section.text: The purchase of a ticket to a carnival or amusement ride is not an assumption of risk by the buyer.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall administer and enforce this title.

paragraph.text: The proposed budget of the Division of Labor and Industry shall include an appropriation from the Workers’ Compensation Commission to cover the cost of administering and enforcing this title.
The Workers’ Compensation Commission shall pay the cost of administering and enforcing this title from money that the Commission receives under § 9-316 of the Labor and Employment Article.

section.text: The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may make an agreement with a municipal corporation or political subdivision of the State or unit of the State government to delegate the power of inspection.

If a political subdivision satisfies the Commissioner that the political subdivision can make the inspections required under this title, the Commissioner shall make an agreement with the political subdivision to delegate the power of inspection.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may retain the right to monitor an inspection by a municipal corporation or political subdivision of the State or unit of the State government.
The Commissioner may revoke the agreement.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may administer oaths, depose witnesses, and certify to official acts.
The Commissioner may issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce evidence.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner shall establish procedures necessary for reporting and keeping records to carry out the duties of the Commissioner under this title.

Whenever an individual who is authorized to inspect property in the State under this title is denied access to the property after making a proper request for access of the owner, tenant, or other person in charge of the property, the individual may apply to the District Court for an administrative search warrant.
The application shall:

paragraph.text: state the nature, purpose, and scope of the inspection; and
show that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant:

sub-subparagraph.text: is authorized by law to make the inspection; and
made a proper request for access at a reasonable time;

subparagraph.text: access was denied; and
the inspection is for a purpose related to safety or health.

subsection.text: An application may not be submitted to the District Court unless approved by the Attorney General.
On application in accordance with this section, the District Court may issue an administrative search warrant.

A person who is adversely affected or aggrieved by an order passed or regulation adopted by the Commissioner under this title may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Rules.

paragraph.text: The filing of an appeal does not stay an order or regulation of the Commissioner.

However, after giving the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing, the court in which the appeal is pending may stay an order or regulation of the Commissioner on the conditions that the court considers proper.
The conditions may include a requirement to post security.

subsection.text: A court shall hear the appeal promptly.
A regulation that the Commissioner adopts under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: is prima facie lawful and reasonable; and
may not be held invalid because of a technical defect, if there is substantial compliance with this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce an order passed or regulation adopted under this subtitle.

Subject to § 3-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, on request of the Commissioner, the Attorney General may proceed in a State or federal court or before any other federal unit to enforce a decision or order of the Commissioner under this title.
A court shall hear the action promptly.
A regulation that the Commissioner adopts under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: is prima facie lawful and reasonable; and
may not be held invalid because of a technical defect, if there is substantial compliance with this title.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Board” means the State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner shall adopt safety regulations for the maintenance and operation of amusement attractions.
There is a State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 9 members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be a mechanical engineer;
1 shall represent owners of carnivals;
1 shall represent the State Fair and the county fairs;
1 shall represent amusement ride rental operators;
2 shall represent owners of amusement parks; and
3 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: In choosing the members of the Board, the Governor shall make every effort to ensure that each region of the State is represented.
The composition of the Board as to the race and gender of its members shall reflect the composition of the population of the State.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board shall be a member of the general public.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 1992.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: The Governor shall designate a chairman from among the consumer members of the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall set the times and places of its hearings and meetings.
Each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Board shall advise and consult with the Commissioner on reasonable regulations to prevent conditions that are detrimental to the public in their use of amusement attractions.

subsection.text: The Board shall recommend to the Commissioner any regulation that it finds necessary for the protection and safety of the public.
The Commissioner may make recommendations to the Board on regulations.
The Board shall base its recommendations for regulations on information that:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner develops or otherwise has available; or
an interested person submits to the Board at a public hearing under this section.
The Board shall hold the public hearings needed to carry out its responsibilities under this subtitle.
At least 15 days before a hearing, the Commissioner shall publish notice of the hearing in the Maryland Register.

section.text: The Board shall submit to the Commissioner, with each recommendation for a regulation, a report that:

paragraph.text: explains the need for the regulation; and
summarizes the information available to the Board, including:

subparagraph.text: testimony that was presented at any public hearing; and
technical information.

section.text: If, after receiving a recommendation from the Board for a regulation, the Commissioner decides to adopt the regulation, the Commissioner shall publish notice of the proposed adoption in the Maryland Register.

The Commissioner may delay the effective date of a regulation for not more than 90 days after publication of the notice of adoption, if the Commissioner finds that the delay is needed to ensure that each manufacturer, operator, or amusement owner of an amusement attraction affected by the regulation knows about and has an opportunity to familiarize employees with the requirements of the regulation.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall:

paragraph.text: compile a set of current regulations adopted under this subtitle;
keep a set of the regulations in the Office of the Commissioner; and
make a copy of the regulations for anyone who asks for one.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may set a fee to cover the cost of making and mailing a copy of the current regulations.
An amusement owner affected by a regulation adopted under this subtitle may apply in writing to the Commissioner for a variance from the regulation.
The Commissioner may grant a variance from a regulation adopted under this subtitle if:

paragraph.text: the variance is necessary to prevent undue hardship; or
an existing condition makes compliance with the regulation impracticable and the Commissioner believes that the reasonable safety of the public can be ensured.

subsection.text: An amusement attraction may not operate unless the amusement owner has purchased insurance for the amusement attraction in accordance with this subtitle.
Except for testing and inspection, an amusement attraction may not be operated unless the Commissioner has issued a certificate of inspection for the amusement attraction.
The Commissioner shall inspect:

paragraph.text: annually, each amusement attraction at an amusement park;
annually, each inflatable amusement attraction in which, while in contact with the attraction, an individual is 4 feet or more above the ground;
except for an inflatable amusement attraction, each amusement attraction, if moved, before it begins operation at another location; and
each new or modified amusement attraction before it begins public operation.
An amusement owner shall notify the Commissioner before operating an amusement attraction that is new, modified, or reconstructed.
An owner or lessee of a carnival or fair shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the Commissioner in writing at least 30 days before opening the carnival or fair at each location; and
give the Commissioner immediate notice of a change in the schedule of locations or dates if the schedule changes after notification.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall issue to an amusement owner a certificate of inspection for each amusement attraction at a carnival, fair, or amusement park if:

paragraph.text: after inspection the Commissioner finds that the amusement attraction complies with this title and the regulations adopted under it; and
the amusement owner submits to the Commissioner a certificate of insurance for the amusement attraction as required by § 3–403 of this subtitle.
A certificate of inspection for an amusement attraction at an amusement park expires not more than 1 year after the date of issuance.
A certificate of inspection for an amusement attraction at a fair or carnival expires not more than 30 days after the date of issuance.

A certificate of inspection for an inflatable amusement attraction in which, while in contact with the attraction, an individual is 4 feet or more above the ground expires not more than 1 year after the date of issuance.

subsection.text: The certificate of inspection shall be posted in plain view on the amusement attraction.
On information or notification of an accident or complaint that involves an amusement attraction, the Commissioner shall investigate the accident or complaint and inspect the amusement attraction.

paragraph.text: An amusement owner shall obtain insurance against liability for injury to an individual that arises out of the use of an amusement attraction.
The insurance shall be in the amount of at least:

subparagraph.text: $350,000 for an amusement ride that operates by mechanical means; or

sub-subparagraph.text: an amusement ride that operates only by human power or gravity, including a water slide or water flume; or
any other amusement attraction.

subsection.text: An amusement owner shall obtain insurance from an insurer or surety that is acceptable to the State Insurance Commissioner.

paragraph.text: A county where an amusement attraction is located may buy, on behalf of a not for profit organization, the amount of insurance required under this section for the amusement attraction.
A county that merely buys insurance for an amusement owner is immune from liability under § 5-516 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.
This subsection applies to a not for profit community service corporation that:

subparagraph.text: is incorporated under Maryland law;
is authorized to collect charges or assessments by a covenant running with the land; and
has gross annual revenues of at least $15,000,000.

paragraph.text: A not for profit community service corporation complies with the insurance requirements of this section for an amusement attraction that the corporation owns and operates if the corporation is self-insured for at least $1,000,000 against liability for injury that arises out of the use of the amusement attraction:

subparagraph.text: under regulations that the State Insurance Commissioner adopts; or

until the State Insurance Commissioner adopts regulations, with the approval of the State Insurance Commissioner, if the corporation is authorized by a covenant running with the land to collect a payment or charge based on the value of real property.

paragraph.text: A not for profit community service corporation that elects to self-insure shall submit periodically in writing to the State Insurance Commissioner the conditions of self-insurance.
The conditions of self-insurance must:

subparagraph.text: be approved by the State Insurance Commissioner; and
conform with the conditions of comprehensive liability insurance policies available in the private market.

subsection.text: Each amusement owner who operates an amusement attraction in the State shall:

paragraph.text: keep and make available to the Commissioner records about the activities of the amusement owner under this title; and
keep accurate records of, and submit periodic reports to the Commissioner on, injuries to the public that occur during use of amusement attractions other than injuries that:

subparagraph.text: are minor;
require only first-aid treatment; and
do not involve medical treatment or loss of consciousness.

subsection.text: Whenever a death or serious physical injury results from the operation of an amusement attraction:

paragraph.text: the person who directly controls the operation of the amusement attraction immediately shall close the amusement attraction until it has been inspected by the Commissioner;
the amusement owner shall report the incident orally or in writing to the Commissioner within 24 hours; and
the Commissioner shall inspect the amusement attraction within 24 hours after receiving notice of the incident.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may prohibit use of an amusement attraction if, after an inspection or investigation, the Commissioner finds that:

paragraph.text: the amusement attraction violates a regulation adopted under this title; and
there is a substantial probability of death or serious physical injury from continued use of the amusement attraction.

subsection.text: To prohibit use of an amusement attraction, the Commissioner shall give an amusement owner written notice that prohibits use of the amusement attraction.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall post a copy of the notice on the amusement attraction.
Only the Commissioner may remove the copy of the notice.

subsection.text: The amusement attraction may not be operated until it is made safe for public use and each required safeguard is provided.

paragraph.text: A person who is aggrieved by a decision of the Commissioner under this section may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the Maryland Rules.

subparagraph.text: The filing of an appeal does not stay the decision of the Commissioner.

However, after giving the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing, the court in which the appeal is pending may stay the decision of the Commissioner on conditions that the court considers proper.
The conditions may include a requirement to post security.

subsection.text: In this section, “workday” means a day that is not a Saturday, a Sunday, or a State holiday.

If, after an inspection or investigation, the Commissioner finds that, within the immediately preceding 6 months, an amusement owner has violated this title or an order passed or regulation adopted under this title, the Commissioner promptly shall issue a citation to the amusement owner.
Each citation shall:

paragraph.text: describe, in detail, the nature of the alleged violation;
cite the provision of this title, order, or regulation that the amusement owner is alleged to have violated; and
set a reasonable time for correction of the alleged violation.

subsection.text: Within a reasonable time after issuance of a citation, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the amusement owner a notice that:

paragraph.text: states the proposed civil penalty, if any, that the Commissioner intends to impose under this title; and
informs the amusement owner of the right to a hearing under this section.

subsection.text: In accordance with any regulation that the Commissioner adopts under this title, an amusement owner who receives a citation shall post the citation or a copy of it conspicuously at or near each place where the citation alleges that a violation occurred.

Within 15 workdays after an amusement owner receives a notice under subsection (d) of this section, the amusement owner may submit to the Commissioner a written request for a hearing on the citation or proposed civil penalty.
Unless an amusement owner requests a hearing as provided in this section, a citation and a notice of a proposed civil penalty are final orders.

After an opportunity for a hearing under this section, the Commissioner may pass an order that affirms or modifies a requirement of a citation for correction of a violation if the amusement owner shows that the amusement owner:

paragraph.text: has made a good faith effort to comply with the requirement; but
has not complied because of a factor beyond the reasonable control of the amusement owner.

subsection.text: An amusement owner shall correct each violation for which the Commissioner issues a citation within the time set for correction in a final order under this subtitle.

If the Commissioner has reason to believe that an amusement owner has failed to correct a violation in a timely manner, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the amusement owner a notice that:

paragraph.text: states that the amusement owner has failed to correct the violation;
states the proposed civil penalty, if any, that the Commissioner intends to impose under this title for the failure; and

informs the amusement owner that, within 15 workdays after receipt of the notice, the amusement owner may submit to the Commissioner a written request for a hearing on the failure to correct the violation or proposed civil penalty.

subsection.text: Unless an amusement owner requests a hearing as provided in this section, the notice, including any proposed civil penalty, is a final order.

paragraph.text: Whenever the Commissioner receives a request for a hearing made in accordance with this section, the Commissioner shall hold a hearing.
To the extent practicable, the hearing shall be held within 30 days after receipt of the request.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall give notice and hold the hearing under this section in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: If a hearing examiner or other officer is appointed to hold a hearing under this section, the officer shall prepare a record that includes testimony.
The officer shall submit a report to the Commissioner and send a copy of the report to any amusement owner affected by the report.
The report becomes final unless, within 10 workdays after the report, the amusement owner submits a written request for a review of the proceeding by the Commissioner.

After a review of a proceeding under this subsection, with or without a hearing, the Commissioner shall pass an order based on findings of fact. The order shall affirm, modify, or vacate the citation or proposed civil penalty or direct other appropriate relief.
An order of the Commissioner under paragraph (4) of this subsection is final 15 days after passage of the order.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make a false representation or false statement in an application, plan, record, report, or other document that the person submits or is required to keep under this title.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

section.text: If an amusement owner willfully violates this title or an order passed or regulation adopted under this title and a member of the public dies as a result of the violation, the amusement owner is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, a fine not exceeding $2,500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both; or
for a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bungee jump” means jumping or falling by an individual from a height while attached to a rope or cord that is elastic, rubber, or latex.
“Bungee jumping operation” means an operation that allows an individual to bungee jump for a fee or dues.

subsection.text: A person may not conduct a bungee jumping operation.
A person who violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.
The Commissioner shall impose a civil penalty for a violation of this title only:

paragraph.text: in accordance with this section; and
after issuing a citation under § 3-406 of this title for the violation.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may impose a civil penalty, not exceeding $500 for each violation, against an amusement owner who:

paragraph.text: violates this title or an order passed or regulation adopted under this title, if the Commissioner finds that the violation is not serious; or
violates a requirement for posting imposed under this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may impose a civil penalty, not exceeding $500 for each day a violation continues, against an amusement owner who fails to correct the violation in the time set for its correction.

The Commissioner may impose a civil penalty, not exceeding $1,000 for each violation, against an amusement owner who violates this title or an order passed or regulation adopted under this title if a substantial probability of death or serious physical injury exists because of the violation, unless the amusement owner did not know and with reasonable diligence could not have known of the violation.
The Commissioner may impose a civil penalty, not exceeding $2,000 for each violation, against a person who:

paragraph.text: operates an amusement attraction without a certificate of inspection from the Commissioner; or
willfully or repeatedly violates this title or an order passed or regulation adopted under this title.

subsection.text: Before the Commissioner imposes a civil penalty, the Commissioner shall consider the appropriateness of the penalty in relation to:

paragraph.text: the size of the business of the amusement owner against whom the penalty is to be imposed;
the gravity of the violation for which the penalty is to be imposed;
the good faith of the amusement owner; and
any previous violations by the amusement owner.

subsection.text: Each civil penalty shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate on July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Boxing” includes sparring.
“Commission” means the State Athletic Commission.

paragraph.text: “Contest” means a boxing, kick boxing, or wrestling:

subparagraph.text: competition;
exhibition;
match;
performance; or
show.

paragraph.text: “Contest” includes a mixed martial arts:

subparagraph.text: competition;
match;
performance; or
show.

paragraph.text: “Contest” does not include a mixed martial arts exhibition.

subsection.text: “Mixed martial arts” means a competition in which contestants use interdisciplinary forms of fighting, including various forms of martial arts, involving:

paragraph.text: striking with the hands, feet, knees, or elbows; and
grappling by take–downs, throws, submissions, or choke holds.

subsection.text: “Mixed martial arts exhibition” means mixed martial arts where:

paragraph.text: contact to the body is permitted in only a restrained manner;
contact to the head is not permitted; and
no contact is permitted that may result, or is intended to result, in physical harm to an opponent.

section.text: There is a State Athletic Commission in the Department.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of 5 members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Commission shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 6 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 1992.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.
The Commission shall elect a chairman from among the members of the Commission.
The manner of election of the chairman and the chairman’s term of office shall be as the Commission determines.

paragraph.text: A majority of the authorized membership of the Commission is a quorum.
The Commission may not act unless a majority of the authorized membership concurs.

subsection.text: The Commission shall set the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: The chairman of the Commission is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: an annual salary of $6,000; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: Each other member of the Commission is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: an annual salary of $4,000; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: While in office, each member of the Commission shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.
The Commission may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
The Commission shall have its general offices in Baltimore City.
The Commission shall control and have jurisdiction over all contests held in the State.
The Commission may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to administer its office;
administer oaths; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce evidence.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle and Subtitle 3 of this title;
keep a record of its proceedings;
keep at its general offices all its books, documents, and papers; and
prepare notices and other papers for service.

section.text: The Commission shall pay all money that it collects into the General Fund of the State.
The Commission exercises its powers and duties subject to the authority of the Secretary.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this subtitle and Subtitle 3 of this title and all regulations adopted under this subtitle and Subtitle 3 of this title shall terminate on July 1, 2021.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, “license” means a license issued by the Commission.
In this subtitle, “license” includes:

paragraph.text: a license to participate as a boxer in a contest;
a license to participate as a kick boxer in a contest;
a license to participate as a wrestler in a contest;
a license to participate as a mixed martial arts contestant in a contest;
a license to act as a manager for a boxer, kick boxer, or mixed martial arts contestant;
a license to act as a referee in a contest;
a license to act as a judge in a boxing, kick boxing, or mixed martial arts contest;
a license to act as a second in a contest;
a license to act as a matchmaker of a boxing, kick boxing, or mixed martial arts contest; and
a license to act as a promoter of a contest.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: intercollegiate, interscholastic, or intramural boxing, kick boxing, or wrestling;
amateur boxing, kick boxing, or wrestling conducted under the supervision of a nationally recognized amateur organization;
amateur mixed martial arts conducted under the supervision of an amateur kick boxing organization or mixed martial arts organization that:

subparagraph.text: has been reviewed by the Commission on a basis that is neither arbitrary nor capricious;
has been approved by the Commission;
administers and enforces amateur mixed martial arts regulations adopted by the Commission; and
does not have a direct or indirect financial interest in:

sub-subparagraph.text: a mixed martial arts contestant; or
the promotion of a mixed martial arts contest;

paragraph.text: martial arts where:

subparagraph.text: contact to the body is permitted in only a restrained manner;
contact to the head is not permitted; and
no contact is permitted that may result, or is intended to result, in physical harm to an opponent; or

paragraph.text: a mixed martial arts exhibition.

subsection.text: Each boxer shall wear protective headgear in each amateur boxing match or exhibition.
A person may not participate as a boxer, kick boxer, wrestler, or mixed martial arts contestant in a contest in the State unless the person has an appropriate license.
A person may not act as a manager, referee, judge, second, matchmaker, or promoter in a contest in the State unless the person has an appropriate license.
