Revenues generated by the Commission shall be at least equal to expenses incurred by the Commission.
The Commission shall pay all money collected under this subtitle into the General Fund of the State.

paragraph.text: A person licensed under this subtitle may not contract or solicit to provide mold remediation services unless the work of the licensee is covered by insurance in the amount of at least $1,000,000.
A licensee shall give the Commission notice of the cancellation of insurance at least 10 days before the effective date of the cancellation.

subsection.text: A person licensed to provide mold remediation services under this subtitle is not required to pay assessments to the Fund under Subtitle 4 of this title.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a company or firm shall be licensed by the Commission before the company or firm provides mold remediation services in the State.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this subtitle.
If the applicant is a company or firm, the company or firm shall appoint a company or firm member as a representative member to make the application on behalf of the company or firm.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Commission in the form that the Commission provides;
pay a nonrefundable application fee established through regulation;

submit proof that each of its employees who provides mold remediation services is certified by an accreditation body as a microbial remediation supervisor or microbial remediation technician, whichever is applicable;
submit proof of insurance as required by § 8–706 of this subtitle; and
provide any other information the Commission may require.

subsection.text: The Commission may grant a waiver to the requirement for a license only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the appropriate application fee; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this subtitle; and
has an active license from another state with licensing requirements that are at least equivalent to the licensing requirements of this State.

subsection.text: The Commission shall issue the license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle and the regulations adopted under it.
Unless the license is renewed as provided in this section, a license expires 2 years after the date of issuance.
Before the license expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be granted a license;
pays to the Commission a renewal fee established by the Commission; and
submits:

subparagraph.text: proof of insurance;
a renewal application in the form that the Commission provides; and

proof that each of the licensee’s current employees who provides mold remediation services holds an active certification from an accreditation body as a microbial remediation supervisor or microbial remediation technician.

subsection.text: The Commission shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: If application for restoration is made within 90 days of expiration of a license, the license may be restored only on payment of a renewal fee.
If application for restoration is not made within the 90–day period, the Commission may require compliance with the process for initial applications as if the applicant had never been licensed.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 8–712 of this subtitle, the Commission may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the Commission finds that the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: obtained a license by false or fraudulent representation;
transferred the authority granted by the license to another person;
willfully or deliberately disregarded and violated any regulations established by the Commission under this subtitle;
willfully or deliberately disregarded and violated laws of the State or of any municipality, city, or county of the State;
is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide mold remediation services;

paragraph.text: aided or abetted a person to evade a provision of this subtitle by allowing a license to be used by an unlicensed person, firm, or corporation;
performed work under a mold remediation services contract or project that is inadequate or incomplete;
made any material misrepresentation in the procurement of a mold remediation services contract or project; or
violated this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 8–712 of this subtitle, the Commission may reprimand a licensee or suspend or revoke a license of a licensee for a violation of this title by an agent, director, employee, manager, officer, partner, or salesperson of the licensee, unless the Commission finds that the licensee:

paragraph.text: had no knowledge of the wrongful conduct; or
could not prevent the violation.

subsection.text: Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license, the Commission may impose a civil penalty under § 8–620 of this title.

The Commission shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide mold remediation services;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: The Commission shall pay any penalty collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.

Except as otherwise provided in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, before the Commission takes any final action under this subtitle, the Commission shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Commission.
The Commission shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Commission may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Commission may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Commission may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10–222 and 10–223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall display:

paragraph.text: the license and the license number conspicuously in the principal place of business of the licensee; and
the license number of the licensee on each vehicle used on the job for providing mold remediation services.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall give the Commission notice of any change of name, address, or employment from that which appears on the current license, at least 10 working days before the change is to take effect.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not provide mold remediation services unless the person is licensed by the Commission.
A licensee may not:

paragraph.text: provide or offer to provide any mold remediation to a structure on which the firm or company or its employees has provided a mold assessment within the last 12 months; or
pay any compensation, inducement, or reward to a mold assessor or a mold assessor’s firm in order to generate the referral of any business to the licensee’s firm or company or its employees.

section.text: Unless licensed to provide mold remediation services under this subtitle, a person may not represent to the public by use of the titles “mold remediation license holder”, “registered mold remediation contractor”, by other title, or by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is licensed to provide mold remediation services.
This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Mold Remediation Services Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this subtitle and all regulations adopted under this subtitle shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2019.
This title is the Maryland Home Improvement Law.
Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate on July 1, 2022.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Client” means an individual who seeks employment through an employment agency.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

paragraph.text: “Employment agency” means a person who, for a fee:

subparagraph.text: obtains, offers to obtain, or attempts to obtain:

sub-subparagraph.text: an employee for a person who seeks an employee; or
employment for a client;

subparagraph.text: provides to a client information to enable the client to obtain employment;
obtains, offers to obtain, or attempts to obtain employment or an engagement in connection with an entertainment, exhibition, or performance, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a ballet;
a circus;
a concert;
the legitimate theater;
modeling;
a motion picture;
an opera;
a phonograph recording;
the radio;
a transcription;
television;
the variety field; or
vaudeville; or
obtains, offers to obtain, or attempts to obtain an alien labor certification or immigrant visa for an individual; and
participates directly or indirectly in the recruitment or supply of an individual who resides outside of the continental United States for employment in the continental United States.

paragraph.text: “Employment agency” does not include a person who merely:

subparagraph.text: conducts a business that directly employs individuals to provide part-time or temporary services to another person;
as a lawyer, directly obtains an immigrant visa for an individual;
conducts a business that:

sub-subparagraph.text: receives a fee that is paid wholly by an employer;
does not collect money from an individual seeking employment; and
does not require an individual seeking employment to make a contract; or

subparagraph.text: operates a nursing referral service agency that is licensed under Title 19, Subtitle 4B of the Health - General Article.

section.text: This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a charitable, educational, fraternal, or religious organization that does not charge a fee for its services other than ordinary dues for membership;
a labor organization while obtaining or attempting to obtain employment for a member of the organization; or
an organization of employers while obtaining or attempting to obtain help for a member of the organization.

section.text: The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under this title.
The Commissioner shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: An employment agency shall submit to the Commissioner a penal bond.
The bond shall:

paragraph.text: run to the State;
be in the amount of $7,000;
be signed by an individual authorized to do so by the employment agency as principal and by a surety company authorized to do business in the State as surety; and

be conditioned that the employment agency will comply with this title and will pay to any person all damages caused by deceit, fraud, misrepresentation, or misstatement of the employment agency or an agent or employee of the employment agency.

subsection.text: To ensure that each employment agency submits the penal bond in accordance with this section, the Commissioner may initiate an investigation or investigate a complaint that an employment agency has failed to submit a penal bond.

If, after investigation, the Commissioner finds that an employment agency has failed to submit a penal bond as required by this section, the Commissioner shall give written notice that directs the employment agency, within 15 days after receipt of the notice:

paragraph.text: to submit the required bond; or
to show written cause why the employment agency is not required to comply with this section.
If the employment agency complies with the requirement to submit a bond or otherwise submits a timely response, the Commissioner may:

subparagraph.text: terminate proceedings against the employment agency; or
schedule a hearing and, by certified mail, give the employment agency written notice of the date, place, and time of the hearing.

paragraph.text: If the employment agency fails to comply with a lawful order of the Commissioner or fails to submit a timely response, the Commissioner may impose a civil penalty of not less than $500 and not more than $1,000 for each failure to comply with the order or failure to submit a timely report.

subsection.text: If after a hearing, the Commissioner finds that the employment agency has violated the provisions of this section, the Commissioner may impose a civil penalty of not less than $500 and not more than $1,000 for each violation of this section.

section.text: An employment agency may not:

paragraph.text: knowingly refer a client to a job if any condition of the job violates any law;
refer a client to an establishment where a labor dispute exists;
as a condition of providing service to a client, require the client before acceptance of a job to execute:

subparagraph.text: a promissory note; or
an instrument with warrant of attorney that authorizes confession of judgment;

paragraph.text: advertise a job for which there is no order by an employer on file;
send a client to an employer for a job with no order on file for the job unless:

subparagraph.text: the employer previously requested regular interviews with qualified clients, the client is qualified, and the employment agency confirms the request before sending the client to the employer; or
the employment agency tells the client that the employment agency has no order for the job;

paragraph.text: split a fee with an employer or representative of an employer, except that the employment agency may accept from an employer all or part of a service fee for a client if the employment agency tells the client of the payment;
charge a client a registration fee or collect in advance from a client a payment for service to be performed for the client to obtain employment;
publish or cause to be published any false, fraudulent, or misleading information or promise;
solicit for other employment an individual who is employed by an employer with whom the employment agency placed the individual, unless the individual reactivates the application;
engage in fraud or dishonest dealing; or
violate this title.

section.text: Each employment agency shall keep a detailed record of:

paragraph.text: each job order from an employer; and
each referral that the employment agency makes on a job order.

subsection.text: Each employment agency shall keep a file of all job advertisements that identifies each advertisement by:

paragraph.text: its date; and
the publication where the advertisement appears.

subsection.text: Each employment agency:

paragraph.text: shall indicate on each advertisement and on all other promotional material the name of the employment agency; and
except in an advertisement that appears in a classified employment agency column of a newspaper, shall use the word “agency” in each advertisement.

subsection.text: Each employment agency shall indicate, on each form that the employment agency uses, that it is an employment agency.
In a contract between an employment agency and a client, the term “acceptance of position by applicant” means:

paragraph.text: commencement of work by a client; or
an agreement between a client and employer for the client to begin work on a fixed date at an agreed remuneration.

subsection.text: In each contract between an employment agency and a client, the employment agency shall state the fee that the employment agency charges the client for placement by the employment agency.

If, within 90 days after a client starts a job, the client is discharged through no fault of the client or leaves the job voluntarily with just cause, an employment agency may charge the client a temporary placement fee of up to the lesser of:

paragraph.text: 20% of the total compensation the client received; or
75% of the permanent placement fee for the same job.

subsection.text: If, within 90 days after a client starts a job, the client is discharged for cause or leaves the job voluntarily without just cause, an employment agency may charge the client a temporary placement fee of up to 75% of the permanent placement fee.

section.text: If, for a pay period, the pay of an employee placed by an employment agency is not more than the minimum wage under § 3-413 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employment agency may not collect or attempt to collect more than 20% of its placement fee from the employee’s pay for the pay period.

Within 24 hours after a client demands reimbursement for ordinary and necessary travel expenses incurred as a result of a referral, an employment agency shall reimburse the client if the client did not obtain employment and:

paragraph.text: the employment agency sent the client to an employer for a job for which the employment agency had no order and failed to tell the client that there was no order;

the client was qualified and the employment agency sent the client to an employer that previously asked for regular interviews with qualified clients, but the employment agency failed to confirm the order with the employer; or
the client was unqualified and the employment agency sent the client to an employer that previously asked for regular interviews with qualified clients.

subsection.text: When an employment agency and a client execute a contract or other document, the employment agency shall give the client a copy of the document.
For each fee that an employment agency receives from a client, the employment agency shall give the client a receipt that states:

paragraph.text: the name of the client;
the date of payment;
the amount of the fee paid; and
the balance of the fee due.

section.text: A person who violates this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
This title is the Maryland Employment Agency Act.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Contractors.
“Contractor” means a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor.

paragraph.text: “Cooling system” means a system in which heat is removed from air, surrounding surfaces, or both.
“Cooling system” includes an air-conditioning system.

subsection.text: “Forced air system” means a heating system that uses air being moved by mechanical means to transmit heat.

paragraph.text: “Heating system” means a system in which heat is transmitted by radiation, conduction, or convection, or a combination of any of these methods, to the air, surrounding surfaces, or both.
“Heating system” does not include a fireplace or woodburning stove not incorporated into or used as a primary heating system.

subsection.text: “Heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor” means an individual who provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services.
“Hydronic system” means a heating and cooling system using liquids or steam to transmit or remove heat.

“Independent agency” means an office, commission, board, department, or agency established as an independent unit of government that may receive budgetary or administrative support from the federal, State, or local government.
“Journeyman license” means a license issued by the Board to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services while under the direction and control of a licensed contractor.

“Journeyman restricted license” means a license issued by the Board to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services while under the direction and control of a licensed contractor, in only one of the following areas:

paragraph.text: heating - forced air systems;
heating - hydronic systems;
ventilation;
air-conditioning; or
refrigeration.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a license issued by the Board to provide or to assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services.
“License” includes, unless the context requires otherwise:

subparagraph.text: a master license;
a master restricted license;
a limited license;
a journeyman license;
a journeyman restricted license; and
an apprentice license.

subsection.text: “Licensed apprentice” means an individual who is licensed by the Board to assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services while:

paragraph.text: under the direction and control of a licensed contractor; and
in training to become a journeyman.

subsection.text: “Licensed contractor” means a contractor who is licensed by the Board to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services, but does not include a licensed apprentice or licensed journeyman.

“Limited license” means a license issued by the Board exclusively to maintain or repair one or more of the following: heating systems, cooling systems, refrigeration systems, ventilation systems, or hydronic systems.
“Master license” means a license issued by the Board to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services.
“Master restricted license” means a license issued by the Board to provide services in only one of the following areas:

paragraph.text: heating - forced air systems;
heating - hydronic systems;
ventilation;
air-conditioning; or
refrigeration.

subsection.text: “Provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services” means to install, maintain, alter, remodel, or repair heating systems, cooling systems, refrigeration systems, ventilation systems, or hydronic systems.
“Refrigeration system” means a system used to cool a surface or area below 55 degrees Fahrenheit or 12.9 degrees Celsius.
“Self-contained appliance” means a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration device that is designed and manufactured:

paragraph.text: with its component parts contained within a single chassis;
with a standard factory-installed electrical line cord that requires a plug-in device;
with no additional external fuel source; and
independent of an air distribution system.

subsection.text: “Subdivision of the State” means any of the 23 counties in Maryland, the City of Baltimore, and any municipal corporation.
“Ventilation system” means the natural or mechanical process of supplying air to, or removing air from, any space:

paragraph.text: whether the air is conditioned or is not conditioned; and
at a rate of airflow of more than 250 cubic feet per minute.

section.text: The purpose of this title is to establish a licensing program for individuals who provide or assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services to:

paragraph.text: protect the public;
provide and maintain efficient and safe systems;
promote high professional standards; and
ensure that qualified individuals carry out subsections (1), (2), and (3) of this section.

section.text: This title does not limit the right of:

paragraph.text: an individual owner of a single-family dwelling while that owner is practicing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services on or within a building or structure owned by the individual;

an individual who is building a single-family dwelling in which that individual will reside while practicing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services on or within that dwelling;
an employee of a public utility company regulated by the Public Service Commission, when engaged in:

subparagraph.text: the development, construction, maintenance, or repair of electric or gas facilities located in the State; or
the construction, maintenance, or repair of electric or gas appliances in the service area of the public utility;

paragraph.text: subject to § 9A-403(a) of this title, an employee of the United States government, the State government, a local government, or an independent agency while that employee is practicing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services on or within buildings or structures owned or solely occupied by the United States government, the State government, a local government, or an independent agency;
an individual employed in the installation, maintenance, alteration, repair, or replacement of self-contained appliances requiring not more than 225 volts or 25 amperes of electrical current;

an individual possessing a master electrician's license issued by the State or any county, when engaged in the installation, alteration, service, repair, or replacement of individually controlled electric resistance heat;

an individual possessing a master plumber's license issued by the State, Baltimore County, or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission when providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services on hydronic heating systems;
an individual possessing a license to practice engineering when providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in connection with the practice of engineering;
an individual who installs, alters, remodels, maintains, or repairs oil burners exclusively while employed by a supplier of home heating fuel; or
an individual regularly employed by the owner of property, or the owner's agent, to engage in maintenance and repair work.

section.text: There is a State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Contractors in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 9 members.
Of the 9 Board members:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be master heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, and refrigeration contractors licensed in the State, a subdivision of the State, or another state provided that state has licensing requirements equivalent to the licensing requirements of this title;
1 shall be a master electrician;
1 shall be a master plumber; and
2 shall be consumer members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members of the Board with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: Except for the initial members of the Board, of the members appointed under subsection (a)(2)(i), (ii), and (iii) of this section:

paragraph.text: 1 shall be from the area that consists of Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne’s, Somerset, Talbot, Wicomico, and Worcester counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Baltimore City, and Baltimore, Cecil, and Harford counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Anne Arundel, Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties;
1 shall be from the area that consists of Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George’s counties; and
1 shall be from the area that consists of Allegany, Carroll, Frederick, Garrett, and Washington counties.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be:

paragraph.text: a citizen of the United States; and
a resident of the State.
Each member appointed under subsection (a)(2)(i), (ii), and (iii) of this section:

subparagraph.text: shall be an active contractor;
shall hold a current active license under this title or under a licensing program in a subdivision of the State; and
shall have provided services as a contractor for not less than 5 consecutive years immediately prior to the date of appointment.

paragraph.text: The master electrician member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: shall be actively engaged in the electrical contracting business as a master electrician;
shall hold a current active license under this article; and
shall have been engaged in business as a master electrician for not less than 5 consecutive years immediately prior to the date of appointment.

paragraph.text: The master plumber member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: shall be actively engaged in the plumbing contracting business as a master plumber;
shall hold a current active license under this article; and
shall have been engaged in business as a master plumber for not less than 5 consecutive years immediately prior to the date of appointment.

subsection.text: Each consumer member of the Board:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to the regulation of the Board; and
may not have had within 1 year before appointment a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on January 1, 1993.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Board members are eligible for reappointment, but may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

subsection.text: From among the Board members, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.
Except for the chairman, the manner of election of officers shall be as the Board determines.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet once a month in a location and office provided by the State.
Special meetings of the Board may be held as the Board provides in its rules and regulations.

subsection.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
Subject to the State budget, each member of the Board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: an annual salary of $3,600; and
reimbursement for reasonable expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere, the Board shall:

paragraph.text: adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this title;
adopt and enforce a code that sets minimum standards for installing, altering, remodeling, maintaining, and repairing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, hydronic, and refrigeration systems;
administer examinations;
issue licenses;
keep a list of all licensees;
keep a record of its proceedings; and
adopt an official seal.

subsection.text: The Board shall enter into a cooperative agreement with a county for the county to enforce the code adopted under this section.
If a county has adopted a code prior to January 1, 1988 the county code shall apply within that county.
The Board may investigate any complaint that alleges facts that constitute a violation of this title.
On receipt of the results of an investigation made under this section, the Board promptly shall take action that is appropriate under this title to ensure compliance with this title.

paragraph.text: If the Board concludes that any conduct alleged to be in violation of this title will result in harm to any citizen of the State, the Board may seek a permanent or temporary injunction with respect to the conduct from the circuit court of any county in which the alleged violation occurs, or in which the violator has its principal place of business.
In seeking an injunction under this subsection, the Board is not required to:

subparagraph.text: post bond;
allege or prove that an adequate remedy at law does not exist; or
allege or prove that substantial or irreparable damage would result from the continued violation of the provision.

paragraph.text: Any 5 members of the Board, or a hearing officer designated by the Board, may administer oaths, hold hearings, and take testimony about all matters within the jurisdiction of the Board.
The Board, or its designee, may take testimony of any person by deposition in the same manner as in judicial proceedings in State civil cases.
Any party to any hearing before the Board has the right to attendance of witnesses, after making a request to the Board and designating the person sought to be subpoenaed.
A member of the Board may not be held personally liable for any action taken under this section.
The Board or its designee may issue a subpoena.
The Police Department of Baltimore City or the sheriff of a county shall serve a subpoena issued under this subsection.
If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this subsection, on petition of the Board, a court of competent jurisdiction may compel compliance with the subpoena.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the Board may set reasonable fees for its services.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, revenues generated by the Board shall be at least equal to expenses incurred by the Board.
The Board shall require the following fees for the issuance or renewal of the following licenses:

paragraph.text: master license - $75;
master restricted license - $25 for each area licensed;
limited license - $75;
journeyman license - $20; and
apprentice license - $10.

subsection.text: The Board shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall be licensed by the Board before the individual provides or assists in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in the State.

subsection.text: To qualify for an apprentice, journeyman, journeyman restricted, master, master restricted, or limited license, an applicant shall meet the requirements of this section.
An applicant for a master heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license shall:

paragraph.text: have been regularly and principally employed in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services under a journeyman, journeyman restricted, limited, or master restricted license for not less than 3 years of active experience under the direction and control of a master heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor and have been so employed for not less than 1,875 hours in the year prior to application; and
pass an examination administered by the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant for a master restricted heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license shall:

paragraph.text: have been regularly and principally employed in providing refrigeration, air-conditioning, forced air heating, hydronic heating, or ventilation services under a journeyman, journeyman restricted, limited, or master restricted license for not less than 3 years of active experience under the direction and control of a master or master restricted heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor and have been so employed for not less than 1,875 hours in the year prior to application; and
pass an examination administered by the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant for a limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration license shall:

paragraph.text: have been regularly and principally employed in providing forced air heating, hydronic heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services under a journeyman license for not less than 2 years of active experience under the direction and control of the holder of a master, master restricted, or limited license under this title, and have been so employed for not less than 1,000 hours in the year prior to application; and
pass an examination administered by the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant for a journeyman license shall:

paragraph.text: have held, for a period of at least 3 years, an apprentice license, and during that period shall have completed at least 1,875 hours of training in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services under the direction and control of a licensed contractor; and
pass an examination administered by the Board.

subsection.text: An applicant for a journeyman restricted license shall:

paragraph.text: have held, for a period of at least 3 years, an apprentice license, and during that period shall have completed at least 1,875 hours of training in providing forced air heating, hydronic heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services under the direction and control of a licensed contractor; and
pass an examination administered by the Board.

The Board may credit not more than 3 years of formal course of study or professional training in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services if, in the opinion of the Board, the study or training provided comparable experience.

The Board may credit not more than 6 years of work experience in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services that fails to meet the requirements of subsection (b)(1), (c)(1), (d)(1), (e)(1), or (f)(1) of this section if, in the opinion of the Board:

subparagraph.text: the work provided comparable experience; and
the failure of the applicant to meet the requirements is not attributable to fault or neglect on the part of the applicant.

paragraph.text: The Board shall credit not more than 3 years of work experience in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services to any applicant under this section who has been teaching formal courses of study in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services for purposes of satisfying the requirements of subsections (b)(1), (c)(1), (d)(1), (e)(1), or (f)(1) of this section.

section.text: An applicant for a license shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Board in the form that the Board provides; and
pay to the Board or the Board’s designee an examination fee established by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the examination.

subsection.text: An applicant who otherwise qualifies for a license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section.
The Board shall offer examinations to applicants at least twice annually, at places within the State and at times that the Board determines.
The Board shall send written notice of the date, hour, and place of examination to each applicant for a license who is required to pass the examination.

paragraph.text: The Board shall determine the subjects, scope, and form of and the passing score for examinations given under this title.
The Board shall provide examination questions that test the competency and qualifications of the applicant.

subsection.text: An applicant for a master restricted, journeyman restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license shall be examined only on subjects in which the applicant has the experience required under § 9A-302 of this subtitle.
To take an examination, an applicant shall pay to the Board or a testing service chosen by the Board the examination fee set by the Board in an amount not to exceed the cost of the examination.

paragraph.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations given under this title.
If the Board uses a testing service, the testing service, subject to requirements set by the Board, may:

subparagraph.text: set the time and place of examinations;
give qualified applicants notice of the time and place of examinations; and
furnish any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, on the affirmative vote of at least a majority of the authorized membership of the Board, the Board may waive the examination requirements of this title for an individual who is licensed in another state to provide heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services as a journeyman, journeyman restricted, master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, and refrigeration contractor.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays the appropriate application fee required by § 9A–207 of this title; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by this title;
holds an active license in good standing in the other state;
holds a license that is equivalent to the State license; and

became licensed in the other state after meeting, in that state, requirements that are at least equivalent to the licensing requirements of this State, including the number of years of work experience equivalent to the experience required under § 9A–302(b), (c), and (d) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver only if the state in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination of licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “BRAC” means the Base Realignment and Closure process as announced by the United States Department of Defense.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section, the Board shall grant a waiver to an applicant who files a request before July 1, 2012, if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: pays the appropriate application fee required under § 9A–207 of this title;
holds an active Virginia license in good standing that is equivalent to the State license;
has experience in the provision of heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services that meets the time requirements of § 9A–302 of this subtitle; and
has relocated to the State as a family member of a BRAC employee.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue without examination a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license to any licensee holding a current, active or inactive master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license, or a similar license issued by a subdivision of the State, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: files an application for a license under this title by 1 year after the date that the members of the Board are appointed; and
submits with the application the prescribed fee and proof of eligibility required by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue without examination a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license, whether a subdivision of the State requires a local license or not, to an individual who:

paragraph.text: has lawfully provided heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in a subdivision of the State for at least 5 years immediately prior to 1 year after the date the members of the Board are appointed;
files an application for a license under this title prior to 1 year after the date the members of the Board are appointed; and
submits with the application the prescribed fee and proof of eligibility required by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue without examination a journeyman license to an individual holding a current, active or inactive, journeyman license, or a similar license issued by a subdivision of the State, if the individual:

paragraph.text: files an application for a license under this title prior to December 31, 1994; and
submits with the application the prescribed fee and proof of eligibility required by the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall issue without examination a journeyman license, whether a subdivision of the State requires a local license or not, to an individual who:

paragraph.text: has lawfully provided heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in a subdivision of the State:

subparagraph.text: under the direction and control of one or more individuals who meet the requirements for a master license under subsection (a) or (b) of this section; and
for at least 3 years prior to December 31, 1994;

paragraph.text: holds an apprentice license at the time of the application;
files an application for a license under this title prior to December 31, 1994; and
submits with the application the prescribed fee and proof of eligibility required by the Board.

The Board shall issue without examination a journeyman license to an individual who has successfully completed an apprentice program in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration approved by the Apprenticeship and Training Council.

The Board shall issue without examination a journeyman restricted license to an individual who has successfully completed an apprentice program in heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration approved by the Apprenticeship and Training Council.

All applicants for a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license on or after 1 year after the date the members of the Board are appointed shall submit to examination under this title.
The application shall include all information required by the Board regarding proof of eligibility.
Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, all applicants for a journeyman license on or after January 1, 1995 shall submit to examination under this title.
The application shall include all information required by the Board regarding proof of eligibility.

subsection.text: An applicant who qualifies for a license under subsection (a) or (b) of this section but fails to apply for the license within the 1-year period:

paragraph.text: may take an examination under this title to be licensed;
may not be required to obtain a journeyman license or an apprentice license; and
may provide services as a master, master restricted, or limited license holder after obtaining the appropriate license.

subsection.text: An individual who holds a limited license or a master restricted license issued under subsection (a) or (b) of this section may take an examination administered by the Board to qualify for a master license or an additional master restricted license without meeting the requirements of § 9A-302 of this subtitle, if the individual:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board on or before December 31, 1996 an application on the form that the Board provides; and
pays to the Board an application fee established by the Board.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license, an applicant shall obtain a grade of at least 70 percent on the examination.

The use of unauthorized material or other misbehavior by an applicant during an examination shall cause the immediate rejection of the application and shall bar the applicant from reexamination for at least 1 year.

paragraph.text: Applicants who have failed an examination or fail to appear for a scheduled examination shall be required to file a new application and pay a new fee.
Examination fees shall be nonrefundable.

subsection.text: Each applicant who has taken an examination required by this title shall be notified of the grade received on the examination as soon as practicable.

If an applicant passes the examination required by the Board and otherwise qualifies for a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license under this title, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for the license; and
the Board will issue the license to an applicant on receipt of:

subparagraph.text: proof of insurance as required under § 9A-402 of this title; and
a license fee established by the Board.

subsection.text: If an applicant passes the examination required by the Board and otherwise qualifies for a journeyman license or journeyman restricted license under this title, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for the license; and
the Board will issue the license to an applicant on receipt of a license fee established by the Board.

subsection.text: Unless the license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, a license expires on the first October 1 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an odd-numbered year.

subsection.text: Before the license expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional 2-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be granted a license;
pays to the Board a renewal fee established by the Board; and
submits:

subparagraph.text: proof of insurance as provided by § 9A-402 of this title; and
a renewal application in the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: At the time of renewal, a licensee who holds a valid heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor license may apply to the Board for inactive status, during which time the licensee may not provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in the State.
If an individual wishes to renew a license on inactive status, the individual shall meet the requirements of subsection (b)(1), (2), and (3)(ii) of this section.
To return to active status the licensee must meet the renewal requirements of subsection (b) of this section.
Unless a licensee on inactive status renews the license as provided in this section, or reactivates the license as provided in this section, the license expires on the first October 1 that comes:

subparagraph.text: after the inactive status certificate has been issued to the licensee; and
in an odd-numbered year.

paragraph.text: If application for restoration is made within 90 days of expiration of a license, the license may be restored only on payment of a renewal fee.
If application for restoration is not made within the 90-day period, the Board may require compliance with the process for initial applications as if the applicant had never been licensed.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, a license issued under this title is not transferable.

paragraph.text: On the death of a licensed heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor, the personal representative of the deceased licensee may retain the license for up to 6 months for the purpose of winding up the business.

In cases of extreme hardship, the Board may allow the personal representative to retain the license for an additional period not to exceed 24 months upon a good faith showing that the personal representative has:

subparagraph.text: acted diligently to conclude the business of the deceased licensee; and
complied with the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

paragraph.text: The Board may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, or suspend or revoke a license after a public hearing conducted in accordance with the provisions of § 9A-311 of this subtitle, if the Board finds that the individual:

subparagraph.text: obtained a license by false or fraudulent representation;
transferred the authority granted by the license to another person;
willfully or deliberately disregarded and violated the code established by the Board under this title;
willfully or deliberately disregarded and violated building codes, electrical codes, or laws of the State or of any municipality, city, or county of the State;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services;

subparagraph.text: aided or abetted a person to evade a provision of this title by allowing a license to be used by an unlicensed person, firm, or corporation;

willfully or deliberately disregarded disciplinary action taken by a municipality, city, or county against the individual in connection with providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services;
abandoned or failed to perform, without justification, any contract or project to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services;
performed work under a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services contract or project that is inadequate or incomplete;

directly or indirectly published any advertisement relating to the providing of heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services that contained an insertion, representation, or statement of fact that is false, deceptive, or misleading;
made any material misrepresentation in the procurement of a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services contract or project;
failed in any material respect to comply with the provisions of this title;
as the holder of a master restricted, limited, journeyman, or apprentice license, performed heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services outside the scope of that license; or
knowingly allowed or permitted another licensee to perform heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services outside the scope of that individual’s license.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(v) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under § 9A-310 of this subtitle, the Board shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Board may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the Board may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Each licensed master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, and refrigeration contractor shall display:

paragraph.text: the license and the license number conspicuously in the principal place of business of the licensee; and
the license number of the licensee on each vehicle used on the job for providing heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a county or municipal corporation may not require a person licensed under this subtitle to display a county or municipal corporation certificate number on each vehicle used on the job for providing heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, and refrigeration services.
This subsection does not apply to Anne Arundel County.

subsection.text: Each licensee shall give the Board written notice of any change of name, address, or employment from that which appears on the current license, at least 10 working days before the change is to take effect.

A holder of a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration license may not contract to provide services on behalf of the licensee, or another person who provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services, unless the work of the licensee, including completed operations, is covered by:

paragraph.text: general liability insurance in the amount of at least $300,000; and
property damage insurance in the amount of at least $100,000.
The insurance required under this section may be bought:

subparagraph.text: by a holder of a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration license; or
by the person who engages in the business of providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services and employs the holder of the master, master restricted, or limited license.

paragraph.text: The insurance requirement of this section is not meant for work that a master, master restricted, or limited license holder does outside the scope of employment for the person who carries the insurance.

A licensed apprentice, licensed journeyman, or licensed journeyman restricted in the employ of a master, master restricted, or limited licensee need not obtain separate insurance while providing or assisting in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services under the control and supervision of the licensee.

Subject to the restrictions of § 9A-309 of this title regarding inactive status, inactive licensees who have had their inactive status approved by the Board need not obtain insurance while maintaining inactive status.
An applicant for any license under this title shall submit proof of the insurance required under this section to the Board with the license application.
Unless the applicant submits proof of insurance, the Board may not issue any license to an applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section apply.

subsection.text: Unless an applicant meets the insurance requirements of this section, the Board may not renew any license of the applicant to whom the insurance requirements of this section apply.
A holder of a master, master restricted, or limited license shall give the Board notice of the cancellation of insurance at least 10 days before the effective date of the cancellation.

If a county, municipal corporation, special taxing district, or other political subdivision requires a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration license holder, or other person who engages in the business of providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services, to execute a surety bond under local heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration requirements, the person may satisfy the bond requirement by submitting proof of the insurance required under this section.
The Board shall specify on each license whether the license holder meets the insurance requirements of this section.
Each individual whom the State, a county, or a local government appoints or employs as a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration inspector shall:

paragraph.text: each year attend a continuing education course that the Board or, with the approval of the Board, a county or local government conducts; and
meet minimum standards that are:

subparagraph.text: established by the Board; and
administered:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a county or local government inspector, by the county or local government that appoints or employs the inspectors; and
for a State inspector by the State.

subsection.text: An individual may not have any financial interest in any business that provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services while employed by the State, a county, or any local government as a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration inspector.

paragraph.text: On appointment or employment, the individual shall place any license that the inspector holds on inactive status subject to § 9A-309 of this title.
The Board may issue a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration inspector identification card to an inspector who has placed the appropriate licensee on inactive status.

On termination of the appointment or employment of an individual as a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration inspector, the Board shall reactivate the license of the individual who is on inactive status, without examination, if the individual:

subparagraph.text: makes a written request to the Board; and
pays to the Board a reactivation fee established by the Board.

section.text: Each advertisement for heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services that is in the name of a person who provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services shall contain the license number and name of a master, master restricted, or limited license holder whom the person employs and designates to direct and control the provision of heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services through the business of the person.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services unless issued a master license by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not assist, attempt to assist, or offer to assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services unless issued a master restricted license by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual may not exclusively maintain or repair heating systems, cooling systems, refrigeration systems, ventilation systems, or hydronic systems in the State unless issued a limited license by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, a holder of a master, master restricted, or limited heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, and refrigeration license, or other person who engages in the business of providing heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services, may not employ an individual to provide or assist in providing heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services unless the individual is licensed by the Board.

A person may not employ an individual to provide or assist in providing heating, ventilation, air–conditioning, or refrigeration services under a public work contract subject to Title 17, Subtitle 2 of the State Finance and Procurement Article unless the individual is licensed by the Board.

A person may not classify an employee under a public work contract subject to Title 17, Subtitle 2 of the State Finance and Procurement Article who is licensed under this title at a specific work classification that is higher than the employee’s license type.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, regardless of whether a person is engaged in the business of providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services, the person may not knowingly employ an individual to provide or assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services in the State unless the individual is licensed by the Board.

Unless licensed to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services under this title, a person may not represent to the public by use of the titles “heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration license holder”, “registered heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractor”, by other title, or by description of services, methods, or procedures, or otherwise, that the person is licensed to provide or to assist in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services.

paragraph.text: In this section, “officer” includes a superintendent, manager, or agent of a corporation regardless of whether the corporation provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services.

Any person, including an officer, who violates § 9A-501, § 9A-502, § 9A-503, or § 9A-504 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both and, on a second or subsequent conviction, subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

subsection.text: Any person who violates any provision of § 9A-402 of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by this title, the Board may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Any subdivision of the State which required a local license to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services on or before January 1, 1990 may continue to require a local license for services performed within that subdivision.

paragraph.text: A subdivision of the State which requires a local license to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services may not discriminate against applicants who are not residents of the subdivision.

A subdivision of the State which requires a local license to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services shall issue a local license to any individual licensed by the Board on receipt from the individual of any application and fee required by the subdivision of the State.

A subdivision of the State may not require an applicant for a local license to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services to take an examination if the applicant is licensed by the Board.

subsection.text: In the event that any subdivision which requires a local license discontinues that requirement after the effective date of this Act, that subdivision may not thereafter adopt a license requirement.
A State license is required to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services anywhere within the State, whether or not the individual holds a local license.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Contractors Act”.

Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2023.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Conveyance” means a carrying or transporting device that has a capacity that exceeds 1,749 gallons exclusive of the fuel supply tank for its own propulsion.
“Conveyance” includes a pipeline, tank car, vehicle, and vessel.

subsection.text: “Dyed diesel fuel” means diesel fuel that is dyed under U.S. Environmental Protection Agency rules for high sulfur diesel fuel or is dyed under Internal Revenue Service rules for nontaxable use.

paragraph.text: “Gasoline” means a product that:

subparagraph.text: is used as fuel in a spark ignited, internal combustion engine; or
is designated as gasoline by the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: “Gasoline” includes:

subparagraph.text: casing head gasoline;
absorption gasoline;
other natural gasoline; and
aviation gasoline, as defined in § 9-101(c) of the Tax - General Article.

subsection.text: “Motor fuel” means:

paragraph.text: gasoline; or
special fuel.

subsection.text: “Motor vehicle” means a vehicle that:

paragraph.text: is self-propelled;
is designed to be operated on a public highway; and
is not operated only on rails.

subsection.text: “Petroleum transporter” means a person who transports motor fuel in interstate or intrastate commerce in a conveyance, whether or not the person owns the conveyance.
“Producer” means a company, or agent, parent company, subsidiary, or joint venture of a company, that extracts crude oil from the earth.

paragraph.text: “Propulsion tank” means a receptacle on a motor vehicle from which motor fuel is supplied for the propulsion of the vehicle.
“Propulsion tank” includes a fuel supply tank of a motor vehicle.

subsection.text: “Refiner” means a person who makes motor fuel from crude oil by changing the physical or chemical characteristics of the crude oil.
“Retail service station dealer” means a person who operates a retail place of business where motor fuel is sold and delivered into the fuel supply tanks of motor vehicles.

paragraph.text: “Special fuel” means a product that is usable as fuel in an internal combustion engine.
“Special fuel” does not include gasoline.

subsection.text: “Vehicle” means a conveyance for transporting motor fuel on a public highway.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall administer and enforce this title.
The Comptroller may delegate any power or duty of the Comptroller under this title.

subsection.text: To enforce this title, the Comptroller may make investigations, hold hearings, examine persons under oath, and receive evidence.
To enforce this title, the Comptroller may issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce evidence.

paragraph.text: For inspection or drawing samples, the Comptroller shall have access, during normal business hours, to:

subparagraph.text: each place where motor fuel is stored for sale;
each conveyance used to transport motor fuel; or
subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, the propulsion tank of any special fuel powered motor vehicle used for business purposes.

paragraph.text: In the case of the propulsion tank of a vehicle described in paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, the Comptroller shall also have access for inspection or drawing samples any time the vehicle is in operation.
A denial of access by an agent, owner, or other person who operates such a place, conveyance, or motor vehicle is prima facie evidence of a violation of this title.

subparagraph.text: The Comptroller may detain a motor vehicle, vessel or railroad tank car placed on a customer’s siding for use or storage for the purpose of inspecting the vehicle’s propulsion tanks.
The Comptroller may remove samples of diesel fuel in reasonable quantities necessary to determine the composition of the fuel.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may inspect and issue citations to operators of motor vehicles for violations of this subtitle at sites where fuel is, or may be, produced, stored, or loaded into or consumed by motor vehicles including:

subparagraph.text: a terminal;
a fuel storage facility or bulk storage facility that is not a terminal;
a retail fuel facility;
a highway rest stop; and
a highway inspection station, weigh station, mobile inspection station, or other similar location designated by the Comptroller.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may adopt regulations necessary to administer and enforce this title.
The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to:

paragraph.text: set minimum specifications for motor fuel marketed in the State consistent with the general practices of other states and the petroleum industry;
specify the information to be included on each loading ticket or manifest; and
specify the form of identification markers for vehicles and the method of annual validation of the markers.

subsection.text: The Comptroller periodically shall collect or cause to be collected and cause to be analyzed samples of all motor fuel that is:

paragraph.text: subject to regulation under this title; and
stored and offered for sale in the State.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall conduct inspections as provided in a memorandum of understanding on behalf of and in coordination with other agencies when collecting motor fuel samples under this section.

section.text: If the Comptroller finds that a person is willfully marketing in the State motor fuel regulated by this title that does not meet minimum specifications set by the Comptroller or otherwise willfully marketing motor fuel in violation of this title or the Tax - General Article or any regulation adopted under this title or the Tax - General Article, the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: shall order the person to stop the violation, including any sale or distribution; and
if the violation continues, shall sue for an injunction to stop the violation.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Comptroller need not analyze, collect, inspect, or set minimum specifications for liquefied petroleum gas.
If it is necessary to protect the public welfare, liquefied petroleum gas is subject to the same provisions of this title as motor fuel.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Below cost” means a price that is less than the total of:

paragraph.text: the most recently published average reseller rack cost of motor fuel by grade and quality, as calculated by the Oil Price Information Service (OPIS), for the particular terminal from which the motor fuel was delivered to the retail service station dealer, or the actual invoice cost from the supplier of the product, whichever is lower; and
the freight charges and all applicable federal, State, and local taxes not included in the invoice cost.
“Dealer” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: imports any gasoline into the State;
blends, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid;
refines, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid; or
acquires, in the State, any gasoline on which the motor fuel tax has not been paid, for:

sub-subparagraph.text: export; or
wholesale distribution.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” includes:

subparagraph.text: the State when it engages in any activities listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
a political subdivision of the State when it engages in any of the activities listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” does not include a person who brings gasoline into the State in the fuel supply tank of an aircraft, motor vehicle, or vessel.

subsection.text: “Manufacturer” means a person who in the State blends gasoline from blend stocks before final sale.
“Special fuel seller” has the meaning stated in § 9-301(s) of the Tax - General Article.
All motor fuel stored or offered for sale in the State is subject to inspection and analysis as provided in this title.
The analysis shall be made by a testing method approved by the Comptroller.
Before storing or selling motor fuel in the State, a person or governmental unit shall register with the Comptroller.
A separate registration is required for each location where a person or governmental unit stores or sells motor fuel.
An applicant for registration shall submit to the Comptroller in the form that the Comptroller requires:

paragraph.text: a statement that the applicant intends to store or sell motor fuel in the State;
a statement that the motor fuel, as supplied or bought from the supplier, conforms to the specifications set by the Comptroller;
the brand, type, and grade of the motor fuel to be stored or sold;
the name and address of the supplier;
if applicable, the number of retail nozzles by type of motor fuel;
the legal business name and federal identification number of the applicant; and
the address of the location where the motor fuel will be stored or sold.
The Comptroller shall issue a certificate of registration to each applicant who meets the requirements of this section.
The Comptroller shall set the form of the certificate of registration.

subsection.text: Registration expires on the first May 31 after its effective date.
Each registrant shall display the certificate of registration conspicuously in each location where the registrant stores or sells motor fuel.
A certificate of registration issued under this title is not transferable.
The Comptroller may waive this section only when consumers in the State otherwise would be subject to extreme hardship during an emergency or civil disturbance.

The Comptroller may not issue a certificate of registration to a retail service station dealer who markets motor fuel through a retail service station altered, enlarged, or structurally modified after July 1, 1977, unless:

paragraph.text: the station contains an enclosed work area where the service of motor vehicles is offered to customers regardless of whether motor fuel is bought; and
the services offered include a battery charge, lubrication, oil change, tire repair, and replacement of accessories such as fan belts, radiator hoses, or wiper blades.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the Comptroller may issue a certificate of registration to a retail service station dealer who markets motor fuel through:

paragraph.text: a retail service station that, before it is altered, enlarged, or structurally modified, lacks an enclosed work area; or
a retail service station that is altered, enlarged, or structurally modified if the owner and retail service station dealer agree to the elimination of an enclosed work area.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a retail service station dealer may not sell motor fuel below cost.
A retail service station dealer may sell motor fuel below cost if the sale is:

paragraph.text: made in good faith to meet competition;
made as part of a final liquidation or closing of the business of the retail service station dealer;
made as part of a bona fide charitable promotion lasting no longer than 2 days; or
made under the direction or order of a court or government entity.
