subsection.text: If the Comptroller receives a complaint in writing that a retail service station dealer is selling motor fuel below cost, the Comptroller shall investigate and determine within 3 business days of the receipt of the complaint whether the allegations contained in the complaint are true.

The Comptroller shall issue a stop sale notice and may suspend or revoke the certificate of registration of a retail service station dealer if the Comptroller determines that the retail service station dealer is in violation of this section.

paragraph.text: Each dealer, manufacturer, refiner, or special fuel seller who imports motor fuel into the State shall submit to the Comptroller refinery specifications, including additive specifications, without regard to where the additives become part of the motor fuel.
The Comptroller may waive this section only when consumers in the State otherwise would be subject to extreme hardship during an emergency or civil disturbance.

When submitting refinery specifications, a dealer, manufacturer, refiner, or special fuel seller, with the approval of the Comptroller, may designate 1 or more components of the motor fuel, including an additive, as a trade secret.
In determining whether a component is a trade secret, the Comptroller shall consider whether a chemist who uses modern analytical techniques reasonably could be expected to identify the component.
The Comptroller shall make every reasonable effort to protect the trade secret.

subsection.text: Before selling motor fuel, each dealer, manufacturer, refiner, special fuel seller, or person operating a facility where motor fuel is stored in bulk for further distribution shall submit to the Comptroller for approval each terminal agreement, each additive specification, and each refinery specification.
Before selling motor fuel, each dealer, manufacturer, or refiner shall submit to the Comptroller for approval each exchange agreement, each additive specification, and each refinery specification.
The Comptroller may waive this section only when consumers in the State otherwise would be subject to extreme hardship during an emergency or civil disturbance.

section.text: An employee of the Office of the Comptroller may not divulge an additive specification or a refinery specification.

subsection.text: Before making the first sale in the State of gasoline imported into the State, the seller shall register with the Comptroller each additive introduced into the gasoline after it was received in the State.
The registration shall:

paragraph.text: include the amount of additive blended into each gallon of gasoline; and
describe the additive by including:

subparagraph.text: its trade name, trademark, and manufacturer;
its quantitative analysis; and
the manufacturer’s trade name or other identification.

subsection.text: An additive may only be introduced into gasoline for resale or distribution by a person who holds a Class “A” dealer license issued in accordance with § 9-322 of the Tax - General Article.

Before making the first sale in the State of special fuel imported into the State, the seller shall register with the Comptroller each additive introduced into the special fuel after it was received in the State.
The registration shall:

paragraph.text: include the specific amount of additive blended into special fuel; and
describe the additive by including:

subparagraph.text: its trade name or trademark;
its quantitative analysis; and
the manufacturer’s trade name or other identification.

subsection.text: An additive may only be introduced into special fuel for resale or distribution:

paragraph.text: by a special fuel seller; and
in a manner set by regulation of the Comptroller.

subsection.text: Before making the first sale in the State of a fluid, material, or other item, in a prepackaged form, imported into the State that purports to be a substitute for or improver of motor fuel, the seller shall:

paragraph.text: submit the item to the Comptroller for inspection;
label the item in a way that the Comptroller approves; and
obtain authorization for the sale from the Comptroller.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information that the Comptroller requires, the seller shall submit to the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: the trade name, trademark, manufacturer, and place of manufacture of the item;
a quantitative analysis of the item;
a copy of any patent for the item;
proof of all claims made for the item;
instructions for use, including dosage;
an amount of the item sufficient to be analyzed; and
the results of each applicable SAE or ASTM test made on the item.

subsection.text: If a material change is made in an item authorized for sale under this section, the item shall be resubmitted to the Comptroller for authorization.
The Comptroller shall order the removal from the State of an unauthorized item offered for sale.
Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, each retail service station in the State:

paragraph.text: shall be operated by a retail service station dealer; and
may not be operated by a producer or refiner of motor fuel:

subparagraph.text: with a commissioned agent, company personnel, or a subsidiary company; or
under a contract with a person who manages the station on a fee arrangement with the producer or refiner.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to facilities that an agricultural cooperative association owns and operates if:

paragraph.text: the agricultural cooperative association is certified by a bank for cooperatives to be eligible to borrow from the bank under Subchapter III of the federal Farm Credit Act of 1971;
the certification is submitted to the Comptroller with the application for registration of a retail service station dealer under this subtitle;
the agricultural cooperative association owns the property on which the facilities are located; and
on the property, the agricultural cooperative association, as part of its business, sells or provides farm supplies or farm business services or distributes motor fuel in bulk to farmers on farms.

subsection.text: A retail service station shall be exempt from subsection (a) of this section for a fiscal year that starts July 1, if:

paragraph.text: on January 1, 1979, the station was operated by a subsidiary of a producer or refiner of motor fuel; and

the gross revenues of the subsidiary from the sale of motor fuel in the State for the preceding calendar year is less than 2% of the gross revenues of the subsidiary from all retail operations in the State for the preceding calendar year.

subsection.text: If a dealer has previously operated a retail service station, the Comptroller may adopt regulations that define the circumstances in which a producer or refiner temporarily may operate the station.

A producer or refiner of motor fuel may not include in any agreement or contract entered into with a service station dealer any provision that directly or indirectly limits or waives any right of the dealer to:

paragraph.text: petition any governmental authority or body; or
lawfully advocate or oppose any governmental or regulatory action with respect to any matter.

subsection.text: Any provision in an agreement or contract that violates the provisions of subsection (a) of this section is deemed to be void and unenforceable.

section.text: Each producer, refiner, or wholesaler of motor fuel who supplies motor fuel to retail service station dealers:

paragraph.text: shall apply all equipment rentals uniformly to all retail service station dealers supplied; and
during periods of shortage:

subparagraph.text: shall apportion uniformly and equitably all gasoline and special fuel to all retail service station dealers supplied; and
may not discriminate among retail service station dealers supplied in their allotments.

section.text: Each contractual relationship between a supplier and retail service station dealer shall conform to the Maryland Gasohol and Gasoline Products Marketing Act and the federal Petroleum Marketing Practices Act.
Each supplier of motor fuel to a retail service station dealer shall ensure that the motor fuel meets specifications set by the Comptroller.

subsection.text: A person who sells motor fuel at retail shall display signs in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: All dispensing equipment for motor fuel shall be marked conspicuously to show in numerals of equal size the price, including taxes, of a gallon of the motor fuel offered for sale.
If numerals that show a fractional cent are used, the combined height and width of the numerator and denominator shall equal the height and width of the other numerals used.
A sign or other means on the premises and approaches to a retail outlet that advertises the retail price of motor fuel:

subparagraph.text: may list the price and each tax separately if the listing of the total of the price and all taxes is the same size as the separate listing of the price; but
shall list the total of the price and all taxes by numerals of uniform size.

paragraph.text: In the listing of the total of the price and all taxes, a denominator need not be used to indicate a fraction, but:

subparagraph.text: if a denominator is used, the numerator and denominator combined shall be the same size as the numeral that indicates the whole number; or
if a denominator is not used, the numerator shall be the same size as the numeral that indicates the whole number.

subsection.text: If the retail price of motor fuel is advertised on a sign or by other means on the premises of and approaches to the retail outlet, the grade designation displayed for any motor fuel in the advertisement shall be the same as the grade designation that is required to be displayed for that motor fuel on the retail dispensing pump as specified by the Comptroller.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a retail service station dealer who operates with not more than 3 dispensing units that combined have not more than 6 nozzles.

subparagraph.text: Each retail service station dealer shall keep a sign on the premises that:

sub-subparagraph.text: states the lowest price for a whole measurement unit of regular gasoline sold on the premises;
states the unit of measurement used; and
is readable by passing motorists.

subparagraph.text: The sign required under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph also may state the lowest price for a whole measurement unit of diesel and other motor fuel products sold on the premises.

paragraph.text: All numerals on the sign shall:

subparagraph.text: be uniform;
be at least 8 inches high and 3.5 inches wide; and
have a brush stroke of at least 1 inch.

paragraph.text: A numeral in a fraction or a letter shall be at least one–third the height of a numeral that indicates a whole number.
If a new or additional sign is required to comply with this subsection, the supplier of the gasoline shall provide the sign and numerals without cost to the retail service station dealer.

subsection.text: A sign required at a service station by this section or any other State or federal law is exempt from the provisions of a local law, ordinance, or regulation for the purpose of determining:

paragraph.text: the total number of signs permitted; and
the area of signs permitted.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, signs regulated by this section or other State law or by federal law may be regulated by the local zoning authority and shall be consistent with the local law, ordinance, or regulation governing signs.

section.text: The Comptroller shall issue a stop sale notice if the Comptroller finds that a person:

paragraph.text: stores or sells motor fuel from a location that does not have a valid certificate of registration;
willfully uses a motor fuel advertisement that is misleading;
willfully markets motor fuel that has not been approved; or
sells motor fuel below cost in violation of § 10-304.1 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may suspend or revoke a registration for a violation of this subtitle, including the submission of a false statement, for a period not exceeding 30 days.

If the Comptroller finds that a person has willfully altered, enlarged, or structurally modified a retail service station in violation of § 10-304 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may suspend or revoke the registration until the violation is corrected.

section.text: If, because of the marketing of an unapproved product, the Comptroller under § 10-317 of this subtitle suspends or revokes the registration of a retail service station dealer who is without fault, the supplier of the unapproved product is liable in damages to the retail service station dealer in an amount equal to the net operating loss sustained during the period of suspension or revocation.
Before a retail or wholesale delivery of motor fuel may be made in a container, the vehicle operator shall remove all liquid volume of:

paragraph.text: gasoline, if the next delivery will be special fuel; or
special fuel, if the next delivery will be gasoline.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) or (c) of this section, a retail service station dealer who reduces the price of motor fuel for self-service shall provide, on request, fueling service at the self-service price to a disabled driver who displays a disabled person’s registration plate or parking permit issued by the Motor Vehicle Administration.
This section does not apply to a retail service station dealer who sells motor fuel from:

paragraph.text: a convenience store that:

subparagraph.text: sells motor fuel through remotely controlled dispensing equipment; and
does not provide fueling service; or

paragraph.text: a station that:

subparagraph.text: is exclusively self-service;
is operated by 1 cashier; and
has remotely controlled dispensing equipment.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a disabled driver who:

paragraph.text: is reasonably capable of providing self-service; or
drives a motor vehicle that carries another individual who is reasonably capable of providing self-service.

subsection.text: A retail service station dealer who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $25.

section.text: After gasoline to be sold at retail has been received in the State, a person may not add lead to the gasoline.
A retail service station dealer or marina may not with intent to defraud commingle gasoline by brand or grade.

subsection.text: A common carrier, contract carrier, manufacturer, refiner, special fuel seller, wholesaler of motor fuel, or person who buys motor fuel in bulk for resale in bulk who is engaged in the transportation of motor fuel may not willfully adulterate or commingle:

paragraph.text: gasoline with special fuel; or
gasoline by brand or grade.

subsection.text: Except for motor fuel intended for its own use, a petroleum transporter may not place an additive in motor fuel.
This section does not prohibit the adulteration or commingling of gasoline that occurs as a result of transit through a pipeline system.

Every motor fuel distributor required to be registered under this subtitle shall report the volume of sales, for each type of motor fuel sold in this State, made to end users that are exempt from the motor fuel tax.
Reporting shall be on a frequency established by the Comptroller through regulations, but may not be more frequent than once per calendar month.
Reporting shall be on forms furnished by the Comptroller.
Completed reports shall be forwarded to and be received by the Comptroller within 15 calendar days of the end of the report period.

paragraph.text: A notice stating “dyed diesel fuel, nontaxable use only” shall be:

subparagraph.text: provided by the terminal operator or distributor to any person that receives dyed diesel fuel at a terminal or distributor rack;

provided by the seller of dyed diesel fuel to its buyer if the fuel is located outside the bulk transfer or terminal system and is not sold from a retail pump on which the notice required by this section has been posted in accordance with item (iii) of this paragraph; and
posted by a seller on any retail pump where the seller sells dyed diesel fuel for use by the buyer of the dyed diesel fuel.

paragraph.text: The notice required under paragraph (1)(i) or (ii) of this subsection shall be provided at the time of the removal or sale of the dyed diesel fuel and shall appear on shipping papers, bills of lading, and invoices accompanying the sale or removal of the dyed diesel fuel.

The Motor Fuel Tax Bureau may determine that compliance with a federal notice provision that is substantially similar to a notice requirement of this subsection satisfies that notice requirement of this subsection.

A person may not operate a motor vehicle on a highway in the State with fuel supply tanks containing dyed diesel fuel unless permitted to do so under a federal law or regulation relating to the use of dyed diesel fuel on the highways.

subparagraph.text: A person may not sell or deliver dyed diesel fuel if the person knows or has reason to know that the dyed diesel fuel will be consumed for a prohibited on–highway use.

A person who dispenses dyed diesel fuel from a retail pump that is not properly labeled with the notice required by subsection (a)(1) of this section, or who knowingly delivers dyed diesel fuel into the storage tank of such a pump, shall be presumed to know that the dyed diesel fuel will be consumed on the highway.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (b)(1) of this section, operate a motor vehicle on a highway in the State with dyed diesel fuel in the propulsion tank of the motor vehicle;
sell or deliver dyed diesel fuel from a retail pump that is not properly labeled as required under subsection (a) of this section;
sell or deliver dyed diesel fuel from a petroleum delivery vehicle into a propulsion tank of a motor vehicle; or
refuse to permit inspection of a propulsion tank in accordance with § 10–201(e) of this title.
A person is guilty of a violation of this section if the person, whether as a principal, an agent, or an accessory, intentionally:

subparagraph.text: commits a violation of this section;
attempts to commit a violation of this section;
conspires to commit a violation of this section;
aids another in the commission of a violation of this section; or
abets another in the commission of a violation of this section.

paragraph.text: A person is guilty of a violation of this section if the person intentionally:

subparagraph.text: induces another to commit a violation of this section;
causes another to commit a violation of this section;
coerces another to commit a violation of this section;
permits another to commit a violation of this section; or
directs another to commit a violation of this section.

subsection.text: A person that violates any provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

In addition to any other penalty provided by law, the Comptroller may assess against any person that violates any provision of this section dealing with the use, sale, transportation, or storage of dyed diesel fuel:

paragraph.text: for the first violation, a fine of $1,000 or $10 per gallon of dyed diesel fuel involved in the violation, whichever amount is greater; and
for a second or subsequent violation, a fine equal to the amount of the penalty assessed under item (1) of this subsection for the first violation multiplied by the total number of violations.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person who violates this subtitle or aids or assists in the violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: Each petroleum transporter shall register with the Comptroller before transporting motor fuel to or from a place in the State.
An applicant for registration shall submit to the Comptroller an application on the form that the Comptroller requires.
The Comptroller shall register and issue a letter of registration to each applicant that meets the requirements of this subtitle.
A petroleum transporter shall notify the Comptroller of each change in registration information within 5 days of the change.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 10-404 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may deny registration to an applicant, reprimand a registrant, or suspend or revoke the registration of a petroleum transporter if the applicant or registrant:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain the registration for the applicant or registrant or for another person;
fraudulently or deceptively uses the registration;
fails to submit a report required under § 10-410 of this subtitle;
submits false information in a report required under § 10-410 of this subtitle; or
violates this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Comptroller takes any final action under this subtitle, the Comptroller shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Comptroller may administer oaths in connection with a proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Comptroller may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: A party to a proceeding before the Comptroller who is aggrieved by a final decision of the Comptroller in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Each vehicle used to transport motor fuel shall be identified on the tank part of the vehicle or another location acceptable to the Comptroller with the name of the petroleum transporter who is registered under this subtitle.
The identification must be discernible at 50 feet from each side or from the rear of the vehicle when the vehicle is at rest.
An operator of a vehicle or vessel who gets motor fuel for transport from a marine terminal, pipeline tank farm, place of manufacture, refinery, or other type of bulk storage shall:

paragraph.text: have a copy of the loading ticket or manifest; and
deliver a copy of the loading ticket or manifest to the buyer or consignee of the motor fuel at the time of delivery.

subsection.text: A loading ticket or manifest shall accompany each conveyance that leaves a place of loading.

section.text: Each petroleum transporter:

paragraph.text: shall keep for inspection a manufacturer’s certificate of origin that shows the measured calibration by pots or compartments for each vehicle that meets the definition of a conveyance; or
if such a certificate is unavailable, shall get and keep for inspection at the request of the Comptroller a certificate from a governmental unit or professional engineer.

section.text: A petroleum transporter shall label each vehicle in accordance with the hazardous materials regulations of the United States Department of Transportation.
Each petroleum transporter required by regulation to report to the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: report monthly on the form required by the Comptroller all motor fuel that the petroleum transporter imports into or exports from the State;
keep for 2 years a record of each interstate and each intrastate shipment of motor fuel;
on request, provide these records to the Comptroller; and
report immediately to the Comptroller the loss of any motor fuel, unless the loss is due to:

subparagraph.text: temperature correction; or
a spill that is reported to another State unit.

section.text: A person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, “police officer” means:

paragraph.text: any uniformed police officer; or

any civilian employee of the Department of State Police or of the Maryland Transportation Authority Police Force assigned to enforce this subtitle or any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, but only while acting under written authorization of the Secretary of State Police.
Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, any police officer shall have the authority to enforce this subtitle and any rule or regulation adopted under it.
A civilian employee of the Maryland Transportation Authority Police Force shall have the authority stated in paragraph (1) of this subsection only if the individual is:

subparagraph.text: acting under the immediate direction and control of a uniformed police officer; and
certified by the Department of State Police to enforce this subtitle and any rule or regulation adopted under it.

subsection.text: Each container of automotive crankcase oil offered for sale at wholesale or retail shall be labeled with the appropriate API/SAE classification and SAE viscosity number, as defined by the API engine service classification system.
Each container of crankcase oil or other lubricant that has been used for lubrication and then reclaimed, refined, or reconditioned shall be labeled with the word “reconditioned”.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a refiner or other supplier of motor fuel to a retail service station may not engage in, sponsor, promote, advertise, or otherwise perform or participate in a game of chance to be marketed or offered to the public at a retail service station in the State.

paragraph.text: A supplier of motor fuel authorized under this title to supply retail service stations may, at such stations, sponsor, promote, advertise, or otherwise perform or participate in a game of chance if the retail service station dealer agrees to participate in the game of chance.
A supplier of motor fuel authorized under this section to conduct a game of chance may not require a retail service station dealer to participate in the game of chance.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a refiner or other supplier of motor fuel to a retail service station may not engage in, sponsor, promote, advertise, or otherwise perform or participate in a game of chance to be marketed or offered to the public at a retail service station in the State.

paragraph.text: A supplier of motor fuel authorized under this title to operate retail service stations may, at such stations, participate in a game of chance promoted or sponsored by entities other than a refiner or supplier of motor fuel.
A supplier of motor fuel authorized under this section to conduct a game of chance may not require a retail service station dealer to pay for any costs related to the game of chance.

subsection.text: In this section, “dirt bike” has the meaning stated in § 21–1128 of the Transportation Article.
This section applies only in Baltimore City.
A retail service station dealer shall post a sign in a conspicuous location at the retail service station that states:

paragraph.text: the provisions of the Baltimore City Code that prohibit a service station or any other person from selling, transferring, or dispensing motor fuel for delivery into a dirt bike; and
the provisions of § 21–1128 of the Transportation Article that prohibit a person from dispensing motor fuel into a dirt bike.

subsection.text: The Comptroller, in consultation with the Washington, Maryland, Delaware Service Station and Automotive Repair Association, shall adopt guidelines for the design of a sign required under this section.
If a retail service station dealer does not post a sign as required by this section, the retail service station dealer:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, shall receive a warning; and
for a second or subsequent offense, is subject to a civil penalty of $100.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Breakage” means the odd cents that remain after all successful bettors are paid to the next lowest multiple of 10 cents.
“Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
“Commission” means the State Racing Commission.
“Handle” means the gross amount, less refunds, of money bet.
“Harness racing” means the racing of horses that trot or pace in harness while pulling drivers in sulkies.
“Intertrack betting” means:

paragraph.text: pari-mutuel betting at a receiving track in the State on a race that is:

subparagraph.text: held live or by interstate simulcast at a sending track in the State; and
shown simultaneously by video signal at the receiving track; and

paragraph.text: transmission of the bets at the receiving track to the sending track.

subsection.text: “License” means a license issued by the Commission to hold a race meeting.
“Licensee” means a person who has been awarded racing days for the current calendar year.
“Mile thoroughbred racing” means thoroughbred horse races at a track that is at least 1 mile long.
“Multiple mutuel pool” means a separate pari-mutuel betting pool in which an interest is represented by a single bet on 2 or more horses.
“Mutuel pool” includes a multiple mutuel pool and a regular mutuel pool.
“Pari-mutuel betting” means the system of betting in which those who successfully bet on horses that finish in specified positions share the mutuel pool, less the takeout and the breakage.
“Purse” means the prize money divided among the owners of horses that finish in specified positions in a race.
“Race meeting” means a period of time to hold racing that extends between specific dates over a number of racing days at a single track.
“Racing” includes:

paragraph.text: harness racing;
mile thoroughbred racing;
special thoroughbred racing;
steeplechase or hurdle racing;
flat racing; and
quarter horse racing.

subsection.text: “Receiving track” means a track where pari-mutuel betting is done on races held at another track.
“Regular mutuel pool” means a separate pari-mutuel betting pool in which an interest is represented by a single bet on 1 horse.

“Sending track” means a track where a race is held live or by interstate simulcast and is sent simultaneously by video signal to a receiving track or a satellite simulcast facility under Subtitle 8, Part III of this title.
“Special thoroughbred racing” means thoroughbred horse racing held by the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc., or the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission.
“Takeout” means the part of the handle that is not returned to successful bettors but is otherwise allocated under this title.
“Track” means a place where racing is held.
This title is statewide and exclusive in its effect.
A county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State may not:

paragraph.text: make or enforce a local law, ordinance, or regulation about racing; or
impose or collect any tax or additional license fee as to racing, except the general property tax.

section.text: Unless pari-mutuel betting is held, this title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Elkridge-Harford Point to Point;
the Grand National;
the Marlboro Trials;
the Maryland Hunt Cup;
the Potomac Trials;
a race at the Cape Pine Farm in Church Hill, Queen Anne’s County;
a race held by the Pocomoke City Fair Committee, Inc. on any day during and in conjunction with the Great Pocomoke Fair; and
any other steeplechase or hunt-type race.

section.text: There is a State Racing Commission in the Department.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of 9 members, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
At the time of appointment and qualification:

paragraph.text: each member shall be:

subparagraph.text: at least 25 years old;
a resident of the State who has resided in the State for at least the last 5 years;
a qualified voter of the State; and
an individual who has not been convicted of a crime that involves moral turpitude;

paragraph.text: at least 3 members of the Commission shall be knowledgeable or experienced in an aspect of thoroughbred racing; and
at least 3 other members shall be knowledgeable or experienced in an aspect of harness racing.
A member of the Commission may not hold an official relation to a licensee or hold any stocks, bonds, or other financial interest in a licensee.
Not more than 4 members who are appointed after July 1, 1989, may have a financial interest in racing in the State.
Not more than 6 members may be of the same political party.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Commission shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the Commission is 4 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 1992.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

Subject to the hearing requirements of this subsection, the Governor, with the advice of the Secretary, may remove a member of the Commission for inefficiency, misconduct in office, or neglect of duty.
Before the Governor removes a member, the Governor shall give the member an opportunity for a public hearing.
At least 10 days before the hearing, the Governor shall give the member:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the charges; and
notice of the time and place of the hearing.

paragraph.text: The member may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If the Governor removes a member, the Governor shall submit to the Secretary of State:

subparagraph.text: a statement of all charges made against the member;
the findings of the Governor; and
a record of the proceedings.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint one member of the Commission to serve as a liaison to the State Lottery Commission established under Title 9 of the State Government Article.
The Governor shall designate a chairman from among the members of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The term of the chairman is 1 year.
The chairman may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms as chairman.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 11-310 of this title, a majority of the members then serving on the Commission is a quorum.
The Commission shall meet in the State, at the times and places that the Commission determines.
Each member of the Commission is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement under the Standard State Travel Regulations for expenses for each Commission meeting attended, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: While in office, each member of the Commission shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint an executive director for the Commission from a list of at least 3 nominees submitted by the Commission.
The executive director is in the executive service in the State Personnel Management System and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.

subsection.text: The executive director shall:

paragraph.text: collect the taxes and fees imposed under this title or regulations adopted by the Commission;
keep the records and papers of the Commission, including a record of each proceeding;
administer the licensing of individuals who work in connection with racing;
prepare, issue, and submit reports of the Commission;
administer the daily operation of the office of the Commission; and
perform any other duty that the Commission directs.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Commission, the executive director shall set the conditions under which a licensee must add to, change, make a reasonable improvement to, or repair property that a licensee owns or leases for racing.
The executive director is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Commission and, except as otherwise provided by law, subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, the executive director shall appoint a staff of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission may employ 4 stewards and 4 harness judges.
The stewards and harness judges shall be recommended by the executive director.
Each licensee and organization that represents owners and trainers may recommend individuals to the Commission and executive director for appointment as stewards or harness judges.
The stewards and harness judges are special appointments of the skilled service or the professional service in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: Each member of the staff of the Commission, steward, and harness judge is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: An individual who holds a position under the Commission may not hold an official relation to a licensee or hold any stocks, bonds, or other financial interest in a licensee.

On the recommendation of the executive director, the Commission may employ additional employees or agents, including auditors, experts, guards, inspectors, a breathalyzer operator at each harness racing track, scientists, Commission secretaries, specimen collectors, veterinarians, and others whom the Commission considers to be essential at or in connection with a race meeting in the best interests of racing.
The licensee who holds the race meeting for which an additional employee is used shall pay:

paragraph.text: the employer contribution for the employee under the Employees’ Pension System;
the employer contribution, as determined by the Department of Budget and Management, for the retiree under § 2-508 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and
an amount required under § 23-306.1(b) of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, if any.

subsection.text: A licensee who holds a race meeting shall employ and pay the officials at the race meeting, other than stewards and harness judges, including each clerk of the course, clerk of the scales, handicapper, paddock judge, patrol judge, placing judge, racing secretary, starter, assistant starter, and timer.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, if a licensee is required to allocate 0.25% of handle to either the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund or the Maryland Harness Track Employees Pension Fund, the licensee shall first pay from the allocation any amounts required to be paid by the licensee under subsection (b) of this section and the remainder shall be paid to the appropriate pension fund.
Each law enforcement officer shall cooperate with the Commission to enforce this title.
On request of the Commission, the Governor may order the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City or the sheriff of a county to assign enough law enforcement officers to prevent unauthorized racing.
Besides its other powers under this title, the Commission has the powers necessary or proper to carry out fully all the purposes of this title.
The jurisdiction, supervision, powers, and duties of the Commission extend to each person who holds racing for a purse, reward, or stake.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations and conditions to govern racing and betting on racing in the State; and
approve or disapprove:

subparagraph.text: prices that a licensee may set for admission to a race, a service performed, or an article sold at a track; and
the size of the purse, reward, or stake to be offered at a race.

subsection.text: The Commission may not adopt regulations that allow:

paragraph.text: racing a breed of horse not now authorized by law; or
holding currently unauthorized:

subparagraph.text: intertrack betting;
off-track betting; or
telephone betting other than telephone account betting.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: enter or investigate the office, track, or place of business of a licensee to ensure that the regulations of the Commission are strictly complied with; and

place an expert accountant or other individual in the office, track, or place of business of a licensee and require that the licensee pay the salary and expenses of the expert accountant or other individual.

subsection.text: The Commission may require that an employee or official of the licensee be removed from the job.
The Commission may require that a licensee keep financial records in the way that the Commission determines.
The Commission may administer oaths.
The Commission may issue a subpoena for the attendance of a witness to testify or to produce evidence.
The Commission may maintain a testing laboratory and have tests done elsewhere.

paragraph.text: Each licensee shall pay a fraction of the yearly costs of the testing laboratory and of the tests done elsewhere.
The numerator of the fraction shall be the number of racing days with pari-mutuel betting privileges that the licensee holds during the year.
The denominator of the fraction shall be the whole number of racing days with pari-mutuel betting privileges held in the State during the year.

subsection.text: On or before September 15 of each year, the Commission shall submit a report to the Secretary and the Legislative Policy Committee about the preceding calendar year.
Each report shall include:

paragraph.text: a statement of receipts and disbursements of the Commission;

a summary of major events that occurred the preceding year that affected horse racing in the State, including any significant changes at tracks in the region as well as a discussion of legislative initiatives in the State;
a 5-year assessment of each track regarding:

subparagraph.text: attendance;
purse distributions;
live racing days that are allocated and used;
betting on live racing that is held at that track broken down by the following categories:

sub-subparagraph.text: betting conducted at the live track;
betting conducted at other Maryland tracks;
betting conducted at satellite simulcast facilities in the State; and
betting conducted through out-of-state satellite simulcasting;

subparagraph.text: betting that is conducted at the live track on races simulcast from other tracks in the State; and
betting that is conducted at the live track on races simulcast from out-of-state tracks;

paragraph.text: information on all simulcast betting at satellite simulcast facilities in the State, including information on how much is wagered on in-State races and how much is bet on out-of-state races;
information on all simulcast betting that is conducted out-of-state on races being run live in this State;
to the extent available, information on the breeding industry in the State, including:

subparagraph.text: the number of breeders in the State;
the number of foals registered in the State;
the average sales prices of foals; and
any other information pertaining to the regional and national ranking of the State for breeding;

paragraph.text: all other information that is currently provided by the Commission in its annual report;
additional information on satellite simulcast facilities, as required under § 11-831 of this title; and
any other information that is useful in explaining the financial viability of horse racing in the State and any recommendations to improve the industry.

section.text: The Commission exercises its powers and performs its duties subject to the authority of the Secretary.
In this subtitle, “beneficial ownership” includes:

paragraph.text: record ownership;

stock or other ownership in an entity in a chain of parent and subsidiary or affiliated entities, any 1 of which participates in the capital or profits of a licensee, regardless of the percentage of ownership involved;
an interest that entitles a person to benefits substantially equivalent to ownership by an agreement, relationship, or other arrangement even though the person is not an owner of record; and
unless there are special circumstances, ownership of a security by a relative of an individual who lives in the home of the individual.

section.text: A person must have an appropriate license whenever the person holds a race meeting in the State where pari-mutuel betting is allowed or a purse, reward, or stake is offered.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall submit to the executive director of the Commission an application:

paragraph.text: in the form that the Commission requires; and
on or before a day that the Commission sets.

subsection.text: The application shall state:

paragraph.text: the dates of the race meetings desired;
the maximum number of racing days desired; and
any other information that the Commission requires.

subsection.text: The Commission shall issue a license to each applicant who:

paragraph.text: is awarded racing days in a race meeting; and
pays the appropriate license fee.

subsection.text: A license shall state:

paragraph.text: the dates of the race meeting awarded;
the total number of racing days awarded; and
the kind of racing to be held.

section.text: A licensee is subject to all rights, regulations, and conditions that the Commission sets for the calendar year in which a race meeting of the licensee is held.
An award of a racing day to a licensee gives the licensee a license for the racing day, but it does not give the licensee an ownership right in the racing day.

paragraph.text: On request of a licensee, the Commission may return to the licensee a fee paid for racing on a day when the licensee fails to hold racing if:

subparagraph.text: on that day, racing is impossible, impracticable, or inadvisable;
the licensee is not in default; and
the reason for the lack of racing is beyond the control of the licensee.

paragraph.text: The decision of the Commission is final.

subsection.text: If a licensee does not hold racing on the full number of its authorized racing days because of bad weather conditions, the Commission may award to the licensee replacement races or racing days.
Subject to the hearing provisions of §§ 11-309 and 11-310 of this subtitle, the Commission may deny a license to an applicant or discipline a licensee in accordance with this section.
The Commission may deny a license to any applicant for any reason that the Commission considers sufficient.

paragraph.text: The Commission may reprimand any licensee or suspend or revoke a license if the licensee violates:

subparagraph.text: this title;
a regulation adopted under this title; or
a condition set by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee fails to:

subparagraph.text: keep records and make reports of ownership of stock that are required under § 11-314 of this subtitle; or
make a reasonable effort to get affidavits required under § 11-314(b) and (c) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Commission may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each racing day that the licensee is in violation of subsection (c) of this section:

subparagraph.text: instead of suspending or revoking a license under subsection (c)(1) of this section; and
in addition to suspending or revoking a license under subsection (c)(2) of this section.

paragraph.text: To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation; and
the good faith or lack of good faith of the licensee.

paragraph.text: A penalty imposed on a licensee shall be paid from the licensee’s share of the takeout.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Commission takes any final action under § 11-308 of this subtitle, it shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Commission or, as provided under § 11-310 of this subtitle, a hearing committee.
The Commission shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Commission may hear and determine the matter.
The Commission may delegate to a hearing committee of at least 3 of its members the power to hold adjudicatory proceedings under this title, including evidentiary hearings.

paragraph.text: A unanimous decision by the hearing committee is binding and is a final decision of the Commission.
If the decision of the hearing committee is not unanimous, a de novo hearing shall be conducted by the Commission.

section.text: A party to a proceeding before the Commission who is aggrieved by a final decision of the Commission in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: On request of the Commission, the following individuals shall give the Commission their fingerprints:

paragraph.text: each individual licensee;
each individual member of an unincorporated association that is a licensee;
each officer or director of a corporation that is a licensee;
each employee of a licensee who actively participates in the racing action of the licensee;

each individual who actively participates in the racing action of a licensee, including each agent, blacksmith, driver, apprentice jockey, jockey, manager, owner, trainer, stable employee, and veterinarian;
each member of the Commission;
the Executive Director of the Commission;
each employee of the Commission under §§ 11-206 and 11-207 of this title; and
each individual who is subject to § 11-316 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: apply to the Central Repository for a State and national criminal history records check for each individual listed in subsection (a) of this section; and
as part of the application for a criminal history records check, submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: a complete set of the individual’s legible fingerprints taken on a form approved by the Director of the Central Repository; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records.

paragraph.text: In addition to a State criminal history records check under this section, the Commission may require an individual listed in subsection (a) of this section to obtain a criminal history records check from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, through the Central Repository.

For each applicant who is required by the Commission to obtain a criminal history records check from the Federal Bureau of Investigation under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall apply to the Central Repository for a national criminal history records check.
As part of the application for a national criminal history records check, the Commission shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: a complete set of the individual’s legible fingerprints taken on a form approved by the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: In accordance with §§ 10-201 through 10-234 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall forward to the individual and the Commission the individual’s criminal history record information.
Information obtained from the Central Repository under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: confidential and may not be disseminated; and
used only for the purpose authorized by this section.

paragraph.text: The subject of a criminal history records check under this section may contest the contents of the printed statement issued by the Central Repository as provided in § 10-223 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

subsection.text: The Commission shall require a licensee, and each officer or stockholder of a licensee, to disclose to the Commission each financial interest that the person has in racing.
On or before the 90th day following the end of a licensee’s fiscal year, the licensee shall submit to the Commission in the form that the Commission requires:

paragraph.text: an itemized statement under oath for the preceding fiscal year of receipts from all sources and of all expenses and disbursements, including salaries of officers, attorney fees, and lobbying expenses; and
a certified audit by a certified public accountant of the financial records of the licensee for the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: The audited statements of all licensees shall be sent to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.
The Office of Legislative Audits shall audit each licensee at least once every 2 years in accordance with the provisions of §§ 2-1217 through 2-1227 of the State Government Article.

The Commission shall require each licensee to keep records that show the beneficial ownership of the stock of the licensee, whether or not the beneficial ownership is registered or stated on the stock.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall require a licensee at least once each calendar year to get by written request an affidavit from each owner of record of the licensee.
The affidavit shall state, to the best of the affiant’s knowledge, information, and belief:

subparagraph.text: whether a person other than the affiant has a right of beneficial ownership in the stock held in the name of the affiant;
the name and address of any other person who has a right of beneficial ownership; and
the amount and nature of the beneficial ownership.

paragraph.text: If a licensee learns that a person, other than a record owner of stock in a licensee, has a beneficial ownership interest in stock of the licensee, the licensee promptly shall request in writing that the person submit an affidavit within 60 days to the licensee.
The affidavit shall state to the best of the affiant’s knowledge, information, and belief:

subparagraph.text: whether the affiant has a right of beneficial ownership in the stock of the licensee that is described in the notice;
the amount and nature of the beneficial ownership;
whether a person other than the affiant and the record owner has a right of ownership of any kind in that stock of the licensee; and
the amount and nature of the ownership of that stock by a person other than the affiant and the record owner.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the affidavit requirements of this section, the Commission may excuse the reporting of beneficial ownership that is less than 2% of the licensee.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall submit the beneficial ownership records and affidavits required under this section to the Commission at least once each year and at any other time that the Commission requires.
A licensee shall report promptly to the Commission each change in beneficial ownership.

section.text: A statement required to be submitted to the Commission under § 11-313 or § 11-314 of this subtitle shall be under oath and signed by each officer of the corporate licensee or by the owner or each partner of an unincorporated licensee.

subsection.text: Before a prospective buyer buys a majority controlling interest in a licensee, the Commission shall review the personal and financial background of the prospective buyer.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.
The regulations shall:

subparagraph.text: require a personal and financial background check of the prospective buyer;
specify a period of time to review the required personal and financial information before a purchase or transfer of racing days is made; and

require that notice and an invitation to comment be given to the Legislative Policy Committee at least 15 days before final approval of a purchase or transfer of racing days resulting from a purchase.

paragraph.text: The background check shall include:

subparagraph.text: a review by a certified public accountant of certified financial statements, including contingent or pledged liabilities, sufficient to determine the ability of the prospective buyer to buy and maintain the licensee;
an income statement for the most recent year;
a statement of financial and related records of any person in which the prospective buyer has at least a majority interest;
a disclosure of each financial interest in racing;
a disclosure of each person who will have beneficial ownership of the licensee as a result of the purchase;
a criminal history records check under § 11-312 of this subtitle; and
a character review.

section.text: Before a license or racing days may be transferred to a buyer or a lessee of a track:

paragraph.text: the Legislative Policy Committee shall have been notified at least 15 days before the transfer;
the Legislative Policy Committee, if it has chosen to do so, shall have provided comment to the Commission about the transfer; and
the transfer shall have been approved by the Commission.

section.text: The Commission may require a licensee to get its approval before the licensee:

paragraph.text: contracts to pay money;
sets a salary, fee, or compensation to be paid; or
builds, extends, or improves a track or structure on property that the licensee owns or leases.

subsection.text: The Maryland Backstretch Employees Pension Fund shall be administered by the organization that represents a majority of the owners and trainers who race thoroughbred horses in the State.
The Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund shall be administered by representatives of:

paragraph.text: each mile thoroughbred racing licensee;
the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc.; and
the employees of the licensees and of the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc.

subsection.text: The Maryland Harness Track Employees Pension Fund shall be administered by representatives of each harness racing licensee and its employees.
This section does not apply to employees of trainers, owners, or concessionaires, or of other employers who are not licensees.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, at least 85% of the individuals employed each day by a licensee shall be citizens of the United States who have maintained a permanent place of residence in the State for at least the 2 years immediately before being employed.
Before the start of employment, each individual shall submit to the licensee who will employ the individual an affidavit that sets forth the qualifications required under this section.
The licensee may rely on the affidavit.

subsection.text: Clockers, heads of departments, and governing and managing officials of a track may be nonresidents of the State and are excluded from the residency computation under subsection (b) of this section.

section.text: There is a Special Fund.
The Special Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: the State share of daily licensee fees;
pari-mutuel taxes;
the impact aid under § 11-812 of this title;
money from uncashed pari-mutuel tickets that are from bets made into the betting pools of licensees; and
any permit fees under §§ 11-820 and 11-832 of this title.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall pay from the Special Fund an annual grant of:

paragraph.text: $825,000 to the Maryland Agricultural Fair Board to promote State and county agricultural fairs and exhibits;
$100,000 to Prince George’s County to replace money formerly received from the admissions and amusement tax;
$40,000 to the Great Frederick Fair to support exhibition harness racing with money for construction and maintenance of new stalls, track maintenance, and purses;
$50 to the City of Bowie for each day that the training facilities are open at the Bowie Race Course Training Center;
$75,000 to the Maryland Agricultural Education Foundation, Inc., to promote and enhance statewide agricultural education;

an amount not to exceed $30,000 in fiscal year 1998 and $20,000 in each fiscal year thereafter to the Great Pocomoke Fair, Inc. to support exhibition harness racing with money for construction and maintenance of new stalls, track maintenance, and purses;
$500,000 to the Maryland Million, Ltd. to support and promote the running of Maryland Million races; and
$350,000 to the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund for the Sire Stakes Program.

subsection.text: If the Maryland State Fair remains at the Timonium Fair Grounds, the Comptroller shall pay from the Special Fund an annual grant of:

paragraph.text: $500,000 to the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc., to:

subparagraph.text: promote and enhance the Maryland State Fair; and
maintain and develop youth programs, with premium money provided to organizations, such as 4-H Clubs and the Future Farmers of America, for recognition and awards; and

paragraph.text: $50,000 to Baltimore County to replace the money formerly received by the county under this subtitle.

To help pay for facilities and services in communities within 2 miles of the Pimlico Race Course or 3 miles of the Laurel Race Course, the Comptroller shall pay money to Baltimore City, the City of Laurel, and Anne Arundel and Howard counties in accordance with this section.
The money shall be paid from the Special Fund in half-yearly installments.

subsection.text: In any year, payments required under this section may not be less than the total allocated for 140 days of live racing at each track.

paragraph.text: If 140 or more days of live racing in a year are held at Pimlico Race Course, the Comptroller shall pay to Baltimore City:

subparagraph.text: $2,800 for each day of live racing; and
$1,400 for each additional day of intertrack betting without live racing held.

paragraph.text: If fewer than 140 days of live racing in a year are held at Pimlico Race Course, the Comptroller shall pay to Baltimore City:

subparagraph.text: $2,800 for each day of live racing or intertrack betting without live racing held, up to a maximum payment for 140 days; and
$1,400 for each additional day of intertrack betting without live racing held.

paragraph.text: If 140 or more days of live racing in a year are held at Laurel Race Course, the Comptroller shall pay:

subparagraph.text: for each day of live racing, $2,000 to Anne Arundel County, $500 to Howard County, and $300 to the City of Laurel; and
for each additional day of intertrack betting without live racing held, $1,000 to Anne Arundel County, $250 to Howard County, and $150 to the City of Laurel.

paragraph.text: If fewer than 140 days of live racing in a year are held at Laurel Race Course, the Comptroller shall pay:

subparagraph.text: for each day of live racing or each day of intertrack betting without live racing held, up to a maximum payment for 140 days, $2,000 to Anne Arundel County, $500 to Howard County, and $300 to the City of Laurel; and
for each additional day of intertrack betting without live racing held, $1,000 to Anne Arundel County, $250 to Howard County, and $150 to the City of Laurel.

section.text: After all deductions from the Special Fund as required under §§ 11-403 and 11-404 of this subtitle are made, the Comptroller shall pay from the Special Fund an annual grant of:

paragraph.text: $300,000 to be allocated in the following way:

subparagraph.text: 70% to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund; and
30% to the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund, to be divided equally between the Sire Stakes Program and the Foaled Stakes Program; and

paragraph.text: $260,000 to the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Fund established under § 2-206 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, with $130,000 to be allocated to support the operations of the Rural Maryland Council.

subsection.text: The fiscal officer of each subdivision that is eligible to receive money under § 11-404 of this subtitle shall submit a written certification to the Comptroller and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Department of Legislative Services on or before November 1 of each year.
The fiscal officer’s certification shall state:

paragraph.text: the purposes for which Special Fund money received under § 11-404 of this subtitle was spent or committed during the fiscal year that ends on the June 30 before the report is submitted; and

that the subdivision will hold Special Fund money in a special account and use the money only to help services and facilities within 2 miles of the Pimlico Race Course or 3 miles of the Laurel Race Course.
The Comptroller may not pay Special Fund money to a subdivision unless the fiscal officer of the subdivision submits a timely certification required under subsection (a) of this section.

The Comptroller shall place Special Fund money withheld under paragraph (1) of this subsection in a special account and add it to the money available for payment to the subdivision in the next fiscal year.

section.text: After all deductions from the Special Fund as required by §§ 11-403, 11-404, and 11-404.1 of this subtitle are made, money that remains in the Special Fund shall be allocated in the following way:

paragraph.text: 50% to the Maryland Agricultural Education and Rural Development Assistance Fund established under § 2-206 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, with one-third of these funds to be allocated to support the operations of the Rural Maryland Council; and
50% to be allocated in the following way:

subparagraph.text: 70% to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund; and
30% to the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund, to be divided equally between the Sire Stakes Program and the Foaled Stakes Program.

section.text: This part applies only to mile thoroughbred racing licensees and to special thoroughbred racing licensees.
Three stewards shall officiate at each race that a licensee holds.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a licensee shall give preference in stall allocation to a trainer:

subparagraph.text: who has a permanent residence in the State; and
whose horse qualifies under the eligibility rules that the Commission or a licensee adopts.

paragraph.text: A licensee need not allocate more than 60% of the licensee’s stalls to trainers who have permanent residences in the State.
A trainer who claims a preferential action under this subsection shall give the licensee an affidavit stating the qualifications and condition of each horse for which the trainer requests a stall.
This subsection applies to trainers who:

subparagraph.text: are from the northeastern area of the State; and
were chosen originally by the licensee as eligible for stall space.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall seek cooperation among licensees to ensure that, when horses are stabled for a race meeting at a track in the State, consideration is given to assigning a trainer, to the extent practicable and without charge, a stall nearest to the county of residence of the trainer.

section.text: A licensee may not hold live racing at Pimlico Race Course after 10:00 p.m. unless circumstances beyond the control of the licensee cause a delay.
This part applies only to mile thoroughbred racing licenses and to licensees who have been awarded racing days to hold mile thoroughbred racing.

subsection.text: If an applicant qualifies for a license under this title, the Commission shall send the applicant a notice stating:

paragraph.text: the fact that the applicant has qualified for a license;
the dates of the race meeting awarded;
the total number of racing days awarded; and
the kind of racing to be held.

subsection.text: Before the Commission may issue a license to an applicant, the applicant shall pay to the Commission a license fee of $25 for each racing day of a race meeting.
A licensee shall pay each year $3,000 to the Maryland Horse Breeders Association, Inc.
A licensee shall pay to the Commission within 10 days after each racing day the State tax imposed in this subtitle on the handle for that racing day.
A licensee or an agent of the licensee shall submit with the daily tax payment a statement under oath of the handle for that day.
The Commission shall pay promptly to the Comptroller all taxes collected under this section.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Commission may not issue a license, or award racing days, for racing at a mile track.
The Commission may issue a license and award racing days only to:

paragraph.text: the Maryland Jockey Club of Baltimore City, Inc.; and
the Laurel Racing Assoc., Inc.
On or before December 1, the Commission shall award all racing days for the next calendar year.
However, the Commission may meet after December 1 to award racing days that are requested in applications.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission may award for any calendar year up to the number of racing days requested by an applicant.

The Commission shall award at least 40 live racing days to be run at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore City in each calendar year unless otherwise agreed to by the racing licensee and the organization that represents the majority of licensed thoroughbred owners and trainers in the State or unless the racing licensee is prevented by weather, acts of God, or other circumstances beyond the racing licensee’s control.

subsection.text: The decision of the Commission on the award of a racing day is final.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 11-513 of this subtitle, the Commission may authorize a licensee to transfer a race meeting from the licensee’s own track to another track:

paragraph.text: on receipt of the appropriate license fees; and
with the express consent of the owner or lessee of the track to which the transfer is made.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Commission shall hold a public hearing before the Commission awards, for racing at a particular track, racing days that:

paragraph.text: total at least 3 more than those awarded for racing at that track in the previous calendar year; or
result from the transfer of racing days to that track from another track in the same year.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: hold the hearing not more than 10 miles from the track where the racing is to be held; and
allow any person to testify.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: at least 15 days before the hearing, shall have notice of the hearing published in at least 1 newspaper with a substantial circulation in the county where the track is located; and
shall try to give notice of the hearing to any public unit or private organization that has made a written request for notice.

If the transfer of racing days from one track to another becomes necessary due to fire, flood, mechanical failure, or any other similar circumstance deemed by the Commission to constitute an emergency:

subparagraph.text: the racing days may be transferred immediately; and
as soon as practicable, the Commission shall provide notice of a hearing and conduct a hearing pursuant to subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: As soon as the track and the facilities of the licensee from which race days were transferred under paragraph (1) of this section are in a condition to continue racing and pari-mutuel betting, any remaining days of the meet that was being conducted when the days were transferred shall be held at the track from which the days were transferred.

subsection.text: A licensee shall deduct from the handle:

paragraph.text: all the breakage;
not more than 18% from each regular mutuel pool;
not more than 21% from each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
not more than 25.75% from each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: Money that remains after deductions are made under subsection (a) of this section shall be returned as winnings to successful bettors.

paragraph.text: The amount deducted by the licensee under subsection (a) of this section shall be the sum of the allocations provided in § 11-515 of this subtitle, unless otherwise provided in a written agreement signed by the authorized representatives of:

subparagraph.text: the licensee;
the group that represents a majority of the owners and trainers licensed in the State at the time the agreement is signed; and
the group that represents a majority of the breeders in the State at the time the agreement is signed.

paragraph.text: Nothing in this subsection may be construed to permit the licensee to in any way alter the mandatory takeout allocated to the Commission for the State tax.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 11-516 of this subtitle, the takeout that a licensee deducts from the handle of a race shall be allocated in accordance with this section.
A licensee shall:

paragraph.text: keep 50% of the breakage;
allocate 45% of the breakage for purses; and
allocate 5% of the breakage to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund.

subsection.text: From the amount that a licensee deducts from each regular mutuel pool, the licensee shall:

paragraph.text: keep 7.70% of each regular mutuel pool, from which the licensee shall pay 0.25% of each regular mutuel pool to the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund;
allocate 0.32% of each regular mutuel pool to the Commission for State tax;
allocate 1.10% of each regular mutuel pool to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund;
allocate 7.70% of each regular mutuel pool for purses;
allocate 0.18% of each regular mutuel pool as an additional amount for purses; and
allocate 1% of each regular mutuel pool paid to the Maryland Million, Ltd., for purses of Maryland Million races.

subsection.text: From the amount that a licensee deducts from each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses, the licensee shall:

paragraph.text: keep 8.70% of each multiple mutuel pool, from which the licensee shall pay 0.25% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund;
allocate 0.32% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Commission for State tax;
allocate 1.10% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund;
allocate 8.70% of each multiple mutuel pool for purses;
allocate 0.18% of each multiple mutuel pool as an additional amount for purses; and
allocate 2% of each multiple mutuel pool paid to the Maryland Million, Ltd., for purses of Maryland Million races.

subsection.text: From the amount that a licensee deducts from each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses, the licensee shall:

paragraph.text: keep 11.70% of each multiple mutuel pool, from which the licensee shall pay 0.25% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund;
allocate 0.32% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Commission for State tax;
allocate 1.10% of each multiple mutuel pool to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund;
allocate 11.70% of each multiple mutuel pool for purses;
allocate 0.18% of each multiple mutuel pool as an additional amount for purses; and
allocate 0.75% of each multiple mutuel pool paid to the Maryland Million, Ltd., for purses of Maryland Million races.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 11-515 of this subtitle, the amount of the takeout relating to purses, the Maryland-Bred Race Fund, and the amount retained by the licensee may be allocated in accordance with the terms of a written agreement signed by the authorized representatives of:

paragraph.text: the licensee;
the group that represents a majority of the owners and trainers licensed in the State at the time the agreement is signed; and
the group that represents a majority of the breeders in the State at the time the agreement is signed.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section may be construed to permit the licensee to in any way alter the mandatory takeout allocated to the Commission for the State tax.

section.text: If the Preakness Stakes is transferred otherwise than under § 11-520(b) of this subtitle or if it is sold to a buyer other than the State, the takeout of the mutuel pools on each race held thereafter shall be allocated as follows:

paragraph.text: to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund, 1% of each mutuel pool;
to the Commission, for State tax, 4.09% of each mutuel pool;
to purses, 5% of each regular mutuel pool, 8% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses, and 14% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses; and
to the licensee, 6.91% of each regular mutuel pool and 5.91% of each multiple mutuel pool, from which the licensee shall pay 0.25% of all pools to the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund.

subsection.text: In this section, “open purse” means any purse, except for one offered in a race funded by the Maryland-Bred Race Fund.
The Commission may direct a deduction from open purse money of 0.25% of all mutuel pools to be paid to the Maryland Backstretch Employees Pension Fund.

Subject to the approval of the Commission, the licensees and an organization that represents a majority of the owners and trainers in the State shall agree on a formula for distributing open purse money.

The formula shall distribute approximately 85% of the open purse money to the overnight races of the current year and approximately 15%, but not more than 17%, to the stakes races of the current year.

The organization that represents a majority of the owners and trainers in the State shall set an amount not less than 1% but not more than 2% that shall be deducted from all open purses and paid to the organization.
The owner of the Bowie Race Course Training Center shall operate the Center as a thoroughbred training facility to provide more stall space for a race meeting that a licensee holds.
The owner of the Bowie Race Course Training Center is responsible for the cost to improve, maintain, and operate the Center.
As long as the Bowie Race Course Training Center is used for the purpose specified in subsection (a) of this section, the Commission shall have general regulatory jurisdiction over the Center to:

paragraph.text: provide enough stalls;
maintain safe operating conditions;
require the owner of the Center to submit an annual operating financial statement; and
order reasonable improvements.

subsection.text: The requirements of this section are established in recognition of the significance of the Preakness Stakes to the State.
The Preakness Stakes may be transferred to another track in the State only as a result of a disaster or emergency.
If the Preakness Stakes is transferred out of the State, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: revoke any racing days awarded to the Maryland Jockey Club of Baltimore City, Inc., or its successor; and
award these racing days to another licensee, notwithstanding § 11-511(b) of this subtitle.
If the Preakness Stakes is offered for sale, the State has the option to buy the Preakness Stakes for the amount of any offer that the licensee wishes to accept.
Within 30 days after receiving an offer that it wishes to accept, the licensee shall give the State notice of the offer.
