If the State wishes to exercise the option, it shall so notify the licensee within 60 days after it receives the notice.

subsection.text: In addition to the other provisions of this subtitle, in accordance with the sovereign power of the State and the provisions of Article III, §§ 40 and 40A of the Maryland Constitution, and subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the State may acquire by purchase or condemnation for public use with just compensation some or all of the following real, tangible, and intangible private property, including any contractual interests or intellectual property:

paragraph.text: Pimlico Race Course, a racetrack located in Baltimore City, including any and all property or property rights associated with it wherever located, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed, and any business entity that owns it;

Laurel Park, a racetrack located in Anne Arundel County, including any and all property or property rights associated with it wherever located, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed, and any business entity that owns it;

Bowie Race Course Training Center, a training center located in Prince George’s County, including any and all property or property rights associated with it wherever located, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed, and any business entity that owns it;

the Preakness Stakes trophy that is known as the Woodlawn Vase, including any and all property or property rights associated with it, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed, and any business entity that owns it;

the name, common law and statutory copyrights, service marks, trademarks, trade names, contracts, horse racing events, and other intangible and intellectual property that are associated with the Preakness Stakes and the Woodlawn Vase;

all property of the Maryland Jockey Club of Baltimore City, Inc., or its successors and assigns, including stock and equity interests in it, and including any and all property or property rights associated with it, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed; and

all property of the Laurel Racing Assoc., Inc., the Laurel Racing Association Limited Partnership, or their respective successors and assigns, including stock and equity interests, and including any and all property or property rights associated with them, whether tangible, intangible, real, personal, or mixed.

subsection.text: All proceedings for the condemnation for public use of the private property described under subsection (a) of this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of Title 12 of the Real Property Article and Title 12, Chapter 200 of the Maryland Rules.

Pursuant to the provisions of Article III, § 40A of the Maryland Constitution, as applicable, the private property described under subsection (a) of this section may be taken immediately on payment for the property consistent with the procedures of §§ 8–334 through 8–339 of the Transportation Article.
In this section, “Arabian breed horse” means a horse that:

paragraph.text: is a purebred Arabian breed horse; and
has a valid certificate of registry with the Arabian Jockey Club of America.

subsection.text: A licensee at Pimlico Race Course may conduct live racing of Arabian breed horses if:

paragraph.text: no more than one Arabian breed race is conducted per day;
no more than three Arabian breed races are conducted during a race meet;
an Arabian breed race is conducted in addition to, and not in place of, an existing thoroughbred race;
an Arabian breed race does not reduce the number of thoroughbred races conducted by the licensee per racing day;
the purse for an Arabian breed race is:

subparagraph.text: not funded by the thoroughbred purse account; and
funded by the licensee or the sponsor of the Arabian horse race;

paragraph.text: the takeout provisions of §§ 11–514 and 11–515 of this subtitle are applied to the race;
the licensee pays all taxes and fees associated with the Arabian breed race that would otherwise be due on a thoroughbred race; and
the Arabian breed race is approved by the State Racing Commission.

section.text: In this part, “State Fair Society” means the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall issue a special thoroughbred racing license to the State Fair Society to hold a race meeting.
The race meeting shall:

subparagraph.text: last not more than 10 days in a calendar year;
be held with or for the benefit of the State Fair or a county fair or agricultural exhibition; and
comply with this title.

subsection.text: The State Fair Society shall pay to the county treasurer of the county where the fair or exhibition is held, for the use of the county, a fee of $50 for each racing day of the race meeting.
The Commission may authorize the State Fair Society to transfer a race meeting from the State Fair Society’s own track to the track of a mile thoroughbred racing licensee:

paragraph.text: on receipt of the appropriate license fees; and
with the express consent of the owner or lessee of the track to which the transfer is made.

subsection.text: If the State Fair Society ends special thoroughbred racing at the Timonium Race Course, the racing days that were awarded to it may be awarded to a mile thoroughbred licensee on the same terms as the additional racing days under § 11-511 of this subtitle.
If racing is discontinued at the Timonium Race Course:

paragraph.text: compensation may not be paid to the State Fair Society to offset revenue loss from the discontinuance of racing; and
payment of the grant to Baltimore County under § 11-403 of this title shall end.

subsection.text: On all races the State Fair Society holds each year, the State Fair Society may keep:

paragraph.text: 10.25% of each regular mutuel pool;
10.25% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses;
10.25% of the money bet in the first race of the day with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses;
14% of the money bet in every other race with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses; and
50% of the breakage.

Within 5 days after the end of a race meeting the State Fair Society each year shall pay to the Commission, from the State Fair Society’s share of the takeout, a 3.5% State tax on the handle for the race meeting.
However, the State Fair Society is exempt from paying the tax on the handle for all racing days held at Timonium Race Course during the State Fair.
The Commission promptly shall pay the tax collected under this subsection to the Comptroller.

subsection.text: For each race that the State Fair Society holds, the State Fair Society shall allocate to purses:

paragraph.text: 5% of each regular mutuel pool;
7% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses;
13% of the money bet in the first race of the day with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses;
9.25% of the money bet in every other race with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses; and
45% of the breakage.

subsection.text: The State Fair Society shall allocate to the Maryland-Bred Race Fund:

paragraph.text: 5% of the breakage; and
1.50% of the mutuel pools.

subsection.text: The State Fair Society shall allocate 0.25% of the mutuel pools to the Maryland Race Track Employees Pension Fund.
In this section, “Park and Planning Commission” means the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission.
The State Racing Commission shall issue a special thoroughbred racing license to the Park and Planning Commission to hold racing in 4 one-day race meetings at the Prince George’s Equestrian Center.
The racing days shall be held:

paragraph.text: on dates that the Park and Planning Commission chooses and the State Racing Commission approves;
on dates when a mile thoroughbred racing licensee does not hold a race; and
in connection with or for the benefit of a county fair or equestrian exhibition or activity.
The Park and Planning Commission shall deduct from the handle:

subparagraph.text: 17% of all money bet in each regular mutuel pool;
19% of all money bet in each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
25% of all money bet in each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

paragraph.text: The Park and Planning Commission shall pay to the Maryland Equestrian Foundation, Inc., a not for profit organization:

subparagraph.text: from the amount deducted under paragraph (1) of this subsection, 8% of the total amount bet in all of the mutuel pools; and
any profit from admission fees or other receipts, less expenses from the operation of racing days.

paragraph.text: On races that the Park and Planning Commission holds each year, the Park and Planning Commission shall allocate for purses:

subparagraph.text: 5% of each regular mutuel pool;
7% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses;
13% of the money bet in the first race of the day with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses; and
9.25% of the money bet in every other race with a multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: Repealed.
An officer of the Park and Planning Commission may not receive a salary or dividends from racing authorized under this section.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advisory Committee” means the Maryland-Bred Race Fund Advisory Committee.
“Fund” means the Maryland-Bred Race Fund.
“Fund Race” means a race funded by the Maryland-Bred Race Fund.

section.text: There is a Maryland-Bred Race Fund.
There is a Maryland-Bred Race Fund Advisory Committee, under the jurisdiction of the Commission, in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Advisory Committee consists of 5 members appointed by the Commission with the approval of the Secretary.
Of the 5 members of the Advisory Committee:

subparagraph.text: 2 shall be members of and recommended by the Maryland Horse Breeders Association;
1 shall be recommended by the mile thoroughbred racing licensees;
1 shall be recommended by the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc.; and
1 shall be a member of and appointed by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the Advisory Committee is 1 year and begins on June 1.

If the Maryland Horse Breeders Association, the mile thoroughbred racing licensees, or the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc., by June 1 fails to recommend an individual to be a member of the Advisory Committee, the Commission with the approval of the Secretary shall appoint the member.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member of the Advisory Committee for incompetence or misconduct.
The member of the Commission who is on the Advisory Committee is the chairman of the Advisory Committee.
The term of the chairman of the Advisory Committee is 1 year.
The Advisory Committee shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Advisory Committee:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Fund and the Maryland-Bred Race Program with the help and advice of the Advisory Committee; and
order each payment that is to be made from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: deposit the money allocated to the Fund by each mile thoroughbred racing licensee and the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc., into at least 1 bank or trust company in the State; and
require the bank or trust company to secure the Fund by collateral.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after a race meeting ends, the licensee shall pay to the Commission, to be held in the Fund, all money that is allocated to the Fund under this title but that was not disbursed during the race meeting.
On recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the Commission may allocate a portion of the Fund to races that are restricted to horses conceived, but not necessarily foaled, in Maryland.

If the Commission uses ordinary care to choose the depository bank or trust company, the members are not personally liable for loss to the Fund because of failure, insolvency, or other fault of the depository bank or trust company.
Each mile thoroughbred racing licensee and the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc., shall provide for the running of races known as the Maryland-Bred Fund Races.
The Commission may approve the running of a Maryland-Bred Fund Race at a thoroughbred track outside the State.

section.text: A horse shall be registered with the Maryland Horse Breeders Association, Inc., before the horse may start in a Fund Race.
A horse may be registered with the Maryland Horse Breeders Association, Inc., only if the horse was foaled in Maryland as shown by a foal certificate from the Jockey Club and:

paragraph.text: the breeder of the horse has maintained a place of abode in Maryland for more than 9 months immediately before registration;
the breeder of the horse keeps breeding stock continually in Maryland;
the horse was conceived in Maryland during the previous season; or
the horse’s dam was sent to Maryland to foal and after foaling was covered by a Maryland stallion during the season of the horse’s birth.

subsection.text: On recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the Commission shall set:

paragraph.text: the number of Fund Races;
the amount of each purse;
the date of each Fund Race;
the location of each Fund Race held outside the State;
the distance of each Fund Race;
each breeder’s award, including awards for races in the State and outside the State; and
any other condition needed to carry out the purpose of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Commission shall set the amount of each purse and the conditions for each Fund Race in time to allow a licensee who provides for a Fund Race to include the purse and conditions in the stake book and condition book of the licensee.
A licensee who provides for a Fund Race:

paragraph.text: need not contribute an amount greater than the allocation to the Fund set under § 11-515 or § 11-525 of this subtitle; but
may add to any purse in a Fund Race.

subsection.text: A purse, authorized under this part and paid in a Fund Race, is specifically excluded from breeders’ bonuses, purses, or stakes that are paid or offered by licensees in races other than Fund Races as determined by agreement or formula between a licensee and an organization that represents a majority of the owners and trainers.
If there are fewer than 5 separate qualified entries in a Fund Race, the Commission shall cancel the Fund Race.
If the Commission cancels a Fund Race, the Commission shall give notice to the licensee in time to allow the licensee to schedule a substitute race.

section.text: In this subtitle, “average handle” means the daily average amount bet in a year.
This subtitle applies only to harness racing licenses and to licensees who have been awarded racing days to hold harness racing.
A licensee may hold harness racing only with standardbred horses.
Three harness judges shall officiate at each race that a licensee holds.
If the Commission approves, harness racing may be held on a Sunday.
A licensee may not hold live harness racing after 2 a.m. unless circumstances beyond the control of the licensee cause a delay.

subsection.text: Subject to § 11-610 of this subtitle, if an applicant qualifies for a license under this title, the Commission shall send the applicant a notice stating:

paragraph.text: the fact that the applicant has qualified for a license;
the dates of the race meeting awarded;
the total number of racing days awarded; and
the kind of racing to be held.

subsection.text: Before the Commission may issue a license to a person, the person shall pay to the Commission a license fee of $25 for each racing day of the race meeting.

section.text: The Commission may not issue:

paragraph.text: licenses to more than 3 racing associations;
a license for use in Carroll, Dorchester, Frederick, Montgomery, or Wicomico County; or
more than 1 license for use in any 1 county.

subsection.text: The Commission may award for any calendar year up to the number of racing days requested by an applicant.
The decision of the Commission on the award of a racing day is final.

section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 11-612 of this subtitle, the Commission may authorize a licensee to transfer a race meeting from the licensee’s own track to another track:

paragraph.text: on receipt of the appropriate license fees; and
with the express consent of the owner or lessee of the track to which the transfer is made.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Commission shall hold a public hearing before the Commission awards, for racing at a particular track, racing days that:

paragraph.text: total at least 3 more than those awarded for racing at that track in the previous calendar year; or
result from the transfer of racing days to that track from another track in the same year.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: hold the hearing not more than 10 miles from the track where the racing is to be held; and
allow any person to testify.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: at least 15 days before the hearing, shall have notice of the hearing published in at least 1 newspaper with a substantial circulation in the county where the track is located; and
shall try to give notice of the hearing to any public unit or private organization that has made a written request for notice.

If the transfer of racing days from one track to another becomes necessary due to fire, flood, mechanical failure, or any other similar circumstance deemed by the Commission to constitute an emergency:

subparagraph.text: the racing days may be transferred immediately; and
as soon as practicable, the Commission shall provide notice of a hearing and conduct a hearing pursuant to subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: As soon as the track and the facilities of the licensee from which race days were transferred under paragraph (1) of this subsection are in a condition to continue racing and pari–mutuel betting, any remaining days of the meet that was being conducted when the days were transferred shall be held at the track from which the days were transferred.
A licensee whose average handle is $150,000 or less shall keep the breakage.
A licensee whose average handle is over $150,000 shall:

subparagraph.text: allocate 50% of the breakage to the Sires Stakes Program; and

keep 50% of the breakage to pay for personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction.

subsection.text: If an average handle is over $600,000, the takeout shall be:

paragraph.text: 17% from each regular mutuel pool;
19% from each multiple mutuel pool for 2 horses; and
25% from each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: If the average handle is $600,000 or less, the takeout shall be:

paragraph.text: not more than 18.75% from each regular mutuel pool;
not more than 20.75% from each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
not more than 26.75% from each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: Money that remains after deductions are made under this section shall be returned as winnings to successful bettors.

section.text: A licensee whose average handle is over $600,000 shall:

paragraph.text: allocate 0.50% of each mutuel pool to the Commission as State tax;
allocate 0.25% of each mutuel pool to the Maryland Harness Track Employees Pension Fund;
keep 16.25% of each regular mutuel pool;
keep 18.25% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
keep 24.25% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: From a licensee’s share of the takeout on each mutuel pool, the licensee whose average handle is over $600,000 shall allocate equally to the Sires Stakes Program and the Foaled Stakes Program of the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund the following amounts:

paragraph.text: on the first $125,000 of the average handle:

subparagraph.text: 0.50% of each regular mutuel pool;
0.50% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
1% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

paragraph.text: on the rest of the average handle:

subparagraph.text: 1% of each regular mutuel pool;
1% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
1.5% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout, the licensee shall allocate 0.50% on the part of an average handle over $150,000 to pay for:

paragraph.text: purses;
personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction; and
maintenance of proper living conditions in the backstretch.

From the licensee’s share of the takeout, the licensee shall allocate 0.25% of each mutuel pool to improve the facilities and services of the track and to increase marketing activity, so as to promote:

subparagraph.text: increased attendance and pari-mutuel betting; and
enhanced well-being of the standardbred racing industry.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly, by statute, may direct that the Commission not award in the following calendar year part or all of the racing days authorized under § 11-610 of this subtitle to the licensee if the General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: the proposed use of the allocation under this subsection is inconsistent with the purposes specified in this section; or
the licensee has not spent the allocation in a way that is consistent with the proposal.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout on each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses, the licensee shall allocate at least 1% of the mutuel pool as follows:

paragraph.text: one-half to purses; and
one-half to personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout on each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses, a licensee shall allocate at least 6.5% of each mutuel pool as follows:

paragraph.text: one-half to purses; and
one-half to personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction.

section.text: A licensee whose average handle is $600,000 or less shall:

paragraph.text: allocate 0.32% of each mutuel pool to the Commission as State tax;
subject to § 11-618 of this subtitle, allocate 0.25% of each mutuel pool to the Maryland Harness Track Employees Pension Fund;

allocate for purses 0.18% of each mutuel pool, or an amount that is otherwise agreed to by the licensee and the organization representing a majority of the harness owners and trainers in the State, which shall provide revenue in addition to any other funds set aside for purses by private parties;
keep 18.00% of each regular mutuel pool;
keep 20.00% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
keep 26.00% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: From a licensee’s share of the takeout on each mutuel pool, the licensee whose average handle is $600,000 or less shall allocate 1.75% to increased purses.

From the licensee’s share of the takeout on each mutuel pool, a licensee whose average handle is over $150,000 shall allocate equally to the Sires Stakes Program and the Foaled Stakes Program of the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund the following amounts:

paragraph.text: on the first $125,000 of the average handle:

subparagraph.text: 0.50% of each regular mutuel pool;
0.50% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
1% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

paragraph.text: on the rest of the average handle:

subparagraph.text: 1% of each regular mutuel pool;
1% of each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses; and
1.5% of each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: A licensee whose average handle is $150,000 or less shall allocate equally to the Sires Stakes Program and the Foaled Stakes Program of the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund:

paragraph.text: 0.50% of each regular mutuel pool;
0.50% of each multiple mutuel pool for 2 horses; and
1% of each multiple mutuel pool for 3 or more horses.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout, the licensee shall allocate 0.50% on the part of an average handle over $150,000 to pay for:

paragraph.text: purses;
personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction; and
maintenance of proper living conditions in the backstretch.

From the licensee’s share of the takeout, the licensee shall allocate 0.25% of each mutuel pool to improve the facilities and services of the track and to increase marketing activity, so as to promote:

subparagraph.text: increased attendance and pari-mutuel betting; and
enhanced well-being of the standardbred racing industry.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly, by statute, may direct that the Commission not award in the following calendar year part or all of the racing days authorized under § 11-610 of this subtitle to the licensee if the General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: the proposed use of the allocation under this subsection is inconsistent with the purposes specified in this section; or
the licensee has not spent the allocation in a way that is consistent with the proposal.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout on each multiple mutuel pool on 2 horses, the licensee shall allocate at least 1% of the mutuel pool as follows:

paragraph.text: one-half to purses; and
one-half to personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction.

subsection.text: From the licensee’s share of the takeout on each multiple mutuel pool on 3 or more horses, a licensee shall allocate at least 6.5% of each mutuel pool as follows:

paragraph.text: one-half to purses; and
one-half to personnel-related expenses, physical improvements, track maintenance, and indebtedness related to the track, including indebtedness for clubhouse and grandstand construction.

section.text: A licensee whose average handle is $125,000 or less is exempt from paying 0.25% of each mutuel pool to the Maryland Harness Track Employees Pension Fund.
A licensee shall:

paragraph.text: deduct the fee for a driver from the purse of an owner; and
pay the fee to the driver not later than 7 work days after the last day of the month in which the driver earns the fee.
A licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: estimate daily the State tax on money bet; and
pay to the Commission the estimated tax, to be credited against the total tax due at the close of the race meeting.

paragraph.text: The first payment of estimated tax is due 33 days after the start of the race meeting and covers the estimated tax for the first 30 days of the race meeting.
The estimated daily tax for each later day of the race meeting shall be paid to the Commission not later than 72 hours after the close of racing for that day.
The total tax due for the race meeting shall be paid within 5 days after the close of the race meeting.

subsection.text: If the estimated tax paid by a licensee is less than 75% of the total tax due at the end of a race meeting, the Comptroller may assess a penalty of 25% of any additional tax due at the end of the race meeting.
The Commission promptly shall send to the Comptroller all taxes and estimated taxes it collects.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advisory Committee” means the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund Advisory Committee.
“Fund” means the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund.
“Fund Race” means a race funded by the Maryland Standardbred Fund.

section.text: There is a Maryland Standardbred Race Fund consisting of the Foaled Stakes Program and the Sires Stakes Program.
There is a Maryland Standardbred Race Fund Advisory Committee, under the jurisdiction of the Commission, in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Advisory Committee consists of members appointed by the Commission with the approval of the Secretary.
Of the members of the Advisory Committee:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be nominated by the chairman of the Commission and be another member of the Commission;
1 shall be nominated by the chairman of the Commission to represent each harness racing licensee;

2 shall be nominated by a majority vote of the organization that represents a majority of Standardbred Breeders in the State, and 1 of those recommended shall be a commercial breeder as defined by the Commission; and
1 shall be nominated by a majority vote of the Cloverleaf Standardbred Owners Association, Inc.

subsection.text: A member of the Advisory Committee shall be a resident of the State.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the chairman of the Advisory Committee.
The term of a member of the Advisory Committee is 4 years and begins on June 1.
A member of the Advisory Committee may serve multiple but not consecutive complete terms.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms in effect for members of the Advisory Committee on October 1, 1992.
If a member other than the 2 members nominated by the chairman of the Commission has not been nominated by June 1, the Commission, with the approval of the Secretary, shall nominate the member.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member of the Advisory Committee for incompetence or misconduct.
The member of the Commission who is on the Advisory Committee is the chairman of the Advisory Committee.

paragraph.text: The term of the chairman of the Advisory Committee is 1 year.
At the end of a term, the chairman continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A chairman who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.
An individual stops serving as chairman when the individual leaves the Advisory Committee.

subsection.text: The Advisory Committee shall set the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Advisory Committee:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Fund with the help and advice of the Advisory Committee; and
order each payment that is to be made from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: deposit the money allocated by each licensee to the Fund into a bank or trust company in the State; and
require the bank or trust company to secure the Fund by collateral.

subsection.text: Within 5 days after a race meeting, the licensee shall pay to the Commission to be held in the Fund all money that is allocated to the Fund under this title but was not disbursed during the race meeting.

If the Commission uses ordinary care to choose the depository bank or trust company, members are not personally liable for loss to the Fund because of failure, insolvency, or other fault of the depository.

section.text: Each licensee shall provide for the running of Fund Races.

subsection.text: A horse shall be registered with the Advisory Committee before the horse may start in a race of the Foaled Stakes Program.
A horse may be registered with the Advisory Committee only if the horse was foaled in Maryland as shown by a foal certificate from the United States Trotting Association and:

paragraph.text: the breeder of the horse has maintained a place of abode in Maryland for more than 9 months immediately before registration;
the breeder of the horse keeps breeding stock continually in Maryland;
the horse was conceived during the previous season by the horse’s dam being covered by a Maryland stallion registered with the Advisory Committee; or
the horse’s dam was sent to Maryland to foal and after foaling was covered by a Maryland stallion during the season of the horse’s birth.

section.text: The offspring of a standardbred sire is eligible for the Sires Stakes Program if:

paragraph.text: the sire is registered with the United States Trotting Association and with the Advisory Committee;
the sire was at stud in the State for a full breeding season; and
the offspring was conceived during that breeding season.

subsection.text: A Fund Race shall be held in accordance with regulations that the Commission adopts on the recommendation of the Advisory Committee.
On recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the Commission shall set:

paragraph.text: the number of Fund Races;
the amount of each purse and bonus;
the date of each Fund Race;
the distance of each Fund Race;
each breeder’s award;
nomination and registration procedures; and
any other condition needed to carry out the purpose of a Fund Race.

subsection.text: The Commission shall set the amount of each purse and the conditions for each Fund Race in time to allow a licensee to include the purse and conditions in the stake book and condition book of the licensee.
A licensee may add to any purse in a Fund Race.

A purse, authorized under this part and paid in a Fund Race, is specifically excluded from breeders’ bonuses, purses, or stakes that are paid or offered by licensees in races other than Fund Races, as determined by agreement or formula between a licensee and an organization that represents a majority of the owners and trainers.

section.text: This subtitle applies only to the licensee that is the Cecil County Breeders’ Fair, Inc., or its successor.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall issue a license to the Cecil County Breeders’ Fair, Inc., or its successor to hold racing on at least 2 but not more than 8 one-day race meetings a year for steeplechase, hurdle, or flat racing at the Fair Hill Natural Resources Management Area.
The racing shall be held on dates that the licensee chooses and the Commission approves.

subsection.text: In conjunction with this racing, an agricultural fair with livestock entered for exhibition shall be held under the auspices of the State Fair Board on at least 1 racing day.

For each racing day, the licensee shall offer at least 1 steeplechase or hurdle race for each flat race, but an additional flat race may be substituted for a steeplechase race or hurdle race that is not filled.
An officer of the licensee may not receive a salary or dividends from racing allowed under this subtitle.
The licensee shall allocate to the Union Hospital of Cecil County all profits earned under this subtitle, including money from pari-mutuel betting, admission charges, and other receipts.

section.text: The Commission may issue a license to the licensee to hold racing on 2 race meetings a year for quarter horse racing at the Fair Hill Natural Resources Management Area.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall deduct from the handle:

subparagraph.text: all the breakage; and

paragraph.text: From the 25% that the licensee deducts from the handle, 9% of the handle shall be paid to the Commission, which shall send it to the Comptroller to be credited to the Fair Hill Improvement Fund established in § 5-908 of the Natural Resources Article.

subsection.text: Money that remains after deductions are made under subsection (a) of this section shall be returned as winnings to successful bettors.

section.text: The Commission may authorize a licensee to hold racing with pari-mutuel betting.

subsection.text: A licensee may not lend or give money to a person for pari-mutuel betting.
The Commission may adopt regulations to enforce this section.

If a winning ticket is not redeemed within 1 year, the licensee into whose betting pool the bet was placed shall pay the amount needed to redeem the ticket to the Commission to be credited to the Special Fund under Subtitle 4 of this title.
Every year for the preceding calendar year, each licensee shall:

paragraph.text: report to the Commission the amount payable to the Commission under this section; and
pay that amount to the Commission.
The license of a licensee shall be revoked if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: fails to report when money under this section is due; or
knowingly or willfully submits a report that understates the amount due.

paragraph.text: A licensee whose license is revoked under this subsection may not hold a license for at least 1 year.

subsection.text: The intent of this section is similar to that of the Interstate Horseracing Act of 1978, 15 U.S.C. §§ 3001 through 3007.
If the Commission approves, a licensee may contract to hold pari-mutuel betting on a race that is held at an out-of-state track where betting on racing is lawful.
Pari-mutuel betting under this section may only occur:

paragraph.text: on a racing day when the Commission has authorized the licensee to hold racing; and

subparagraph.text: at the track of the licensee;
at any track where pari-mutuel betting on races on the racing program of the licensee for that day is authorized; or
at a satellite simulcast facility.

paragraph.text: The breakage and takeout for pari-mutuel betting under this section shall be computed in the way normally applicable to pari-mutuel betting on racing the licensee holds.
From the takeout the licensee shall deduct:

subparagraph.text: the State tax on all mutuel pools;
the amount to be paid under the contract to the out-of-state track; and
the cost of transmission.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall then allocate the rest of the takeout in the way applicable to the racing that the licensee holds.

subsection.text: A contract with an out-of-state track under this section is subject to the approval of the group that represents a majority of the owners and trainers who race horses at that track and the group that represents a majority of the applicable breeders in this State.
Subject to the Interstate Horseracing Act of 1978, 15 U.S.C. §§ 3001 through 3007, a licensee may simulcast races held in this State to another jurisdiction where betting on racing is lawful.
All payments to the licensee under this section shall be allocated to the licensee, purses, and the applicable bred fund in the way agreed to by:

paragraph.text: the licensee;
the group that represents a majority of the applicable owners and trainers licensed in the State; and
the group that represents a majority of the applicable breeders in the State.

section.text: Notwithstanding § 11-804(c) of this subtitle, a licensee in Allegany County may conduct pari-mutuel betting under § 11-804 of this subtitle on a day when the Commission has authorized the licensee to hold racing only:

paragraph.text: at the track of the licensee;
at a satellite simulcast facility:

subparagraph.text: in which the licensee has majority ownership interest; and
which complies with the requirements of § 11-825(a) of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: at a receiving track located more than 35 miles from any of Laurel Park, Pimlico Race Course, and Rosecroft Raceway.

subsection.text: Except for racing held by the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, the Commission may authorize telephone betting at any track where racing is authorized.
The breakage and takeout on all telephone betting shall be computed in the way normally applicable to pari-mutuel betting on racing the licensee holds.
An employee of a receiving track is not considered an employee of the sending track because of this part.
The Commission has jurisdiction over all intertrack betting and other activities at a receiving track to the same extent as when live racing is held at the track.
The Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out this part.
Only a licensee may operate a receiving track or a sending track.

paragraph.text: A receiving track shall transmit directly to the sending track all pari-mutuel information about the money bet at the receiving track.
A sending track shall incorporate this information with information on pari-mutuel betting at the sending track.

subsection.text: Money bet in intertrack betting shall be:

paragraph.text: included in the applicable mutuel pools at the sending track; and
considered as if bet at the sending track.
The breakage, State tax, and takeout on all intertrack betting at a receiving track shall be computed in the way normally applicable to pari-mutuel betting on a race at the sending track.
The takeout shall be allocated in the same proportions that are normally applicable to racing held at the sending track, after deductions for:

subparagraph.text: the State tax;
the amount to be kept by the receiving track under the simulcast agreement with the sending track; and
the cost to the sending track of the transmission.

subsection.text: On a race that a licensee holds and simulcasts to an out-of-state facility or on a simulcast of a race that a licensee receives, the licensee may, with the approval of the Commission, combine bets made at the licensee’s track with bets of the same type made at the out-of-state facility where betting is lawful.
This section allows the creation of common mutuel pools for calculating odds and determining payouts.
Bets made at an out-of-state facility may not be considered part of the licensee’s mutuel pools for any purpose other than the purpose stated in subsection (b) of this section.

For races that are held by a licensee in this State and simulcast to an out-of-state facility, the takeout on bets made in this State that are commingled in a common mutuel pool shall be the takeout as prescribed for the licensee by this title.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title governing the amount of takeout, for a race that is held by an out-of-state facility and simulcast to a licensee in this State, the takeout on bets made in this State that are commingled in a common mutuel pool shall be, subject to the approval of the Commission, as agreed by the licensee and the out-of-state facility.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this title governing the allocation of takeout, for a race that is held by an out-of-state facility and simulcast to a licensee in this State, the allocation of takeout on bets made in this State that are commingled in a common mutuel pool shall be, subject to the approval of the Commission, allocated in the following manner:

paragraph.text: to the State for taxes on the handle of the licensee as provided under this title;
to the host racing association where live racing is conducted in an amount determined by the licensee and the out-of-state facility; and
the remainder to the licensee, the applicable pension funds created by this title, purse money, and the applicable bred fund in proportion to their respective shares of the takeout under this title.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fair Hill” means the Cecil County Breeders’ Fair, Inc., or its successor.
“State Fair Society” means the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society, Inc.

subsection.text: This section applies only to intertrack betting in which:

paragraph.text: the sending track is equipped to transmit simulcast races and is:

subparagraph.text: a mile thoroughbred track;
a harness track;
a track where racing is conducted by Fair Hill; or
a track where racing is conducted by the State Fair Society; and

paragraph.text: the receiving track is:

subparagraph.text: equipped to receive simulcast races and hold intertrack betting on those races; and
one of the tracks specified in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Commission may authorize intertrack betting involving tracks of:

paragraph.text: mile thoroughbred racing licensees;
harness racing licensees;
Fair Hill; or
the State Fair Society.

subsection.text: The Commission may authorize licensees, Fair Hill, or the State Fair Society to participate in intertrack betting by operating sending tracks and receiving tracks only if:

paragraph.text: the operators of the sending track and the receiving track submit a joint application to the Commission;
the Commission holds a public hearing on the matter;

the operator of the receiving track shows to the satisfaction of the Commission that the operator has held, is holding, or will hold regularly scheduled race meetings at the receiving track in accordance with a license and has complied with the terms of the license; and
the receiving track meets the requirements of subsection (e) of this section, unless the Commission has waived them, and subsection (f) of this section.

Laurel Race Course, a track where racing is conducted by the State Fair Society or Rosecroft Raceway may be a receiving track only if live racing was held there in the previous calendar year on at least 75% of the racing days available to it.
Ocean Downs may be a receiving track only if at least 40 days of live racing were held there in the previous calendar year.
Pimlico Race Course may be a receiving track only if at least 90 days of live racing were held there in the previous calendar year.
A track where racing is conducted by Fair Hill may be a sending track only on days when Fair Hill is licensed to conduct and actually conducts live racing.
A track in Allegany County may be a sending track:

subparagraph.text: to any receiving track:

sub-subparagraph.text: on days when the track is licensed to conduct and actually conducts live racing; and
for live races conducted at the track; and

subparagraph.text: to a receiving track located more than 35 miles from any of Laurel Park, Pimlico Race Course, and Rosecroft Raceway:

sub-subparagraph.text: on any day the Commission has authorized the licensee to hold racing; and
for simulcast races conducted at the track.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 11-804.2 of this subtitle, nothing in paragraph (5) of this subsection shall limit the ability of a track in Allegany County to act as a sending track to a satellite simulcast facility.
A track in Allegany County may be a receiving track:

subparagraph.text: during its opening year if it has scheduled at least 21 days of live racing within 12 months of its opening and the Commission has granted its application to race on those days; and
in subsequent years if at least 21 days of live racing were held at the track in the previous calendar year.

paragraph.text: The Commission may waive a requirement of this subsection if the receiving track could not meet the requirement because of:

subparagraph.text: an act of God; or
what the Commission finds to be an emergency.

paragraph.text: Intertrack betting may be held only if the organizations specified in this subsection approve the agreement between the receiving track and the sending track to simulcast races.
If the sending track is a mile thoroughbred track or a track where racing is conducted by the State Fair Society or Fair Hill, approval shall be by an organization representing:

subparagraph.text: a majority of the owners and trainers at the sending track; and
a majority of the thoroughbred breeders in the State.

paragraph.text: If the sending track is a harness track, approval shall be by an organization representing:

subparagraph.text: a majority of the owners, trainers, and drivers of standardbred horses at the sending track; and
a majority of the standardbred breeders in the State.

paragraph.text: If the receiving track is a mile thoroughbred track or a track where racing is conducted by the State Fair Society, approval shall be by an organization representing:

subparagraph.text: a majority of the owners and trainers at the receiving track; and
a majority of the thoroughbred breeders in the State.

paragraph.text: If the receiving track is a harness track, approval shall be by an organization representing:

subparagraph.text: a majority of the owners, trainers, and drivers of standardbred horses at the harness track; and
a majority of the standardbred breeders in the State.

paragraph.text: The simulcast signal shall be encoded.
The licensee of the receiving track may not transmit the simulcast signal beyond the premises where pari-mutuel betting is allowed.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (f) of this section, if a track where racing is conducted by the State Fair Society is within the 35-mile radius of a mile thoroughbred track, it shall first obtain the concurrence of that mile thoroughbred track before it may be a receiving track during a period of time when the State Fair Society is not licensed to conduct live racing.

A mile thoroughbred racing licensee operating a sending track shall pay to the Commission, within 10 days after each day of intertrack betting on thoroughbred racing at a receiving track, $1,000 of the impact aid to be paid to political subdivisions for intertrack betting for that day under § 11–404(c) and (d) of this title.

The licensee shall deduct from the takeout the payment under subsection (a) of this section and then shall allocate the rest of the takeout in the way normally applicable to racing at the sending track.
The Commission shall pay promptly to the Comptroller all money collected under this section.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Permit” means a permit granted under this part to hold satellite simulcast betting.
“Satellite simulcast betting” means:

paragraph.text: pari-mutuel betting at a satellite simulcast facility in the State on a race that is simulcast from a sending track by a mile thoroughbred racing licensee, a harness racing licensee, or the State Fair Society; and
transmission of the pari-mutuel information regarding bets at the satellite simulcast facility to the sending track.

subsection.text: The Commission may approve satellite simulcast facilities that may conduct satellite simulcast betting.
This part does not authorize satellite simulcast betting at or through the direct use of lottery terminals in the State.
The Commission has jurisdiction over all satellite simulcast betting and other activities at a satellite simulcast facility to the same extent as when live racing is held by a licensee.
A person must have a permit granted by the Commission whenever the person holds satellite simulcast betting.
Nothing in this Part III of this subtitle may preempt local zoning laws or ordinances.
Any person may apply for a permit.
An applicant for a permit shall submit to the executive director of the Commission an application in the form that the Commission requires.
Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, the Commission shall conduct a personal and financial background check of an applicant for a permit including:

paragraph.text: a review, by a certified public accountant, of the certified financial statements of the applicant, including contingent or pledged liabilities, sufficient to determine the ability of the applicant to purchase or lease, and develop and maintain the satellite simulcast facility for which the permit is sought;
an income statement of the applicant for the most recent year;
a statement of financial and related records of any person in which the applicant has at least a majority interest;
a disclosure of all financial interests in horse racing and any other legalized betting activity;
the disclosure of each person who is a beneficial owner of the applicant;
with the assistance of federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities, a criminal background review; and
a character review.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations establishing uniform procedures for conducting the personal and financial background check required by this section.
The Commission may waive portions of the review that it determines to be appropriate for any applicant that is a licensee.

section.text: The factors that the Commission shall consider in deciding whether to grant a permit shall include:

paragraph.text: the needs and convenience of the public;
whether the satellite simulcast facility:

subparagraph.text: would be expected to interfere unreasonably with attendance at tracks; and
meets the requirements of § 11-825(a) of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: the desires of the political subdivision where the proposed satellite simulcast facility is to be located;
the interests of the racing industry; and
other matters that the Commission finds appropriate.

subsection.text: The Commission shall grant a permit to each applicant whose application the Commission approves after the applicant pays the permit fee that the Commission requires.
A permit shall state the specific location where the permit applies.
If the Commission approves, an applicant for a permit may change the location for which a satellite simulcast facility is being applied.

section.text: A permit entitles the holder to hold satellite simulcast betting at the satellite simulcast facility specified in the permit, but does not give the permit holder an ownership right to the permit or the simulcast signal.

subsection.text: The Commission shall set the term of each permit.
If the Commission approves, a permit may be transferred to another person if:

paragraph.text: the satellite simulcasting facility remains at the same location; and
the person complies with all regulations of the Commission established under § 11-316 of this title for the purchase or transfer of an entity licensed to conduct racing.

section.text: A permit holder shall keep records of ownership and submit annual reports of ownership as required under § 11-314 of this title.
Applicants for and holders of permits are subject to the denial of license and disciplinary provisions of § 11-308 of this title.

subsection.text: A satellite simulcast facility:

paragraph.text: shall be in premises owned or leased by a permit holder;

may not be within a 35-mile radius of any mile thoroughbred track or harness track unless approved by the track licensee, the group that represents a majority of the applicable owners and trainers licensed in the State and the group that represents a majority of the applicable breeders in the State, considered separately;

unless the track agrees otherwise, may not operate during hours on those days that racing with pari-mutuel betting is permitted at a racetrack located in this State within a 35-mile radius of the satellite simulcast facility; and
shall offer pari-mutuel betting facilities and amenities that the Commission finds are:

subparagraph.text: comparable to those available in the sports palace facilities of the mile thoroughbred racing licensees including:

sub-subparagraph.text: high quality dining, lounge, and seating areas that are of a manner generally found in fine restaurants; and
teletheatre screen capacity; and

subparagraph.text: appropriate for the area where the satellite simulcast facility is located.

subsection.text: A mile thoroughbred racing licensee or a harness racing licensee shall own or lease the pari-mutuel betting equipment at a satellite simulcast facility and shall, with its employees, operate the equipment.
A mile thoroughbred racing licensee or a harness racing licensee shall submit to the Commission all contracts and agreements relating to satellite simulcast betting under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall periodically be assured by permit holders that facilities continue to meet the requirements of this section.

subparagraph.text: The Commission shall inspect satellite simulcast facilities at least four times each year to determine if the permit holders are continuing to comply with the provisions of this section.
The inspections under this subsection shall include evaluations of the financial and physical conditions of each satellite simulcast facility.

paragraph.text: If the Commission finds that a permit holder is not complying with the provisions of this section, the Commission may impose a penalty on the permit holder similar to those penalties levied on licensees as provided under § 11-308 of this title.

subsection.text: All money bet at a satellite simulcast facility shall be included in the applicable mutuel pools at the sending track.

Except as provided in § 11-827 of this part, the breakage, State tax, and takeout on all satellite simulcast betting shall be computed in the way normally applicable to pari-mutuel betting on a race at the sending track.

section.text: After the respective portions have been retained by each person listed below, those persons may allocate, from the takeout at the satellite simulcast facility, the costs of operating a satellite simulcast facility and holding satellite simulcast betting:

paragraph.text: the licensee of the sending track, from the licensee’s share;
the group that represents a majority of the applicable owners and trainers licensed in the State, from the purse share; and
the group that represents a majority of the applicable breeders in the State, from the bred fund share.

subsection.text: A satellite simulcast facility shall transmit directly to the sending track all pari-mutuel information about the money bet at the satellite simulcast facility.
A sending track shall incorporate this information with information on pari-mutuel betting at the sending track.

section.text: Except for betting on races of national or international prominence which have been approved by the Commission, satellite simulcast betting may not be conducted:

paragraph.text: on any day other than Sunday between 1:30 a.m. and 10:00 a.m.; and
between 1:30 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. on Sunday.

section.text: A permit holder under this subtitle may not lend or give money to a person for pari-mutuel betting.
The Commission shall include in its annual report to the Legislative Policy Committee of the Maryland General Assembly:

paragraph.text: the effect of satellite simulcast betting on the racing industry in the State;
an appraisal of each permit holder, taking into consideration the results of inspections required under this section and any financial information that is submitted to the Commission;
if any additional permit has been granted under this section:

subparagraph.text: the reasons for granting the permit; and
the anticipated impact of the new facility on existing permit holders and racing licensees; and

paragraph.text: if an application for a permit or permit renewal has been denied:

subparagraph.text: the reasons for denying the permit or renewal; and
the impact on racing licensees if the Commission denied a permit renewal application.

section.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations to:

paragraph.text: define the criteria for applicants for a satellite simulcast betting permit, which may include a nonrefundable application fee;
define allowable costs of operations under § 11-827 of this part; and
otherwise carry out this part.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Jockey Fund” means the Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc.
There is a Maryland Jockey Injury Compensation Fund, Inc., established as a not for profit corporation in the Department.
The Jockey Fund shall get workers’ compensation insurance on a blanket basis for all jockeys who are covered employees under § 9-212 of the Labor and Employment Article.

subsection.text: The Jockey Fund shall be managed by a Board of Directors.
The Board of Directors of the Jockey Fund consists of the members of the Commission.
The Board of Directors shall carry out this part.
The Jockey Fund shall use the moneys paid to it under this part to:

paragraph.text: get workers’ compensation insurance for jockeys; and
administer the workers’ compensation program for jockeys that is required under this subtitle and the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act.

subsection.text: The liability of the Jockey Fund under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act is limited to:

paragraph.text: providing workers’ compensation insurance; and
paying any penalty that results from a failure to provide the insurance.
The Commission shall assess each licensed owner and licensed trainer of a thoroughbred horse an amount sufficient to pay the cost of workers’ compensation insurance that the Jockey Fund gets.
The Commission shall pay each assessment that the Commission collects under this subsection to the Jockey Fund.
The Commission shall suspend or revoke the license of each owner or trainer who fails to pay the assessment under subsection (a)(1) of this section.
The Commission may not reinstate or renew the license of the owner or trainer during the period of default.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Standardbred Horsemen’s Assistance Fund, Inc., and a Maryland Horsemen’s Assistance Fund, Inc.
The clerk of the course at each thoroughbred track and at each harness track shall:

paragraph.text: collect each overpayment on a tote machine and each fine and penalty that is not imposed on a licensee; and
pay that money to the Commission within 10 days after the close of each race meeting.

subsection.text: The Commission shall pay the money collected under subsection (b) of this section from each harness track to the Maryland Standardbred Horsemen’s Assistance Fund, Inc., and the money collected from each thoroughbred track to the Maryland Horsemen’s Assistance Fund, Inc., on or before December 31 of each year, if the Commission is satisfied that:

paragraph.text: the recipient fund is operated entirely for the charitable purposes consistent with the interests of racing; and

money that the Commission sends to a recipient fund or net earnings of a recipient fund is not used for the benefit of a director, member, or officer of that fund, or for the benefit of any private individual who is not an object of the charitable purposes of that fund.

subsection.text: Except in accordance with a license, a person may not hold, or aid or abet in holding, a race meeting at which horses are raced for a purse, reward, or stake.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 for each day of violation or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

section.text: This title is the Maryland Horse Racing Act.
Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, this title and all regulations adopted under this title shall terminate on July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means the Pimlico Community Development Authority.

“Park Heights Corridor” means the area designated as an urban renewal district in Baltimore City that is bounded by Northern Parkway on the north, Greenspring Avenue on the east, Druid Park Drive on the south, and the railroad tracks of the Western Maryland Railroad on the west.

section.text: There is a Pimlico Community Development Authority.

subsection.text: The Authority consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: the Baltimore City Planning Director;

ten members, five of whom shall be business owners, residents, or service providers of the areas described in § 9–1A–31(a)(1)(ii) of the State Government Article, appointed by the Mayor of Baltimore City, after consultation with the members of the Baltimore City Delegation in the General Assembly representing legislative districts 40 and 41;
the State Senators representing legislative districts 40 and 41; and
one State Delegate representing legislative district 40 and one State Delegate representing legislative district 41, each appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The Baltimore City Planning Director shall serve as Chair of the Authority.

paragraph.text: The term of a member appointed by the Mayor is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members on October 1, 2005.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
At the end of a term, resignation, or removal of a member, the Mayor shall appoint a new member to the Authority.

subsection.text: A member may be removed by the Mayor for incompetence, misconduct, or failure to perform the duties of the position.

section.text: The Authority shall meet at a regular time and place to be determined by the Authority.

subsection.text: The Authority shall receive 80% of the money from the Special Fund, established under § 11-401 of this title, that is designated for payment to Baltimore City under § 11-404 of this title.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, the money received by the Authority shall be used to pay for facilities and services in communities in the Baltimore City limits within 2 miles of the Pimlico Race Course.

In making its determinations on the use of the money provided to the Authority under subsection (a) of this section, the Authority shall give considerable weight to the housing, economic, and community development needs of the Park Heights Corridor, based on statistics including poverty and population statistics.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Compact committee” means the organization of officials from the party states that is authorized and empowered by this compact to carry out the purposes of this compact.
“Compact license” means a license issued by the compact committee.
“Official” means the duly selected member of a party state racing commission, or its equivalent, who represents that party state as a member of the compact committee.
“Participants in live racing” means participants in live horse racing with pari-mutuel wagering in the party states.
“Party state” means each state that has enacted this compact.
“State” means each of the several states of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and each territory or possession of the United States.

section.text: The purposes of this compact are to:

paragraph.text: derive uniform requirements among the party states for the licensure of participants in live horse racing with pari–mutuel wagering;
ensure that all licensees pursuant to this compact meet a uniform minimum standard of honesty and integrity;
facilitate the growth of the horse racing industry by simplifying the process for qualified applicants for a license to participate in live racing;
reduce the cost incurred by each state and applicant from the separate licensing process conducted by each state that conducts live horse racing;
authorize the Commission to participate in this compact;
permit officials from the party states to participate in this compact;
through the compact committee established by this compact, enter into contracts with governmental agencies and other persons to carry out the purposes of this compact; and
establish the compact committee created by this compact as an interstate governmental entity duly authorized to request and receive criminal history record information from:

subparagraph.text: the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
state and local authorities; and
foreign law enforcement agencies.

section.text: This compact shall become effective as to any party state that enacts this compact on the affirmative vote of a majority of the officials on the compact committee.
Any state that has adopted or authorized horse racing with pari-mutuel wagering shall be eligible to become a party to this compact.

subsection.text: Any party state may withdraw from this compact by enacting a statute repealing this compact, but no such withdrawal shall become effective until the head of the executive branch of the withdrawing state has given notice in writing of such withdrawal to the head of the executive branch of all other party states.

If withdrawals reduce participation in this compact to less than three party states, this compact no longer shall be in effect until there are three or more party states again participating in this compact.

There is hereby created an interstate governmental entity known as the compact committee, to be comprised of one official from the racing commission, or its equivalent, of each party state, who shall be selected, serve, and be removed in accordance with the laws of the official’s party state.

Each official shall have, in accordance with the laws of that party state, the assistance of that state’s racing commission, or its equivalent, in considering issues related to licensing of participants in live racing and in acting as representative of that state on the compact committee.
Where an official is unable to perform any duty of the compact committee:

paragraph.text: an alternate shall serve, until the original can return to duty, as that party state’s official on the compact committee; and
the designation of an alternate shall be communicated by that party state’s racing commission, or its equivalent, to the compact committee, as required by the applicable bylaws.

subsection.text: The Chairman of the Commission shall designate the official, and official’s alternate, to represent the State of Maryland on the compact committee.
In order to carry out the purposes of this compact, the compact committee is hereby granted the power and duty to:

paragraph.text: determine which categories of participants in live racing shall be issued a compact license;
establish the term, initial requirements, and renewal requirements for each category of compact license;
adopt licensure requirements comparable, in its judgment, to the most restrictive party state’s requirements for such a license;
investigate applicants for a compact license and, as permitted by federal and state law, gather information, including criminal history record information, from:

subparagraph.text: the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
state and local authorities; and
foreign country law enforcement agencies; and

paragraph.text: issue or renew compact licenses for participants in live racing who are found by the compact committee to have met its licensure or renewal requirements.

subsection.text: The compact committee may not deny a state license to an applicant.

If the compact committee determines that an applicant is not eligible for a compact license, the compact committee, on giving notice to the applicant, shall stop processing the applicant’s application for a state license or renewal of a state license.
After receiving the notice, an applicant who wishes to appeal the determination may present evidence at a hearing that the compact committee conducts.
The decision of the compact committee after a hearing is final.
The compact committee may:

paragraph.text: enter into contracts and agreements with governmental agencies and other persons to provide personal services for its activities and such other services as may be necessary;

subparagraph.text: create, appoint, and abolish all those offices, employments, and positions, including an executive director, useful to fulfill its purposes;
prescribe their powers, duties, and qualifications;
hire persons; and
provide for their term, tenure, removal, compensation, fringe and retirement benefits, and other conditions of employment;

paragraph.text: borrow, accept, and contract for the services of personnel from any state, federal, or other governmental agency or from any other person or entity;
acquire, hold, and dispose of any real or personal property by gift, purchase, lease, license, and similar means in furtherance of the purposes of this compact;
charge and collect a fee, whether for licensure or renewal, from each license applicant; and
receive additional funds through gifts, grants, and appropriations.

subsection.text: Criminal history record information may be received and reviewed only by the officials on, and employees of, the compact committee which may be used only for the purposes of this compact.

No official or employee of the compact committee may disclose or disseminate criminal history record information to any person or entity other than another official on, or employee of, the compact committee.
The compact committee, its employees, or its designee shall:

paragraph.text: take the fingerprints of each license applicant in accordance with the procedures in § 11-312 of this title; and
in accordance with P.L. 92-544 or P.L. 100-413, forward the fingerprints to an identification bureau or to an association of state officials regulating pari-mutuel wagering.

section.text: The compact committee shall have the following voting requirements:

paragraph.text: each official shall be entitled to one vote on the compact committee;
a majority vote of the total number of officials on the compact committee shall be required to:

subparagraph.text: admit another party state;
issue or renew a racing license; and
receive or distribute any funds;

paragraph.text: a two-thirds majority vote of the total number of officials on the compact committee shall be required to adopt, amend, or rescind the bylaws;
all other actions by the compact committee shall require a majority vote of those officials who are present for the vote; and
no action may be taken by the compact committee unless a quorum of the officials on the compact committee is present for the vote.

section.text: The compact committee shall:

paragraph.text: annually elect, from its members:

subparagraph.text: a chair;
a vice chair; and
a secretary/treasurer;
adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
publish the bylaws in a convenient form; and
file a copy of the bylaws, including any amendments, with the secretary of state, or its equivalent agency, of each party state; and

paragraph.text: delegate day-to-day management and administration of its duties, as needed, to an executive director and support staff, who shall be considered governmental employees.

section.text: No official of a party state or employee of the compact committee shall be held personally liable for any reasonable action taken in good faith that occurs during the performance, and within the scope, of their responsibilities and duties under this compact.
Each party state in the compact shall:

paragraph.text: accept the decisions of the compact committee regarding the issuance or renewal of licenses;
reimburse, or otherwise pay, the expenses of its official on the compact committee;
not treat as a denial a notification to an applicant by the compact committee regarding its inability to process their application;
reserve the right to:

subparagraph.text: charge a fee for the use of a compact license within that party state;
apply its own standards to determine whether a compact committee license should be suspended or revoked;

apply its own standards for licensure or renewal of state applicants who do not meet the licensure requirements of the compact committee, or who are within a category of participants in live racing which the compact committee does not license; and
apply its own standards for licensure of nonracing employees at horse racetracks and at separate or satellite wagering facilities;

paragraph.text: through its racing commission or its equivalent, promptly notify the compact committee of any suspension or revocation that the party state has imposed on a compact committee licensee; and
not be held liable for the debts or other financial obligations incurred by the compact committee.

subsection.text: This compact shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate its purposes.
The provisions of this compact shall be severable.
If any phrase, clause, sentence, or provision of this compact is declared to be contrary to the Constitution of the United States, the remainder of this compact shall remain in full force and effect.

If any phrase, clause, sentence, or provision of this compact is declared to be contrary to the constitution or laws of a party state, subject to the provision of § 1305(b), the compact shall remain in full force and effect as to the remaining states.

If the applicability of this compact to any government, agency, person or circumstance is held invalid, the applicability of the compact to other governments, agencies, persons or circumstances shall not be affected thereby.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” means:

subparagraph.text: an individual who acquires commercially from the public or trades commercially with the public in secondhand precious metal objects;
an individual who for compensation arranges for the sale or delivery of a secondhand precious metal object on behalf of a person that does not hold a license under this title; or
unless otherwise provided, a pawnbroker.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” includes a retail jeweler as to transactions in which the retail jeweler acquires commercially from the public or trades commercially with the public in secondhand precious metal objects.

subsection.text: “Employee” means an individual who is employed by a dealer or pawnbroker to buy, sell, or supervise directly the buying or selling of secondhand precious metal objects.
“Fixed business address” means a single physical location in Maryland where a licensee regularly conducts business and at which the licensee or an employee of the licensee is physically present:

paragraph.text: during normal business hours; or

other hours as provided in the application for the license which are sufficient to provide an authorized law enforcement officer or agent access to the licensee’s place of business as provided in § 12–306 of this title.

subsection.text: “License” means a license issued by the Secretary to do business as a dealer.

“Local law enforcement unit” means the Maryland Department of State Police, a Maryland police department, or Maryland sheriff, as designated by resolution of the county or municipal governing body, with jurisdiction over any place where a dealer transacts business other than the dealer’s fixed business address.
“Pawnbroker” means a person who engages in pawn transactions.

“Pawn transaction” means a loan of money by a dealer on deposit or pledge of personal property or other valuable thing other than securities or printed evidences of indebtedness, or a purchase by a dealer of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back at a stipulated price.
“Precious metal object” means:

paragraph.text: a precious metal that is:

subparagraph.text: gold;
iridium;
palladium;
platinum; or
silver;

paragraph.text: a precious or semiprecious stone, or a pearl, that is or appears to have been attached to or inlaid in a precious metal listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection or any alloy of a precious metal; or
an object that is composed of a precious metal listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection or any alloy of a precious metal if:

subparagraph.text: the market value of the metal in the object lies principally in its precious metal component; or
at least 25% of the weight of the object is precious metal.

subsection.text: “Primary law enforcement unit” means the Department of State Police, a police department, or sheriff, as designated by resolution of the county or municipal governing body in the county in which the license is held.
