This title does not apply to a transaction that involves:

paragraph.text: merchandise acquired from an established manufacturer or dealer who holds a license under this title, other than a pawnbroker, if the dealer who acquires the merchandise keeps an invoice or other customary proof of origin for the merchandise;
a metal acquired for use in dentistry by a dentist licensed to practice dentistry under Title 4 of the Health Occupations Article;
coins or numismatic items; or
the purchase of junk or scrap metal that is subject to the record keeping and reporting requirements under § 17–1011 of this article.

subsection.text: If a retail jeweler has a fixed business address in the State, this title does not apply to a transaction in which the retail jeweler:

paragraph.text: accepts, in accordance with a posted return policy, the return of an item that the jeweler originally sold;
accepts, in accordance with a published trade–in policy, merchandise in trade that the jeweler originally sold;
repossesses merchandise that the jeweler originally sold, if the original buyer has defaulted;
retains merchandise that the jeweler originally accepted for repair as a bailee for hire, if the customer who deposited the merchandise:

subparagraph.text: defaulted; or
failed to reclaim the merchandise within the time agreed on with the jeweler; or

paragraph.text: accumulates pieces of precious metals in the course of performing repairs, remountings, fabrications, or custom orders.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, this title does not apply to a pawnbroker located in a county that regulates pawnbrokers unless the pawnbroker does business as a dealer.

paragraph.text: A county or municipal corporation may not enact a law to regulate dealers, coins, or numismatic items.
This title supersedes any existing law of a county or municipal corporation that regulates dealers, coins, or numismatic items.

section.text: The Secretary may adopt and enforce regulations to carry out this title.
The Secretary shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an individual shall have a license before the individual does business as a dealer in the State.
Except those pawnbrokers who are exempt from State licensing under § 12-102(c) of this title, all pawnbrokers must be licensed as dealers.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary an application on the form that the Secretary provides; and
pay to the Secretary an application fee of $300.

paragraph.text: The application fee is nonrefundable.

subsection.text: The applicant shall sign the application under oath.
In addition to any other information that the Secretary requires, the application shall state:

paragraph.text: the name, date of birth, and residence address of the applicant;
the fixed business address of the applicant;

the fixed address in the State where precious metal objects will be stored, if different from the fixed business address, provided, however, that a bank or safe deposit box is not an acceptable storage location unless written consent by the applicant and a bank official authorizing access to the storage facility and examination of its contents by law enforcement officers or agents accompany the application;
a telephone number at which the applicant can be reached during normal business hours;
each address where the applicant has conducted any business during the 36 months before application;
the driver’s license number, if any, of the applicant; and
the name and permanent address of each employee who will work with the applicant in the business of the applicant.

subsection.text: The application form shall contain, immediately above the signature line, the following:

“If issued a license, I agree to allow a municipal, county, or State police officer or agent acting in the course of a stolen property investigation or an investigation of a violation of this title to inspect and photograph all precious metal objects and records at my business or storage locations.”

section.text: Before an individual may begin work for a dealer as an employee:

paragraph.text: the dealer shall submit to the Secretary, on the form that the Secretary provides, the name of the individual; and
the individual shall apply for a national and State criminal history records check required under § 12-204(b) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

Applicants for licenses under § 12-201 of this subtitle and individuals whose names must be submitted to the Secretary under § 12-203 of this subtitle shall apply to the Central Repository for a national and State criminal history records check on a form approved by the Director of the Central Repository.
The Central Repository shall provide to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: the national and State criminal history records of each individual requiring a criminal history records check under subsection (b) of this section and issue a printed statement listing any convictions and pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal charge;

an update of the initial criminal history records check for an individual requiring a criminal history records check and issue a revised printed statement listing any convictions and pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal charge occurring in the State after the date of the initial criminal history records check; and
an acknowledged receipt of the application for a criminal history records check by an individual requiring a criminal history records check.

subsection.text: An individual requiring a criminal history records check shall submit a complete set of legible fingerprints taken at any designated State or local law enforcement office in the State or other agency or location approved by the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to the Central Repository.
An individual requiring a criminal history records check under subsection (b) of this section shall pay:

paragraph.text: the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records.

subsection.text: A dealer or an applicant may pay for the costs borne by the employee or other individual requiring a criminal history records check under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: Information obtained by the Secretary from the Central Repository under Title 12 of this article shall be confidential and may be disseminated only to the individual who is the subject of the criminal history records check.

Nothing in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall preclude the Secretary from notifying a dealer or an applicant of the approval or disqualification of the employee for employment based on information obtained by the Secretary under this section.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall verify periodically the continued employment or licensure of individuals requiring criminal history records checks in accordance with regulations adopted by the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

Upon receipt of a complete national and State criminal record report from the Central Repository in accordance with § 12-204 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
The Secretary:

paragraph.text: may issue a license only for a fixed business address; but
may not issue a license for an address that is:

subparagraph.text: a hotel or motel room;
a motor vehicle;
a post office box; or
a location which does not meet the qualifications as defined in § 12-101(d) of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary may not issue more than 1 license for any single business location unless the dealers at that location are in partnership.
The Secretary may not issue a license to a minor.

Whenever a license is suspended or revoked, another license may not be issued to a dealer for the same business location unless the applicant provides the documentation and information, which the Secretary establishes by regulation, is necessary to demonstrate that the applicant will be engaging in a business which is separate and independent from the business of the revoked or suspended license.
A license authorizes the licensee to do business as a dealer only at the address for which the license is issued.
Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a dealer who holds a license under this subtitle may:

paragraph.text: make purchases at an estate and judicial sale; and
transact business at the residence of the owner of a precious metal object or a place where the owner keeps a precious metal object:

subparagraph.text: on request of the owner; and
after giving written notice of the proposed transaction and its location to the local law enforcement unit with jurisdiction over that location.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first April 30 that comes:

paragraph.text: after the effective date of the license; and
in an even-numbered year.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Secretary must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew it for an additional 2–year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: submits to the Secretary a renewal application on the form that the Secretary provides;
signs the renewal application under oath;
updates the information submitted in the original application and states that the information is current;
except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, agrees to comply with each requirement applicable to the original application;
states that the licensee:

subparagraph.text: has not violated this title;
has not been convicted of an offense specified in § 12–209 of this subtitle; and
has not had a similar license denied, suspended, or revoked in another jurisdiction;

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed; and
pays to the Secretary a renewal fee of $265.

subsection.text: The Secretary may require a licensee to submit a national and State criminal history records check with the renewal application.
The Secretary shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
A license is not transferable and may be used only to benefit the licensee.

paragraph.text: A licensee may change the place of business for which a license is issued only if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: submits to the Secretary an application to transfer the license to a new business location on a form that the Secretary provides; and
receives the written approval of the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Within 45 days after the application is filed with the Secretary, the Secretary shall approve or disapprove the application and notify the licensee of the approval or disapproval, in writing.
If the Secretary approves a proposed change of place of business, the licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary a current list of names of each employee to be employed at the new location; and
attach the written approval of the Secretary to the license until an amended license is received by the licensee.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
Each licensee shall display the license conspicuously in the place of business of the licensee.

paragraph.text: Only a licensed dealer may advertise for the commercial trading with the public or acquiring from the public in secondhand precious metal objects.

An advertisement for the commercial trading with the public or acquiring from the public in secondhand precious metal objects shall include the name and license number of the licensee, in compliance with applicable regulations adopted by the Department.

Except as otherwise provided, in this subsection, a dealer’s or applicant’s agents, employees, management personnel, or partners include only those individuals who are directly involved in pawn transactions or the acquisition or sale of secondhand precious metals on behalf of the dealer or applicant.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 12-210 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to an applicant, reprimand a licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee or an agent, employee, manager, or partner of the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another person;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
has a similar license denied, suspended, or revoked in another jurisdiction;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of a:

sub-subparagraph.text: felony; or
misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to be involved in a pawn transaction or the sale or acquisition of secondhand precious metals;

subparagraph.text: knowingly employs or knowingly continues to employ, after being notified by the Secretary, an individual who, under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the employee to be involved in a pawn transaction or the sale or acquisition of secondhand precious metals;

subparagraph.text: knowingly employs or knowingly continues to employ in any capacity, after being notified by the Secretary, an individual whose precious metals dealer’s license has been revoked;
willfully fails to provide or willfully misrepresents any information required to be provided under this title;
violates this title; or
violates a regulation adopted under this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Secretary may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Secretary shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.
The Secretary shall distribute periodically to all dealers a list of individuals whose licenses have been revoked in the State.

If a licensee is charged with a violation of this title that could result in suspension or revocation of the license, or if the Secretary has probable cause to believe that this title has been, or will be, violated through transactions likely to occur pursuant to § 12-206 of this subtitle, the Secretary may seek from a circuit court an immediate restraining order to prohibit the licensee from:

subparagraph.text: buying or selling a secondhand precious metal object;
disposing of a secondhand precious metal object; or
disposing of a record about a secondhand precious metal object.

paragraph.text: The restraining order is in effect until:

subparagraph.text: the court lifts the order;
the charges are adjudicated or dismissed; or
in the case of an event held in accordance with § 12-206 of this subtitle, arrangements are made by the licensee which will ensure compliance with the provisions of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(2)(iv) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to act as a pawnbroker or a secondhand precious metal object dealer;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 12-209 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in a proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the individual against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: A party to a proceeding under this title who is aggrieved by a final decision of the Secretary in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary shall inform each primary law enforcement unit of each license that is issued, renewed, changed to a new business location, denied, suspended, or revoked.
A dealer may not acquire a precious metal object, or take any merchandise in a pawn transaction, from an individual who is a minor.

paragraph.text: Each dealer shall make a written record, on a form provided by the Secretary, of each business transaction that involves the acquisition of a secondhand precious metal object when the transaction is made.
Each dealer shall retain the original copy of the written record required to be made under paragraph (1) of this subsection at the dealer’s place of business.

subsection.text: Each pawnbroker shall make a written record, on a form provided by the Secretary, of each business transaction that involves:

paragraph.text: lending money on pledge of personal property, other than a security or printed evidence of indebtedness;
buying personal property on condition of selling it back at a stipulated price; or
buying the following items for the purpose of resale:

subparagraph.text: binoculars;
cameras;
firearms;
furs;
household appliances;
musical instruments;
office machines or equipment;
radios, televisions, videodisc machines, videocassette recorders, and stereo equipment;
personal computers, tapes, and disc recorders;
watches;
bicycles; and
tangible personal property pledged as collateral.

subsection.text: Each pawnbroker shall make a written record, on a form provided by the Secretary, of each transaction that involves the acquisition of an item described in subsection (b)(3) of this section for the purpose of resale.

paragraph.text: A separate record entry shall be made for each item involved in a transaction.
Items in a matching set may be recorded as a set if acquired in a single transaction.

subsection.text: During the holding period required under § 12–305 of this subtitle, a dealer may place all of the items acquired in a single transaction in a secure container that has been approved by the primary law enforcement unit, if:

paragraph.text: each item in the transaction has a separate record entry in the written record required under this section; and

the secure container is tagged by the dealer with the number that corresponds to the transaction under which the items were acquired and the written record listing the items obtained in the transaction.

When a dealer places items into their inventory, the dealer shall tag each item individually with a number that corresponds to the transaction under which it was acquired. However, items acquired in a matching set may be tagged as a set.
Each item tagged by a dealer under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall remain tagged for the entire period the item is stored in the dealer’s inventory.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, there is a presumption that an object is a precious metal object if:

paragraph.text: it reasonably appears to be a precious metal object; and
it was received by a dealer in the course of business or is found in the place of business or storage facility of a dealer.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required by the Secretary, the records of a dealer shall include:

paragraph.text: the date, place, and time of each transaction that involves the acquisition of a precious metal object;
the name and address of the principal, if the transaction is by an agent;
a description of the precious metal object, including:

subparagraph.text: its approximate metallic composition;
any jewels, stones, or glass parts;
any mark, number, word, or other identification on the precious metal object;
its weight, if payment is based on weight;
a statement whether it appears to have been altered by any means, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: obscuring a serial number or identifying feature;
melting; or
recutting a gem; and

subparagraph.text: the amount paid or other consideration;

paragraph.text: for each individual from whom the dealer acquires a precious metal object:

subparagraph.text: the name, date of birth, and driver’s license number of the individual; or
identification information about the individual that:

sub-subparagraph.text: positively identifies the individual from at least 2 forms of identification, which may include an age of majority card, military identification, or passport; and
provides a physical description of the individual, including the sex, race, any distinguishing features, and approximate age, height, and weight of the individual;

paragraph.text: a statement indicating whether or not the person making the transaction is personally known to the dealer; and
the signature of the person from whom the precious metal object or personal property is acquired and the dealer or employee who accepted the precious metal object.

subsection.text: In addition to any other information required by the Secretary, the records of a pawnbroker shall include, for each item pawned:

paragraph.text: the type of item;
its manufacturer, model number, year of manufacture if known, and serial number if known; and
its color and size.

section.text: Unless otherwise authorized by the Secretary, a dealer shall keep the records required by this subtitle, at a location within the State, for 3 years after the date of the transaction.

paragraph.text: A dealer shall submit the required information from each record to the primary law enforcement unit in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

If the dealer transacts business in accordance with § 12–206(b) of this title, the dealer also shall submit the required information from the records to the local law enforcement unit in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.
On the request of a dealer, the Secretary shall provide to the dealer a list of local law enforcement units.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the dealer shall submit the records by transmitting the required information from the records electronically, in a format acceptable to the receiving law enforcement unit, by noon of the next business day.
A dealer may request an extension of up to 48 hours to submit the records required under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Each record, submitted to the primary law enforcement unit and, if applicable, local law enforcement unit, shall include:

paragraph.text: the license number of the dealer;
the location of each item listed in the record; and
the information required under § 12–302 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The required information from a record submitted under this section:

paragraph.text: shall be kept confidential;
is not a public record; and
is not subject to Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The primary law enforcement unit shall adopt a procedure for a dealer to amend a record required to be submitted under this section.
A law enforcement unit may cease to maintain a record submitted under this section after 1 year from the date the law enforcement unit receives the copy.

sub-subparagraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a dealer who acquires a precious metal object shall keep it in the county where the dealer holds a license from the time of acquisition until at least 18 days after submitting a copy of a record of its acquisition under § 12–304 of this subtitle.
Notwithstanding subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the 18–day holding period established under this subparagraph applies to a precious metal object that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a dealer licensed in Prince George’s County acquired in a pawn transaction; and
an individual seeks to redeem by presenting the original ticket issued as part of the pawn transaction.

subparagraph.text: A dealer who holds a license in Prince George’s County and who acquires a precious metal object, other than a pawned precious metal object described in subparagraph (i)2 of this paragraph, shall keep it in Prince George’s County from the time of acquisition until at least 30 days after submitting a copy of a record of its acquisition under § 12–304 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A dealer who acquires a precious metal object at an event which takes place at a location other than the dealer’s fixed business address shall place the object and a record of its acquisition at a location in accordance with subsection (d)(1) or (2) of this section by the next business day after acquiring the object.

In partial compliance with the 18–day holding requirement under this subsection, a dealer may maintain an object and the record of its acquisition at a location other than the dealer’s fixed business address, if the local law enforcement unit in the jurisdiction where the item was acquired provides written approval.
A dealer may submit to the primary law enforcement unit a written request for a shorter holding period for a specific precious metal object.
Within 48 hours after the primary law enforcement unit receives a request, the primary law enforcement unit shall approve or deny the request.
After inspecting the precious metal object, the primary law enforcement unit may authorize in writing a shorter holding period.
If the primary law enforcement unit denies the request, the primary law enforcement unit shall state the reasons in writing.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a dealer may not alter a precious metal object before or during the holding period.

During the holding period, a dealer may chemically test a precious metal object to determine its metal content or value if the dealer does not alter the precious metal object so as to affect its identification or value.

subsection.text: During the holding period for a precious metal object, a dealer shall keep the precious metal object and the record of its acquisition in:

paragraph.text: the place of business of the dealer; or
a storage facility specified in the license application of the dealer.

subsection.text: A dealer shall allow an authorized law enforcement officer or agent, on request, to enter the place of business or storage premises of the dealer during business hours to inspect a record required to be maintained under this title or precious metal object as part of a stolen property investigation or an investigation of a violation of this title.

paragraph.text: On request of the dealer, the officer or agent shall make the inspection in the presence of the dealer or an agent of the dealer.
If the dealer refuses to allow access or produce the record or precious metal object for inspection, the officer or agent shall seek a search warrant.

A warrant authorizing an administrative inspection for possible regulatory violations shall be issued if the officer or agent establishes probable cause for the selection of the place of business in question for inspection and that the inspection will be reasonably limited in time, place, and scope.

subsection.text: A dealer who refuses to allow access or to produce records, precious metal objects for inspection on request, shall be subject to the provisions of § 12-209 of this title and, in addition, may be assessed a civil penalty as provided in subsection (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may impose on a licensee who violates this section a civil penalty not exceeding $500 for each violation.
In setting the amount of a civil penalty under this subsection, the Secretary shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any previous violations;
the harmful effect of the violation on the complainant, the public, and the business of the dealer or pawnbroker; and
any other relevant factors.

subsection.text: This section applies to all dealers and all pawnbrokers wherever located in the State.

A dealer or pawnbroker shall release to the primary law enforcement unit an item of personal property, other than a security or printed evidence of indebtedness, located at the place of business of the dealer or pawnbroker if:

paragraph.text: the item is established to have been stolen;
the owner of the item or victim of the theft has positively identified the item;
the owner of the item or the agent or designee of the owner has provided an affidavit of ownership;
the stolen property report describes the item by:

subparagraph.text: a date;
initials;
an insurance record;
a photograph;
a sales receipt;
a serial number;
specific damage;
a statement of the facts that show that the item is one of a kind; or
a unique engraving; and

paragraph.text: the primary law enforcement unit provides to the dealer or pawnbroker a receipt that describes the item and that notifies the dealer or pawnbroker of the dealer’s or pawnbroker’s right to file an application for a statement of charges against the individual who sold the item to the dealer or pawnbroker, or other alleged thief for theft under § 7-104 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: A dealer shall retain in the dealer’s place of business, for an additional period of 12 days, any item of personal property or other valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidence of indebtedness, if:

paragraph.text: the primary law enforcement unit requests that the dealer retain the item;
the primary law enforcement unit has reasonable cause to believe the item has been stolen; and
the item has not been identified under subsection (b)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: When a primary law enforcement unit no longer needs an item for evidence, the primary law enforcement unit shall give the item to its owner.
A dealer or pawnbroker who is required to release an item under this section is not entitled to reimbursement for any pledge or purchase price paid for the item from:

paragraph.text: the primary law enforcement unit to which the dealer released the item;
the owner of the item; or
the victim of the theft.

subsection.text: If the owner of the item or the victim of the theft chooses to participate in the prosecution of the alleged identified thief, then the charges of theft from the owner or the victim of the theft and the charges of theft from the dealer or pawnbroker may be heard in a joint trial.

The Secretary shall distribute to licensed dealers or post on the Department’s website the name of the primary law enforcement unit responsible for enforcing this title in each jurisdiction, including municipalities.

section.text: A person that sells an item to a dealer shall sign a statement, under the penalties of perjury, that the person is the owner of the item.

subsection.text: If there is probable cause to believe that a violation of this title has occurred, the Secretary shall have the authority to issue subpoenas for records, reports, or articles in connection with any investigation or administrative proceeding under this title.
If a licensee or a licensee’s employee fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section, on petition of the Secretary, a circuit court may compel compliance with the subpoena.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not do business as a dealer in the State unless the person has a license.

paragraph.text: A person who willfully or knowingly violates this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

Each associate, employee, manager, or partner who participates in or consents to a violation of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
Each violation of this title is a separate offense.
The Secretary may impose on a person who violates any provision of this title a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
In setting the amount of the penalty, the Secretary shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
any history of previous violations by the violator; and
any other relevant factors.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: This title is the Maryland Secondhand Precious Metal Object Dealers and Pawnbrokers Act.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Business” means a commercial entity that provides locksmith services.
“Employee” means an individual employed by a licensed locksmith to provide locksmith services on behalf of the licensed locksmith.
“Fixed business address” means a single physical location where a licensee conducts business and at which the licensee or an employee of the licensee is available:

paragraph.text: during normal business hours; or
other hours as provided in the application for the license.

subsection.text: “License” means a license issued by the Secretary to provide locksmith services.
“Licensed locksmith” means, unless the context requires otherwise, a business that is licensed by the Secretary to provide locksmith services.
“Local law enforcement unit” means the Department of State Police, a police department in the State, or sheriff in the State:

paragraph.text: designated by the county or municipal governing body for a licensee with an in–State fixed business address; or
designated by the Secretary for a licensee with an out–of–state fixed business address.

subsection.text: “Provide locksmith services” means to engage professionally and for compensation in:

paragraph.text: repairing, rebuilding, rekeying, repinning, recombinating, adjusting, or installing mechanical, electrical, or electromechanical locking devices, safes, vaults, or safe deposit boxes; or

operating a mechanical, electrical, or electromechanical locking device or opening safes, vaults, or safe deposit boxes by a means other than that intended by the manufacturer of such locking devices.

section.text: The purpose of this title is to safeguard the life, health, and property of the residents of Maryland to promote their welfare by regulating persons that provide locksmith services.
The provisions of this title may not be construed to prohibit the following:

paragraph.text: bona fide sales demonstrations to locksmiths or locksmith suppliers by sales representatives who are not licensed;
emergency opening services by members of police departments, fire departments, or other government agencies in their official line of duty in order to protect against loss of life or property;
the acquisition, making, or use of any key duplication or key blanks;
the replacing of a removable or interchangeable core or recombinating a cylinder in a lock that was specifically designed by the manufacturer to be changed by the end user by use of a key;
the installation, repair, replacement, or rebuilding of a lock by the manufacturer of the lock;
the installation, repair, replacement, or rebuilding of an automotive lock by an automotive repair and service facility, the lock manufacturer, or the manufacturer’s agent;
the installation of locks by building trades personnel on projects that require a building permit;
the installation or replacement of locks by a retailer or the retailer’s agent:

subparagraph.text: on the premises of the retailer; or
off the premises of the retailer if the installation or replacement of locks is incidental to the retailer’s normal course of business;

paragraph.text: the installation or replacement of locks by a security systems technician who is licensed under Title 18 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article; and
the installation, repair, replacement, rekeying, or adjusting of locks or lock components for property by an employee or agent of the property owner or a management company.

section.text: The Secretary may adopt and enforce regulations to carry out this title.
The Secretary shall pay all money collected under this title into the General Fund of the State.
Except as otherwise provided in this title, a business shall be licensed by the Secretary before the business and employees of the business provide locksmith services in the State.

subsection.text: The owner of a business or the owner’s designee shall apply on behalf of the business for a license under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary an application on the form that the Secretary provides;
submit a passport–size photograph, taken within 6 months immediately preceding the date of the filing of the application, of each of the following individuals:

sub-subparagraph.text: the owner of the business; and
each employee of the applicant;

subparagraph.text: provide any other documents or information required by this section or required by the Secretary; and
pay to the Secretary an application fee set by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The application fee is nonrefundable.

subsection.text: The applicant owner or designee shall sign the application under oath.
In addition to any other information that the Secretary requires, the application shall state:

paragraph.text: the name, birth date, and residence address of the following individuals:

subparagraph.text: the applicant owner or designee; and
each employee of the applicant;

paragraph.text: the fixed business address of the applicant;
a telephone number at which the applicant can be reached during normal business hours, and, if applicable, an electronic mail address;
each address where the applicant has conducted any business during the 36 months before application;
the driver’s license number of the applicant owner or designee and each employee of the applicant; and
the name of the insurer and policy number of the general liability insurance coverage required under § 12.5–205 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The application form provided by the Secretary shall contain a statement advising the applicant that willfully making a false statement on an application is a misdemeanor, subject to a fine or imprisonment or both, as provided under § 12.5–504 of this title.

section.text: Before an individual may begin work for a licensee as an employee:

paragraph.text: the licensee shall submit to the Secretary, on the form that the Secretary provides, the name of the individual; and
the individual shall apply for a national and State criminal history records check required under § 12.5–204(b) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this section, “Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

paragraph.text: The owner of a business that is an applicant for a license under § 12.5–202 of this subtitle and an individual whose name is required to be submitted to the Secretary under § 12.5–203 of this subtitle shall apply to the Central Repository for a national and State criminal history records check on a form approved by the Director of the Central Repository.

As a part of an application to the Central Repository for a national and State criminal history records check, the owner of a business that is an applicant and an individual whose name is required to be submitted to the Secretary under § 12.5–203 of this subtitle shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: two complete sets of legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation;
the fee authorized under § 10–221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to the State criminal history records; and
the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

subsection.text: A licensee or applicant may pay for the costs borne by the employee or other individual requiring a criminal history records check under subsection (b) of this section.
The Central Repository shall provide to the Secretary:

paragraph.text: the national and State criminal history records of each individual requiring a criminal history records check under subsection (b) of this section and issue a printed statement listing any convictions and pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal charge;

an update of the initial criminal history records check for an individual requiring a criminal history records check and issue a revised printed statement listing any convictions and pleas of guilty or nolo contendere to any criminal charge occurring in the State after the date of the initial criminal history records check; and
an acknowledged receipt of the application for a criminal history records check by an individual requiring a criminal history records check.
Information obtained by the Secretary from the Central Repository under this section:

subparagraph.text: is confidential;
may not be redisseminated; and
may be used only for the license purpose authorized by this title.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not preclude the Secretary from notifying a licensee or an applicant of the approval or disqualification of the employee for employment based on information obtained by the Secretary under this section.

subsection.text: The subject of a criminal history records check under this section may contest the contents of the printed statement issued by the Central Repository as provided in § 10–223 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

The Secretary shall verify periodically the continued employment or licensure of individuals requiring criminal history records checks in accordance with regulations adopted by the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
Each licensed locksmith shall maintain general liability insurance:

paragraph.text: in the amount of at least $300,000;
with coverage appropriate for the individual’s circumstances; and
in accordance with the regulations adopted by the Secretary under this section.

subsection.text: A licensee shall give the Secretary notice of the cancellation of insurance at least 10 days before the effective date of the cancellation.
The Secretary shall issue a license to each applicant that meets the requirements of this subtitle and on receipt of:

paragraph.text: a complete national and State criminal history record report from the Central Repository in accordance with § 12.5–204 of this subtitle; and
documentation of current general liability insurance in the amount required under § 12.5–205 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall determine the size, form, and content of any license certificate that the Secretary issues.
The Secretary:

paragraph.text: may issue a license only for a fixed business address; but
may not issue a license for an address that is:

subparagraph.text: a hotel or motel room;
a motor vehicle;
a post office box; or
a location that does not meet the qualifications of a fixed business address as defined in § 12.5–101(d) of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary may not issue a license to an individual who is 18 years old or younger.
A license issued under this title is not transferable.

Each licensed locksmith shall issue a photo identification card to each individual providing locksmith services on behalf of the licensed locksmith, including each individual identified as an employee of the licensed locksmith under § 12.5–202 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the licensed locksmith shall determine the size, form, and content of a photo identification card that the licensed locksmith issues.
The photo identification card issued by a licensed locksmith under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: be composed of durable material;
include a current passport–size photograph of the individual to whom the photo identification card is issued; and
include the license number and license expiration date of the licensed locksmith’s license.

section.text: While a license is in effect, the license authorizes the licensee and the employees of the licensee to provide locksmith services in the State.

subsection.text: A license is issued for a term of 2 years.
Unless a licensee meets the insurance requirements of § 12.5–205 of this subtitle, the Secretary may not renew the license of the licensee.

paragraph.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 2–year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the second anniversary of the effective date of the license.
A licensee that meets the requirements of this section may obtain a renewal of a license before the license expires for an additional 2–year term.
Once expired, a license may not be renewed.

subsection.text: At least 60 days before a license expires, the Secretary shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form;
a form that allows a licensee to update the information submitted in the original application or state that the information is current and accurate;
except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, a form that requires the licensee to agree to continue to comply with each requirement applicable to the original application; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Secretary must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: The Secretary may require a licensee to submit a national and State criminal history records check with the renewal application.
The Secretary shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: A licensee may change the fixed business address for which a license is issued only if the licensee:

subparagraph.text: submits to the Secretary an application to transfer the license to a new business location on a form that the Secretary provides; and
receives the written approval of the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Within 45 days after the application is filed with the Secretary, the Secretary shall approve or disapprove the application and notify the licensee of the approval or disapproval, in writing.
If the Secretary approves a proposed change of fixed business address, the licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Secretary a current list of names of each employee to be employed at the new location; and
attach the written approval of the Secretary to the license until an amended license is received by the licensee.

subsection.text: The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.
Each licensee shall display the license conspicuously in the place of business of the licensee.
A licensee and an employee of a licensee shall:

paragraph.text: carry a valid photo identification card issued by a licensed locksmith under § 12.5–207 of this subtitle at all times the licensee or employee of a licensee is engaged in providing locksmith services; and
display the valid photo identification card as required by regulation.

subsection.text: If a photo identification card is lost or destroyed, the licensee immediately shall notify the licensed locksmith that issued the photo identification card.

paragraph.text: To change the name of a licensee on a license, a licensee shall submit to the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: an application on the form provided by the Secretary;
the license of the licensee;
any documentation about the name change that the Secretary requires; and
the fee set by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: On receipt of the application, fee, and any required documentation, the Secretary shall issue a new license bearing the new name of the licensee.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 12.5–212 of this subtitle, the Secretary may deny a license to an applicant, reprimand a licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee or an agent, employee, manager, or partner of the applicant or licensee:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license or photo identification card for the applicant or licensee or for another person;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license or photo identification card;
presents or attempts to present the license or photo identification card of another licensee or employee of a licensee as the applicant’s or licensee’s license or photo identification card;
uses or attempts to use an expired, suspended, or revoked license or false photo identification card;
has a similar license or certificate denied, suspended, or revoked in another jurisdiction;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of a:

sub-subparagraph.text: felony; or
misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to be involved in providing locksmith services;

subparagraph.text: knowingly employs or knowingly continues to employ an individual who, under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a felony that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the employee to be involved in providing locksmith services; or
a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the employee to be involved in providing locksmith services;

subparagraph.text: fails to maintain the liability insurance required under § 12.5–205 of this subtitle;
engages in a pattern of unfair or deceptive trade practices under the Consumer Protection Act, as determined by a final administrative order or judicial decision;
knowingly uses or permits the use of any of the licensee’s or an employee of a licensee’s skills, tools, or facilities for the commission of any crime;
willfully fails to provide or willfully misrepresents any information required to be provided under this title;
violates this title; or
violates a regulation adopted under this title.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the Secretary may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Secretary shall consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of an applicant or licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(1)(vi) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;
with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee to act as a locksmith;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10–226 of the State Government Article, before the Secretary takes any final action under § 12.5–211 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Secretary.
The Secretary shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary may administer oaths in a proceeding under this section.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Secretary may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Secretary in a contested case, as defined in § 10–202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Secretary shall inform each local law enforcement unit of each license that is issued, renewed, changed to a new business location, denied, suspended, or revoked.
Each licensed locksmith shall include on each invoice or receipt for services the following information regarding each service call:

paragraph.text: the address where the services were provided by the locksmith;
the type of lock being serviced;
the vehicle identification number, if applicable;
the quoted cost of the service provided to the customer prior to agreeing to provide the service; and
the actual cost of the service paid by the customer.

section.text: Unless otherwise authorized by the Secretary, a licensed locksmith shall keep a copy of each invoice or receipt for services required by this subtitle, at the fixed business address provided by the licensee to the Secretary, for 3 years after the date of the service call and, on reasonable notice from the Department, make required records available for inspection by the Department.

paragraph.text: A licensed locksmith shall provide to a local law enforcement unit or the Department a copy of each invoice or receipt for services requested by either a local law enforcement unit or the Department.
The Secretary shall encourage licensed locksmiths to develop a system for maintaining the records required by this subtitle electronically.

subsection.text: On a request for an invoice or a receipt for services under subsection (a) of this section, the licensed locksmith shall submit the item by one of the following methods:

paragraph.text: by delivering or mailing a copy of the invoice or receipt for services within 5 business days after receiving the request; or

by transmitting a copy of the invoice or receipt for services electronically, in a format acceptable to the receiving local law enforcement unit or the Department, within 2 business days after receiving the request.

subsection.text: Each copy of an invoice or a receipt for services, submitted to the local law enforcement unit or the Department, shall include:

paragraph.text: the license number of the licensed locksmith; and
the information required under § 12.5–301 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A copy of an invoice or receipt for services submitted under this section:

paragraph.text: shall be kept confidential;
is not a public record; and
is not subject to Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: A local law enforcement unit or the Department may destroy the copy of an invoice or receipt for services submitted under this section after 1 year from the date the local law enforcement unit or the Department receives the copy.

section.text: Each locksmith advertisement, business card, or any other means of providing notice to the public of the business providing locksmith services shall include the name of the licensed locksmith and the license number of the licensed locksmith.

A person may not knowingly use or permit the use of the licensee’s or an employee of the licensee’s skills, tools, or facilities to aid or abet an unlicensed locksmith in any activity for which a locksmith license is required for the commission of a crime.
A licensed locksmith or employee of a licensed locksmith may not willfully or deliberately disregard any building or safety laws of the State or local government unit.

A licensed locksmith or employee of a licensed locksmith may not fail in any material respect to complete the installation, repair, opening, or modification of a lock for the price stated in the contract for services.

Except for a violation of § 12.5–505(a) of this subtitle, a person that violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a person may not act as, offer to act as, hold oneself out as, or impersonate a locksmith in the State unless the person is a licensee or employee of a licensee.

A person that violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on first conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 and, on second or subsequent conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000.

Subject to the notice and hearing provisions of Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, the Secretary may bring a civil administrative action against a person that violates § 12.5–505(a) of this subtitle.
After a hearing, if the Secretary finds that a person has violated § 12.5–505(a) of this subtitle, the Secretary may:

paragraph.text: order the person to cease and desist from unlawful practice; and
impose a civil penalty not exceeding $100 for each day of unlawful practice.

subsection.text: Any person aggrieved by a decision and order of the Secretary under this section may take an appeal as allowed in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
This section applies only if there is no greater criminal penalty provided under this title or other applicable law.
A person that engages in repeated violations of the provisions of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000.

section.text: This title may be cited as the “Maryland Locksmiths Act”.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Trading stamp” means a stamp or other similar device issued in connection with the retail sale of goods or services, as a cash discount or for any other marketing purpose, that is redeemable for cash, goods, or services.
“Trading stamp” does not include a redeemable device that:

subparagraph.text: a manufacturer or packer of an article uses to advertise or sell the article; or
a magazine, newspaper, or other publication issues and redeems.

subsection.text: “Trading stamp company” means a person who, in any way:

paragraph.text: distributes trading stamps for retail issuance by others; or
redeems trading stamps for retailers.

section.text: A person must be registered with the Secretary of State whenever the person does business as a trading stamp company in the State.

subsection.text: On or before July 1 of each year, each trading stamp company shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the Secretary of State:

subparagraph.text: a statement of registration;
samples of its current trading stamps, trading stamp collection books, trading stamp redemption catalogues, and trading stamp distribution and redemption agreement forms;
a short form of its balance sheet for its last fiscal year, certified by an independent certified public accountant; and
a bond in accordance with § 13-104 of this title; and

paragraph.text: pay to the Secretary of State a fee of $25.

subsection.text: The statement of registration shall include:

paragraph.text: the name and principal address of the trading stamp company;
the state of its incorporation;
the names and addresses of its principal officers, partners, or owners;
the address of its principal office in the State;
the name and address of its principal officer, employee, or agent in the State;
the address of each place in the State where trading stamps will be redeemed; and

the gross income of the trading stamp company from its trading stamp business in the State for its last fiscal year, certified by an independent certified public accountant, unless it submits the maximum bond under § 13-104 of this title.

subsection.text: The bond required by this subtitle shall be:

paragraph.text: payable to the State;
conditioned that the trading stamp company shall redeem its trading stamps whenever rightful holders present them for redemption; and
executed by:

subparagraph.text: the trading stamp company; and
a corporate surety qualified to do business in the State.

paragraph.text: The amount of the bond shall be based on the gross income of the principal obligor from trading stamp business in the State during its last fiscal year.
The amount of the bond is:

subparagraph.text: $25,000, if the principal obligor has not previously done business in the State or if the gross income was not more than $250,000;
$50,000, if the gross income was more than $250,000 but not more than $500,000;
$75,000, if the gross income was more than $500,000 but not more than $750,000; and
$100,000, if the gross income was more than $750,000.

paragraph.text: If a trading stamp company fails to redeem its trading stamps, each rightful holder of its trading stamps may make a claim against the bond in accordance with this section.
For purposes of this section, a rightful holder includes a retailer that rightfully holds trading stamps for issuance to customers.

subsection.text: The claim shall be submitted to the Secretary of State within 3 months after the failure to redeem trading stamps.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State promptly shall determine whether the trading stamp company should have redeemed its trading stamps.
If the Secretary of State so determines, the Secretary of State shall notify the trading stamp company of that determination.

If the trading stamp company fails to redeem its trading stamps within 10 days after the notification, the Secretary of State shall publish notice of the failure in 3 consecutive issues of 1 or more newspapers that have general circulation in the State.
The notice shall state the time within which proofs of claim and the trading stamps on which they are based must be submitted to the Secretary of State.

subsection.text: Proofs of claim and the trading stamps on which they are based shall be submitted to the Secretary of State within 3 months after the first publication of the notice.
Promptly after the end of the 3-month period, the Secretary of State shall determine the validity of all claims.
The surety shall pay to the Secretary of State the lesser of:

paragraph.text: the amount necessary to satisfy:

subparagraph.text: all valid claims; and
reasonable administrative costs to determine and pay the claims; or

paragraph.text: the amount of the bond.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State promptly shall:

paragraph.text: distribute equitably to the claimants the proceeds of the bond, less reasonable administrative costs; and
destroy the trading stamps surrendered to the Secretary of State.
On the effective date of each new bond that a trading stamp company submits, all liability on earlier bonds ends.
A rightful holder who makes a claim under this section on or after that date shall make the claim only against the new bond.

subsection.text: A trading stamp company may not do business as a trading stamp company in the State unless:

paragraph.text: a rightful holder may redeem trading stamps for cash if the trading stamps have a total cash value of at least 25 cents; and
the cash redemption value of the trading stamps is at least equal to the highest cash redemption value that the trading stamp company offers in any other jurisdiction.
Each trading stamp collection book shall contain a notice that states:
“If the total cash value of your trading stamps is at least 25 cents, they may be redeemed for cash instead of goods.
The cash value of a filled book of trading stamps is at least $(cash value to be stated)”.
The notice shall be printed in 12 point or larger type on the inside front cover of the book.
The trading stamp company shall display the same notice conspicuously at each place where the trading stamp company redeems trading stamps.

section.text: Each retailer shall display conspicuously at each place where the retailer issues trading stamps the address of the nearest place where the trading stamps may be redeemed.
At least 90 days before a trading stamp company ends or suspends the redemption of trading stamps in the State, the trading stamp company shall:

paragraph.text: notify the Secretary of State in writing of its intention to end or suspend the redemption of trading stamps; and
mail a copy of the notice to each retailer in the State that, within the previous 12 months, issued trading stamps that the trading stamp company is bound to redeem.

section.text: While doing business as a trading stamp company in the State, a trading stamp company may not:

paragraph.text: commit fraud;
make a false representation; or
use a lottery.

section.text: A person who violates this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Business opportunity” means an arrangement between a buyer and seller in which:

paragraph.text: the seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller provides to the buyer products, equipment, supplies, or services that enable the buyer to start a business;

the buyer is required to pay the seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller $300 or more during the period beginning any time before commencing operations and ending 6 months after commencing operations of the business; and
the seller represents, directly or indirectly, orally or in writing, that:

subparagraph.text: the seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller will help the buyer in finding locations for the use or operation of vending machines, racks, display cases, or other similar devices on premises that are not owned or leased by the buyer or seller;
the seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller will help the buyer in finding outlets or accounts for the buyer’s products or services;
the seller or a person specified by the seller will buy products made, produced, fabricated, grown, bred, or modified by the buyer;
the seller guarantees that the buyer will receive from the business income an amount that exceeds the price paid to the seller;

if the buyer is not satisfied with the business, the seller will refund all or part of the price paid to the seller, or repurchase any of the products, equipment, or supplies provided by the seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller; or
the seller will provide a marketing plan.

subsection.text: “Buyer” means a person who buys or leases products, equipment, supplies, or services in connection with a business opportunity.
“Commissioner” means the Securities Commissioner in the Office of the Attorney General.

“Marketing plan” means advice or training that a seller or a person recommended or referred by the seller provides to the buyer, relating to the sale of any products, equipment, supplies, or services, and the advice or training includes preparing or providing:

paragraph.text: promotional literature, brochures, pamphlets, or advertising materials;
training regarding the promotion, operation, or management of the business opportunity; or
operational, managerial, or financial guidelines or assistance.

subsection.text: “Seller” means a person who sells or leases products, equipment, supplies, or services in connection with a business opportunity.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the sale of business opportunities is a field in which investment problems and deceptive practices are common; and
this subtitle is needed to regulate this field adequately and prevent these deceptive practices.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies to an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity if:

paragraph.text: the offeree or buyer is a resident of the State;
the business opportunity will be or is operated in the State;
the offer to sell is made in the State; or
the offer to buy is accepted in the State.
For purposes of this section, an offer to sell is made in the State, whether or not either party is then present in the State, if the offer:

subparagraph.text: originates from the State; or
is directed by the offeror to the State and is received at:

sub-subparagraph.text: the place to which it is directed; or
a post office in the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, an offer to sell is not made in the State only because the publisher circulates or there is circulated on the publisher’s behalf in the State:

subparagraph.text: a newspaper or other publication of general, regular, and paid circulation that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is not published in the State; or
is published in the State but has had more than two-thirds of its circulation outside the State during the past 12 months; or

subparagraph.text: a radio or television program that originates outside the State and is received in the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, an offer to buy is accepted in the State if acceptance:

subparagraph.text: is communicated to the offeror in the State; and
has not been communicated previously to the offeror, orally or in writing, outside the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, acceptance is communicated to the offeror in the State, whether or not either party is then present in the State, if:

subparagraph.text: the offeree directs acceptance to the offeror in the State reasonably believing the offeror to be in the State; and
the acceptance is received at:

sub-subparagraph.text: the place to which it is directed; or
a post office in the State.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a sale of an ongoing business if the owner of the business sells and intends to sell only that one business opportunity;
a not-for-profit sale, for less than $500, of sales demonstration equipment, materials, or samples;
an offer to sell or sale of a franchise registered or exempt from registration under Subtitle 2 of this title;
an offer to sell or sale of a business if the offer or sale is regulated under the Maryland Gasohol and Gasoline Products Marketing Act or the federal Petroleum Marketing Practices Act;

an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity with a marketing plan made in conjunction with the licensing of a federally registered trademark or service mark, provided that the seller has a minimum net worth of $1,000,000 as determined on the basis of the seller’s most recent audited financial statement prepared within 13 months of the first offer that the seller makes in the State; or
any other sale or transaction if the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: exempts the sale or transaction, by regulation or order, as not being within the purposes of this subtitle; and
finds the registration of the sale or transaction to be unnecessary, inappropriate, not in the public interest, or not for the protection of investors.

subsection.text: Net worth may be determined on a consolidated basis if:

paragraph.text: at least 80% of the seller is owned by one person; and

the person that owns at least 80% of the seller expressly guarantees the obligations of the seller with regard to the offer or sale of a business opportunity that the seller seeks to exclude under this paragraph.

section.text: The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under this subtitle.
To enforce this subtitle, the Commissioner may pass orders and adopt regulations and forms.
The Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: publish information about violations of this subtitle and of regulations adopted and orders passed under it;
report to the appropriate law enforcement officer information about violations of this subtitle; and
help, develop, and hold programs of public education and information about this subtitle.

section.text: The Commissioner may investigate in or outside the State to:

paragraph.text: determine if a person has violated this subtitle;
adopt regulations or forms under this subtitle; or
enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may hold public hearings in connection with an investigation under this subtitle.

Unless otherwise provided in this subtitle or in regulations adopted under it, the Commissioner shall hold hearings authorized by this subtitle in accordance with Title 10 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: Whenever the Commissioner determines that a person has engaged or is about to engage in an act or practice that constitutes a violation of this subtitle or a violation of a regulation adopted or order passed under this subtitle, the Commissioner may, without a prior hearing, pass a summary order directing the person to cease and desist from engaging in the activity that constitutes a violation.
The summary order shall provide:

subparagraph.text: notice of the opportunity for a hearing before the Commissioner to determine whether the cease and desist order should be vacated, modified, or entered as final; and

notice that the Commissioner shall enter the order as final if the person subject to the cease and desist order fails to request a hearing within 15 days after the receipt of the cease and desist order.

paragraph.text: Whenever the Commissioner determines after notice and a hearing that a person has engaged in any act or practice constituting a violation of this subtitle, the Commissioner may in the discretion of the Commissioner and in addition to taking any other action authorized under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: pass a final cease and desist order against the person;
bar the person from engaging in the offer and sale of business opportunities in the State; or
take any combination of the actions specified in this section.

paragraph.text: The person subject to the cease and desist order may waive the right to a hearing.
If a person subject to a cease and desist order waives the right to a hearing, the Commissioner is not required to hold a hearing to take any action under subsection (a)(3) of this section.

Whenever the Commissioner determines that any person has engaged in or is about to engage in an act or practice constituting a violation of this subtitle or a violation of a regulation or order under this subtitle, the Commissioner may sue in the circuit court to obtain one or more of the following remedies:

subparagraph.text: a temporary restraining order;
a temporary or permanent injunction;
a declaratory judgment;
the appointment of a receiver or conservator for the defendant or the defendant’s assets;
a freeze of the defendant’s assets;
a civil penalty up to a maximum amount of $5,000 for any single violation of this subtitle;
restitution;
rescission; or
any other relief as the court finds just.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may not be required to post a bond in any action under this section.

section.text: In connection with a hearing, investigation, or other proceeding under this subtitle, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: administer oaths;
receive evidence; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce evidence.

subsection.text: A person is not excused from attending, testifying, or producing evidence before the Commissioner, in a proceeding brought by the Commissioner, or in obedience to a subpoena of the Commissioner on the ground that the testimony or evidence may:

paragraph.text: tend to incriminate the person; or
subject the person to a penalty or forfeiture.

If a person claims the privilege against self-incrimination as to a specific subject, and is then compelled to testify or produce evidence on that subject, the person may not be prosecuted or subjected to a penalty or forfeiture in connection with that subject.
A person who testifies is not exempt from prosecution and punishment for perjury or contempt committed while testifying.

section.text: A person may not sell or offer to sell any business opportunity in the State or to any prospective buyer in the State unless the business opportunity is registered under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In order to register a business opportunity, the seller shall file with the Commissioner one of the following disclosure documents:

paragraph.text: a uniform franchise offering circular prepared in accordance with the guidelines adopted by the North American Securities Administrators Association, Inc., as amended through January 1, 1996;

a disclosure document prepared in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission rule entitled “Disclosure Requirements and Prohibitions Concerning Franchising and Business Opportunity Ventures” under 16 C.F.R. Part 436;
a disclosure document prepared in accordance with § 14-114 of this subtitle; or
any other document that the Commissioner specifies by regulation or order.

subsection.text: The seller shall attach to the disclosure document filed in accordance with subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: the cover sheet required under § 14-114(b) of this subtitle;
the consent to service of process required under subsection (c) of this section; and
the filing fee required under subsection (d) of this section.

Every seller shall file, in a form that the Commissioner requires, an irrevocable consent appointing the Commissioner as the seller’s registered agent in any noncriminal suit, action, or proceeding against the seller or the successor or personal representative of the seller that arises under this subtitle.
After the consent has been filed, the consent has the same force and validity as if served personally on the person filing the consent.
Service may be made by delivering a copy of the process to the office of the Commissioner.
Service made under paragraph (3) of this subsection is not effective unless:

subparagraph.text: the plaintiff or petitioner, who may be the Commissioner, promptly sends notice of the service and a copy of the process by registered or certified mail to the defendant or respondent, at the address on file with the Commissioner; and

the plaintiff’s affidavit of compliance under this subsection is filed in the noncriminal suit, action, or proceeding on or before the return date of the process, if any, or within further time as the court allows.

subsection.text: The initial fee to file an application to register a business opportunity offering is $250.
