paragraph.text: A business opportunity offering registration becomes effective at midnight on the 10th business day after the day on which the seller files all required documents for registration, provided that no order has been passed or proceeding is pending under § 14-119 of this subtitle.
By order, the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: may waive or reduce the time period between the date of the filing and the date that the registration is effective if the seller has filed all required documents for registration; or
may postpone the date that the registration becomes effective at midnight on the 10th business day after the day on which the seller files an amendment to the registration.

subsection.text: The registration is effective for 1 year from the date of effectiveness.
The Commissioner may by regulation require the filing of all proposed literature or advertising prior to its use.
The Commissioner may by regulation require the filing of sales reports.

A person may not sell or offer to sell a business opportunity unless a written disclosure document, filed under § 14–113.1(a) of this subtitle, is delivered to the buyer at least 10 full business days before the buyer executes a contract or an agreement that imposes a binding legal obligation on the buyer or the payment by a buyer of any consideration in connection with the sale or offer to sell a business opportunity.
The disclosure statement shall include a cover sheet that contains only:

paragraph.text: a heading, in boldface capital letters in 10–point or larger type, that states “disclosure required by Maryland law”;

under the heading, in 10–point or larger type, the following statement: “The State of Maryland has not reviewed and does not approve, recommend, endorse, or sponsor any business opportunity. The information in this disclosure statement has not been verified by the State. If you have any questions about this investment, see an attorney before you sign a contract or contact the Division of Securities in the Office of the Attorney General. You are to be given 10 business days to review this document before signing any contract or agreement or making any payment to the seller or the seller’s representative.”; and
the current address and telephone number of the Division of Securities.

subsection.text: After the cover sheet, the disclosure statement shall include the following information:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the seller;
whether the seller is doing business as an individual, partnership, or corporation;
the names under which the seller has done, is doing, or intends to do business;
the name of any parent or affiliated company that will engage in business transactions with buyers or that takes responsibility for statements of the seller;

the name, address, and title of each of the seller’s officers, directors, trustees, general partners, general managers, principal executives, and others responsible for the seller’s activities that relate to the sale of business opportunities;
the names and residential addresses of the salespersons who engage in the sale or offer to sell a business opportunity in the State;
prior business experience of the seller relating to business opportunities, including:

subparagraph.text: the name, address, and a description of any business opportunity previously offered by the seller;
the length of time the seller has offered each business opportunity; and
the length of time the seller has conducted the business opportunity currently being offered to the buyer;

paragraph.text: a full and detailed description of the acts and services that the seller agrees to perform for the buyer;

subparagraph.text: whether the seller or any person described in item (5) of this subsection has been convicted of a felony, has pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge, or has been adjudged liable in a civil action, if the felony or civil action involved fraud, embezzlement, fraudulent conversion, or misappropriation of property; and
if so, the court, date of the conviction or the judgment, and any penalty imposed or damages assessed;
whether the seller or any person described in item (5) of this subsection is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: a currently effective order of the Federal Trade Commission; or

a currently effective order that enjoins or restricts business activity as a result of an action brought by a public agency, including an action that affects a license as a real estate broker, associate real estate broker, or real estate salesperson; and

subparagraph.text: if so, the date, nature, and issuer of the order and any penalty imposed;

paragraph.text: whether the seller or any person identified in item (5) of this subsection has filed for bankruptcy, been adjudged bankrupt, been reorganized due to insolvency, or was an owner, principal officer, or general partner of any other person that has filed bankruptcy, been adjudged bankrupt, or was reorganized due to insolvency during or within the last 7 years;
a copy of the form of agreement proposed;
the conditions of any financing arrangement offered directly or indirectly by the seller or an agent or affiliate of the seller;
whether the buyer receives an exclusive territory;
a complete description of any training that the seller promises, including the length of the training;
a complete description of:

subparagraph.text: any services that the seller promises will be performed in connection with the placement of the buyer’s products, equipment, or supplies at various locations; and
the kind of agreement to be made with the owner or manager of each location;

paragraph.text: a complete description of any licenses or permits that are necessary in order for the buyer to operate or engage in the business opportunity;

if the seller gets a surety bond under § 14–115 of this subtitle, the following statement, or a similar statement required by the Commissioner: “As required by Maryland law, the seller has secured a bond issued by _____ (name and address of surety company), a surety company authorized to do business in the State. Before signing a contract to buy this business opportunity, you should ask the surety company about the current status of the bond.”;

if the seller establishes a trust account under § 14–115 of this subtitle, the following statement, or a similar statement required by the Commissioner: “As required by Maryland law, the seller has established a trust account _____ (account number) with _____ (name and address of bank or savings institution). Before signing a contract to buy this business opportunity, you should ask the bank or savings institution about the current status of the trust account.”;

the following statement: “If the seller fails to deliver the products, equipment, or supplies necessary to begin substantial operation of the business within 45 days after the delivery date stated in your contract, you may notify the seller in writing and demand that the contract be canceled.”;
if the seller makes a statement about sales, earnings, or range of sales or earnings that may be made through the business opportunity, a statement of:

subparagraph.text: the total number of buyers who have bought from the seller, within 3 years before the date of the disclosure statement, business opportunities that involve the products, equipment, supplies, or services being offered; and
to the seller’s knowledge, the total number of those buyers who have actually received earnings in the amount or range specified;

paragraph.text: a statement of:

subparagraph.text: the total number of business opportunities that are the same or similar in nature to those that have been sold or organized by the seller;
the names and addresses of buyers who have requested a refund or rescission from the seller within the last 12 months and the number of those buyers who have received the refund or rescission; and
the total number of business opportunities that the seller intends to sell in the State within the next 12 months;

paragraph.text: a copy of the most recent audited financial statement of the seller, prepared within 13 months after the date of the first offer in the State, together with a statement of any material changes in the financial condition of the seller from the date of the most recent audited financial statement;
a list of states in which this business opportunity is registered;
a list of states in which the disclosure statement is on file;
a list of states that have denied, suspended, or revoked the registration of this business opportunity;

a section entitled “Risk Factors” containing a series of concise statements summarizing the principal factors that make this business opportunity a high risk or of a speculative nature, each statement including a cross–reference to the page on which further information regarding that risk factor may be found in the disclosure document; and
any other information that the Commissioner requires by regulation or order.

subsection.text: If a seller guarantees that a buyer will derive from a business opportunity income that will exceed the price paid for the business opportunity or represents that the seller will refund all or part of the price paid or repurchase the products, equipment, or supplies sold or leased by the seller if the buyer is not satisfied with the business opportunity, the seller shall:

paragraph.text: get a surety bond in favor of the State from a surety company authorized to do business in the State; or
establish a trust account in favor of the State with an insured bank or savings institution in the State.

subsection.text: The amount of the bond or trust account shall be at least $50,000.

paragraph.text: A person may bring an action against the bond or trust account to recover damages resulting from:

subparagraph.text: a violation of this subtitle; or
the seller’s breach of the contract for the sale of a business opportunity.

paragraph.text: The surety or trustee is liable only for actual damages up to the amount of the bond or trust account.

section.text: The seller shall:

paragraph.text: file with the Commissioner an amendment to the documents previously submitted to the Commissioner whenever a material change in the required information occurs; and
pay a fee of $50 for filing the amendment.

subsection.text: Unless the registration of a business opportunity is renewed for a 1-year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the first anniversary of its effective date.
Before the registration expires, the registrant periodically may renew it for an additional 1-year term, if the registrant:

paragraph.text: files with the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Commissioner provides;
a current disclosure document along with any other documents or information that the Commissioner may require by order or regulation; and
proof that the seller has satisfied the bond and trust account requirements under § 14-115 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: pays a renewal fee of $100.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall renew the registration of a business opportunity if the registrant complies with the requirements of this section.
Each contract for the sale of a business opportunity shall be in writing.
The contract shall include:

paragraph.text: the terms and conditions of payment;
a full and detailed description of the acts or services that the seller agrees to perform for the buyer;
the address of the seller’s principal office;
the name and address of the seller’s resident agent; and
the approximate date that the seller will deliver to the buyer any products, equipment, or supplies.

subsection.text: When a buyer signs a contract for the sale of a business opportunity, the seller shall give the buyer a copy of the contract.

The Commissioner may pass an order denying effectiveness to, or suspending or revoking the effectiveness of, any registration if the Commissioner finds that the order is in the public interest and that:

subparagraph.text: the registration as of its effective date, or as of any earlier date in the case of an order denying effectiveness, is incomplete in any material respect or contains any statement made that was, in light of the circumstances under which it was made, false or misleading with respect to any material fact;

an amendment as of its effective date is incomplete in any material respect or contains any statement made that was, in light of the circumstances under which it was made, false or misleading with respect to any material fact; or
a report is incomplete in any material respect or contains any statement made that was, in light of the circumstances under which it was made, false or misleading with respect to any material fact;

paragraph.text: any provision of this subtitle or any order or condition lawfully imposed under this subtitle has been violated, in connection with the business opportunity by:

subparagraph.text: the person filing the registration;
a seller, any partner, officer, or director of the seller, or any person occupying a similar status or performing similar functions as the seller; or
a person that directly or indirectly controls or is controlled by the seller if the person filing the registration is directly or indirectly controlled by or acting for the seller;

paragraph.text: except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, the business opportunity registered or sought to be registered is the subject of an order denying, suspending, or revoking a registration or a permanent or temporary injunction of any court of competent jurisdiction;
the seller’s enterprise or method of business, or that of the business opportunity, includes or would include activities that are illegal where performed;
the business opportunity or the offering of a business opportunity has worked or tended to work a fraud upon purchasers or would so operate;
there has been a failure to file any documents or information required by § 14-113.1 of this subtitle; or
the seller’s literature or advertising is misleading, incorrect, incomplete, or deceptive.
The Commissioner may enter a denial order if the Commissioner finds that the order is in the public interest and the seller has failed to pay the proper registration fee.
The Commissioner shall vacate any such order when the deficiency has been corrected.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may not:

paragraph.text: institute a proceeding against an effective registration under subsection (a)(3) of this section more than 1 year after the date of the order or injunction relied on; or

pass an order under subsection (a)(3) of this section on the basis of an order or injunction entered under any other state act unless that order or injunction was based on facts which would currently constitute grounds for an order under this section.

subsection.text: By order, the Commissioner summarily may postpone or suspend the effectiveness of the registration pending final determination of any proceeding under this section.
Upon the entry of the order, the Commissioner shall promptly notify the seller:

paragraph.text: that the order has been entered;
the basis for the order; and
that within 15 days after the day on which the Commissioner receives a written request by the seller, the matter will be set down for a hearing.

subsection.text: If the seller fails to request a hearing and the Commissioner fails to order a hearing, the order shall remain in effect until the Commissioner modifies or vacates the order.

If the seller requests a hearing or the Commissioner orders a hearing, the Commissioner, after providing notice of an opportunity for hearing to the seller, may modify or vacate the order or extend it until final determination.

The Commissioner may not enter an order described under subsection (b) of this section without first providing to the seller notice in accordance with subsection (e) of this section, an opportunity for hearing, and written findings of fact and conclusions of law.

If the Commissioner finds that the conditions which prompted its entry have changed or that it is otherwise in the public interest, the Commissioner may vacate or modify an order passed under this section.

section.text: In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not make any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary in order to make the statement made, in light of the circumstances under which it is made, not misleading.

In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not engage in any act, practice, or course of business or employ any device, scheme, or artifice to defraud that operates or would operate as a fraud or deceit on another person.
In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not represent that the business opportunity provides income or earning potential of any kind unless:

paragraph.text: the seller has documentation to substantiate the representation; and
the person discloses the documentation to the prospective buyer when the representation is made.

section.text: In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not use the trademark, service mark, trade name, logotype, advertising, or other commercial symbol of a business unless:

paragraph.text: the business controls the ownership interest in the seller;
the business accepts responsibility for each representation that the seller makes about the business opportunity; or
it is clear from the circumstances that the owner of the commercial symbol is not involved in the sale of the business opportunity.

section.text: In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not make or authorize making a reference to compliance with this subtitle in an advertisement or other contact with prospective buyers other than by use of the disclosure statement or other disclosure documents required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a business opportunity, a person may not fail to deliver products, equipment, or supplies necessary to begin substantial operation of the business within 45 days after the delivery date stated in the contract for the sale of the business opportunity.
This section does not apply if the Commissioner or a court in a civil proceeding finds that the failure is due to the conditions stated in § 2-615 of the Commercial Law Article.

paragraph.text: If a seller violates a provision of §§ 14-120 through 14-125 of this subtitle, the buyer, within 1 year after the date of a contract for the sale of a business opportunity:

subparagraph.text: may void the contract; and
is entitled to receive from the seller a refund of any money paid to the seller.

paragraph.text: On receipt of the refund, the buyer shall make available to the seller any products, equipment, or supplies received from the seller at:

subparagraph.text: the buyer’s address; or
the place where the products, equipment, or supplies were located when notice to void the contract was given.

paragraph.text: However, the buyer may not be unjustly enriched by exercising a remedy under this subsection.

subsection.text: A buyer may sue for damages, including reasonable attorney’s fees, if the buyer is injured by:

paragraph.text: a violation of this subtitle; or
the seller’s breach of a contract for the sale of a business opportunity.

subsection.text: On complaint that a seller has violated this subtitle, the circuit court may enjoin the seller from further violation.
The remedies in this section are in addition to any other remedy provided by law or in equity.

A person who sells a business opportunity may not, in a disclosure statement or amendment to it, willfully make a false or misleading statement of a material fact or willfully omit to state a material fact required or necessary to make the statements in a disclosure statement not misleading.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

section.text: A person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, unless another criminal penalty is specifically provided elsewhere, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
This subtitle is the Maryland Business Opportunity Sales Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advertisement” means a communication that:

paragraph.text: is published in connection with an offer to sell or sale of a franchise; and
is:

subparagraph.text: written or printed;
made by means of a recorded telephone message; or
spoken on radio, television, or similar communications media.

subsection.text: “Area franchise” means an agreement between a franchisor and subfranchisor in which, for consideration, the subfranchisor is granted the right to sell or negotiate the sale of franchises in the name of or for the franchisor.
“Commissioner” means the Securities Commissioner in the Office of the Attorney General.

paragraph.text: “Franchise” means an expressed or implied, oral or written agreement in which:

subparagraph.text: a purchaser is granted the right to engage in the business of offering, selling, or distributing goods or services under a marketing plan or system prescribed in substantial part by the franchisor;

the operation of the business under the marketing plan or system is associated substantially with the trademark, service mark, trade name, logotype, advertising, or other commercial symbol that designates the franchisor or its affiliate; and
the purchaser must pay, directly or indirectly, a franchise fee.

paragraph.text: “Franchise” includes an area franchise.
“Franchise fee” means a charge or payment that a franchisee or subfranchisor is required or agrees to pay for the right to enter into a business under a franchise agreement.
“Franchise fee” includes payment for goods or services.
“Franchise fee” does not include:

subparagraph.text: the purchase of or agreement to purchase goods at a wholesale price;
the payment of a reasonable service charge to the issuer of a credit card by an establishment that accepts the credit card;
the amount paid to a licensed trading stamp company by a person issuing trading stamps in connection with the retail sale of goods or services;
the purchase of or agreement to purchase goods on consignment, if the proceeds remitted by the franchisee from the sale are the wholesale price of the goods;
the repayment by a franchisee of a bona fide loan that the franchisor has made to the franchisee;
the purchase of or agreement to purchase goods at a retail price subject to a commission or compensation plan that in substance is a wholesale transaction;
the purchase of or agreement to purchase, at their fair market value, supplies or fixtures that are needed to enter into the business or continue the business under a franchise agreement;
the purchase or lease of or agreement to purchase or lease, at its fair market value, real property that is needed to enter into the business or continue the business under a franchise agreement; and
the amount paid for sales demonstration material and equipment, sold at no profit by the seller, for use in making sales and not for resale.

subsection.text: “Franchisee” means a person to whom a franchise is granted.
“Franchisor” means a person who grants a franchise.
“Subfranchisor” means a person to whom an area franchise is granted.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the widespread sale of franchises has created many investment and business problems; and
franchisees have suffered substantial losses when the franchisor or its representative has not given complete information about:

subparagraph.text: the franchisor-franchisee relationship;
the franchise agreement; and
the business experience of the franchisor or its representative.

subsection.text: The intent of this subtitle is to:

paragraph.text: give each prospective franchisee necessary information about any franchise offer;
prohibit the sale of franchises if the sale would lead to fraud or a likelihood that the franchisor’s representations would not be fulfilled; and
protect the franchisor-franchisee relationship.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies to an offer to sell or sale of a franchise if:

paragraph.text: the franchisee must pay a franchise fee of more than $100; and

subparagraph.text: the offeree or franchisee is a resident of the State;
the franchised business will be or is operated in the State;
the offer to sell is made in the State; or
the offer to buy is accepted in the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, an offer to sell is made in the State if the offer:

subparagraph.text: originates from the State; or
is directed by the offeror to the State and is received at the place to which it is directed.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, an offer to sell is not made in the State only because the franchisor circulates or there is circulated on the franchisor’s behalf in the State an advertisement in:

subparagraph.text: a newspaper or other publication of general, regular, and paid circulation that has had two-thirds of its circulation outside the State during the past 12 months; or
a radio or television broadcast that originates outside the State and is received in the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, an offer to buy is accepted in the State when acceptance is communicated to the offeror in the State.
For purposes of this section, acceptance is communicated to the offeror in the State when:

subparagraph.text: the offeree directs acceptance to the offeror in the State reasonably believing the offeror to be in the State; and
the acceptance is received at the place to which it is directed.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to the renewal or extension of an existing franchise if there is no interruption in the operation of the franchised business.

section.text: The powers, remedies, procedures, and penalties of this subtitle are in addition to and not in limitation of any other powers, remedies, procedures, and penalties provided by law.
The Commissioner may delegate any power or duty of the Commissioner under this subtitle.
The Commissioner may adopt and enforce regulations to administer and enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may publish information about violations of this subtitle.
Under regulations that the Commissioner adopts, the Commissioner may make available to any person any information submitted to the Commissioner.

section.text: The Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: investigate in or outside the State to:

subparagraph.text: determine if a person has violated this subtitle or a regulation adopted or order passed under it;
adopt regulations or forms under this subtitle; or
enforce this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: require or allow a person to submit a written statement, under oath or otherwise as the Commissioner determines, about the matter being investigated.

subsection.text: On request, the Commissioner may issue an interpretive opinion.

paragraph.text: A request for an interpretive opinion shall be in writing.
The requester shall pay a fee of $100.

Whenever the Commissioner finds that a person has violated or is about to violate this subtitle or a regulation adopted or order passed under it, the Commissioner may order the person to cease and desist from the further offer to sell or sale of the franchise until the offer or sale complies with this subtitle.
After passage of a cease and desist order, the alleged violator may submit to the Commissioner a written request for a hearing.
The hearing shall begin:

subparagraph.text: within 15 business days after the Commissioner receives the request for a hearing; or
at a later date, with the consent of the alleged violator.

paragraph.text: Unless there is a timely hearing, the cease and desist order is rescinded.

Whenever the Commissioner finds that a person has violated or is about to violate this subtitle or a regulation adopted or order passed under it, the Commissioner may sue in the circuit court to enjoin the violation or enforce this subtitle or the regulation or order.
The court shall:

subparagraph.text: determine if a violation of this subtitle has been or is about to be committed; and
if so, pass any order the court considers necessary to prevent the violation or remove the effects of the violation and prevent it from continuing or being renewed in the future.

paragraph.text: The court may exercise all equitable powers necessary for this purpose, including:

subparagraph.text: injunction;
revocation, forfeiture, or suspension of the charter authority or privileges of a business organization operating under the laws of the State;
dissolution of a corporation or association organized under the laws of the State;
suspension or termination of the right of a corporation or association organized under the laws of another state or country to do business in the State;
restitution;
restraining order;
award of damages to be paid by a franchisor or subfranchisor to a person injured by a violation of this subtitle; and
appointment of a receiver or conservator.

paragraph.text: The court may not require the Commissioner to post bond.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may not exercise a power under this section more than 3 years after the violation occurs.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may refer to the State’s Attorney evidence of a criminal violation of this subtitle.
With or without the referral of evidence, a State’s Attorney may bring appropriate criminal proceedings under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A criminal proceeding may not be brought more than 3 years after the alleged violation.

section.text: In connection with an investigation or proceeding under this subtitle, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: administer oaths;
receive evidence; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to:

subparagraph.text: testify; or
produce evidence.

subsection.text: A person is not excused from attending, testifying, or producing evidence before the Commissioner, in a proceeding brought by the Commissioner, or in obedience to a subpoena of the Commissioner on the ground that the testimony or evidence may:

paragraph.text: tend to incriminate the person; or
subject the person to a penalty or forfeiture.

If a person claims the privilege against self-incrimination as to a specific subject, and is then compelled to testify or produce evidence on that subject, the person may not be prosecuted or subjected to a penalty or forfeiture in connection with that subject.
A person who testifies is not exempt from prosecution and punishment for perjury or contempt committed while testifying.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person must register the offer of a franchise with the Commissioner before the person offers to sell, through advertisement or otherwise, or sells the franchise in the State.
The registration requirement of this section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a transaction by an executor, administrator, sheriff, receiver, trustee in bankruptcy, guardian, or conservator;
an offer to sell or sale of a franchise that is substantially similar to a franchise already owned by the offeree or buyer; and
any other transaction that the Commissioner exempts by regulation because:

subparagraph.text: the transaction is not within the purpose of this subtitle; and
the registration of the transaction is not necessary or appropriate in the public interest or for the protection of investors.

paragraph.text: The registration requirement of this section does not apply to the offer to sell or sale of a franchise by a franchisee for the franchisee’s own account, or the offer to sell or sale of the entire area franchise owned by a subfranchisor for the subfranchisor’s own account.
A sale is not effected by or through a franchisor merely because a franchisor has a right to approve or disapprove a different franchisee.
The Commissioner may require by regulation that a franchisor or subfranchisor who claims under subsection (b)(3) of this section to be exempt from the registration requirements of this section:

subparagraph.text: file with the Commissioner a notice of claim of exemption in the form that the Commissioner requires; and
pay a fee of $250.

paragraph.text: The franchisor or subfranchisor shall sign and verify the notice of claim of exemption.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, an applicant for registration shall:

paragraph.text: file with the Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: an application in the form that the Commissioner requires; and
a prospectus for the franchise; and

paragraph.text: pay an application fee of $500.

subsection.text: Instead of the application for registration and prospectus described in subsection (a) of this section, the Commissioner may accept an application for registration and prospectus that:

paragraph.text: are found by the Commissioner to include disclosure requirements similar to those of this subtitle; and
are:

subparagraph.text: required by a unit of the federal government or another state government; or
approved by an association of administrators of state franchise laws.

subsection.text: The applicant shall sign and verify the application for registration.
The prospectus shall contain:

paragraph.text: the material information set forth in the application for registration, as required by regulation of the Commissioner; and
any other disclosures that the Commissioner requires.

subsection.text: The prospectus shall state, in 10-point or larger bold type, that registration is not approval, recommendation, or endorsement by the Commissioner.
The prospectus shall include the following information:

paragraph.text: the name of the franchisor;
the name under which the franchisor does or intends to do business;
the name of any parent or affiliated company that engages in business transactions with franchisees;
the address of the principal office of the franchisor;
the name and address of the resident agent of the franchisor;
whether the franchisor does business as an individual, partnership, or corporation;
information about the identity and business experience of persons affiliated with the franchisor, as the Commissioner requires;

subparagraph.text: whether any person identified in the prospectus has been convicted of a felony, has pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge, or has been adjudged liable in a civil action by final judgment, if the felony or civil action involved fraud, embezzlement, fraudulent conversion, or misappropriation of property; and
if so, the court, date of the conviction or the judgment, and any penalty imposed or damages assessed;
whether any person identified in the prospectus is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: a currently effective order of the Securities and Exchange Commission, or the securities administrator of a state, that denies registration to or suspends or revokes the registration of the person as a securities broker, securities dealer, or investment adviser;

a currently effective order of a national securities association or national securities exchange, as defined in the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, that suspends or expels the person from membership in the Association or Exchange;
a currently effective order of the Federal Trade Commission; or

a currently effective order that enjoins or restricts business activity as a result of an action brought by a public agency, including an action that affects a license as a real estate broker, associate real estate broker, or real estate salesperson; and

subparagraph.text: if so, the date, nature, and issuer of the order and any penalty imposed;

paragraph.text: the length of time the franchisor has:

subparagraph.text: conducted business of the type to be operated by a franchisee;
granted franchises for that business; and
granted franchises in other lines of business;

paragraph.text: a recent financial statement of the franchisor and a statement of each material change in the financial condition of the franchisor since the financial statement was made;
a copy of the typical franchise agreement used or proposed for use in the State;

the franchise fee or, if the franchise fee is not the same in each case, the formula that the franchisor uses to set the amount of the franchise fee and the way the franchisor will apply the franchise fee;

any payment other than a franchise fee that the franchisee or subfranchisor must pay to the franchisor, including any royalty or payment that the franchisor collects wholly or partly for a third party;
the conditions under which the franchisor may terminate, refuse to renew, or repurchase the franchise;
a description of all goods, fixtures, and services that, under the franchise agreement or by practice, the franchisee or subfranchisor must buy from the franchisor or a designee of the franchisor;
whether, under the franchise agreement or by practice, the franchisee is limited in the goods or services that the franchisee may offer to customers;
the conditions of any financing arrangement offered directly or indirectly by the franchisor or an agent or affiliate of the franchisor;
any past or present practice or any intent of the franchisor to sell, assign, or discount to a third party, wholly or partly, a note, contract, or other obligation of the franchisee or subfranchisor;

a copy of any statement of estimated or projected franchisee earnings prepared for presentation to prospective franchisees, subfranchisors, or others and a statement of the information on which the estimation or projection is based;
any compensation or other benefit given or promised to a public figure that arises wholly or partly from:

subparagraph.text: the use of the public figure in the name or symbol of the franchise; or
the endorsement or recommendation of the franchise by the public figure;

paragraph.text: the number of franchises currently operating or proposed to be sold, as the Commissioner requires by regulation;
whether franchisees or subfranchisors receive an exclusive territory or area franchise;
an authorization for the Commissioner to examine the applicant’s financial records that relate to the sale of franchises;
an irrevocable consent to be sued in the State;
appointment of the Commissioner as attorney to receive service of process for the franchisor;
any other information that the franchisor wants to give; and
any other information that the Commissioner reasonably requires.

subsection.text: If the applicant is a subfranchisor, the application shall include the same information about the subfranchisor as is required from the franchisor under this section.
The Commissioner by regulation may:

paragraph.text: set the form and content of financial statements required under this subtitle;
state the circumstances under which consolidated financial statements may be submitted; and
state the circumstances under which financial statements shall be audited by an independent certified public accountant or other public accountant.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner finds that it is necessary and appropriate for the protection of prospective franchisees or subfranchisors because a franchisor has not made adequate financial arrangements to fulfill the franchisor’s obligations under an offering, the Commissioner may require the franchisor to escrow franchise fees or other money paid by a franchisee or subfranchisor until the obligations have been satisfied.

paragraph.text: At the option of the franchisor, the franchisor may post an adequate surety bond as provided by regulations of the Commissioner.
The total liability of the surety under the bond may not exceed the penal sum of the bond.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall register an offer of a franchise if it meets the requirements of this subtitle.
Unless a stop order is in effect, registration of the offer of a franchise automatically takes effect at:

paragraph.text: noon on the 30th business day after an application for registration or the last amendment to it is filed; or
an earlier time that the Commissioner sets.
Unless registration of an offer of a franchise is renewed for a 1-year term as provided in this section, the registration expires on the first anniversary of its effective date.
However, the Commissioner by regulation or order may set a different term of registration.
Before registration expires, the registrant periodically may renew it for an additional 1-year term, if the registrant:

subparagraph.text: at least 15 business days before the expiration of registration files with the Commissioner:

sub-subparagraph.text: a renewal application on the form that the Commissioner provides; and
a prospectus;

subparagraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be registered; and
pays a renewal fee of $250.

paragraph.text: The registrant shall sign and verify the renewal application.
The Commissioner by order may allow a registrant to submit a renewal application after the 15th business day before expiration of the registration.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall renew the registration of an offer of a franchise if it meets the requirements of this section.
Unless a stop order or other order is in effect under this subtitle, renewal of the registration of the offer of a franchise automatically takes effect at:

paragraph.text: noon on the day when the previous registration is due to expire; or
an earlier time that the Commissioner sets.

subsection.text: If there is a material change in the information that a registrant previously filed with the Commissioner, the franchisor shall:

paragraph.text: file promptly with the Commissioner an application to amend the registration; and
pay a fee of $100.

subsection.text: The registrant shall sign and verify the application to amend the registration.
The Commissioner by regulation may state:

paragraph.text: what constitutes a material change; and
the circumstances under which a revised prospectus shall accompany an application to amend the registration.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner approves the amendment to the registration, the amendment takes effect on the date the Commissioner sets after considering the public interest and the protection of franchisees.

section.text: The Commissioner summarily may pass a stop order to deny, suspend, or revoke a registration if the Commissioner finds that:

paragraph.text: there has been a violation of this subtitle or a regulation adopted under it;
the offer to sell or sale of the franchise would constitute misrepresentation to, deceit of, or fraud on the buyer;

a person identified in an application has been convicted of an offense or has had a civil judgment entered against the person as described in § 14-216(c)(8) of this subtitle or is subject to an order described in § 14-216(c)(9) of this subtitle, and the involvement of the person in the sale or management of the franchise creates an unreasonable risk to prospective franchisees;
the prospectus or amendment to it is incomplete or inaccurate in any material respect;

the prospectus or amendment to it includes a false or misleading statement of a material fact or omits to state a material fact required to be stated in the prospectus or amendment or necessary to make the statements in the prospectus or amendment not misleading;

in connection with an offer to sell or sale of a franchise, a person in the State is engaging or is about to engage in a false, fraudulent, or deceptive practice or in a device, scheme, or artifice to defraud; or

the financial condition of the franchisor affects or will affect the ability of the franchisor to meet an obligation under the franchise or other agreement and the franchisor is not able or willing to comply or has failed to comply with a regulation, order, or administrative determination of the Commissioner under § 14-217 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: After passing a stop order, the Commissioner promptly shall send to the applicant or registrant a notice that:

paragraph.text: states that the stop order has been passed;
states the reasons for the stop order; and
informs the applicant or registrant of the right to a hearing under this section.
The applicant or registrant may submit to the Commissioner a written request for a hearing on the stop order.
The Commissioner shall schedule a hearing within 15 business days after the Commissioner receives the request unless the applicant or registrant consents to a later date.
The Commissioner may schedule a hearing even if the applicant or registrant does not request a hearing.
If a hearing is not requested and is not scheduled by the Commissioner and therefore is not held, the stop order remains in effect until the Commissioner modifies or vacates it.
If a hearing is held, after the hearing, the Commissioner may modify or vacate the stop order or extend it until the Commissioner makes a final determination.
The Commissioner may modify or vacate a stop order if the Commissioner finds that:

subparagraph.text: conditions have changed; or
it is otherwise in the public interest to vacate or modify the stop order.

section.text: A franchisor may not sell a franchise in the State without first giving a prospective franchisee a copy of the offering prospectus and a copy of each proposed agreement that relates to the sale of the franchise at the earlier of:

paragraph.text: 14 calendar days before the execution by the prospective franchisee of any binding agreement with the franchisor;
14 calendar days before payment of any consideration that relates to the franchise relationship; or
a reasonable request by a prospective franchisee to receive a copy of the offering prospectus.

section.text: Each franchisor or subfranchisor shall keep a complete set of records of each sale of a franchise.
A person may not publish an advertisement offering to sell a franchise subject to registration under this subtitle unless:

paragraph.text: the person submits a copy of the advertisement to the Commissioner for review at least 7 business days before the first publication of the advertisement unless the Commissioner by regulation or order allows a later submission; or
the advertisement is exempted from review by regulation of the Commissioner.

section.text: As a condition of the sale of a franchise, a franchisor may not require a prospective franchisee to agree to a release, assignment, novation, waiver, or estoppel that would relieve a person from liability under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A person who sells or grants a franchise is civilly liable to the person who buys or is granted a franchise if the person who sells or grants a franchise offers to sell or sells a franchise:

subparagraph.text: without the offer of the franchise being registered under this subtitle; or

by means of an untrue statement of a material fact or any omission to state a material fact necessary in order to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which they are made, not misleading, if the person who buys or is granted a franchise does not know of the untruth or omission.

paragraph.text: In determining liability under this subsection, the person who sells or grants a franchise has the burden of proving that the person who sells or grants a franchise did not know and, in the exercise of reasonable care, could not have known of the untruth or omission.

subsection.text: The person who buys or is granted a franchise may sue under this section to recover damages sustained by the grant of the franchise.
A court may order the person who sells or grants a franchise to:

paragraph.text: rescind the franchise; and
make restitution to the person who buys or is granted a franchise.
Joint and several liability under this section extends to:

subparagraph.text: each person who directly or indirectly controls a person liable under this section;
each partner in a partnership liable under this section;
each principal officer or director of a corporation liable under this section;
each other person that has a similar status or performs similar functions as a person liable under this section; and
each employee of a person liable under this section, if the employee materially aids in the act or transaction that is a violation under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: However, liability under this subsection does not extend to a person who did not have knowledge of or reasonable grounds to believe in the existence of the facts by which the liability is alleged to exist.

subsection.text: An action under this section must be brought within 3 years after the grant of the franchise.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not offer to sell, through advertisement or otherwise, or sell a franchise in the State unless the offer of the franchise has been registered under this subtitle.

A person who willfully sells a franchise knowingly violating this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
In connection with an offer to sell or sale of a franchise, a person, directly or indirectly, may not:

paragraph.text: employ a device, scheme, or artifice to defraud;
make an untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary in order to make the statement made, in light of the circumstances under which it is made, not misleading; or
engage in an act, practice, or course of business that operates or would operate as a fraud or deceit on another person.

subsection.text: A person who willfully sells a franchise knowingly violating this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

In a prospectus or amendment to it, a person may not willfully make a false or misleading statement of a material fact or willfully omit to state a material fact required to be stated in the prospectus or amendment or necessary to make the statements in the prospectus or amendment not misleading.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

A person may not make or cause to be made an untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact in an application for registration, to amend registration, or for renewal or in a notice or report filed with the Commissioner under this subtitle.

A person who willfully sells a franchise knowingly violating this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
A person may not fail to notify the Commissioner promptly of a material change as required by § 14-220 of this subtitle.

A person who willfully sells a franchise knowingly violating this section is guilty of a felony and, on conviction, is subject for each violation to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

section.text: This subtitle is the Maryland Franchise Registration and Disclosure Law.

In this subtitle, “multilevel distribution company” means a person who, for consideration, distributes goods or services through independent agents, contractors, or distributors at different levels of distribution with rates of pricing or discounting that differ from 1 level to another.

subsection.text: A multilevel distribution company may not require a participant in its marketing program to buy goods or services or pay any other consideration to participate in the marketing program unless the multilevel distribution company agrees to repurchase the goods:

paragraph.text: that are in resalable condition; and
that the participant has been unable to sell 3 months after receipt of the goods first ordered.

subsection.text: A multilevel distribution company shall state in writing in each contract of participation in its marketing program that:

paragraph.text: a participant may cancel the contract for any reason within 3 months after the date of receipt of goods or services first ordered by written notice to the multilevel distribution company; and
on cancellation, the multilevel distribution company shall repurchase the goods.

subsection.text: The repurchase price shall be at least 90% of the original price paid by the participant.

section.text: A multilevel distribution company may not represent directly or indirectly that participants in its marketing program may or will earn a stated gross or net amount or represent in any way the past earnings of participants unless the stated gross amount, net amount, or past earnings:

paragraph.text: are those of a substantial number of participants in the community or geographic area where the representation is made; and
accurately reflect the average earnings of participants under circumstances similar to those of the participant or prospective participant to whom the representation is made.

subsection.text: The Attorney General or a State’s Attorney may sue to enjoin, wholly or partly, the activities of a multilevel distribution company that violate this subtitle.

At least 10 days before seeking injunctive relief, the Attorney General or State’s Attorney shall send written notice of the alleged violation by certified mail to the principal place of business of the multilevel distribution company.
A person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000.

Each officer and each director of a corporation that violates this subtitle, each partner of a partnership that violates this subtitle, and the owner of a sole proprietorship that violates this subtitle is also subject to the penalty under this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “valuable” means money, jewelry, securities, or plate.
Except for § 15-105 of this subtitle, this subtitle applies only to those hotels that display in each guest room a notice of the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A hotel is not liable for the loss, by robbery or otherwise, of a valuable belonging to a guest if:

paragraph.text: the hotel provides a safe or other secure depository for keeping valuables of guests;
the guest does not deposit the valuable with the hotel for safekeeping; and
the loss does not result from the collusion or negligence of the hotel or its agent.

A hotel is not liable for more than $300 for the loss of valuables that a guest deposits with the hotel for safekeeping unless, at the time of deposit, the guest shows the valuables to an agent of the hotel and declares a greater value to the agent.
A hotel need not accept for safekeeping valuables with a declared value of more than $1,000.

subsection.text: A hotel is not liable for more than $1,000 for the loss of or damage to valuables belonging to a guest, whether or not the valuables were offered to or accepted by the hotel for safekeeping.

section.text: A hotel is not liable for more than $300 for the loss of property other than valuables of a registered guest from the room of the registered guest.
A hotel is not liable for more than $75 for the loss of property that a guest leaves with an agent or employee of the hotel at a checkroom or other similar place if:

paragraph.text: the hotel has posted conspicuously at each such place a notice that states the limitation on liability under this section;
the agent or employee gives to the guest an identification ticket that:

subparagraph.text: states on its face, in 10 point or larger type, the limitation on liability under this section; and
provides a space for declaring a greater value; and

paragraph.text: the guest does not declare a value greater than $75 on the duplicate of the identification ticket that the hotel keeps.

section.text: A hotel is not liable for more than $300 for the loss of property that a guest leaves with an agent or employee of the hotel at a baggage room or other similar storage area.
A hotel is not liable for the loss of property of a guest or other person as a result of a fire that is proved to have occurred without the negligence of the hotel or its agents or employees.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Innkeeper” means the owner, operator, manager, or keeper of a lodging establishment, or the agent of an owner, operator, manager, or keeper of a lodging establishment.
“Lodging establishment” means an inn, hotel, motel, or other establishment that has at least four rooms available for a fee to transient guests for lodging or sleeping purposes.

section.text: Except as provided in this subtitle for an individual who is under the age of 21 years, this subtitle may not be construed to alter the prohibition against discrimination by an innkeeper or lodging establishment under Title 20, Subtitle 3 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: An innkeeper may refuse to provide lodging or services to or may remove from a lodging establishment an individual who:

paragraph.text: refuses to pay or is unable to pay for lodging or services;
while on the premises of the lodging establishment is under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or other intoxicating substance so as to create a public nuisance;
while on the premises is disorderly so as to create a public nuisance;
destroys, damages, or defaces property of the lodging establishment or its guests, or threatens to do so;

the innkeeper reasonably believes is using the lodging establishment for the unlawful possession or use of a controlled dangerous substance in violation of Title 5 of the Criminal Law Article or for the consumption of alcohol by an individual under the age of 21 years in violation of Article 2B, § 12-108 of the Code;
the innkeeper reasonably believes possesses property that may be dangerous to other individuals, such as firearms or explosives; or
refuses to abide by any conspicuously posted rule or policy of the lodging establishment.
If an innkeeper seeks to remove an individual from a lodging establishment as provided under this section, the innkeeper shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the individual, either orally or in writing, that the lodging establishment refuses to provide further lodging or services to the individual and that the individual should immediately leave the lodging establishment; and

if the individual has paid for lodging or services in advance, refund any unused portion of the advance payment, but the lodging establishment may withhold payment for a full day’s lodging if the individual was lodged for a portion of a day.

paragraph.text: If an individual attempts to remain in a lodging establishment after having been requested to leave under the provisions of this section, an innkeeper may:

subparagraph.text: if the individual is a guest, lock the door of the individual’s room;
remove the individual’s baggage and other personal property; and
using no more force than necessary, eject the individual from the lodging establishment.

subsection.text: An innkeeper may require a prospective guest to demonstrate an ability to pay by cash or valid credit card.
An innkeeper may require each guest at a lodging establishment to register and may require the guest to produce:

paragraph.text: a valid driver’s license;
a valid military identification card;
a valid passport; or
any valid government issued identification card.

subsection.text: An innkeeper may limit the number of individuals who may occupy a particular guest room in a lodging establishment.
For an individual who is under the age of 18 years, an innkeeper may require a parent or guardian of the individual to:

paragraph.text: accept liability for the charges for the individual’s lodging and any damages to the lodging establishment caused by the individual; and
provide a valid credit card or make an advance cash damage deposit of not more than $500 to cover any charges incurred or damages caused by the individual.

subsection.text: If an innkeeper requires an advance deposit under subsection (a) of this section, the innkeeper shall, following a room inspection at the time of checkout, refund any amount of the deposit not needed to cover reasonable charges for damages.

section.text: An innkeeper shall post a copy of this subtitle, together with all rules of the lodging establishment, in a conspicuous place at or near the guest registration desk and in each guest room.

paragraph.text: The Department shall design a sign that states the following:
“REPORT HUMAN TRAFFICKING: National Human Trafficking Resource Center –– 1–888–373–7888. CALL FOR HELP IF YOU OR SOMEONE YOU KNOW:
• Is being forced to have sex without consent • Has had an ID or documents taken away • Is being threatened by or is in debt to an employer • Wants to leave a job but cannot freely do so.
TOLL–FREE. 24/7. CONFIDENTIAL. INTERPRETERS AVAILABLE.
This sign is required under State law.”
The sign shall:

subparagraph.text: be at least 3 by 5 inches in size;
contain the text required under paragraph (1) of this subsection in English, Spanish, and any other languages required by the federal Voting Rights Act;
draw attention to the phone number of the National Human Trafficking Resource Center Hotline by showing the phone number in bold type; and
be placed on the Department website.

paragraph.text: A State, county, or municipal law enforcement agency may issue a civil citation to a lodging establishment requiring it to post prominently in each guest room for 1 year the sign that is identical to the notice required to be placed on the website of the Department under subsection (a) of this section, if the lodging establishment is located on property where arrests leading to convictions of prostitution, solicitation of a minor, or human trafficking under Title 11, Subtitle 13 of the Criminal Law Article have occurred.

A State, county, or municipal law enforcement agency shall consider any assistance it receives from a lodging establishment in an investigation leading to a conviction under paragraph (1) of this subsection in determining whether to issue a citation under this subsection.
The owner of a lodging establishment that violates subsection (b)(1) of this section is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000.
Each guest room that does not have a sign is not a separate violation.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Cigarette” means any size or shaped roll for smoking that is made of tobacco or tobacco mixed with another ingredient and wrapped in paper or in any other material except tobacco.
“County license” means a license issued by the clerk to sell cigarettes at retail in a county.
“Sell” means to exchange or transfer, or to agree to exchange or transfer, title or possession of property, in any manner or by any means, for consideration.

paragraph.text: “Sell cigarettes at retail” means to sell cigarettes to a consumer.
“Sell cigarettes at retail” includes selling cigarettes through a vending machine.

section.text: The Comptroller may delegate any power or duty of the Comptroller under this title.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“License” means:

paragraph.text: a license issued by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to:

subparagraph.text: act as a manufacturer;
act as a subwholesaler;
act as a vending machine operator;
act as a wholesaler; or
act as a storage warehouse; or

paragraph.text: a license issued by the clerk under § 16–205(b) of this subtitle to act as a retailer.

subsection.text: “Licensed manufacturer” means a person licensed by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to act as a manufacturer.
“Licensed retailer” means a person licensed by the clerk under § 16–205(b) of this subtitle to act as a retailer.
“Licensed storage warehouse” means a facility licensed by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to act as a storage warehouse.
“Licensed subwholesaler” means a person licensed by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to act as a subwholesaler.
“Licensed vending machine operator” means a person licensed by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to act as a vending machine operator.
“Licensed wholesaler” means a person licensed by the Comptroller under § 16–205(a) of this subtitle to act as a wholesaler.
“Manufacturer” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: operates one or more cigarette manufacturing plants; or
is a participating manufacturer; and
sells unstamped cigarettes to a licensed cigarette wholesaler located in Maryland;
sells unstamped cigarettes that may lawfully be sold in Maryland to a licensed cigarette wholesaler located outside of Maryland;
unless otherwise prohibited or restricted under local law, this article, or the Criminal Law Article, distributes sample cigarettes to consumers located in Maryland; or
stores unstamped cigarettes in a cigarette storage warehouse in Maryland for subsequent shipment to licensed wholesalers, federal reservations, or persons out of state.

subsection.text: “Participating manufacturer” has the meaning stated in § 16–501 of this title.
“Retailer” means a person who:

paragraph.text: sells cigarettes to consumers through vending machines on fewer than 40 premises;
otherwise sells cigarettes to consumers; or
holds cigarettes for sale to consumers.

subsection.text: “Stamped cigarettes” means a package of cigarettes to which tobacco tax stamps are affixed in the amount and manner required by § 12–304 of the Tax – General Article.
“Storage warehouse” means a storage facility in Maryland operated for the purpose of storing unstamped cigarettes on behalf of a licensed cigarette manufacturer.

paragraph.text: “Subwholesaler” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: holds stamped cigarettes for sale to another person for resale; or
sells stamped cigarettes to another person for resale.

paragraph.text: “Subwholesaler” does not include a person who sells unstamped cigarettes or holds unstamped cigarettes for sale.

subsection.text: “Unstamped cigarettes” means a package of cigarettes to which tobacco tax stamps are not affixed in the amount and manner required by § 12–304 of the Tax – General Article.
“Vending machine operator” means a person who:

paragraph.text: holds cigarettes for sale to consumers through vending machines on 40 or more premises; or
sells cigarettes to consumers through vending machines on 40 or more premises.

subsection.text: “Wholesaler” means a person who:

paragraph.text: holds cigarettes for sale to another person for resale; or
sells cigarettes to another person for resale.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person must have an appropriate license whenever the person acts as a manufacturer, retailer, storage warehouse, subwholesaler, vending machine operator, or wholesaler in the State.
A person need not get a retailer license to act as a retailer at a vending stand operated under a trader’s license issued to Blind Industries and Services of Maryland.
A license to act as a retailer is required for each place of business where a person acts as a retailer.

paragraph.text: A person licensed as a manufacturer, or person connected with the business of a licensed manufacturer or related by ownership, may not at the same time hold or have any financial interest in a wholesaler license or in any business of a wholesaler.

A person licensed as a wholesaler, or person connected with the business of a licensed wholesaler or related by ownership, may not at the same time hold or have any financial interest in a manufacturer license or in any business of a manufacturer.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a manufacturer shall maintain an established place of business for the manufacture and storage of cigarettes.
An applicant for a license to act as a storage warehouse shall maintain an established place of business for the storage of unstamped cigarettes.
An applicant for a license to act as a subwholesaler shall maintain:

paragraph.text: an established place of business, including warehouse facilities, for the sale of cigarettes; and
necessary equipment and vehicles for the storage and distribution of cigarettes.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a vending machine operator shall maintain an established place of business, including warehouse facilities, for the purchase, storage, and distribution of cigarettes.
An applicant for a license to act as a wholesaler shall maintain:

paragraph.text: an established place of business, including warehouse facilities, for the sale of cigarettes; and
necessary equipment and vehicles for the storage and distribution of cigarettes.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a manufacturer shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Comptroller on the form and containing the information that the Comptroller requires; and
pay to the Comptroller a fee of $25.
An applicant for a license to act as a retailer shall:

subparagraph.text: obtain the county license required under § 16-301 of this title;
submit to the clerk an application for each permanent or temporary place of business located in the same enclosure and operated by the same applicant; and
pay to the clerk a fee of $30.

paragraph.text: The application shall:

subparagraph.text: be made on the form that the clerk requires; and
contain the information that the Comptroller requires.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a storage warehouse shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Comptroller on the form and containing the information that the Comptroller requires; and
pay to the Comptroller a fee of $25.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a subwholesaler shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Comptroller on the form and containing the information that the Comptroller requires; and
pay to the Comptroller a fee of:

subparagraph.text: $500 for a 1-year term; or
the amount that results when $500 is prorated to the nearest month, if the application is for less than a 1-year term.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a vending machine operator shall:

paragraph.text: obtain the county license required under § 16-301 of this title;
submit an application to the Comptroller on the form and containing the information that the Comptroller requires; and
pay to the Comptroller a fee of $500.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license to act as a wholesaler shall:

paragraph.text: submit an application to the Comptroller on the form and containing the information that the Comptroller requires; and
pay to the Comptroller a fee of $750.

subsection.text: If a person has had a license revoked under § 16-210 of this subtitle, the person may not reapply for a license within 1 year after the date when the prior license was revoked.

paragraph.text: In addition to the license fee otherwise required under this section:

subparagraph.text: an applicant for the initial issuance of a license issued by the Comptroller under this title shall pay to the Comptroller a nonrefundable application fee of $200; and
an applicant for renewal of a license issued by the Comptroller under this title shall pay to the Comptroller a renewal fee of $30.

paragraph.text: The application and renewal fees required under this subsection do not apply to a license that is issued by the clerk or to a storage warehouse license application.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall issue an appropriate license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle for a license to act as a manufacturer, storage warehouse, subwholesaler, vending machine operator, or wholesaler.
The clerk shall issue to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle a license to act as a retailer.
A manufacturer license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: sell unstamped cigarettes to:

subparagraph.text: a licensed cigarette wholesaler located in Maryland; and
a licensed cigarette wholesaler located outside of Maryland if the unstamped cigarettes may lawfully be sold in Maryland;

paragraph.text: except as otherwise prohibited or restricted under local law, this article, or the Criminal Law Article, distribute sample cigarettes to consumers located in Maryland;
store unstamped cigarettes in a licensed cigarette storage warehouse for subsequent shipment to licensed wholesalers, federal reservations, or persons out of state; and
upon approval of the Comptroller, act as an agent of a Maryland licensed wholesaler for stamping and distribution of cigarettes.

subsection.text: A retailer license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: act as a retailer; and
buy stamped cigarettes from a subwholesaler or wholesaler.
A storage warehouse license authorizes the licensee to operate a storage facility in Maryland for the purpose of storing unstamped cigarettes on behalf of a licensed cigarette manufacturer.

If a storage warehouse licensee is a licensed cigarette wholesaler or licensed cigarette subwholesaler, the storage warehouse license authorizes the holder to store stamped cigarettes and cigarettes with another state’s tax stamp.

subsection.text: A subwholesaler license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: act as a subwholesaler;
buy stamped cigarettes from a wholesaler or another subwholesaler; and
store stamped cigarettes and cigarettes with another state’s tax stamp at a licensed cigarette storage facility.

subsection.text: A vending machine operator license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: act as a vending machine operator; and
buy stamped cigarettes from a subwholesaler or wholesaler.

subsection.text: A wholesaler license authorizes the licensee to:

paragraph.text: act as a wholesaler;
buy unstamped cigarettes directly from a cigarette manufacturer;
hold unstamped cigarettes;
buy tobacco tax stamps as authorized by § 12-303 of the Tax - General Article;
transport unstamped cigarettes in the State;
sell unstamped cigarettes to another licensed wholesaler if the Comptroller specifically authorizes;
upon approval of the Comptroller, designate a licensed manufacturer to act as its agent for the stamping and distribution of cigarettes; and
store stamped cigarettes and cigarettes with another state’s tax stamp at a licensed cigarette storage facility.

subsection.text: Unless a license is renewed for a 1-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the first April 30 after its effective date.
At least 1 month before a license issued under this subtitle expires, the issuing official shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee, a renewal notice that states:

paragraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the issuing official must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before a license issued under this subtitle expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional 1-year term, if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
submits to the issuing official a renewal application on the form that the issuing official requires; and
pays to the issuing official:

subparagraph.text: the license fee required under § 16-204 of this subtitle; and
if the license is issued by the Comptroller, the renewal fee required under § 16-204(h) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The issuing official shall renew the license of each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.

paragraph.text: A licensed retailer or licensed vending machine operator may not assign the license.

If a licensed subwholesaler or licensed wholesaler sells the licensee’s cigarette business and pays to the Comptroller a license assignment fee of $10, the licensee may assign the license to the buyer of the business.

subsection.text: If the cigarette business of a licensee is transferred because of bankruptcy, death, incompetency, receivership, or otherwise by operation of law, the Comptroller shall transfer the license without charge to the new owner of the licensee’s business.

paragraph.text: If a licensed subwholesaler or licensed wholesaler surrenders the license to the Comptroller and if no disciplinary proceedings are pending against the licensee, the Comptroller shall refund a pro rata part of the license fee for the unexpired term of the license.
A licensed retailer or licensed vending machine operator is not allowed a refund for the unexpired term of the license.

subsection.text: A licensee shall display a license in the way that the Comptroller requires by regulation.
A licensee who sells cigarettes through a vending machine:

paragraph.text: shall place each package of cigarettes in the machine so that when the package is visible the tax stamps required by § 12-304 of the Tax - General Article are also visible; and
in the way that the Comptroller requires by regulation, shall:

subparagraph.text: identify each vending machine with a conspicuous label that states the licensee’s name, address, and telephone number; and
display on a conspicuous label applicable prohibitions and penalties under § 10-107 of the Criminal Law Article.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 16–211 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may deny a license to an applicant, reprimand a licensee, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another person;
fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
fails to comply with the Maryland Cigarette Sales Below Cost Act or regulations adopted under that Act;
fails to comply with the provisions of Title 11, Subtitle 5A of the Commercial Law Article;
buys cigarettes for resale:

subparagraph.text: in violation of a license; or
from a person who is not a licensed cigarette manufacturer, licensed subwholesaler, licensed vending machine operator, or licensed wholesaler;

paragraph.text: is convicted, under the laws of the United States or of any other state, of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or
a misdemeanor that is a crime of moral turpitude and is directly related to the fitness and qualification of the applicant or licensee; or

paragraph.text: has not paid a tax due before October 1 of the year after the tax became due.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 16–211 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may suspend or revoke a license if the licensee violates:

paragraph.text: Title 12 of the Tax – General Article, or regulations adopted under that title; or
this title or regulations adopted under this title.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 16-211 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall deny a license to any applicant who has had a license revoked under this section until:

paragraph.text: 1 year has passed since the license was revoked; and
it satisfactorily appears to the Comptroller that the applicant will comply with this title and any regulations adopted under this title.

subsection.text: Prior to the issuance or renewal of any license, the Comptroller shall conduct an investigation with regard to:

paragraph.text: the applicant;
the business to be operated; and
