subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 10–226 of the State Government Article, before the Comptroller takes any final action under § 16.5–208 of this subtitle, the Comptroller shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Comptroller may administer oaths in a proceeding under this section.
The person against whom the action is contemplated may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Comptroller may hear and determine the matter.

Subject to the notice requirement of subsection (c) of this section, if a licensee engages in an act or omission that is a ground for discipline under § 16.5–208 of this subtitle, the Comptroller may suspend the license for a consecutive period that:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, is not less than 5 nor more than 20 business days; or
for a subsequent offense, is not less than 20 business days nor more than 6 months.

subsection.text: Subject to the notice requirement under subsection (c) of this section, the Comptroller may revoke a license if a licensee:

paragraph.text: willfully and persistently engages in an act or omission that is a ground for discipline under § 16.5–208(a) of this subtitle; or
violates this title or Title 12 of the Tax – General Article or regulations adopted under these titles.

subsection.text: If a license is suspended or revoked under this section:

paragraph.text: the Comptroller shall give the licensee notice of the suspension or revocation; and
the suspension or revocation may not take effect until at least 5 business days following notice of the suspension or revocation.

subsection.text: The transfer, renewal, or expiration of a license will not bar or abate a disciplinary action under this section.

paragraph.text: Except for a violation of § 10–107 of the Criminal Law Article, whenever any license issued under the provisions of this subtitle is suspended or revoked by the Comptroller, the licensee may, before the effective date of the suspension or revocation, petition the Comptroller for permission to make an offer of compromise consisting of a sum of money in lieu of serving the suspension or revocation.
Money paid in lieu of suspension or revocation shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.
An offer of compromise may not exceed $2,000 in the case of retail licensees and may not exceed $50,000 for other licensees.
The Comptroller may accept the offer of compromise if:

subparagraph.text: the public welfare and morals would not be impaired by allowing the licensee to operate during the period set for the suspension or revocation; and
the payment of the sum of money will achieve the desired disciplinary purposes.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may adopt regulations to carry out this subsection.

section.text: A party to a proceeding before the Comptroller who is aggrieved by a final decision of the Comptroller in a contested case, as defined in § 10–202 of the State Government Article, is entitled to judicial review as provided in §§ 10–222 and 10–223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 16.5–201(b) of this subtitle, a person may not act, attempt to act, or offer to act as a licensed other tobacco products manufacturer, a licensed other tobacco products retailer, a licensed other tobacco products storage warehouse, a licensed other tobacco products wholesaler, or a licensed tobacconist in the State unless the person has an appropriate license.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.
Each day that a violation of this section continues is a separate offense.
The Comptroller shall pay into the General Fund of the State all license fees collected under this title.
All license fees collected by the counties are subject to the distribution provisions of § 17–206 of this article.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that these license fees be used to administer this title.
Each other tobacco products wholesaler:

paragraph.text: shall get an invoice for each purchase of other tobacco products;
shall keep a record of all other tobacco products received, to which the other tobacco products wholesaler shall post each day:

subparagraph.text: the invoice number;
the date of receipt;
the quantity received;
the brand;
the manufacturer; and
the name of the person from whom the other tobacco products are received;

paragraph.text: for other tobacco products sales to other tobacco products retailers and tobacconists:

subparagraph.text: shall keep a record of the name and address of each other tobacco products retailer and tobacconist to whom a sale is made; and

except for a transfer of other tobacco products to retail stock by a written memorandum, shall prepare for each sale an invoice that shows the political subdivision where the other tobacco products retailer and each tobacconist is located; and

paragraph.text: shall keep a complete and accurate record of each sale of other tobacco products to an out–of–state person for resale to out–of–state consumers.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each other tobacco products wholesaler shall make an inventory record each month of all other tobacco products on the premises or under the control of the other tobacco products wholesaler:

subparagraph.text: at the beginning or end of the month; or

on another specific day of the month, if the other tobacco products wholesaler finds it more practical to take inventory on that day and notifies the Comptroller that inventory will be taken on that day.

paragraph.text: Other tobacco products transferred to retail stock by written memorandum need not be included in the inventory record.

subsection.text: Each other tobacco products wholesaler shall:

paragraph.text: keep the records required by this section for 6 years or for a shorter time set by the Comptroller; and
allow the Comptroller to examine the records.

subsection.text: A licensed other tobacco products retailer who purchases premium cigars or pipe tobacco from an other tobacco products manufacturer or a licensed tobacconist shall, for a period of 2 years, keep and maintain available for inspection at the license location during business hours:

paragraph.text: all invoices and bills of lading; and
all records covering all purchases and sales of other tobacco products.

subsection.text: A person who transports other tobacco products by vehicle on a public road shall have in the vehicle a delivery ticket or an invoice that states:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the seller or consignor;
the name and address of a buyer or consignee who is:

subparagraph.text: a person in the State authorized by Title 12 of the Tax – General Article to hold other tobacco products on which the tobacco tax has not been paid; or
a person in another jurisdiction authorized to hold other tobacco products on which the tax imposed by that jurisdiction has not been paid; and

paragraph.text: the quantity and brands of the other tobacco products that are being transported.

subsection.text: The Comptroller by regulation may require a common carrier that brings other tobacco products into the State to submit to the Comptroller a copy of any freight bill relating to the other tobacco products shipment.
A person may not ship, import, or sell into or within this State any other tobacco products unless that person:

paragraph.text: is the owner of the brand;
is the United States importer for the brand; or
is a designated agent in Maryland of:

subparagraph.text: the owner of the brand; or
the United States importer of the brand; and

paragraph.text: holds any license required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who ships, imports, or sells other tobacco products into or within this State:

paragraph.text: shall comply with any federal and State requirements concerning the placement of warning labels or other information on the containers or individual packages of other tobacco products; and
shall ensure that the containers or individual packages of other tobacco products do not contain any information or markings that are false, misleading, or contrary to:

subparagraph.text: federal trademark or tax laws;
the trademark law of this State under Title 1, Subtitle 4 of this article; or
the tax laws of this State under Title 12 of the Tax – General Article.

subsection.text: A person who ships, imports, or sells other tobacco products into or within this State in violation of this section is subject to disciplinary action by the Comptroller under § 16.5–208 of this subtitle and to the penalty specified in § 13–1015 of the Tax – General Article.
This section applies to a person who is engaged in the business of selling or distributing other tobacco products.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the order, purchase, sale, or shipment of premium cigars or pipe tobacco by a licensed other tobacco products retailer or licensed tobacconist.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a person covered under this section may not:

subparagraph.text: sell or ship other tobacco products, ordered or purchased by mail or through a computer network, telephonic network, or other electronic network by a consumer or other unlicensed recipient, directly to a consumer or other unlicensed recipient in this State; or

cause other tobacco products, ordered or purchased by mail or through a computer network, telephonic network, or other electronic network by a consumer or other unlicensed recipient, to be shipped directly to a consumer or other unlicensed recipient in this State.

paragraph.text: A licensed other tobacco products retailer or licensed tobacconist may deliver not more than two packages of other tobacco products directly to a consumer if the delivery is made by the licensed other tobacco products retailer or licensed tobacconist or an employee of the licensed other tobacco products retailer or licensed tobacconist.
A licensee who sells or ships other tobacco products in violation of this section or causes other tobacco products to be shipped in violation of this section is:

subparagraph.text: subject to discipline by the Comptroller under § 16.5–208 of this subtitle; and
guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50 for each package of other tobacco products transported or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

paragraph.text: A person other than a licensee who sells or ships other tobacco products in violation of this section or causes other tobacco products to be shipped in violation of this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50 for each package of other tobacco products transported or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

section.text: Unless otherwise specified in this title, a person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Goods” means tangible personal property.
“Sale” includes barter.
“Sell” includes barter.
“Trader” includes a person who operates a room or other place of business for selling goods at auction.
“Trader’s license” means a license issued by the clerk to do business as a trader.

section.text: This title does not apply to a person who does not buy or sell in a trade or business carried on for profit.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, “license” means a license issued by a clerk under this title.
In this subtitle, “license” includes:

paragraph.text: a console machine license issued under Subtitle 4 of this title;
a pinball machine license issued under Subtitle 4 of this title;
a Wicomico County pinball machine license issued under Subtitle 4 of this title;
a Garrett County amusement device license issued under Subtitle 4 of this title;
a billiard table license issued under Subtitle 5 of this title;
a construction license issued under Subtitle 6 of this title;
a nonresident construction license issued under Subtitle 6 of this title;
a wholesale farm machinery dealer’s license issued under Subtitle 7 of this title;
a garage license issued under Subtitle 8 of this title;
a peddler license issued under Subtitle 9 of this title;
a magazine seller license issued under Subtitle 9 of this title;
a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license issued under Subtitle 10 of this title;
an agent license issued under Subtitle 10 of this title;
a Calvert County junk dealer or scrap metal processor license issued under Subtitle 10 of this title;
a license to do the business of cleaning, dyeing, pressing, or laundering issued under Subtitle 11 of this title;
a license to keep a storage warehouse issued under Subtitle 12 of this title;
a State juke box license issued under Subtitle 13 of this title;
a Harford County juke box license issued under Subtitle 13 of this title;
a promoter license issued under Subtitle 14 of this title;
a plumber’s license issued under Subtitle 15 of this title;
a restaurant license issued under Subtitle 16 of this title;
a trader’s license issued under Subtitle 18 of this title;
a chain store license issued under Subtitle 18 of this title;
a vending machine license issued under Subtitle 19 of this title; and
a license to do business as a trading stamp issuer issued under Subtitle 20 of this title.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall enforce this title.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: shall appoint a chief license inspector; and
may appoint assistant license inspectors.

paragraph.text: The chief license inspector and each assistant license inspector is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may delegate any power or duty of the Comptroller under this title.

To enforce this title, the Comptroller may make investigations and hold hearings on any matter covered by this title, at any time or place in the State, and, in connection with an investigation or hearing, may:

paragraph.text: administer oaths;
examine witnesses;
receive evidence; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce evidence.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may adopt regulations to:

paragraph.text: carry out this title; and
define any term used in this title.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: cause to be printed or otherwise prepared, in the form required by law or usage, blank licenses of each kind authorized by law; and
deliver to the clerks the number and kind of blank licenses that they need.
Before May 1 of each year, each clerk shall apply to the Comptroller for the number of blank licenses that the clerk is likely to need for the year that begins on May 1.
Each clerk shall apply to the Comptroller for blank licenses at other times as necessary.

subsection.text: If a clerk fails to comply with subsection (b) of this section, the clerk shall pay a penalty of $1,000 for each violation.
On or before the first Monday of June and the first Monday of December of each year, each clerk shall submit to the Comptroller, under oath, a list and account of licenses issued by the clerk.
The list shall contain:

paragraph.text: the number of licenses issued;
the kind of each license issued;
the date of issuance of each license;
the license fee received for each license;
the name of each licensee; and
the number and kind of any blank licenses remaining unissued.

subsection.text: If a clerk fails to comply with this section, the Comptroller shall:

paragraph.text: charge the clerk, at the rates set by law, with the whole amount of blank licenses delivered to the clerk; and
immediately bring suit against the official bond of the clerk to recover that amount.

section.text: On or before the tenth day of each month, each clerk shall send to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation a copy of each license and the application for each license that the clerk issued during the preceding month.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a console machine license, pinball machine license, Wicomico County pinball machine license, or Garrett County amusement device license issued under Subtitle 4 of this title;
a Calvert County peddler license or magazine seller license issued under Subtitle 9 of this title;
a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license, agent license, or Calvert County junk dealer or scrap metal processor license issued under Subtitle 10 of this title;
a license to keep a storage warehouse issued under Subtitle 12 of this title;
a State juke box license or Harford County juke box license issued under Subtitle 13 of this title;
a promoter license issued under Subtitle 14 of this title;
a vending machine license issued under Subtitle 19 of this title; or
a license to do business as a trading stamp issuer issued under Subtitle 20 of this title.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section or otherwise in this title, each clerk shall account for and distribute the fees received for licenses issued under this title as follows:

paragraph.text: the clerk shall pay into the General Fund of the State:

subparagraph.text: the percentage of license fees authorized by law as a fee of the office;
the additional issuance fee now allowed; and
3% of license fees to defray the expenses of the State License Bureau; and

paragraph.text: except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the clerk shall distribute the remaining license fees:

subparagraph.text: to the municipal corporation where the licensed business or activity is located, if the licensed business or activity is located in a municipal corporation; or
to the county where the licensed business or activity is located, if the licensed business or activity is not located in a municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection, per capita revenue shall be computed by using the population figures from the later of:

subparagraph.text: the most recent federal census; or
an official local census.

paragraph.text: The clerk may not distribute license fees to a county or municipal corporation unless the county or municipal corporation:

subparagraph.text: levies, in its current fiscal year, taxes sufficient to collect at least $1.00 per capita in revenue; and
certifies to the Comptroller a copy of the levy.

paragraph.text: The clerk shall pay into the General Fund of the State any money that is not distributed at the end of the fiscal year of a county or municipal corporation because the county or municipal corporation failed to make the levy and certification required by paragraph (2) of this subsection.

section.text: In this subtitle, “license” has the meaning stated in § 17-201 of this title.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, an applicant for a license under this title shall:

paragraph.text: submit to the clerk, in duplicate, an application on the form that the clerk provides;
submit to the clerk a receipt or certificate for taxes in accordance with subsection (c) of this section; and
pay to the clerk the appropriate license fee required by this title.

subsection.text: Each application for a license shall be verified in the way and contain the information that the Comptroller requires by regulation.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “county treasurer” includes the Director of Finance or other chief fiscal officer of a county that does not have a county treasurer.
This subsection does not apply to a domestic corporation that has shares subject to taxation under State law.
An applicant for a license shall submit to the clerk:

subparagraph.text: a certification by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation of the value of the goods, fixtures, and stock in trade in each county where the business is located for the applicant’s business for the valuation year;
a certification by the county treasurer of that county that there are no unpaid taxes due to the State or county on the goods, fixtures, or stock in trade; and
a certification by the municipal corporation, if any, where the business is located that there are no unpaid taxes due to the municipal corporation on the goods, fixtures, or stock in trade.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the valuation year:

subparagraph.text: in Washington County, is the fiscal year that includes May 1 of the calendar year when the license is issued; or
in each other county, is the last calendar year before the year for which the license is sought.

subsection.text: In Washington County, the clerk may not issue a license under this title for the first time unless the applicant submits to the clerk a certification that the location of the business for which the license is sought has proper zoning. The certification must be from the county planning commission or, if the business is located in a municipal corporation, from the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Calvert County.

The clerk may not issue a license under this title for the first time to a business that will be located in Calvert County unless the applicant submits to the clerk a certification that the location of the business for which the license is sought is zoned for the type of business for which the applicant is seeking a license.
The certification must be issued from:

subparagraph.text: the Calvert County Department of Planning and Zoning; or
the appropriate municipal corporation, if the location of the proposed business is within the boundaries of a municipal corporation.

subsection.text: The minimum license fee under this title is $2.50.

Except as otherwise provided in this title, the license fee shall be prorated quarterly, but not below $2.50, if an applicant applies after May 1 for a license that will become effective before the following April 30.

paragraph.text: A person who must have a license under this title but does not get the license on time shall pay to the clerk, in addition to the required license fee, a late fee.
The late fee shall be the sum of:

subparagraph.text: 10% of the required license fee for the calendar month following the calendar month when the required license fee is due; and
2% of the required license fee for each calendar month or part of a month after that.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, the clerk shall issue an appropriate license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this title.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a license is effective on May 1.
Whenever a person begins business after May 31, the clerk shall issue a license that is effective on the first of the month when the person begins business under the license.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, a license expires on the first April 30 after its effective date.

section.text: The holder of a license to do business at a particular place specified in the license shall display the license conspicuously at that place.

paragraph.text: If a specific place for doing business is stated in a license, the licensee may change the place of business only if the clerk endorses the change on the license.
Subject to subsections (b), (c), and (d) of this section, on application of the licensee, the clerk shall endorse the change on the license.

subsection.text: In Baltimore County, the clerk may not endorse a change in the place of business until the zoning commissioner approves the new place.

In Washington County, the clerk may not endorse a change in the place of business until the licensee meets the zoning requirements of § 17–302(d) of this subtitle for a license issued for the first time.

In Calvert County, the clerk may not endorse a change in the place of business until the licensee meets the zoning requirements of § 17–302(e) of this subtitle for a license issued for the first time.

section.text: If a licensee dies, the surviving spouse or personal representative of the licensee may do business under the license for the rest of the term of the license.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Free-play console machine” means a machine that:

paragraph.text: has a backboard that displays combinations of numbers or symbols;
has 2 or more reels that spin on the insertion of 1 or more coins or tokens; and

when the reels stop on combinations that match those on the backboard, rewards the player with a specified number of free games, allowing the player to continue to play the machine without inserting additional coins or tokens.

subsection.text: “Free-play pinball machine” means a machine that:

paragraph.text: on insertion of 1 or more coins or tokens, releases 1 or more balls for the player to propel by a plunger; and

if the player gets a certain score or combination of numbers, rewards the player with a specified number of free games, allowing the player to continue to play the machine without inserting additional coins or tokens.

section.text: A political subdivision that issues a license for an amusement device shall send to the Comptroller within 10 days after issuing the license:

paragraph.text: a copy of the license;
the name and address of the owner of the amusement device;
the location of the amusement device;
the name of the owner of the place where the amusement device is located; and
a description of the amusement device.

subsection.text: In Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Console machine license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a free-play console machine for public use.
“Pinball machine license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a free-play pinball machine for public use.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, Part II of this subtitle applies only in Baltimore City and Baltimore, Caroline, Dorchester, Harford, Kent, Montgomery, Queen Anne’s, and Talbot counties.
In Montgomery County, Part II of this subtitle does not apply to free-play console machines.

section.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore may license free-play pinball machines and free-play console machines under Chapter 27 of the Acts of 1951 and the ordinances implementing that chapter.

Notwithstanding any other law, it is lawful to keep and operate a free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine and to award free games to players if the free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine is licensed under Part II of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Whenever a person keeps a free-play pinball machine for public use in the State, the person must have a pinball machine license for that free-play pinball machine.
Whenever a person keeps a free-play console machine for public use in the State, the person must have a console machine license for that free-play console machine.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a pinball machine license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $10 for each free-play pinball machine in Caroline County, Kent County, or Queen Anne’s County; or
$20 for each free-play pinball machine in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Dorchester County, Harford County, Montgomery County, or Talbot County.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a console machine license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $25 for each free-play console machine in Caroline County, Kent County, or Queen Anne’s County; or
$35 for each free-play console machine in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Dorchester County, Harford County, or Talbot County.

paragraph.text: Baltimore City, Baltimore County, and Harford County may impose fees in addition to the license fee required under subsection (a) of this section.
In Harford County:

subparagraph.text: an applicant for a pinball machine license shall pay an additional fee of $20 for each free-play pinball machine; and
an applicant for a console machine license shall pay an additional fee of $35 for each free-play console machine.

subsection.text: The license fee shall be prorated monthly.
All money collected under Part II of this subtitle shall be paid into the general fund of the county where it is collected.
For each free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine licensed under Part II of this subtitle, the clerk shall issue a certificate that the license fee for the current year has been paid.
The certificate shall be attached to the free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine.
A pinball machine license may be transferred to another free-play pinball machine.
A console machine license may be transferred to another free-play console machine.
A person may not keep a free-play pinball machine for public use in the State unless the person has a pinball machine license that covers that free-play pinball machine.
A person may not keep a free-play console machine for public use in the State unless the person has a console machine license that covers that free-play console machine.

section.text: A free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine may not pay out cash or tokens.
A person who keeps a free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine for public use may not allow a minor to operate the free-play pinball machine or free-play console machine.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to free-play pinball machines that are in locked storage and not available for public use.
In Montgomery County, not more than 2 free-play pinball machines may be kept on the same floor of a building.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person who violates Part II of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each violation.
In Montgomery County, a person who violates Part II of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 for each violation.

section.text: In Part III of this subtitle, “Wicomico County pinball machine license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a pinball machine for public use in Wicomico County.
Part III of this subtitle applies only in Wicomico County.

subsection.text: Free-play console machines and free-play pinball machines may not be licensed or kept for public use in Wicomico County.
Pinball machines may be licensed under Part III of this subtitle and kept for public use in Wicomico County if they:

paragraph.text: are amusement devices only; and
are not free-play console machines or free-play pinball machines.

section.text: Whenever a person keeps a pinball machine for public use in Wicomico County, the person must have a Wicomico County pinball machine license for that pinball machine.

subsection.text: An applicant for a Wicomico County pinball machine license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $20 for each pinball machine.
The license fee shall be prorated monthly.
All money collected under Part III of this subtitle shall be paid into the general fund of Wicomico County.
For each pinball machine licensed under Part III of this subtitle, the clerk shall issue a certificate that the license fee for the current year has been paid.
The certificate shall be attached to the pinball machine.

section.text: A Wicomico County pinball machine license may be transferred to another pinball machine of the same type.
A person may not keep a pinball machine for public use in Wicomico County unless the person has a Wicomico County pinball machine license that covers that pinball machine.
A person who keeps a pinball machine for public use in Wicomico County may not allow a minor to operate the pinball machine.
A person who violates Part III of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each offense.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Amusement device” means a machine for public use that is activated by a coin or token and the result of whose operation depends wholly or partly on the skill of the player, whether or not the machine rewards a successful player.
“Amusement device” includes:

subparagraph.text: a claw machine;
a console or other pinball machine;
a shuffleboard game; and
a mechanical bowling game.

paragraph.text: “Amusement device” does not include a service or vending machine.

subsection.text: “Garrett County amusement device license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep an amusement device for public use in Garrett County.

section.text: Part IV of this subtitle applies only in Garrett County.
Whenever a person keeps an amusement device for public use in Garrett County, the person must have a Garrett County amusement device license for that amusement device.

subsection.text: An applicant for a Garrett County amusement device license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $50 for each amusement device.
All money collected under Part IV of this subtitle shall be paid into the general fund of Garrett County.
For each amusement device licensed under Part IV of this subtitle, the clerk shall issue a certificate that the license fee for the current year has been paid.
The certificate shall be attached to the amusement device.

section.text: A Garrett County amusement device license may be transferred to another amusement device of the same type.
A person who violates Part IV of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Billiard table” includes a pool table.
“Billiard table license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a billiard table for commercial use.
This subtitle does not apply in Washington County.
This subtitle does not impair the right of Baltimore City or a municipal corporation of the State to impose a tax on billiard tables.

section.text: A person must have a billiard table license whenever the person keeps a billiard table for commercial use in the State.
An applicant for a billiard table license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $10 for each billiard table in a county other than Baltimore City, Baltimore County, or Cecil County;
$20 for each billiard table in Cecil County; or
$40 for each billiard table in Baltimore City.

subsection.text: A person may not keep a billiard table for commercial use unless the person has a billiard table license.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $500 for each billiard table kept for commercial use in violation of this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Construction license” means a license issued by the clerk to do construction business.
“Do construction business” means to agree to:

paragraph.text: pave or curb a sidewalk, street, or other public or private property;
excavate earth, rock, or other material for a foundation or other purpose; or
do work on or in a building or other structure that requires the use of a building material, including:

subparagraph.text: paint;
stone;
brick;
mortar;
wood;
cement;
structural iron;
structural steel;
sheet iron;
galvanized iron;
metallic piping;
tin;
lead;
electric wiring; or
any other metal.

subsection.text: “Nonresident construction license” means a construction license issued by the clerk to a person who is incorporated or has its principal office in another state.
Except as provided in § 8-317 of this article, a person must have a construction license whenever the person does construction business in the State.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a person who is incorporated or has its principal office in another state must also have a nonresident construction license whenever the person does construction business in this State.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, an additional nonresident construction license is required for each contract to do construction business in this State if the gross amount of the contract exceeds $1,000.

No nonresident construction license is required if the state where the person is incorporated or has its principal office does not require a similar license for a Maryland contractor doing construction business in that state.

subsection.text: An applicant for a construction license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $15 for a construction license in a county other than Baltimore City, Baltimore County, or Cecil County;
$40 for a construction license in Baltimore City or Baltimore County; or
$30 for a construction license in Cecil County.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an applicant for a nonresident construction license shall pay to the clerk:

subparagraph.text: a license fee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $50 for a nonresident construction license in a county other than Baltimore City or Baltimore County; or
$60 for a nonresident construction license in Baltimore City or Baltimore County; and

subparagraph.text: for each contract for which the applicant is required to get an additional nonresident construction license, an additional license fee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $50, if the contract will be performed in a county other than Baltimore City or Baltimore County; or
$60, if the contract will be performed in Baltimore City or Baltimore County.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a nonresident construction license who is incorporated or has its principal office in another state shall pay to the clerk the total fees imposed in that state on a similar nonresident business if the total fees are higher than the total license fees under this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “wholesale farm machinery dealer’s license” means a license issued by the clerk to sell farm machinery at wholesale.
A person must have a wholesale farm machinery dealer’s license whenever the person sells farm machinery at wholesale in the State.
An applicant for a wholesale farm machinery dealer’s license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $50 for a business in a municipal corporation with a population of not more than 10,000;
$100 for a business in a municipal corporation with a population of 10,001 to 50,000; or
$200 for a business in a municipal corporation with a population of more than 50,000.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Garage” means a building or part of a building where motor vehicles are stored for a fee.
“Garage license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a garage.

section.text: A person must have a garage license whenever the person keeps a garage in the State.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a garage license shall pay to the clerk a license fee based on the floor area of each garage.
In a county other than Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $20 for a garage with not more than 2,000 square feet;
$40 for a garage with more than 2,000 and not more than 3,000 square feet;
$75 for a garage with more than 3,000 and not more than 5,000 square feet;
$125 for a garage with more than 5,000 and not more than 7,500 square feet;
$200 for a garage with more than 7,500 and not more than 10,000 square feet; or
$200 for a garage with more than 10,000 square feet plus $50 for each additional 5,000 square feet or part of 5,000 square feet.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the license fee is $6 for each 100 square feet of each garage.

subsection.text: The floor area on which the license fee is based is the total floor area of all floors of the garage, excluding:

paragraph.text: the space occupied by a machine shop that is defined by permanent partitions; and
the floor area of a space 15 feet wide and extending the entire length or depth of the garage on each floor on which a law requires that a space be kept open.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Peddler” includes a hawker, a huckster, and a mobile vendor.
“Peddler license” means a license issued by the clerk to act as a peddler.
In Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Foot peddler” means a peddler who travels on foot.
“Motor vehicle peddler” means a peddler who travels by motor vehicle.
“One horse peddler” means a peddler who travels with a wagon or other vehicle drawn by 1 horse or other beast of burden.
“Two horse peddler” means a peddler who travels with a wagon or other vehicle drawn by 2 horses or other beasts of burden.
Part II of this subtitle does not apply in Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Calvert, Cecil, Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George’s counties.
In Allegany County, Part II of this subtitle does not apply to a trader who holds a trader’s license and has kept a regular place of business in Allegany County for at least 5 years.
In Charles County, Part II of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: applies to the sale of goods from a motor vehicle or temporary stand; but
does not apply to the sale of goods from a motor vehicle or temporary stand in connection with a permanent business in Charles County if:

subparagraph.text: the seller has the written permission of the owner of the business; and
the motor vehicle or temporary stand is on or adjacent to the premises of the business.

subsection.text: In Harford County, Part II of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: applies to the sale of goods from a vehicle or temporary stand; and
does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: the sale of goods on property that the seller owns or leases; or
a not for profit organization.

subsection.text: In St. Mary’s County, Part II of this subtitle applies to a nonresident of St. Mary’s County who sells goods from a motor vehicle, temporary stand, or other temporary location.
Except in Harford County, Part II of this subtitle does not apply to the sale of:

paragraph.text: fish or oysters in their natural and unpreserved condition; or
perishable fruits or vegetables in their natural condition.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part II of this subtitle, a person must have a peddler license whenever the person acts as a peddler in the State.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a peddler license shall pay to the clerk the applicable license fee.
If the applicant is a foot peddler, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: in Baltimore City, $200;
in St. Mary’s County, the amount set by the County Commissioners, by resolution; and
in any other county, $100.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a one horse peddler, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: in Baltimore City, $250;
in St. Mary’s County, the amount set by the County Commissioners, by resolution; and
in any other county, $150.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a two horse peddler, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: in Baltimore City, $300;
in St. Mary’s County, the amount set by the County Commissioners, by resolution; and
in any other county, $200.

paragraph.text: If the applicant is a motor vehicle peddler, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: in Baltimore City, $500;
in St. Mary’s County, the amount set by the County Commissioners, by resolution; and
in any other county, $300; but

sub-subparagraph.text: in Garrett County, the license fee is $100 for a resident of Garrett County; and
in Worcester County, the license fee is $100 for a resident of Worcester County who sells only ice cream.

paragraph.text: In Harford County, an applicant for a peddler license must have the written permission of the owner or lessee of the property where the applicant will do business.
The written permission shall include:

subparagraph.text: the name, address, and telephone number of the owner or lessee of the property;
the name, permanent address, and telephone number of the applicant;
a description of the goods to be sold by the applicant; and
the times of day and the number of days per month that the applicant is allowed to do business on the property of the owner or lessee.

section.text: The clerk shall provide a metal tag or stamp to each one horse peddler, two horse peddler, or motor vehicle peddler who holds a peddler license.

subsection.text: A peddler license authorizes the holder to act as a peddler only in the county where the peddler license is issued.
In Harford County, a peddler may not sell goods on:

paragraph.text: a county right-of-way; or
a State right-of-way, unless the peddler gets a lease agreement from the appropriate State unit.

subsection.text: Each one horse peddler, two horse peddler, and motor vehicle peddler shall keep the metal tag or stamp issued under this subtitle attached to the vehicle so as to be clearly visible.
A peddler in Harford County shall:

paragraph.text: keep with the peddler at all times the peddler license and a copy of the original written permission of the property owner required under this subtitle; and
produce the peddler license and copy of the written permission on request.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part II of this subtitle, a person may not act as a peddler unless the person has a peddler license.
A peddler is considered to be acting as a peddler without a peddler license if the peddler:

paragraph.text: acts or offers to act as a peddler without the peddler license with the peddler at the time; or
fails to show the peddler license to a law enforcement officer on request.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.
This section does not apply in Allegany and Washington counties.
A municipal corporation may not require a local license or impose a local fee or tax to sell fresh fruits, vegetables, or other country produce from a wagon at retail if the seller is the producer.
However, a municipal corporation by ordinance may:

paragraph.text: provide for the issuance of identification cards or tags to producers of country produce who sell the produce from a wagon at retail;
set a fee, not exceeding 50 cents for each producer, for the issuance of identification cards or tags; and
require producers to get and display identification cards or tags.

A person who is not the producer may not sell or offer to sell any fresh fruits, vegetables, or other country produce from a wagon at retail in a municipal corporation that requires a local license or imposes a local fee or tax to do so without getting the license or paying the fee or tax.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $25.

section.text: If the County Commissioners of St. Mary’s County set a license fee for a license issued under § 17-907 of this subtitle, the County Commissioners shall notify the Comptroller of the Treasury by December 31 of the year before the year the license fee takes effect.

subsection.text: In Part III of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Magazine seller license” means a license issued by the clerk to act as a nonresident itinerant magazine seller.
“Nonresident itinerant magazine seller” means a person who:

paragraph.text: is not a resident of Calvert County; and
sells or offers to sell a subscription to a magazine or other publication.

subsection.text: Part III of this subtitle applies only in Calvert County.
Part III of this subtitle does not apply to sales by producers of their own vegetables or other perishable farm products.
Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person must have a peddler license whenever in Calvert County the person:

paragraph.text: sells or offers for sale at wholesale or retail any vegetables, eggs, poultry, meats, or other farm products; or
sells or offers for sale at retail any dry goods or clothing.

subsection.text: A person must have a magazine seller license whenever the person acts as a nonresident itinerant magazine seller in Calvert County.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a peddler license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $75, if the applicant sells at wholesale; or
$150, if the applicant sells at retail.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a magazine seller license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $50.

subsection.text: The clerk shall pay all money collected under this subtitle to the County Treasurer of Calvert County to be placed in the general fund of Calvert County.

section.text: The clerk shall issue to each holder of a peddler license a metal tag that indicates that the license fee for the current year has been paid.
Each holder of a peddler license shall keep the metal tag attached to any vehicle used by the peddler.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, unless a person has a peddler license, the person may not in Calvert County:

paragraph.text: sell or offer for sale at wholesale or retail any vegetables, eggs, poultry, meats, or other farm products; or
sell or offer for sale at retail any dry goods or clothing.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person may not act as a nonresident itinerant magazine seller in Calvert County unless the person has a magazine seller license.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $300.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agent” means a person who buys or sells junk or scrap metal for a junk dealer or scrap metal processor.
“Antique dealer” means a person who does business buying and selling antiques.
“Antiques” means objects made in, or typical of, an earlier period of time, that either have special value because of their age or are examples of works of art or handicrafts.

paragraph.text: “Junk” or “scrap metal” includes:

subparagraph.text: nonferrous articles made wholly or substantially of:

sub-subparagraph.text: aluminum;
babbitt metal;
brass;
bronze;
light copper;
heavy copper;
lead;
low carbon chrome;
low carbon manganese;
molybdenum;
monel metal;
pewter;
nickel;
stainless steel;
tin;
vanadium;
zinc;
platinum;
gold;
rhodium; or
other nonferrous metals; and

subparagraph.text: the following used articles, made of either ferrous or nonferrous metal:

sub-subparagraph.text: catalytic converters;
metal bleachers;
hard–drawn copper;
metal beer kegs;
cemetery urns;
grave markers;
propane tanks; and
any other used articles owned by a public utility including:

paragraph.text: “Junk” or “scrap metal” does not include beverage cans or food cans.
“Junk dealer” or “scrap metal processor” means a person who does business buying or selling junk or scrap metal.
“Junk dealer” or “scrap metal processor” does not include a dealer or pawnbroker licensed under Title 12 of this article.

subsection.text: “Primary law enforcement unit” means the Department of State Police, a police department, or sheriff, as designated by a resolution of the county or municipal governing body in the county in which the license of the junk dealer or scrap metal processor is held.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a dealer or pawnbroker licensed under Title 12 of this article;
a person doing business other than junk business or scrap metal business whenever the person:

subparagraph.text: buys or transports junk or scrap metal used in the operation of the business; or
transports, for disposal or sale, junk or scrap metal accumulated by the business to dispose of or sell the junk or scrap metal; or

paragraph.text: a vehicle that a common carrier uses to transport junk or scrap metal in the business of the common carrier.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 17–1012 of this subtitle, this subtitle does not apply to antique dealers.

A county or municipal governing body in the county in which the license of the junk dealer or scrap metal processor is held shall designate by resolution the primary law enforcement unit to receive records in accordance with § 17–1011(b) of this subtitle.

If a municipal governing body designates a county police department or sheriff as the primary law enforcement unit under this section, the county may designate the Department of State Police as the primary law enforcement unit.
In Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agent license” means a license issued by the clerk to act as an agent.
“Junk dealer or scrap metal processor license” means a license issued by the clerk to do business as a junk dealer or scrap metal processor.
“Nonresident junk dealer” or “nonresident scrap metal processor” means a junk dealer or scrap metal processor who is not a resident of the State.
“State junk license” includes:

paragraph.text: a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license; and
an agent license.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person must have a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license whenever the person does business as a junk dealer or scrap metal processor in the State.
This subsection does not apply to a situation in which:

subparagraph.text: a nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor buys junk or scrap metal from a junk dealer or scrap metal processor licensee who is a resident of the State; or
the nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor transports that junk or scrap metal.

paragraph.text: If a nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor comes into the State in a vehicle, the nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor may not transport from the State in that vehicle any junk or scrap metal bought in the State unless the nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor holds a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person must have an agent license whenever the person acts as an agent in the State.
This subsection does not apply to a salaried employee of a junk dealer or scrap metal processor licensee.

section.text: An applicant for a State junk license shall:

paragraph.text: certify to the clerk the applicant’s name and business address; and
pay to the clerk a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $10 for a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license, if the applicant is a resident of the State;
$5 for an agent license, if the applicant is a resident of the State; or
$100 for a junk dealer or scrap metal processor license or agent license, if the applicant is not a resident of the State.

subsection.text: The clerk shall:

paragraph.text: issue, in numerical order, a State junk license to each applicant who meets the requirements of Part II of this subtitle; and
collect an issuing fee of 50 cents per State junk license.

subsection.text: The clerk shall keep a record of the name, business address, and license number of each State junk licensee.

section.text: A State junk license is not transferable.
A nonresident junk dealer or nonresident scrap metal processor may not keep a fixed place of business in the State.

paragraph.text: This section applies to all junk dealers and scrap metal processors doing business in the State, including nonresident junk dealers and nonresident scrap metal processors.

This section applies to an automotive dismantler and recycler or scrap metal processor licensed under Title 15, Subtitle 5 of the Transportation Article if the automotive dismantler and recycler or scrap metal processor:

subparagraph.text: conducts business as a licensed junk dealer or scrap metal processor;
acquires vehicle parts that qualify as junk or scrap metal as defined under § 17–1001(e) of this subtitle; or
acquires articles that are listed, or made of metals that are listed, in § 17–1001(e) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: an automotive dismantler and recycler or scrap metal processor that only acquires whole vehicles for the purpose of dismantling, destroying, or scrapping them for the benefit of their parts or the materials in them; or
a person that buys scrap metal to use as raw material to produce 1,000,000 tons of steel or more in the State per calendar year.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, this section preempts the right of a county or municipality to regulate the resale of junk or scrap metal.
This section does not limit the power of a county or municipality to license junk dealers and scrap metal processors.
This section supersedes any existing law of a county or municipality that regulates the resale of junk or scrap metal.

paragraph.text: For each purchase of junk or scrap metal in the State, a junk dealer or scrap metal processor shall keep an accurate record in English.
The record shall state:

subparagraph.text: the date and time of purchase;
a description of the junk or scrap metal purchased, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the type and grade of the junk or scrap metal; and
if payment is based on weight, the weight of each type and grade of junk or scrap metal;

subparagraph.text: the amount paid or other consideration for the junk or scrap metal;
the registration plate number, make, and model of any vehicle used;
the name and address of the individual from whom the junk or scrap metal is acquired;
the signature of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the individual from whom the junk or scrap metal is acquired; and
the junk dealer, scrap metal processor, or employee who accepted the junk or scrap metal; and

subparagraph.text: for each individual from whom the junk dealer or scrap metal processor acquires junk or scrap metal:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date of birth and driver’s license number of the individual; or

identification information about the individual from a valid State–issued photo ID that provides a physical description of the individual, including the sex, race, any distinguishing features, and approximate age, height, and weight of the individual.

paragraph.text: The records required under this subsection shall be kept in electronic form.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph, the junk dealer or scrap metal processor shall submit a copy of each record required under this paragraph to the primary law enforcement unit in accordance with subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph.

A junk dealer or scrap metal processor shall submit a record by transmitting a copy of the records electronically, in a format acceptable to the receiving primary law enforcement unit, by the end of the first business day following the date of the transaction.
Each copy of a record submitted to the primary law enforcement unit shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date and time of purchase;
a description of the junk or scrap metal, including its weight if payment is based on weight;
whether the amount paid or other consideration for the junk or scrap metal exceeds $500;
the registration plate number of any vehicle used by the individual from whom the junk or scrap metal is acquired;
the name and address of the individual from whom the junk or scrap metal is acquired;
the date of birth and driver’s license number of the individual from whom the junk or scrap metal is acquired;

identification information about the individual from a valid State–issued photo ID that provides a physical description of the individual, including the sex, race, age, height, and weight of the individual; and
an electronic scan or photocopy of the valid State–issued photo ID under item 7 of this subparagraph.

subparagraph.text: The provisions of subparagraphs (i), (ii), and (iii) of this paragraph may not be construed to require a junk dealer or scrap metal processor to incur a substantial financial burden to comply with the requirements of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: A copy of a record submitted under paragraph (4) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be kept confidential;
is not a public record; and
is not subject to Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: The primary law enforcement unit may destroy the copy of a record submitted under paragraph (4) of this subsection after 1 year from the date that the primary law enforcement unit receives the copy.

subparagraph.text: The primary law enforcement unit may waive the holding of electronic records under paragraph (3) of this subsection or the submission of electronic records under paragraph (4) of this subsection by a junk dealer or scrap metal processor.
Any waivers granted under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall be limited to authorizing a junk dealer or scrap metal processor to:

sub-subparagraph.text: extend the reporting deadline under paragraph (4) of this subsection for an extra day;
hold written records; or
submit records by facsimile or by mail.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to junk dealers and scrap metal processors who are residents of the State.
Each junk dealer or scrap metal processor shall keep the records required by subsection (b) of this section for 1 year after the date of the transaction.

The records kept in accordance with this subsection shall be open to inspection during business hours by State or local law enforcement personnel for an investigation of a specific crime involving the materials listed under § 17–1001(e) of this subtitle.

A junk dealer or scrap metal processor may not barter, buy, exchange, or accept from a person any junk or scrap metal unless the junk dealer or scrap metal processor keeps records and makes entries in them in accordance with Part II of this subtitle.
A junk dealer or scrap metal processor may not purchase a catalytic converter from an individual unless the individual, at the time of purchase, provides identification as:

subparagraph.text: a licensed automotive dismantler and recycler or scrap metal processor; or
an agent or employee of a licensed commercial enterprise.

paragraph.text: A junk dealer or scrap metal processor may not purchase a cemetery urn, grave marker, or any other item listed under § 17–1001(e)(1)(ii) of this subtitle from an individual unless the individual, at the time of purchase, provides appropriate authorization from a relevant business or unit of federal, State, or local government specifically authorizing the individual to conduct the transaction.

subsection.text: State or local law enforcement personnel may request information from the records required under subsection (b) of this section pursuant to an investigation of a specific crime involving the materials listed under § 17–1001(e) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The record and reporting requirements of subsection (b) of this section do not apply to an item that is acquired from:

subparagraph.text: a licensed junk dealer or scrap metal processor;
a unit of federal, State, or local government; or
a commercial enterprise with a valid business license that has entered into a written contract with a junk dealer or scrap metal processor who has provided to the primary law enforcement unit:

sub-subparagraph.text: the name and business address of the commercial enterprise; and
the type of junk or scrap metal subject to the contract.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a contract under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection shall be open to inspection by a local law enforcement agency on the premises of the junk dealer or scrap metal processor during business hours.

Notwithstanding any other law, a contract open to inspection by a local law enforcement agency under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph may not be open for public inspection without the consent of the junk dealer or scrap metal processor.

paragraph.text: If a State or local law enforcement agency has reasonable cause to believe that junk or scrap metal that is in the possession of a junk dealer or scrap metal processor is stolen, the law enforcement agency may issue a written hold notice.
The written hold notice shall:

subparagraph.text: identify the items of junk or scrap metal alleged to be stolen and subject to hold;
inform the junk dealer or scrap metal processor of the hold imposed on the items of junk or scrap metal; and
specify the time period for the hold, not to exceed 15 days.

paragraph.text: On receipt of a written hold notice from a law enforcement agency, a junk dealer or scrap metal processor may not process or remove from the junk dealer’s or scrap metal processor’s place of business before the end of the hold period any items of junk or scrap metal identified in the hold notice, unless the item is released by the law enforcement agency or by court order.

subsection.text: Local law enforcement personnel of the county where the place of business of the junk dealer or scrap metal processor is located or where the junk or scrap metal was purchased may enforce this section.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: a fine not exceeding $500 for a first offense; and
a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both for a subsequent offense.

subsection.text: In this section, “historic marker or plaque” means a marker, plaque, or tablet commemorating a historic person or event, or identifying a historic place, structure, or object.
This section applies to all junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and antique dealers who are residents of the State.

paragraph.text: Each junk dealer, scrap metal processor, or antique dealer subject to this section who purchases a historic marker or plaque shall register with the sheriff or other law enforcement official designated by the governing body of the county in which the business of the junk dealer, scrap metal processor, or antique dealer is located a complete description of the historic marker or plaque.
The description shall include:

subparagraph.text: the date and time of purchase;
the name and address of the seller;
the license tag number of any vehicle used; and
a description of the historic marker or plaque, including the full text, any installation date, and the name of any installation sponsor.

paragraph.text: The registration required under this section shall be made within 3 business days after the date of the purchase of the historic marker or plaque.

subsection.text: The sheriff or other law enforcement official promptly shall notify the Maryland Historical Trust with a copy to the junk dealer, scrap metal processor, or antique dealer who registered with the sheriff.
A historic marker or plaque may not be sold or otherwise disposed of for a period of 30 days from the date of the notice required under subsection (d) of this section.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.

section.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided in Part II of this subtitle, a person who violates Part II of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 for each offense.
In this subtitle, “license” means a license issued by the clerk to do the business of cleaning, dyeing, pressing, or laundering.
A person must have a license whenever the person does the business of cleaning, dyeing, pressing, or laundering, other than hand laundering, in the State.

subsection.text: An applicant for a license shall pay to the clerk the applicable license fee.
In a county other than Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the license fee is:

paragraph.text: $15 for a business that employs not more than 10 individuals;
$50 for a business that employs 11 to 20 individuals; and
$100 for a business that employs more than 20 individuals.

subsection.text: In Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the license fee is:

paragraph.text: $40 for a business that employs not more than 10 individuals;
$125 for a business that employs 11 to 20 individuals; and
$250 for a business that employs more than 20 individuals.

section.text: In this subtitle, “license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a storage warehouse.
A person must have a license whenever the person keeps a storage warehouse where goods are stored for a fee in the State.
An applicant for a license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $30 for a storage warehouse in a municipal corporation with a population of not more than 10,000;
$50 for a storage warehouse in a municipal corporation with a population of 10,001 to 20,000;
$75 for a storage warehouse in a municipal corporation with a population of 20,001 to 50,000; or
$150 for a storage warehouse in a municipal corporation with a population of more than 50,000.

subsection.text: Before a moving and storage firm or warehouse that stores household goods provides any service, the moving and storage firm or warehouse shall give notice to the buyer of the service that the buyer should get insurance to protect the buyer from loss of goods.
The notice shall be:

paragraph.text: in writing;
printed in 12-point or larger type; and
included in the application for service or in a separate statement.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “State juke box license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a juke box for public entertainment.
Whenever a person keeps a juke box for public entertainment in the State, the person must have a State juke box license for that juke box.

subsection.text: An applicant for a State juke box license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $10 for each juke box.
The clerk shall pay to the Comptroller all license fees collected under this subtitle.

section.text: The clerk shall issue each State juke box license in the name of the owner of the juke box.
A State juke box license is transferable.
Each State juke box licensee shall display the State juke box license on the premises where the juke box is located.

subsection.text: A person may not keep a juke box for public entertainment in the State unless the person has a State juke box license that covers that juke box.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $100.

section.text: In Part III of this subtitle, “Harford County juke box license” means a license issued by the clerk to keep a juke box for public entertainment in Harford County.
Whenever a person keeps a juke box for public entertainment in Harford County, the person must have both a State juke box license and a Harford County juke box license for that juke box.
An applicant for a Harford County juke box license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $10 for each juke box.
The clerk shall issue each Harford County juke box license in the name of the owner of the juke box.
A Harford County juke box license is transferable.
Each Harford County juke box licensee shall display the Harford County juke box license on the premises where the juke box is located.

subsection.text: A person may not keep a juke box for public entertainment in Harford County unless the person has a Harford County juke box license that covers that juke box.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $100.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Health officer” means the health officer for the county where an outdoor musical festival will be held.
“Outdoor musical festival” means an event at which a group of individuals participates in musical entertainment:

paragraph.text: in an open space;
not in a permanent structure; and
not on publicly owned property.
“Promoter” means a person who:

subparagraph.text: organizes, operates, produces, or stages an outdoor musical festival; or
owns or leases property where an outdoor musical festival is held.

paragraph.text: “Promoter” does not include the State or a political subdivision of the State.

subsection.text: “Promoter license” means a license issued by the clerk to act as a promoter.
This subtitle does not apply in Baltimore City or Allegany, Howard, and Montgomery counties.
This subtitle does not apply to an outdoor musical festival held in:

paragraph.text: Carroll County by a college or public school; or
Kent County by a not for profit agricultural, charitable, civic, fraternal, religious, social welfare, or war veterans’ organization operating in Kent County.

In Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Calvert, Caroline, Cecil, Charles, Dorchester, Garrett, Harford, Prince George’s, Somerset, St. Mary’s, Talbot, Wicomico, and Worcester counties, this subtitle applies only to an outdoor musical festival with 1,000 or more spectators in attendance.
In Carroll, Frederick, Kent, Queen Anne’s, and Washington counties, this subtitle applies only to an outdoor musical festival with 500 or more spectators in attendance.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only if admission is charged to attend the outdoor musical festival.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person must have a promoter license whenever the person acts as a promoter in the State.

subsection.text: An applicant for a promoter license shall:

paragraph.text: pay to the clerk a license fee of $500;
get a health permit from the health officer; and
get a safety permit from the Secretary of State Police.

subsection.text: An applicant for a health permit shall:

paragraph.text: post a bond in accordance with § 17-1405 of this subtitle;
establish adequate health facilities and sanitation in accordance with any regulations adopted by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to govern outdoor musical festivals; and
show that the applicant has obtained approval of the local law enforcement unit.
An applicant for a safety permit shall show that the applicant has provided:

subparagraph.text: adequate security for the safety of spectators and their property;
adequate arrangements for the orderly flow of traffic to, at, and from the outdoor musical festival; and
adequate security for those persons who might reasonably be affected by the outdoor musical festival and for their property.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection does not apply in St. Mary’s County.

subsection.text: In St. Mary’s County, this section does not apply if the promoter owns the property where the outdoor musical festival will be held.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, each promoter shall post a cash bond with the application for a health permit.
The amount of the bond:

subparagraph.text: shall be determined by the health officer; but
may not exceed:

sub-subparagraph.text: $25,000 in Frederick and Washington counties; or
$50,000 in the other counties to which this subtitle applies.

paragraph.text: In St. Mary’s County, a promoter may pledge real or personal property instead of posting a cash bond if the promoter submits to the health officer a verified financial statement confirming that the fair market value of the pledged property equals or exceeds the amount of the bond required.

subsection.text: The health officer:

paragraph.text: shall keep the bond until 30 days after the end of the outdoor musical festival; and
after that time, shall return to the promoter any money that has not been used and is not needed to satisfy pending claims.

subsection.text: If, within 72 hours after an outdoor musical festival ends, the promoter fails to remove all trash, and to begin repair of any damage to property, including crops and livestock, that the outdoor musical festival or its spectators caused or created, the health officer may use as much of the bond as necessary to remove the trash and repair the damage.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not affect any common law remedy that the person has against the promoter.
Any person who has a claim against the bond shall submit the claim to the health officer within 30 days after the outdoor musical festival ends.
If a claim is submitted, the health officer shall determine and keep the amount necessary to cover the claim.

section.text: Notwithstanding the license fee imposed under this subtitle, the Department of State Police may charge an applicant for a promoter license a fee of not more than $12 to cover the costs of securing records from a source other than the Department of State Police.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not act as a promoter in the State unless the person has a promoter license.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “plumber’s license” means a license issued by the clerk to do business as a plumber or gas fitter.
This subtitle does not apply to a person who holds a trader’s license issued under Subtitle 18 of this title.
A person must have a plumber’s license whenever the person does business as a plumber or gas fitter in the State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) or (c) of this section, an applicant for a plumber’s license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $5 for each place of business in a municipal corporation with a population of less than 5,000;
$10 for each place of business in a municipal corporation with a population of 5,000 to 9,999;
$15 for each place of business in a municipal corporation with a population of 10,000 or more; or
$40 for each place of business in Baltimore City or Baltimore County.

subsection.text: In Cecil County, an applicant for a plumber’s license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $30.

An applicant for a plumber’s license who is incorporated or has its principal office in another state shall pay to the clerk the fee imposed in that state on a similar nonresident business if that fee is higher than the appropriate license fee under this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “restaurant license” means a license issued by the clerk to operate a restaurant or other eating place.
This subtitle does not apply in Montgomery County.
A person must have a restaurant license whenever the person operates a restaurant or other eating place in the State.
An applicant for a restaurant license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $50 for each place of business in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, or Cecil County;
$25 for each place of business in a municipal corporation with a population of 8,000 or more in any other county; or
$10 for each place of business elsewhere in the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Blind Industries” means Blind Industries and Services of Maryland.
“Chain store license” means a license issued by the clerk to operate 2 or more stores under the same general management or ownership.
