“Exhibitor” means a person who rents space from a promoter to display and sell goods at a show.
“Licensed trader” means a trader who is licensed by the clerk under this subtitle.
“Promoter” means a person who rents space at a show to an exhibitor.
“Show” includes an antique show, coin show, flea market, gun show, stamp show, and show of a temporary nature.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the sale of alcoholic beverages.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by State law and notwithstanding any local ordinance or regulation to the contrary, a manufacturer located and doing business in the State may sell and deliver goods to licensed traders in the State and for doing so need not get a license from or pay a fee to a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision.
A county or municipal corporation may require a local license to sell goods at auction.

Notwithstanding any public general or public local law to the contrary, if a visually handicapped individual or Blind Industries holds a trader’s license under this subtitle, the individual or Blind Industries need not get an additional license or pay an additional license fee to do business as a trader during the term of the trader’s license.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person must have a trader’s license whenever the person:

paragraph.text: does business as a trader in the State; or
does business as an exhibitor in the State.

subsection.text: A separate trader’s license is required for each store or fixed place of business that a person operates in the State.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a grower, maker, or manufacturer of goods;

a nonresident traveling salesperson, sample merchant, or representative of a foreign mercantile or manufacturing business while selling to or soliciting an order from a licensed trader in the State; or
a private individual while publicly selling the individual’s personal effects on the individual’s property, if the individual holds only 1 sale not exceeding 14 consecutive days in a calendar year.
An exhibitor need not get a trader’s license for a show if the show is promoted by:

subparagraph.text: a church, as defined in § 5–301(b) of the Corporations and Associations Article;
a governmental unit;
an amateur radio organization;
an antique vehicle, machine, and equipment organization;
a volunteer fire department or rescue squad; or
a model train collectors’ association.

paragraph.text: An exhibitor need not get a trader’s license for a show if the exhibitor gives to the promoter an exhibitor’s affidavit stating that the exhibitor:

subparagraph.text: receives less than 10% of the exhibitor’s annual income from selling the kind of goods that the exhibitor will display and sell at the show; and

has not participated in more than three shows, not including participation in one show sponsored by a national organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, during the previous 365 days.

paragraph.text: An exhibitor at an antique show, coin show, or collector show need not get a trader’s license for the show if the exhibitor gives to the promoter an exhibitor’s affidavit stating that the exhibitor:

subparagraph.text: will display and sell at the show;
receives less than 10% of the exhibitor’s annual income in the State from selling the kind of goods that the exhibitor will display and sell at the show; and
has not participated in more than three antique shows, coin shows, or collector shows in the State during the previous 365 days.

paragraph.text: An exhibitor who has a trader’s license need not get an additional trader’s license for a show if, before the show, the exhibitor gives the promoter a photocopy of the trader’s license.

section.text: A person must have a chain store license whenever the person operates 2 or more retail stores under the same general management or ownership in the State.

subsection.text: An applicant for a trader’s license shall state in the application the place where the applicant will do business as a trader.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply if the average value of the applicant’s stock in trade exceeds $10,000.
An applicant for a trader’s license may apply under this subsection if the applicant has a defect in vision such that:

subparagraph.text: visual acuity in the applicant’s better eye does not exceed 20/140 with correcting lenses; or
the widest diameter of the applicant’s visual field subtends an angle not exceeding 20 degrees.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a trader’s license under this subsection shall submit to the clerk:

subparagraph.text: a signed certificate, from a licensed physician who specializes in treatment of the eye, that the applicant’s vision meets the standard of paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
an affidavit that the applicant is the owner of the place of business listed in the application.

paragraph.text: Blind Industries also may apply for a trader’s license under this subsection for a business that it operates, if Blind Industries submits to the clerk an affidavit that:

subparagraph.text: Blind Industries operates the business listed in the application; and
the manager of the business has vision that meets the standard of paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: In Baltimore County, the clerk may not issue a trader’s license for the first time without the approval of the zoning commissioner.

In an area of Cecil County where the Cecil County Office of Planning and Zoning has jurisdiction, the clerk may not issue a trader’s license for the first time until the applicant has obtained zoning approval from that office.

paragraph.text: In Howard County, the clerk may not issue a trader’s license for the first time without the approval of the Director of the Office of Planning and Zoning.

Within 3 working days after an application for a trader’s license is submitted for review to the Director of the Office of Planning and Zoning, the Director shall notify the clerk of the approval or disapproval of the application.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, an applicant for a trader’s license shall pay to the clerk a license fee based on the value of the applicant’s stock–in–trade.
In a county other than Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $15, if the value of the applicant’s stock–in–trade is not more than $1,000;
$18, if the value is more than $1,000 but not more than $1,500;
$20, if the value is more than $1,500 but not more than $2,500;
$25, if the value is more than $2,500 but not more than $4,000;
$30, if the value is more than $4,000 but not more than $6,000;
$40, if the value is more than $6,000 but not more than $8,000;
$50, if the value is more than $8,000 but not more than $10,000;
$65, if the value is more than $10,000 but not more than $15,000;
$80, if the value is more than $15,000 but not more than $20,000;
$100, if the value is more than $20,000 but not more than $30,000;
$125, if the value is more than $30,000 but not more than $40,000;
$150, if the value is more than $40,000 but not more than $50,000;
$200, if the value is more than $50,000 but not more than $75,000;
$250, if the value is more than $75,000 but not more than $100,000;
$300, if the value is more than $100,000 but not more than $150,000;
$350, if the value is more than $150,000 but not more than $200,000;
$400, if the value is more than $200,000 but not more than $300,000;
$500, if the value is more than $300,000 but not more than $400,000;
$600, if the value is more than $400,000 but not more than $500,000;
$750, if the value is more than $500,000 but not more than $750,000; or
$800, if the value is more than $750,000.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore City, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $20, if the value of the applicant’s stock–in–trade is not more than $1,000;
$40, if the value is more than $1,000 but not more than $5,000;
$80, if the value is more than $5,000 but not more than $10,000;
$160, if the value is more than $10,000 but not more than $50,000;
$375, if the value is more than $50,000 but not more than $100,000;
$1,000, if the value is more than $100,000 but not more than $300,000;
$1,500, if the value is more than $300,000 but not more than $750,000; or
$2,125, if the value is more than $750,000.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore County, the license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $20, if the value of the applicant’s stock–in–trade is not more than $1,000;
$40, if the value is more than $1,000 but not more than $5,000;
$80, if the value is more than $5,000 but not more than $10,000;
$160, if the value is more than $10,000 but not more than $50,000;
$375, if the value is more than $50,000 but not more than $100,000;
$450, if the value is more than $100,000 but not more than $200,000;
$500, if the value is more than $200,000 but not more than $300,000;
$775, if the value is more than $300,000 but not more than $400,000;
$1,000, if the value is more than $400,000 but not more than $500,000;
$1,250, if the value is more than $500,000 but not more than $750,000; and
$1,600, if the value is more than $750,000.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a domestic corporation that has shares subject to taxation under State law.

In determining the value of an applicant’s stock-in-trade, the clerk shall accept as prima facie evidence the values shown on the certification of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation required by § 17-302 of this title.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, if the average value of the applicant’s stock-in-trade is $10,000 or less, a visually handicapped applicant who meets the standards of § 17-1806(b)(2) of this subtitle or Blind Industries shall pay to the clerk a license fee of only $6.
This section does not apply to an automobile service station where the principal business is the sale or distribution of motor fuel.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a chain store license shall pay to the clerk a license fee based on the value of the applicant’s stock–in–trade under § 17–1808 of this subtitle and an additional license fee.
In a county other than Baltimore City, Baltimore County, or Cecil County, the additional license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $5 for each store for 2 to 5 stores;
$20 for each store for 6 to 10 stores;
$100 for each store for 11 to 20 stores; or
$150 for each store for more than 20 stores.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore City or Baltimore County, the additional license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $12 for each store for 2 to 5 stores;
$50 for each store for 6 to 10 stores;
$250 for each store for 11 to 20 stores; or
$375 for each store for more than 20 stores.

paragraph.text: In Cecil County, the additional license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $10 for each store for 2 to 5 stores;
$30 for each store for 6 to 10 stores;
$100 for each store for 11 to 20 stores; and
$300 for each store for more than 20 stores.

section.text: The clerk shall state on each trader’s license the place where the licensed trader may do business as a trader.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a trader’s license authorizes the holder to offer goods for sale in any part of the State.
However, a trader may keep a store or fixed place of business only at the place stated in the trader’s license.

subsection.text: A trader’s license issued to an exhibitor authorizes the holder to do business as an exhibitor at any show in the State.

paragraph.text: If a trader disputes the value of the trader’s stock-in-trade on which the license fee is based, the trader may submit in accordance with the Tax - Property Article an appeal to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation as to the value of the stock-in-trade.
To avoid being in default, the trader may pay the license fee and get a trader’s license with the understanding that the trader will get a refund of any excess amount paid for the trader’s license.

If the State Department of Assessments and Taxation reduces the value of the stock-in-trade, resulting in a lower license fee, the licensed trader may get a refund of any excess amount paid by submitting to the clerk who issued the trader’s license:

subparagraph.text: a claim for the refund; and
supporting evidence of the reduction from the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: On approving the claim, the clerk shall pay the refund.

subsection.text: If the clerk pays a refund, the clerk shall deduct the amount of the refund from the license fees distributed to the county or municipal corporation that receives the fee.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a trader may transfer the trader’s license to a person who:

paragraph.text: buys the stock-in-trade of the trader; and
buys or rents the place of business of the trader.
A trader’s license issued to a visually handicapped individual or Blind Industries is not transferable.

However, Blind Industries may change the manager of the place of business for which a trader’s license was issued if the new manager has vision that meets the standard of § 17-1806(b)(2) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Whenever a trader sells the trader’s stock-in-trade and transfers the trader’s license:

paragraph.text: the transfer of the trader’s license shall be reported to the clerk who issued the license; and
the clerk shall:

subparagraph.text: record the transfer of the trader’s license; and
charge 50 cents for doing so.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore County, the clerk may not issue a transferred trader’s license without the approval of the zoning commissioner.

subparagraph.text: In Howard County, the clerk may not issue a transferred trader’s license without the approval of the Director of the Office of Planning and Zoning.

Within 3 working days after an application for issuance of a transferred trader’s license is submitted for review by the Director of the Office of Planning and Zoning, the Director shall notify the clerk of the approval or disapproval of the application.

subsection.text: A person who buys a trader’s license may do business as a trader for the rest of the term of the trader’s license.
A promoter may not allow an exhibitor to do business at a show unless, before the show, the exhibitor submits to the promoter:

paragraph.text: a photocopy of the trader’s license of the exhibitor; or
an exhibitor’s affidavit in accordance with § 17-1804(d)(2) or (3) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The exhibitor’s affidavit or the photocopy of the trader’s license shall be displayed conspicuously during the show.
Within 7 days after a show ends, the promoter shall submit to the Comptroller the exhibitors’ affidavits.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Yacht brokerage” means the sale of new or used vessels.

subparagraph.text: “Yacht salesperson” means an individual who provides yacht brokerage services on behalf of a licensed trader.
“Yacht salesperson” includes a licensed yacht broker.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, a licensed trader who sells yachts may, at the trader’s option, utilize as an independent contractor, employ, or otherwise contract with a yacht salesperson.
A yacht salesperson:

paragraph.text: may operate under a trader’s license; and
is not required to be licensed personally.
A licensed trader shall exercise reasonable and adequate supervision over the provision of yacht brokerage services by a yacht salesperson on behalf of the trader.
The requirement of paragraph (1) of this subsection shall apply regardless of the manner in which a yacht salesperson is affiliated with the trader on whose behalf the services are rendered.

section.text: A person, including a licensed physician, who violates or conspires to violate any provision of this subtitle that relates to trader’s licenses for visually handicapped individuals or Blind Industries is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or both.
In this subtitle, “vending machine license” means a license issued by the clerk to sell goods or offer goods for sale through a vending machine.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the sale or offering for sale of cigarettes, newspapers, magazines, paper cups, paper or cloth towels, soap, toilet seat covers, postage stamps, or sanitary napkins; or
the sale or offering for sale of merchandise through a bulk vending machine as defined in § 11–201.1 of the Tax – General Article.

section.text: Whenever a person sells goods or offers goods for sale through a vending machine in the State, the person must have a vending machine license that covers that machine.
An applicant for a vending machine license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of $2.50 for each vending machine.

subsection.text: The clerk shall give each vending machine licensee an identification label for each vending machine.

paragraph.text: Subject to regulations adopted by the Comptroller, the identification label shall be attached to the vending machine so that the identification label is easily visible.

In addition, the name and telephone number of the vending machine licensee or owner of the vending machine shall be displayed on each vending machine so that the name and telephone number are easily visible.
If an inspector finds that a vending machine does not display the identification label required by this section, the inspector promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the vending machine licensee or owner in writing of the violation; and
require that the vending machine licensee or owner display the identification label properly within 10 days after receiving notice of the violation.

paragraph.text: If the vending machine licensee or owner fails to display the identification label properly within 10 days, the inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: seal the vending machine to prevent further use; and
take necessary action to enforce the licensing provisions of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If neither the identification label nor the name and telephone number of the vending machine licensee or owner are displayed properly, the inspector:

subparagraph.text: immediately shall seal the vending machine to prevent further use; and
shall take necessary action to enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not sell goods or offer goods for sale through a vending machine in the State unless the person has a vending machine license that covers that machine.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.
An unauthorized person may not remove or tamper with a seal on a vending machine.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“License” means a license issued by the clerk to do business as a trading stamp issuer.
“Trading stamp” means a certificate, coupon, label, stamp, ticket, or other similar device that is redeemable for goods.

paragraph.text: “Trading stamp issuer” means a person who sells or delivers trading stamps to another person in connection with a sale of goods by the other person.
“Trading stamp issuer” includes a manufacturer or packer that issues trading stamps in connection with the sale of its products.

section.text: A person must have a license whenever the person does business as a trading stamp issuer in the State.
An applicant for a license shall pay to the clerk a license fee of:

paragraph.text: $50 for an applicant that is a manufacturer or packer that issues trading stamps in connection with the sale of its products; or
$500 for any other applicant.

section.text: In this subtitle:

paragraph.text: “transient vendor” means a person who makes sales subject to the sales and use tax in the State from a motor vehicle or from a roadside or temporary location, excluding sales from a location that the vendor owns; and
“transient vendor” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a person whose only activities in the State are the delivery of goods in interstate commerce into the State from outside the State pursuant to orders that were solicited or placed by mail or other means;
a person who hand crafts items for sale at special events, including fairs, carnivals, art and craft shows, and other festivals and celebrations in the State;
an exhibitor, within the meaning of § 17-1801(d) of this title; or

an individual who sells by catalogue, sample, or brochure for future delivery and who makes sales to the owner or legal occupant of the premises pursuant to the invitation of the owner or legal occupant of the premises.

paragraph.text: Before conducting business in the State, a transient vendor shall obtain a transient vendor’s license.
The Comptroller may not issue a transient vendor’s license unless the transient vendor has a sales and use tax license and any necessary trader’s license and has paid all State taxes.
An application for a transient vendor’s license shall be in the form and contain the information that the Comptroller requires by regulation.
A license required under this section shall be valid for not more than 90 days.
The Comptroller may not renew a license required under this section unless the transient vendor has a sales and use tax license and any necessary trader’s license and has paid all State taxes.

subsection.text: A transient vendor shall display the transient vendor’s license at each transient place of business.
The transient vendor’s license shall be on the form specified by the Comptroller.

The Comptroller may provide by regulation or may order in an individual case that at least 10 days before entering the State to conduct business, a transient vendor shall notify the Comptroller, in writing, of the location or locations where it intends to conduct business and the date or dates on which it intends to conduct business.
While conducting business in the State, a transient vendor shall permit the Comptroller to inspect:

paragraph.text: its sales records, including sales receipts and inventory or price lists; and
the goods offered for sale.

subsection.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of subsection (d) of this section, the Comptroller may suspend or revoke a license issued to a transient vendor under this subtitle if the transient vendor:

paragraph.text: fails to notify the Comptroller as required under subsection (a) of this section;
provides false information to the Comptroller;
fails to collect the sales and use tax on all sales as required under Title 11 of the Tax - General Article; or
otherwise fails to comply with the provisions of the sales and use tax law or the provisions of this subtitle.

Except as otherwise provided in § 10-226 of the State Government Article, before the Comptroller takes any final action under this section, the Comptroller shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Comptroller may administer oaths in a proceeding under this subsection.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Comptroller may hear and determine the matter.

Subject to the hearing provisions of subsection (b) of this section, if a transient vendor conducting business in the State fails to display a valid transient vendor’s license, the Comptroller may order an immediate stop sale until a transient vendor’s license is obtained or may order a law enforcement officer to seize the goods that the transient vendor is offering or has offered for sale.

Subject to the hearing provisions of subsection (b) of this section, if a transient vendor sells or offers to sell goods in the State without stating and charging the sales and use tax separately from the sale price as required under Title 11 of the Tax - General Article, the transient vendor’s license is void and shall be seized by the law enforcement officer and returned to the Comptroller, and the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection apply.
The Comptroller may order summarily a stop sale or a seizure of the transient vendor’s goods or license if the Comptroller:

subparagraph.text: finds that the public health, safety, or welfare requires emergency action; and
promptly gives the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: written notice of the stop sale or seizure, the finding, and the reasons that support the finding; and
an opportunity to be heard.

subparagraph.text: If the Comptroller finds that emergency action is not necessary under paragraph (1) of this subsection, before the Comptroller takes any final action under subsection (a) of this section, the Comptroller shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Comptroller.
The Comptroller shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Comptroller may administer oaths in a proceeding under this subsection.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated does not appear, nevertheless the Comptroller may hear and determine the matter.

paragraph.text: All property seized by a law enforcement officer under this section shall be deemed prima facie to be contraband of law.

All rights, title, and interest in the property seized shall vest immediately in and to the local government, if seized by a law enforcement official of a local government, or to the State, if seized by State authorities, and may not be returned to the vendor or any other person, except as provided in this section.

If the ultimate disposition of charges, in connection with which the property may have been seized, results in a record of conviction being entered against the vendor, the State Treasurer or the fiscal officer of the local government, within 90 days from the date of the record of the entry of conviction, unless the case is appealed, shall apply to the District Court or circuit court of the county for an order declaring and ordering that the property be forfeited to the sole use of the State or local government.

Before the court to which an application is directed shall proceed to order a forfeiture of the property to the State or local government, the court shall establish to its satisfaction that there is no pending and undetermined suit or proceeding that has been filed in a court of competent jurisdiction against the State or the local government seeking a return or recovery of the property held in custody.
All applications for the forfeiture of contraband shall be by petition.
A copy of the petition and show cause order shall be served in the first instance in accordance with the Maryland Rules.

On disposition of a charge resulting in acquittal, dismissal, a stet, a nolle prosequi, or probation under § 6-220 of the Criminal Procedure Article, a vendor claiming that the seized property is not contraband of law under subsection (c) of this section and should be returned to the vendor may apply, within 1 year after the date the judgment or order was entered or the action was taken that constituted the disposition and on giving 10 days’ prior written notice to the State Treasurer or appropriate local fiscal officer, to the appropriate court for a determination that the property is the property of the claimant and for an order that it be returned.

In a proceeding on that application, an acquittal, dismissal, or nolle prosequi with respect to any indictment involved in the seizure of the property is prima facie evidence that the property is not contraband.
A conviction, plea of guilty or of nolo contendere, or probation under the provisions of § 6-220 of the Criminal Procedure Article is prima facie evidence that the property is contraband.
No presumption in the proceeding shall attach to an entry of stet.
If a petition is not timely and properly filed, or if it is finally decided against the claimant, the seized property shall be forfeited to the custodian without further judicial action.

Timely notice shall be given by certified mail or other appropriate means to any known claimants, at their last known address, of the requirements of this section for making claim for the return of the seized property or the seized property may not be forfeited as provided in paragraph (5) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section shall be enforced by any State or local law enforcement officer.

section.text: A transient vendor who conducts business in the State without displaying a valid transient vendor’s license is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is subject to a fine not to exceed $500 for each offense.
The requirements of this subtitle are in addition to and do not exempt or otherwise alter the obligations of a transient vendor under the requirements of:

paragraph.text: the sales and use tax law under Titles 11 and 13 of the Tax - General Article; and
any other licensing or permit requirements under this title or under any other laws of the State or a subdivision of the State.

section.text: In this subtitle, “license” has the meaning stated in § 17-201 of this title.
A person may not do any business in the State for which a license is required under this title unless the person has an appropriate license.
A person may not fail to display a license as required by this title.
With the approval of the Comptroller, the chief license inspector or an assistant license inspector shall begin proceedings to prosecute each person who:

paragraph.text: is required to get a license from a clerk under this title; but
fails to get the license or to pay an adequate license fee.

section.text: In a prosecution for selling goods without an appropriate license, proof that the defendant displayed or offered the goods for sale or kept a place of business where the goods were displayed or offered for sale is prima facie evidence that the defendant sold goods.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided in this title, a person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $300 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days.
Each agent or officer of a corporation convicted of violating this subtitle who actually engaged in the unlicensed business is individually subject to the penalties provided by law.
The penalty provided in this section does not affect any other penalty specifically provided by law for a violation of a license law.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to the laws that relate to the sale of alcoholic beverages.
This section does not apply in Wicomico County.

subsection.text: Subject to this section and § 3–704 of the Labor and Employment Article, a retail or wholesale establishment may do business on Sunday.
Notwithstanding an agreement to the contrary between a merchant and landlord:

paragraph.text: the landlord may not directly or indirectly require the merchant to open the merchant’s place of business on Sunday; and
a landlord may not directly or indirectly cancel or refuse to renew the merchant’s lease because the merchant refuses to open the merchant’s place of business on Sunday.

subsection.text: Except in Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George’s counties, and except as provided in subsections (g) and (h) of this section, a new or used car dealer may not sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale a motor vehicle or certificate of title for a motor vehicle on Sunday.

In Anne Arundel County, a dealer may sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale on Sunday a new or used camping trailer, mobile home, or travel trailer, as those terms are defined in Title 11 of the Transportation Article.
A new or used car dealer who violates subsection (d) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine not exceeding $10,000.

In Anne Arundel County and Worcester County, a dealer may sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale a motorcycle, as defined in § 11–136 of the Transportation Article, or certificate of title for a motorcycle on Sunday.

In Baltimore City, a used car dealer may sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale a motor vehicle or certificate of title for a motor vehicle on Sunday, instead of Saturday, if the dealer notifies the Motor Vehicle Administration in advance that the dealer intends to conduct business on Sunday, instead of Saturday.

section.text: A professional sports team may play a game at any time after 1 p.m. on a Sunday or at any earlier time provided by local law or ordinance.
This subtitle applies only in Wicomico County.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the laws that relate to the sale of alcoholic beverages.
Subject to this section and § 3-704 of the Labor and Employment Article, a retail or wholesale establishment may do business on Sunday.
Notwithstanding an agreement to the contrary between a merchant and landlord:

paragraph.text: the landlord may not directly or indirectly require the merchant to open the merchant’s place of business on Sunday; and
a landlord may not directly or indirectly cancel or refuse to renew the merchant’s lease because the merchant refuses to open the merchant’s place of business on Sunday.

subsection.text: A new or used car dealer may not sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale a motor vehicle or certificate of title for a motor vehicle on Sunday.
The State’s Attorney of Wicomico County may sue in the circuit court for Wicomico County to enjoin a violation of this section.

A person other than as an agent or employee of the United States or a state or a political subdivision of the United States or a state may not use the word “official”, or its equivalent, in connection with a tourist or travelers’ guide or information service or with related advertising or publicity.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “advertisement” includes a display or sign that is visible from a public highway.

A person may not conduct or operate a tourist or travelers’ information service unless each affixed advertisement that announces the service by the prominent display of the word “information” or a synonym includes, in letters that are at least half the size of the largest letters in the advertisement and that are lighted and displayed with substantially equal prominence, a complete list of names, headed “Sales Agents For” or the equivalent, of each business from which a person, directly or indirectly connected with the service, receives a commission, fee, or other payment or remuneration for referrals to the business.
This subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: a bona fide chamber or association of commerce of cities, towns, or counties of the State; or
an information service furnished by a retail business if remuneration is not received from any other business other than for goods sold on the premises.

subsection.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a penalty not exceeding $500 for each offense.
This section applies to each corporation or company that acts as a common carrier or forwarder in the State, including a railroad, steamboat, transportation, or forwarding company.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a common carrier or forwarder may sell at public auction freight that is forwarded on the common carrier or forwarder to a point in the State if:

subparagraph.text: for 3 months after arriving at its destination the freight remains unclaimed and the legal charges on the freight remain unpaid;

the owner or consignee cannot be found after diligent inquiry, or, for 3 months after being found and notified of the arrival of the freight, does not receive the freight and pay the legal charges on the freight; and

the common carrier or forwarder at least 10 days before the sale has posted notices of the time and place of the sale in three public places in the county or municipal corporation in which the sale is to be made.

paragraph.text: Out of the proceeds of the sale the common carrier or forwarder:

subparagraph.text: may pay the legal charges, including the costs of storage of the freight; and
shall pay, on demand, any balance to the owner or consignee of the freight.

paragraph.text: A judge of the circuit court for a county in which freight is located that has been forwarded by a common carrier or forwarder may pass an order for the sale of the freight if the judge deems the sale expedient, on the terms and notice that the order prescribes, if:

subparagraph.text: the common carrier or forwarder files with the judge an application, verified by affidavit, that sets forth the reasons for which the application is made;

the freight is livestock, is perishable, or is so damaged or of such other character as to make it impracticable for it to remain in the possession of the company owning or operating the common carrier or forwarder for 3 months after its arrival at its destination; and

the owner or consignee cannot be found after diligent inquiry, or, for 24 hours after being found and notified of the arrival of the freight, does not receive the freight and pay the legal charges on the freight.

paragraph.text: Out of the proceeds of the sale, the common carrier or forwarder:

subparagraph.text: may pay the expenses incident to the sale and legal charges, including the cost of the keep of the livestock or the cost of storage of the freight; and
shall pay, on demand, any balance to the owner or consignee of the freight.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “baggage” includes personal baggage, sample packages, bundles, or luggage.
A common carrier or forwarder may sell at public auction baggage that is transported by the common carrier or forwarder to any point in the State if:

subparagraph.text: the baggage remains at its destination for 3 months or, if it is lost or stray baggage, remains unclaimed by the owner or the consignee for 3 months at the place to which it has been transported;

the owner or consignee cannot be found after diligent inquiry, or, after being found and notified of the arrival of the baggage, does not receive the baggage and pay the reasonable charges on the baggage; and

the common carrier or forwarder at least 10 days before the sale has posted notices of the time and place of the sale in three public places in the county or municipal corporation in which the sale is to be made.

paragraph.text: Out of the proceeds of the sale the common carrier or forwarder:

subparagraph.text: may pay the legal charges, including the costs of storage of the baggage; and
shall pay, on demand, any balance to the owner or consignee of the baggage.

subsection.text: In this section, “truck stop” means a facility:

paragraph.text: the primary purpose of which is to provide services to long–haul truck drivers; and
that provides:

subparagraph.text: shower facilities to the truck drivers for a fee; or
parking for the truck drivers’ vehicles.

paragraph.text: The owner of a privately owned bus station or truck stop shall post the National Human Trafficking Resource Center Hotline information sign described in § 15–207 of this article in each restroom of the bus station or truck stop.
A sign required under this section shall be posted:

subparagraph.text: on the inside of each stall door in the restroom; or
on the back of the door at the entrance to the restroom.

paragraph.text: An agency that enforces this section and determines that a violation of this section has occurred shall notify the business owner of the bus station or truck stop, or the business owner’s agent, of the violation.

If the business owner of the bus station or truck stop does not post signs as required under this section within 24 hours after receiving the notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the business owner is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000.
For each restroom in which a business owner fails to post a sign in accordance with this section, the business owner is subject to a separate civil penalty.

section.text: In this subtitle, “organization” means an incorporated or unincorporated society, association, organization, lodge, order, fraternal society, beneficial association, fraternal and beneficial society or association, historical, military, or veterans’ organization, labor union, foundation, federation, degree, branch, subordinate lodge, or auxiliary.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, an organization may register with the Secretary of State a facsimile, duplicate, or description of its name or insignia, including a badge, motto, button, decoration, charm, emblem, or rosette if the principles and activities of the organization are not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of the United States or this State.
An organization that registers a name or insignia under this subsection may change or cancel the registration by reregistration.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State may not register a name or insignia of an organization if the name or insignia is similar to, imitates, or so nearly resembles another name or insignia registered under this section as to be likely to deceive.

section.text: The chief executive officer of the organization shall apply for registration under this subtitle on the form that the Secretary of State provides.

subsection.text: Any fees that the Secretary of State establishes for registration, alteration, cancellation, research, and the issuance of certificates under this subtitle shall be as provided by law for similar services.
The Secretary of State shall pay fees collected under this subtitle, less administrative costs, into the General Fund of the State.

section.text: A registration under this subtitle is for the use, the benefit, and on behalf, of the organization, or a subsidiary or member in the State of the organization.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State shall keep a properly indexed record of registrations granted under this subtitle.
The record shall show any altered or canceled registration.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall issue a certificate of registration to each person granted a registration under this subtitle.

A person may not falsely impersonate an officer or member of a military or patriotic organization, grand or subordinate lodge, or fraternal or sororal society that is chartered or has grand or subordinate lodges in the State.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may not wear, or use to obtain aid, assistance, or personal or social recognition from a person in the State, the insignia of a military or patriotic organization, or a lodge or fraternal society that is chartered or has grand or subordinate lodges in the State, unless the person is entitled to use or wear the insignia under the constitution, bylaws, or rules of the organization, lodge, or society.

Nothing in this subsection may be construed to prohibit a person from wearing an insignia of a lodge or society if the person is a parent, sibling, child, or spouse of a member of the lodge or society who is entitled to wear the insignia under this subsection.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $200.

A person may not wear willfully, or use to obtain aid or assistance in the State, the insignia of the American Legion, the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, or the Disabled American Veterans, unless the person is entitled to use or wear the insignia under the constitution, bylaws, or rules of the organization.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

subparagraph.text: a fine not exceeding $25; or
if payment of the fine is defaulted, imprisonment not exceeding 30 days.

paragraph.text: A person may not willfully wear, exhibit, display, print, or use the insignia that is registered under this subtitle, unless the person is entitled to use or wear the insignia under the constitution, bylaws, or rules of the organization.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

subparagraph.text: a fine not exceeding $100; or
if payment of the fine is defaulted, imprisonment not exceeding 60 days.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Returnable container” means a device made of any material:

subparagraph.text: that is used to hold, contain, or convert goods into a package, either by necessity or for convenience of delivery or sale;
that is suitable for repeated use; and
the title to which the seller does not intend to pass with the sale of the goods or the transport or return of the goods, as provided in item (2)(ii) of this section.

paragraph.text: “Returnable container” includes:

subparagraph.text: a basket, tray, milk crate, or any type of container that is used by a bakery, dairy, distributor, retailer, food service establishment, or its agent, to transport, store, or carry goods including bakery or dairy products; and
a bag, box, basket, or any other device:

sub-subparagraph.text: that is intended for repeated use;
that is used to hold or contain goods that are being:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: transported to a laundry, dry cleaning, or dyeing establishment to be washed, laundered, dry cleaned, or dyed; or
returned to the person entitled to the return; and

sub-subparagraph.text: the title to which the seller does not intend to pass by the transport or return of the goods.

subsection.text: “Returnable textile” means a garment, towel, table linen, or bed linen with an identifying name, mark, or device woven, impressed, or produced on it, that is regularly supplied clean, and periodically exchanged for a similar soiled textile.
In this subtitle, requiring or accepting a deposit on a registered returnable container, whether optional, conditional, or otherwise, does not constitute a sale of the container.
This subtitle does not prohibit:

paragraph.text: the owner of a returnable container or returnable textile from bringing a civil action, including an action for injunctive relief, to preserve the rights of the owner, to recover damages, or to recover the returnable container or returnable textile, from a person who unlawfully possesses the returnable container or returnable textile of the owner; or
a prosecution for theft under § 7-104 of the Criminal Law Article.
A person may register:

subparagraph.text: a class of returnable containers if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the person owns or deals in goods handled or delivered in a returnable container; and
the returnable container has an identifying name, mark, or device securely attached, impressed, or imprinted; or

subparagraph.text: a class of returnable textiles, if the person:

sub-subparagraph.text: is in the business of regularly supplying clean laundered returnable textiles; and
periodically exchanges the clean returnable textiles for soiled returnable textiles.

paragraph.text: A person who has registered a returnable container or returnable textile under State law is not required to reregister the returnable container or returnable textile.

subsection.text: To register a returnable container or returnable textile a person shall:

subparagraph.text: prepare a clear statement of the character of the returnable container or returnable textile; and
prepare a comprehensive description of the identifying name, mark, or device attached, impressed, imprinted, woven, or produced;

paragraph.text: sign and acknowledge the comprehensive description before an officer qualified to take an acknowledgment to deeds in the State;
publish the signed and acknowledged comprehensive description:

subparagraph.text: in two successive issues, in different weeks, of a newspaper published in the county in which the principal office, place of business, or agency of the person is located; or
twice a week for 2 successive weeks in a daily newspaper published in Baltimore City if the principal office, place of business, or agency of the person is located in Baltimore City; and

paragraph.text: file with the Secretary of State the comprehensive description and a certificate of publication, certified by the owner or manager of the newspaper in which the comprehensive description was published.

subsection.text: A person may transfer a registration by filing a copy of the assignment or transfer with the Secretary of State.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State shall record each:

subparagraph.text: comprehensive description filed under subsection (b) of this section;
certificate of publication filed under subsection (b) of this section; and
transfer filed under subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: On application, the Secretary of State shall provide to the applicant a certified copy of a recorded filing.
The Secretary of State shall establish reasonable fees:

subparagraph.text: for recording under this section; and
for providing copies of records filed under this section.

subsection.text: A certified copy of a comprehensive description and a certificate of publication or of a transfer with the seal of the Secretary of State attached is:

paragraph.text: evidence that the person complied with this subtitle; and
prima facie evidence of:

subparagraph.text: title to or right to use, collect, or deliver the corresponding returnable containers; and
title to the corresponding returnable textiles.

paragraph.text: After the recordation, a person may not:

subparagraph.text: use a registered returnable container of another with contents of a nature different from that delivered; or
sell, buy, rent, or otherwise traffic in a registered returnable textile of another.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $50; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $250 or both; and

subparagraph.text: shall forfeit to the rightful owner possession of the property involved in the violation.

paragraph.text: After the recordation, a person may not willfully deface, remove, conceal, or destroy an identifying name, mark, or device attached, impressed, or imprinted on a returnable container or returnable textile of another.
A person who violates this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $50; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $250 or both; and

subparagraph.text: shall forfeit to the rightful owner possession of the property involved in the violation.

paragraph.text: After the recordation, a person may not willfully break, destroy, or otherwise injure a returnable container or returnable textile of another.
A person who violates this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $50; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $250 or both; and

subparagraph.text: shall forfeit to the rightful owner possession of the property involved in the violation.

paragraph.text: After the recordation, a person may not buy, offer for sale, sell, use, give, receive, hire, rent, lend, transport, collect from ash or garbage receptacles, dumps, or premises, keep in stock or store, or dispose of a returnable container or returnable textile of another without an assignment from or the written consent of the registered owner.
A person who violates this subsection:

subparagraph.text: is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: for each first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $50; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $250 or both; and

subparagraph.text: shall forfeit to the rightful owner possession of the property involved in the violation.

subsection.text: A person may not adopt and register under this subtitle a returnable container or returnable textiles, or a description, name, mark or device, that:

paragraph.text: has been previously registered by another; or
is in use by another in good faith.

A person who receives a registered returnable container or registered returnable textile may not fail on demand to surrender promptly the container or textile to the person from whom the container or textile was received.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of $1.

A person who receives a registered returnable container that has come into immediate contact with a dairy product shall thoroughly clean the inside of the container immediately after emptying the contents.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of $1.

subsection.text: A District Court judge shall issue a search warrant, authorizing a search of the premises specified in the warrant, to a sheriff, deputy sheriff, or other law enforcement officer to whom a warrant may be directed, if a person who has registered a returnable container or returnable textile, or the person’s agent, makes an affidavit before the judge, stating that:

paragraph.text: the affiant demonstrates probable cause to believe that a violation of § 19-304(a), (b), (c), or (d) of this subtitle has occurred; and
evidence of the violation may be obtained by a search of premises specified by the affiant.

subsection.text: If all or part of a registered returnable container, or returnable textile is found on or about the premises specified in the warrant:

paragraph.text: the law enforcement officer executing the search warrant shall report the findings under oath to the judge; and
after receiving the report and charging a violation of § 19-304(a), (b), (c), or (d) of this subtitle, the judge shall issue an arrest warrant for the person against whom the charge is made.

subsection.text: In a prosecution under this subtitle, a charging document is sufficient if it:

paragraph.text: describes the returnable container or returnable textile in a way that allows its identification;
affirms that the returnable container or returnable textile is distinctly marked and registered under this subtitle; and
gives the name of the owner of the returnable container or returnable textile, the person using the returnable container or returnable textile through registration, or, if applicable, the transferee.

subsection.text: In a prosecution under this subtitle, a charging document need not:

paragraph.text: state or describe the name, mark, or device attached, impressed, or imprinted on a returnable container or returnable textile; or
state the particulars of the registration of the returnable container or returnable textile or of the assignment or transfer of the registration.

subsection.text: In a prosecution under § 19-304(a), (b), (c), or (d) of this subtitle, possession by a person charged of all or part of the registered returnable container or returnable textile is prima facie evidence that the person is guilty of the charge.
Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a garbage collector who collects a registered returnable container or returnable textile in the regular course of business;
the possession of a registered returnable container by a person who received the container with its contents; or
the possession of a registered returnable textile.
In this section, “plastic secondary packaging” means a plastic crate or shell used for the bulk transportation, storage, or carrying of retail items.
“Plastic secondary packaging” includes milk crates, bakery and soft drink trays, and other commercial plastic secondary packaging.

subsection.text: Other than a manufacturer of plastic secondary packaging, a person may not purchase four or more items of plastic secondary packaging for the purpose of recycling, shredding, or destroying the items.

paragraph.text: Each person that purchases an item of plastic secondary packaging, including a person that is in the business of recycling, shredding, or destroying plastic secondary packaging, shall make a written record of each transaction in which a person sells four or more items of plastic secondary packaging, that shows that the person selling the plastic secondary packaging has lawful possession or ownership of the plastic secondary packaging.
For each transaction subject to paragraph (1) of this subsection, the purchaser shall:

subparagraph.text: verify the seller’s identity by a driver’s license or other government–issued identification; and
make a record of each transaction that includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: the name, address, telephone number, and signature of the seller or the seller’s authorized representative;
the name and address of the purchaser;
the registration number and license tag number of any vehicle used in the delivery of the plastic secondary packaging;
a description of the items sold, including the number of units; and
the date of the transaction.

subsection.text: The purchaser shall keep the records required by this section for at least 1 year after the date of purchase.
A person that violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of $100.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Beneficial owner” means a person for whose benefit a boat broker is entrusted to hold money.
“Boat” means any vessel that is propelled by sail or machinery in the water.
“Boat broker” means a person who provides boat brokerage services for another person.
“Boat broker trust account” means an account that a broker maintains at a financial institution for the deposit of trust money.
“Boat brokerage services” means to engage in any of the following activities for an expectation of compensation:

paragraph.text: selling a boat, offering to sell a boat, or negotiating to sell a boat;
buying a boat, offering to buy a boat, or negotiating to buy a boat;
soliciting or obtaining a listing of a boat; or
negotiating the purchase, sale, or exchange of a boat.

subsection.text: “Trust money” means a deposit, payment, or other money that a person entrusts to a boat broker to hold for the benefit of the person or a beneficial owner.
A boat broker shall place any trust moneys received in anticipation of a boat purchase into a boat broker trust account until the boat broker:

paragraph.text: disburses the trust moneys to the beneficial owner on completion of the boat purchase; or
returns the trust moneys to the purchaser if the boat purchase is not completed.

subsection.text: A boat broker trust account established under this section shall be separate from the boat broker’s operating account.

section.text: In this subtitle, “soldier” means:

paragraph.text: an active duty member of the armed forces of the United States, including the Army, Marine Corps, Navy, Air Force, Coast Guard, National Guard, Reserve forces, and any other standard United States military agency; or
a federal active duty member of the State National Guard or Reserve force.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the use of a soldier’s name, portrait, picture, or image in an attempt to portray, describe, or impersonate that soldier in a live performance, single and original work of fine art, play, book, article, film, musical work, radio or television programming, or other audio or audiovisual work, if the performance, fine art, play, book, article, film, musical work, radio or television programming, or other audio or audiovisual work does not constitute a commercial advertisement for any product, good, ware, or merchandise;
the use of a soldier’s name, portrait, picture, or image for noncommercial purposes, including any news, public affairs, or sports broadcast or account;
the use of a soldier’s name in truthfully identifying the soldier as the author of a particular work or program or as the performer in a particular performance;
any promotional materials, advertisements, or commercial announcements for a use described in item (1), (2), or (3) of this section;

unless the exhibition is continued by the professional photographer after written notice objecting to the exhibition by a person with the authority to grant consent for use under § 19–503 of this subtitle, the use of photographs, video recordings, and images by a person practicing professional photography to exhibit, in or about the professional photographer’s place of business or portfolio, samples of the professional photographer’s work;
the use of a soldier’s picture, portrait, or image that is not facially identifiable; and
a photograph of a monument or a memorial that is placed on any product, good, ware, or merchandise.

section.text: A person may not knowingly use the name, portrait, picture, or image of a soldier killed in the line of duty within the previous 50 years in advertising for the sale of a product, good, ware, merchandise, or service, for the purpose of gaining a commercial advantage, without obtaining prior consent for use from the soldier or the surviving spouse, the personal representative, or the majority of the heirs of the deceased soldier.
A person who violates § 19–503 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Basic rights information” means information applicable to a noncitizen, including information about human rights, immigration, and emergency assistance and resources.
“Client” means an individual who is a citizen or resident of the United States and the State of Maryland and who uses the services of an international marriage broker to meet recruits.
(d) “Criminal history record information” means criminal history record information as described in § 10–201 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

paragraph.text: “International marriage broker” means a corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, or other legal entity that does business in the United States and offers to Maryland residents dating, matrimonial, or social referral services involving recruits by:

subparagraph.text: exchanging names, telephone numbers, addresses, photographs, or statistics or otherwise facilitating communication between a client and a recruit; or
providing a social environment for introducing clients to recruits in person.

paragraph.text: “International marriage broker” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a traditional marriage broker that operates on a nonprofit basis and otherwise operates in compliance with the laws of the countries in which it operates, including the laws of the United States; or

an entity that provides dating services if its principal business is not to provide international dating services between Maryland residents and foreign nationals and it charges comparable rates and offers comparable services to all individuals it serves regardless of the individual’s gender or country of citizenship.

subsection.text: “Marital history information” means a declaration of an individual’s current marital status, the number of times the individual has been married, the number of domestic violence protective orders issued against the individual, and whether any previous marriage occurred as a result of receiving services from an international marriage broker.

“Recruit” means an individual who is not a citizen or resident of the United States and who uses the services of or is recruited by an international marriage broker for dating, matrimonial, or social referral services.

paragraph.text: An international marriage broker shall provide each recruit with criminal history record information and marital history information of its client and basic human rights information before personal contact information about a recruit is given to the client.
The human rights information provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection may be prepared by an organization that is not affiliated with the international marriage broker.

subsection.text: The information required in subsection (a) of this section must be:

paragraph.text: in the recruit’s native language; and
displayed in a manner that:

subparagraph.text: separates the criminal history record information, the marital history information, and the basic rights information from any other information; and
is highly noticeable.

subsection.text: The international marriage broker shall pay the costs incurred to translate the information.
In accordance with federal law, a client shall:

paragraph.text: provide the client’s own marital history information to the international marriage broker; and
notify the international marriage broker if the client has previously sponsored an international spouse.

subsection.text: The international marriage broker shall require the client to affirm that the marital history information is complete and accurate and includes information regarding marriages, annulments, dissolutions, and the number of domestic violence protective orders issued against the client that occurred in this State, in another state, or in a foreign country.

The international marriage broker may not provide any personal contact information to the client or the recruit, including the last name, phone number, address, or electronic mail address of the client or the recruit, until the international marriage broker has:

paragraph.text: received the information from the criminal history records check required under § 19–604 of this subtitle;
received the requested marital history information; and
provided the information to the recruit.

subsection.text: Information obtained by the international marriage broker under this section shall be confidential and may not be used for any purpose other than that for which it was disseminated.

section.text: Prior to the release of any personal contact information to the client or the recruit, the international marriage broker shall conduct a State and national criminal history records check of the client, including a search of the sex offender registry.
An international marriage broker may disclose personal contact information on a recruit only after obtaining consent from the recruit, written in the recruit’s native language.

An international marriage broker shall be deemed to be doing business in the State if it contracts for services with a Maryland resident or is considered to be doing business under other laws of the State.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $12,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both, in addition to any penalty imposed under federal law.
In determining the penalty, the court shall consider:

paragraph.text: any previous violations of this subtitle by the international marriage broker;
the seriousness of the violation, including the nature, circumstances, and extent of the violation;
the demonstrated good faith of the international marriage broker; and
the necessity of deterring future violations.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Breeder” means a person who breeds or raises dogs to sell, exchange, or otherwise transfer to the public.
“Clinically ill” means an illness that is apparent to a licensed veterinarian based on observation, examination, or testing of the dog.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” means a person who, for compensation:

subparagraph.text: buys, sells, or negotiates the purchase of a dog; or
delivers for transport or transports a dog.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” does not include a person who transports a dog as a carrier only.

subsection.text: “Nonelective surgical procedure” means a surgical procedure that is necessary to preserve or restore the health of an animal or to correct a condition that would:

paragraph.text: interfere with the animal’s ability to walk, run, jump, or otherwise function in a normal manner; or
cause pain and suffering to the animal.

subsection.text: “Purchaser” means any person who purchases a dog from a retail pet store.
“Retail pet store” means a for–profit establishment open to the public that sells or offers for sale domestic animals to be kept as household pets.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to a bona fide nonprofit organization operating within a retail pet store.

subsection.text: A retail pet store that sells dogs shall:

paragraph.text: post conspicuously on each dog’s cage:

subparagraph.text: the breed, age, and date of birth of the dog, if known;
the state in which the breeder or dealer of the dog is located; and
the United States Department of Agriculture license number of the breeder or dealer, if required;

paragraph.text: maintain a written record that includes the following information about each dog in the possession of the retail pet store:

subparagraph.text: the breed, age, and date of birth of the dog, if known;
the sex, color, and any identifying markings of the dog;

documentation of all inoculations, worming treatments, and other medical treatments, if known, including the date of the medical treatment, the diagnoses, and the name and title of the treatment provider;
the name and address of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the breeder or dealer who supplied the dog;
the facility where the dog was born; and
the transporter or carrier of the dog, if any;

subparagraph.text: the United States Department of Agriculture license number of the breeder or dealer, if required;
any identifier information, including a tag, tattoo, collar number, or microchip; and
if the dog is being sold as registered or registrable:

sub-subparagraph.text: the names and registration numbers of the sire and dam; and
the litter number; and

paragraph.text: for each dog acquired by the retail pet store, maintain a written record of the health, status, and disposition of the dog, including any documents that are required at the time of sale.

subsection.text: A retail pet store shall maintain a copy of the records required under subsection (a)(2) of this section for at least 1 year after the date of sale of the dog.
A retail pet store shall make the records required under subsection (a)(2) of this section available to:

paragraph.text: the Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General on reasonable notice;
any bona fide prospective purchaser on request; and
the purchaser at the time of a sale.

subsection.text: A retail pet store shall provide to a purchaser at the time of a sale of a dog:

paragraph.text: a health certificate from a veterinarian licensed in the State issued within 30 days before the date of sale certifying that the dog:

subparagraph.text: has no known disease, illness, or congenital or hereditary condition which is diagnosable with reasonable accuracy; and
does not appear to be clinically ill from parasitic infection at the time of the examination;

paragraph.text: the written record about the dog maintained by the retail pet store under § 19–703(a)(2) of this subtitle; and
a statement notifying the purchaser of the specific rights available to the purchaser under this subtitle.

subsection.text: It is an unfair or deceptive trade practice within the meaning of Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article for a retail pet store to include any false or misleading statements in the health certificate or written record provided to a purchaser under subsection (a) of this section.

paragraph.text: A person who purchased a dog from a retail pet store is entitled to a remedy under this section if:

subparagraph.text: within 7 days after the date of the sale, the person had the dog examined by a veterinarian licensed in the State and, within 14 days after the date of the sale, the licensed veterinarian states in writing that the dog suffers from or has died of a disease or illness adversely affecting the health of the dog and that existed in the dog on or before the date of delivery to the purchaser; or

within 180 days after the date of the sale, a licensed veterinarian states in writing that the dog possesses or has died of a congenital or hereditary condition adversely affecting the health of the dog or that requires hospitalization or a nonelective surgical procedure.

paragraph.text: Intestinal or external parasites may not be considered to adversely affect the health of the dog unless the presence of the parasites makes the dog clinically ill.
A purchaser entitled to a remedy under subsection (a) of this section may:

subparagraph.text: return the dog to the retail pet store for a full refund of the purchase price;
exchange the dog for another dog of comparable value chosen by the purchaser, if available; or
retain the dog and be reimbursed by the retail pet store for reasonable and documented veterinary fees for diagnosis and treatment of the dog, not exceeding the purchase price of the dog.

paragraph.text: Unless the owner or operator of the retail pet store contests a reimbursement required under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, the reimbursement shall be made to the purchaser no later than 10 business days after the retail pet store receives the veterinarian’s statement under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: To obtain a remedy under this section, a purchaser shall provide to the owner or operator of the retail pet store, within 5 business days after receipt, a written statement from a licensed veterinarian that the dog suffers from or has died of a disease, illness, or congenital or hereditary condition adversely affecting the health of the dog and that existed in the dog on or before the date of delivery to the purchaser.
A purchaser is not entitled to a remedy under this section if:

paragraph.text: the illness or death resulted from:

subparagraph.text: maltreatment or neglect by the purchaser;
an injury sustained after the delivery of the dog to the purchaser; or
an illness or disease contracted after the delivery of the dog to the purchaser;

paragraph.text: the purchaser does not carry out the recommended treatment prescribed by the veterinarian who made the diagnosis; or
the illness, disease, or congenital or hereditary condition was disclosed at the time of purchase.

section.text: A violation of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: is an unfair or deceptive trade practice within the meaning of Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article; and
is subject to the enforcement and penalty provisions contained in Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article.

section.text: Nothing in this subtitle limits:

paragraph.text: the rights or remedies otherwise available to a purchaser;
the ability of the owner or operator of a retail pet store and purchaser to agree to additional terms and conditions that do not impair the rights granted to a purchaser under this subtitle; or
the ability of the State or a local government to prosecute the owner or operator of a retail pet store for any other violation of law.
